HEADLINE: House Democrats Scuttle Revolt On Campaign Finance Measure

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Weary House Democrats late tonight narrowly quelled an internal revolt against their leadership's plan to overhaul campaign spending laws, but the effort left them so spent that they quit for the night, leaving passage of the measure something less than assured.
That left the principal vote on approving the package for Monday, with virtually all the chamber's Republicans and a fair number of Democrats still opposed to many of the measure's most important provisions. 
 After a night in which top House Democrats scrambled to the last minute for support, the lawmakers refused by a margin of 220 to 207 to let a dissident Democrat, Representative Mike Synar of Oklahoma, offer a rival campaign-spending proposal that could well have doomed his superiors' intricate plan.
"Hey, man, they're throwing everything at me," Mr. Synar said early in the day. "It's hand-to-hand combat in the trenches."
The Synar bill would have embarrassed President Clinton, who has called overhauling the campaign-financing laws one of his Administration's chief goals.
The Democratic leadership and President Clinton support the House bill, a true grab-bag of election overhauls that includes voluntary limits on campaign spending, curbs on unregulated contributions and taxpayer financing for candidates' purchases of advertising.
 
Stark Differences With Senate
 Even if the House passes a version of campaign reform, it is not at all clear that it can be successfully mated with a wholly different version that the Senate passed after a long Republican filibuster in June.
Mr. Synar, who offered a simpler package of curbs on political action committees and wealthy donors, called the bill a sham intended to help incumbent Democrats and said the Republicans' alternative was no better.
"Not one campaign race will be any cheaper or any fairer if either of these bills pass," he said. "Both bills are so clearly unconstitutional that it begs the question of the sincerity of either of the parties."
Indeed, he and his backers noted, the leadership's caps on campaign spending would allow candidates to spend up to $1 million on an election -- more than twice the median for House races. Moreover, the measure would not take effect until the Congress passed a separate bill, yet to be written, that would set up a Federal fund to pay for campaign advertising.
The measure's principal sponsor, Representative Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut, allowed that the proposal was not perfect. But he said it "does what is important and what is needed," and "gives everyone a chance to run for Congress" instead of merely the well-off.
The bill now before the House -- drafted after a summer of excruciating negotiations -- tries to curb what many Democrats see as some of the political system's worst excesses, but leaves some of the most beloved vices relatively intact.
Backers depict the measure as an eight-lane highway of good intentions. It would address a signal problem in politics, the exploding cost of running for office, by allowing for voluntary campaign spending limits of $600,000, adjusted for inflation, or $800,000 for candidates who waged hotly contested and expensive primary races.
Candidates who agreed to abide by the limit, and then exceeded it, would be liable for a fine.
Candidates would have an incentive to accept the spending limits: those who did would be awarded up to $200,000 in so-called communications vouchers, applicable to bills for radio or television time, print advertisements or other means of reaching voters.
The total value of the vouchers would equal the total contributions from individual donors, to a maximum of $200 per donor. The aim would be to give candidates an incentive to raise money from large numbers of small donors, since those donations could be largely matched by the vouchers.
The bill also addresses another perceived flaw, the influence of political action committees and rich contributors, by capping political action committee donations at $200,000 per candidate, and limiting large individual donations -- that is, donations exceeding $200 -- to a total of $200,000. Both those limits would cover an entire election cycle, including both primary and general election campaigns.
The measure also seeks to limit outside interests from mounting independent campaigns on behalf of or against an already-declared candidate. The bill tries to choke off financing for such campaigns by making it illegal for anyone who has given money to a declared candidate to then give money to an independent campaign involved in the same election race.
 
Aiming at 'Soft Money'
 The bill also tries to rein in unregulated "soft money" by requiring that all money spent on Federal elections be raised under Federal rules and law. That would prohibit the parties and big donors from raising and shoveling millions of dollars into state and local parties' "get-out-the-vote" efforts that are actually ill-disguised expenses on behalf of Federal candidates.
Instead, the measure would set up a Federally regulated grass-roots fund in each state that would be devoted to efforts by state parties to help Federal candidates.
Most of the major groups involved in efforts to overhaul campaigning, like Common Cause and the League of Women Voters, support the measure. The Republican leadership opposes it because it includes some taxpayer financing, which the party is adamantly against, and because party leaders say it is biased in favor of Democratic incumbents.
Indeed, the bill has a few catches. The principal one is that none of its provisions would take effect until taxpayers agreed, through a checkoff on their tax forms, to finance a fund that would purchase advertising for candidates.
Critics in both parties say that renders the bill moot because, in their view, the public is unlikely to pony up enough tax money any time soon to finance the advertising budgets of more than a thousand major political races.
Moreover, while the bill would impose voluntary limits on campaign spending, it places no ceiling on the total contributions that candidates can raise. That would enable incumbents to carry surpluses from election to election, amassing war chests that would enable them to ignore voluntary spending limits during an especially tough re-election race.
Nor are the voluntary spending limits of up to $800,000 and the $200,000 limit on political action committee contributions especially onerous. The median amount of money raised by winning House members in 1992 was only about $463,000. Of that, 43 percent, or $198,000, came from political action committee donations.
When Republicans are thrown out of that calculation, and victorious Democrats alone are considered, the share of donations coming from action committees rises to 49 percent.
President Clinton had originally sought to reduce the influence of political action committees by reducing their maximum allowed contribution to $1,000 from $5,000, but that effort failed amid stiff opposition from House Democrats.
By contrast, Mr. Synar's package was more modest and straightforward. It would cut the maximum contribution by a political action committee to $1,000 per election from the current $5,000, and the top individual contribution to $500 from $1,000. It also would have counted contributions by minors toward the total of contributions by their parent or guardian, eliminating one common way of subverting limits.
The proposal also would limit "soft money" along the lines of the leadership's proposal. And rather than granting vouchers for advertising or limiting independent campaigns, the plan would have given candidates free broadcast time to respond to attacks by independent forces.
Mr. Synar said he would like eventually to do more. But he said he favored a smaller stopgap package that would reduce contributions by political action committees, curb independent expenditures and close selected loopholes until the two parties can agree on a more workable and comprehensive overhaul.
Both the House and Senate Democrats united behind a campaign-overhaul bill last year that included both spending limits and public financing of campaigns, but that was an election year, when reform was in vogue. Democrats were also confident that President George Bush would veto the bill, and he did.
This year, with angry voters otherwise occupied and the White House controlled by a Democrat, the urge for temperance has been more muted.
The Senate's version of campaign-overhaul legislation applies for the most part only to senators. It wiggled through the Senate last June only after a string of Democratic compromises converted enough Republicans to quash a two-week filibuster against the measure.
The bill provides voluntary spending limits of $2 million to $8.25 million for each Senate election, with the amount gauged to the size of each state's voting-age population.
The measure allows for some public financing of Senate campaigns, but only some. Taxpayer money would be allotted to a candidate only if he agreed to abide by the voluntary caps on campaign spending, and only if an opponent spent more than those caps permitted.
Only two provisions apply to the House as well as the Senate. One bans taxpayer-financed mass mailings by incumbents to their constituents during an election year. The second bans contributions by political action committees outright unless that is ruled unconstitutional, as many anticipate. In that event, donations by the action committees would be limited to $1,000 per election.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK REGION EXPECTING TO GAIN IN JOBLESS RECOUNT

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania stand to reap tens of millions of dollars from a revamping of the Government survey from which unemployment rates are calculated, according to Federal and state officials.
The extra money would result mainly from the states' greater share of Federal aid for job training, job placement and other programs tied to the severity of unemployment in a state or locality. Since the total pool of aid is more or less fixed, other states, like California and Texas, would lose. 
 Officials caution that the figures are preliminary and that the experimental survey used samples too small to be statistically reliable. Still, New York appears to be the biggest potential winner, although Labor Department officials say they are baffled about why.
 
Potential Windfall of Millions
 "It would be in the millions, no question," said Thomas A. Rodick, director of research for the New York State Department of Labor, where confirming data are eagerly anticipated. But he said no plans were being formed for distributing such an inflow, adding, "We never count our chickens."
The potential windfall, which could amount to hundreds of millions of dollars or more, arises from the Government's redesign of its Current Population Survey. This $30 million, seven-year project is aimed at improving the accuracy of this monthly statistical anchor, the best single gauge of the nation's economic performance.
The new methodology involves more precise survey questions, refined definitions and more thorough computerization. Last week the Labor Department announced that an experiment using the new survey had produced an unemployment rate of 7.6 percent in the 12 months through August, five-tenths of a percentage point higher than the 7.1 percent reported under the old methodology.
 
More Precise Questions
 One of the main reasons for this difference was that some unemployed women had been wrongly counted as homemakers and therefore out of the labor force. If a person is not looking for work, he or she is not considered unemployed, and thus the unemployment rate is lowered. Older people were similarly, but to a lesser degree, misclassified, which officials contend is different from undercounted.
Responding to a subsequent inquiry by The New York Times, John E. Bregger, an assistant commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, provided additional figures for regions and for seven individual states.
Nationally, the difference between the old and new figures was five-tenths of 1 percentage point. In New York it was 1.2 points, the biggest difference in the group. Pennsylvania was 1.1 points higher. California and Texas showed virtually no change, while Ohio, Florida and Illinois were close to the national average.
Higher jobless rates also occurred in New Jersey, but the Labor Department would not provide the specific figure for the state because it regards the sample as too small.
And it said it had no good explanation for the concentration of large differentials in the three states that make up the department's Mid-Atlantic region.
Because New York City has a relatively low proportion of working women compared with other areas, "one can speculate that more women were missed there," Mr. Bregger said. But he said he could not say why this was the case nor could he speculate why some areas outside of New York City had large differentials.
Mr. Rodick said tonight that New York now receives $210 million a year in job training money, a figure set to rise to $250 million or $260 million in 1994. He noted, however, that a further increase based on the new survey computation would not take full effect until 1996, because the program uses 12-month averages. Half the new money would come in 1995, none in 1994.
A spokesman in Harrisburg said Pennsylvania officials were reviewing the Labor Department's findings and could not yet comment on them.
Should these results be repeated when the new procedure takes effect in January -- and Labor Department officials warn that they may not since only 12,000 households were surveyed in the pilot program instead of the usual 60,000 -- a large number of Federal programs involving billions of dollars could be affected.
These programs, all tied at least partly to national or state unemployment rates, include:
*Job training, under which $1.7 billion is provided for teaching skills to the disadvantaged and to workers dislocated by shifts in the economy.
*Wagner-Peyser, an $800 million program that pays for local job-placement and counseling services.
*A $575 million program of benefits tied, among other things, to long-term jobless rates (15 weeks or more).
*Summer jobs for youth, $670 million in the latest fiscal year.
*Emergency food and shelter for the homeless, a $130 million program administered by private charities overseen by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Yet another Federal program provides for the State Department to issue an additional 3,000 visas to encourage immigrant entrepreneurs to set up businesses in areas where unemployment is at least 50 percent above the national average.
In addition to the updated methodology, the job figures are to be adjusted in January to incorporate for the first time population estimates from the 1990 census. These figures themselves are to reflect an adjustment for the undercounting, especially of blacks and Hispanics, that occurs with each census.
The population adjustment, which would add one-tenth of a percentage point to the national unemployment rate, does little for New York, Mr. Bregger said today. California, with its huge Hispanic population, will be the big winner, at least partly offsetting the loss of money to other states from the methodological overhaul.
Nationally, the census adjustment will raise the population 16 and over in April 1990 by 1.1 million, with 855,000 more people employed, 165,000 more people unemployed and the remainder not in the work force.
By region, the experimental survey showed unemployment in the Northeast averaging nine-tenths of a point above the traditionally calculated rate, with the Midwest seven-tenths of a point higher and the South two-tenths of a point higher. The West showed no change over all, with a four-tenths of a point rise for the Mountain states offset by a one-tenth of a point decline for the more populous Pacific states, the Labor Department found.

HEADLINE: Strikers at American Airlines Say the Objective Is Respect

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Nov. 21

 BODY:
It is not so much the pay or the benefits or the sometimes grinding, four- and five-city, one-day trips or the interminable, unpaid delays between some flights. It is the little things that the striking flight attendants at American Airlines say grate on them and amount to a lack of respect.
"They treat us like we're disposable, a number," said Helen Neuhoff, a 33-year-old international flight attendant who lives here with her husband and two children and had earned $23,000 this year until the start of the strike. 
 And Kylee Haviland, 24, an attendant for three years, said: "I'd rather be on the planes. But I've got to stand up for what I believe. My self-respect is more important than my job."
 
Threats and Suspicions
 This is one of those strikes, like the ones at Greyhound Bus Lines and Eastern Air Lines a few years ago and last year at Caterpillar, in which an intangible issue -- a suspicion of senior management -- arouses the workers more than anything that can be written into contracts. Some attendants acknowledged in interviews over the weekend that they feared for their jobs but, they said, not so much that they would be intimidated by the threat that American's management renewed today to replace them permanently with new recruits.
At the price of disrupting the travel plans of tens of thousands of people and forcing their own employer to swallow a crippling loss of fares, the attendants said they simply had no other option to make their point to the chairman of American Airlines, Robert L. Crandall. The strike by American's 21,000-member Association of Professional Flight Attendants, 85 percent of them women, ended its fourth day today.
The company is seeking changes in work rules and benefits in its proposed new contract. It has offered wage increases, but the work rule changes mean that attendants would work longer hours. A company spokesman, Marty Heires, said: "We are faced with a dire situation here. We simply have to cut costs to become competitive. They don't grasp the economic facts of this industry, or they have chosen to ignore them."
 
Anger Over Attitudes
 But Wendy Cook-Palmer, 26, the leader of the 330 attendants based in Nashville, did not see the strike simply in dollars-and-cents terms. At a potluck supper and rally for the strikers on Saturday night, she offered an example of the things that angered the strikers. An attendant for six years who earned close to $21,000 last year, she said all attendants based in the United States were ordered to attend three-hour "Commitment to Courtesy" classes, without pay.
"They told us the reason we were losing money was because we were rude to passengers," Ms. Cook-Palmer said. Her class watched a film opening with the image of a graveyard of the broken fuselages of fallen airlines like Pan Am and Eastern. Later the students were assigned to small groups, each of which was given markers and a poster board to draw a picture showing attendants being nice to passengers.
"People got livid," she said, more livid than they did about a class last year when, she said, they were told how to arrange food on a plate or than they still do when supervisors prop quarters against the attendants' ears to see that their earrings do not violate a dress-code regulation that they be no larger than the coin. "They treated us like we were back in kindergarten," said Linda Engen, 34, another attendant.
 
Quiet as a Church
 Smokey Stover, the head of the Allied Pilots Association's office for American in Nashville, said, "The basic issue is the way they're treated, the way all employeees in this company are treated." The union is picketing the airport in sympathy with the flight attendants, although its members continue to fly.
Management and the union have quibbled about whether more or less than 10 percent of the attendants have crossed the picket line and stayed on the job, but the strike is clearly mutilating the business here. Passengers are still showing up at American's ticket counters in Nashville, one of the airline's smaller hubs with 96 flights coming and going a day. But beyond the counters, the corridors to American gates are almost as still as a church on a weekday.
Flight attendants are an uncommon group of workers. Typically they are paid for just 71 hours of work a month. But that is time in the air. They spend many more, unpaid hours between flights and sleeping far from home. Barbara Thrower, 44, a veteran of Eastern and an American attendant for less than two years who earns about $15,000, recounted a typical trip that began on Tuesday, Aug. 31.
From Nashville she flew to Tampa, Fla., on to Raleigh, N.C., and then to Albany. Her layover in Albany was 9 hours, 40 minutes, and she slept about six hours. On Wednesday, she flew to Raleigh and then to Charleston, S.C., where she had a relatively long layover of 19 hours. On Thursday, she flew to Raleigh, to Syracuse, back to Raleigh and finally back to Nashville. After such a schedule she could be at home for a day or a week.
The majority of 20 attendants interviewed here are single. Some have college degrees, but some went no further than high school. What they have in common, instead of any particular skill, is an open, energetic, friendly demeanor. This is what American Airlines looks for when it chooses among the legions of young applicants. Those who are considered good candidates are invited to the company's headquarters in Fort Worth for interviews around tables with other applicants.
 
New Attendants Struggle
 At the end of the sessions, some are told to expect a letter in two weeks, Ms Haviland said. But an interviewer subtly approaches a few. " 'Come with me to this room,' she said," Ms. Haviland recalled. "You get weighed. They ask you if they can cut your hair. They have us looking like Barbie dolls when we get through. I don't mind that. The recruits also receive six weeks of training, mostly in safety procedures."
Attendants earn an average of $23,000. New attendants, especially single mothers, struggle to get by on their $15,000 or so a year, and with little seniority, they are less able than longer-term attendants in arranging their schedules to be assured of regular days off or two consecutive weeks off, which most attendants prefer.
Veteran attendants who fly international routes earn up to $40,000 and are allowed full-day layovers in foreign cities. Some who have predictable schedules also work second jobs.
Ms. Haviland seems typical of the younger agents, the sort the airline has been recruiting in recent years. They have little seniority and are vulnerable to the permanent replacement or the permanent layoff that Mr. Crandall has promised as he tries to shrink the business. She ranks 16,498 on the flight attendant seniority list of 21,000.
With a foot-long pony tail, Ms. Haviland is vigorous and seemingly uncontainably happy. She was raised in Phoenix and finished high school there. At 16 she worked at a McDonald's, and at 17 she took her first regular job, as an office manager at a drug and alcohol treatment center.
"I'm real junior," she said adding that she was single and without children. "Our flights are awarded by seniority, so I get what's left over. I'm the flight attendant we're fighting for, the extra on the plane. I get on with different crews every leg."
American wants to eliminate extras as regular crew members and meet the need for additional help by calling on reserve attendants, those who are periodically assigned a month without any flights but are on constant call.
Ms. Haviland said she earned $17,000 last year, $2,000 or $3,000 more than her regular pay, because she worked many days off as a $60-a-day, part-time clerk in American's flight service representative's office here. "I did it practically every day I didn't fly," she said.
 
'It's Very Exciting'
 She cherishes her job. "I love it all," she said. "I get on that plane! I say, 'Welcome aboard!' It's very exciting. I love helping old ladies get on. I love helping unaccompanied children.
"But you open the paper, and it says Bob Crandall says he doesn't know if American Airlines is going to be around in 10 years. And he says it's because of the labor contract. He doesn't say maybe we made a mistake with value pricing. All he says is labor costs, labor costs, labor costs."
Like Ms. Haviland, the attendants here are exhilarated because all alone, this largely female union has stood up to Mr. Crandall, who they see as a symbol of their anger with the airline. They say he has singled them out for blame for the airline's $1.2 billion loss over the last three years; it turned profitable this year. The attendants maintain that the huge expansion of terminals and fleets in the 1980's and Mr. Crandall's ill-fated "value pricing plan" last year in which he cut fares by 50 percent, were bigger contributors to American's losses.
"On one hand," Ms. Thrower said, "management says you're No. 1. Then a contract comes along. They say 'We can get rid of you just like that.' "

THE TARGET IN THE FRONT SEAT
The average take in a livery cab robbery, $75, is worth a driver's life. But to the families of the 186 New York cabdrivers slain in the last five years, almost always poor immigrants, the loss is incalculable. A1

HEADLINE: Four-Day Prescription: Europe's Workweek Debate -- A special report.;
Europeans Ponder Working Less So More of Them Can Have Jobs

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
France, it is sometimes said, has little inclination for reform and a penchant for revolution. True to its reputation, the country has suddenly become obsessed by a revolutionary idea: a wholesale switch to a four-day workweek that would, its proponents insist, slash unemployment, improve family life and bring new hope to a disenchanted society.
The proposal's chief advocate, Pierre Larrouturou, 29, a consultant for the accounting firm Arthur Andersen, has achieved such fame in recent weeks that he is now known simply as "le gourou." Swept from Elysee Palace to Government offices to television talk shows, Mr. Larrouturou has tapped what appears to be a thirst for a radical solution at a time of political torpor and economic recession in Europe. 
 "The four-day week can create two million jobs without sacrificing competitiveness," Mr. Larrouturou said in an interview. "The alternative, more and more people in Europe perceive, is creeping despair."
 
Resonance Beyond France
 Although the debate has been most intense in France, the four-day week has also struck a deep chord in Germany and other Western European countries reeling from high unemployment.
Companies like Volkswagen see the shorter workweek as an emergency measure to save thousands of jobs, while some politicians promote it as a "New Deal" to transform and inspire societies beset by economic insecurity.
In Italy, unions are pushing the slogan "Lavorare meno, lavorare tutti" -- "Work less, and everyone works."
The Larrouturou gospel in France is based on a switch, proposed for 1996, from the nation's current five-day, 39-hour workweek to a four-day, 33-hour week; an average 5 percent reduction in salary; a 10 percent increase in the private work force to create two million new jobs, and tax cuts and incentives to compensate companies for the added costs. It also offers a rosy vision of the plan's economic effects, from lower absenteeism and higher productivity to a more motivated society.
 
It May Seem a Dream<HGE>
With Western Europeans working fewer hours than their competitors in the United States and Japan, let alone South Korea and Singapore, the four-day week may seem a wistful dream rather than a serious model for change in French or European society.
Germans already work a 37-hour week with six weeks of paid vacation -- "by far the shortest working hours among industrialized nations," Klaus Friedrich, chief economist for Dresdner Bank, said.
Nonetheless, politicians of varying political stripes are jumping on the bandwagon. A French parliamentary committee voted last week in favor of experimenting with a 33.3-hour workweek at companies that increase their staffs by 10 percent.
Despite talk of a progressive New Deal, some workers fear that companies will use the four-day week to exploit employees without creating any new jobs. Others dismiss Mr. Larrouturou's plan as illogical. "The 32-hour week is a utopia and a joke," said Gerard Grannec, 39, a technician at the A.M.P. electronics plant in the northwestern Paris suburb of Pontoise. "You reduce working time and wages. But what is the worker going to do with his extra leisure time if he has no money? And where's this supposed boost to consumption going to come from if people are broke?"
 
The Challenge
Desperate People Look for Answers
 Behind the growing fascination with a shorter workweek is a combination of economic pressure and psychological angst.
A long recession and a steady surge in European unemployment have made many people insecure. At the same time, the inexorable advance of technology, global competition and leaner production methods has created what the French sociologist Edgar Morin called "a crisis of the future in which people no longer believe things will get better and are looking desperately for alternatives."
Computers, robots and other machines, workers and executives say, will go on replacing people, European companies will go on moving to Singapore or India, where labor is much cheaper, and instant global communications will keep on showing up the high cost of doing business in Europe, with its costly social welfare programs.
More than 1.5 million people in the European Community have lost their jobs in the last year in a process that a leading Gaullist, Philippe Seguin, has called "a social Munich." More than 11.3 percent, or 19.1 million people, in the 12 European Community countries are unemployed.
In France, the jobless rate stands at 11.8 percent, almost double the rate in the United States. In Germany, the council of economic advisers told Chancellor Helmut Kohl this month that unemployment would rise to four million, or 10 percent of the work force, next year, from the current level of 3.5 million or 9.2 percent.
With the drumbeat of layoffs from such industry giants as Philips, Daimler-Benz and Michelin continuing, any consultant giving a European politician advice for a campaign today could be very succinct: "It's jobs, stupid."
"Jobs are disappearing so fast, people are saying we must look for new solutions," said Alain Touraine, a French political scientist. "The French could not give a damn today if they are governed by the left or the right; what matters is unemployment."
In Germany, too, a conviction has taken hold among many people that Europe's emergence from recession, repeatedly postponed and now projected for the second half of 1994, will not restore the lost jobs. Most economists estimate that with 3 percent growth, few if any jobs would be created. With 4.5 percent growth, new jobs would result, but no one expects such an economic spurt in the foreseeable future.
"I am skeptical that jobs will come back," said Berthold Huber, the chief wage negotiator for the the huge I. G. Metall labor union, representing 3.2 million German metalworkers. "About four million unemployed are going to remain in Germany, and that is a major problem for democracy. So we have to at least look at the shorter working week."
 
Some Answers
In an Ill Wind, Different Tacks
 Behind the four-day idea lurk a lot of different notions. They range from emergency steps like Volkswagen's recent proposal to avoid mass dismissals by switching to a four-day week with 20 percent less pay to idealistic visions of societies turning their backs on the scourge of frenetic global competition in favor of a more balanced way of life. In between those extremes, many companies have already acted.
At the Regensburg plant of the German automaker B.M.W., for example, a four-day, 36-hour week has existed since 1990.
The idea behind the plan was for individuals to work less but more flexibly, enabling machinery to operate for longer periods. Thus a Saturday shift, generally taboo in Germany, was introduced and weekday shifts were extended from eight to nine hours. Although wages were unchanged, productivity gains more than offset the cost of hiring more people, B.M.W. says.
"I was skeptical at first, particularly about working Saturday, because that is when I play soccer for my local team," said Otto Sollner, a production line worker. "But now I appreciate the advantages, particularly the intermittent long weekends."
Similar changes have taken place this year at the French subsidiaries of the American computer manufacturers Digital Equipment and Hewlett-Packard. Hit by the recession and squeezed margins in the worldwide computer market, they faced the alternatives of layoffs or a sweeping reorganization of working schedules.
"The choice we put to workers at our Grenoble plant was simple: either change working habits, or we relocate to Singapore and all the jobs will be lost," said Marese Cosseron, a spokeswoman for Hewlett-Packard.
The result was an entirely new work structure that has tripled production at the plant, which produces microcomputer components. No employee works more than four days a week, but the plant is kept open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, instead of the previous five days.
Working weeks now vary from 26 hours and 50 minutes for employees working night and weekend shifts, 33 hours and 30 minutes for those on afternoon shifts and 34 hours and 40 minutes for those on morning shifts. All 250 employees, including 40 new ones, are paid on the basis of the plant's former week of 37 hours and 30 minutes.
"We are pleased by experiments like Hewlett-Packard," said Gilbert Fournier, a senior official of the French Confederation of Democratic Labor, a moderate union. "We are convinced that shorter working weeks that also leave machinery functioning as long or longer represent a key to creating employment in Europe."
The Communist union, the General Labor Confederation, opposes such flexibility on the basis that it would institutionalize night and weekend work without overtime. "Flexibility is often just a code word for companies to cut wage costs by getting people to work when they like without overtime," Chantal Rey, a union official, said.
Digital introduced a different plan earlier this year involving salary cuts averaging about 7 percent for people choosing a four-day week. With 530 employees of a total of 4,000 opting for the plan, 90 jobs that were to have been cut were saved.
"A large number of people were interested in working less and being paid less," Robin Ashmore, a Digital spokeswoman, said. "Young people want to divide their lives differently and have more leisure time."
Digital says its productivity has not suffered.
 
The Message
Some Buy Idea, Others Don't
 Martine Dessemond, a personnel manager at Digital who opted for the four-day week, said she was now spending more time with her grandson and had started a small consulting business in her spare time.
"I am more efficient in my work, less stressed and speedy outside it, and have not seen my life style much affected by the pay cut," she added. "But I am convinced the four-day week must be negotiated business by business rather than be the object of some grand reform or government diktat."
The idea has stirred far less interest among British companies, which are wary of managed solutions to unemployment and generally convinced that excessive regulation lies at the core of Europe's economic problems.
But in France, Michel Rocard, who will be the Socialist Party's presidential candidate in 1995, sees the germ of a social revolution in the four-day week, a means, as he has said, "to jump-start society."
In this vision, the four-day week would be a way to live differently, an exchange of slightly lower pay for greater personal freedom, a means to enjoy the benefits of automation rather than suffer its ravages, a vote for solidarity over ever more grueling economic competition, a fresh start for a disaffected Continent.
In recent weeks, Mr. Larrouturou has carried this message to Anne Lauvergeon, the economic adviser to President Francois Mitterrand. The President later spoke favorably of the four-day week. The "gourou" suggests that the reform be put to the French in a referendum or as a theme of the 1995 presidential election.
 
Pro and Con
The Numbers: Do They Add Up?
 As envisaged in Mr. Larrouturou's 54-page manifesto, everything goes swimmingly. After national legislative approval, French companies move to a four-day week in 1996 and take on 10 percent more staff. Wages cuts vary from 3 percent for the lowest paid to 8 percent for higher salaries, with an average of 5 percent.
Young technocrats from the best French state schools would help companies prepare their reorganization, including the introduction of profit-sharing schemes that would eventually help compensate for pay cuts.
To offset increased corporate costs, the state assumes the financing of unemployment insurance, suppressing the 8.8 percent payroll tax. On top of the 5 percent wage cut and an estimated 5 percent productivity gain through the reorganization of work shifts, this should make the revolution "cost neutral" for companies, Mr. Larrouturou estimates.
Paradoxical as it may seem, the theory is that companies will not actually face higher costs if more people work less.
Equally miraculously, the state does not suffer financially from abolishing the unemployment payroll tax, which is expected to bring in $21.8 billion this year. Rather, with two million fewer people unemployed, the state would save about $27.5 billion in payments that would have gone to people without jobs, and thereby come out ahead. With more people working, the economy would supposedly rebound, widening the tax base.
Yet among five workers interviewed at the A.M.P. electronics plant in Pontoise, only one worker, Michel Angard, said he would support the idea -- "providing it means a guaranteed end to layoffs and my salary cut does not exceed 1 percent."
Mr. Grannec, the technician, said: "Companies will just keep a smaller staff and make employees work more. Or they'll use short-term contracts with no benefits, promotions or bonuses to pay."
Management seems far more open to the four-day week. "We are on the eve of a revolution in the way work is organized in Europe," said Jean-Pierre Nannio, personnel director at U.A.P., the big state-owned insurance group in Paris.
A seeming majority in the French Parliament now backs the notion of a shorter workweek, despite warnings from several economists and former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing that if France is to remain competitive, a 32-hour week would mean an 18 percent cut in wages.
Certainly the management of Germany's Volkswagen believes that a 20 percent cut in work time only makes sense if accompanied by a 20 percent cut in wages. That is what it has proposed, as an alternative to dismissing 31,000 people by 1995. Discussion of the proposal began last week.
"The four-day week could be useful in crisis management, as at Volkswagen, Mr. Friedrich of Dresdner Bank said. "But as a medium-term policy, it is a great craziness. You do not resolve a problem by working less.
"The basic question in Europe should be how to make our economies flexible enough to create jobs with low growth," he said. "In other words, get rid of the regulations, like no weekend work in Germany. The machinery is not Catholic or Protestant."
 
Assessment
Critics Lay Blame On Rigid Rules
 Opponents of the four-day week, particularly in Britain, say the solution to Europe's unemployment crisis lies in doing away with regulations and costly welfare programs that add considerably to wage costs and have made the European job market the most inflexible in the world. Since 1970, real economic growth in the 12 countries that now form the European Community has totaled 73 percent, but employment has risen only 7 percent.
"Unemployment is proportional to the degree of state involvement and rigidity in an economy," said Alain Madelin, France's conservative Economic Development Minister. "When Europe grows, unlike the United States, it does not create jobs, because we are overregulated."
Nevertheless, there are signs that European workers have run out of patience with arguments based on the global market. When Air France workers went on strike last month against proposed job cuts, surveys showed that 70 percent of French people supported them, despite the disruption. The French Government retreated, aware that people saw the strikers not as vandals but as crusaders for the security of everyone's jobs.
"The lesson of Air France is that people have had enough," Mr. Touraine, the sociologist, said.
He said the French now appeared to be saying, "Look, my plumber can't fix the bathroom anymore, so I'm damn well going to change plumber."
"And, for all its current vagueness," Mr. Touraine said, "the only real recipe for change they see is the four-day week."
Mr. Huber, the wage negotiator for the I.G. Metall union, said he was tired of German executives telling him that one German worker now costs as much as 70 Russian workers and that some benefits would have to be abandoned if Germany was to remain competitive.
"Where are the cuts supposed to stop?" he asked. "At the Czech level? Or the Thai? Or the Russian?"

HEADLINE: U.S. Revising North Korea Strategy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Even as President Clinton and leaders from across Asia met here to declare the arrival of a new "Pacific community" based on economic rather than security links, Administration officials working the back rooms of Asia's first summit meeting were quietly revising their strategy for forcing North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons program.
This week in Washington, Mr. Clinton and South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, are expected to agree on a long-brewing change of course in its dealings with the bankrupt but volatile North Korean Government. Under a so-called "package deal," the United States will offer a series of small concessions and larger promises of future aid to North Korea -- and steps toward diplomatic recognition -- in return for immediate, limited inspections of its nuclear sites. 
 Until now, Secretary of Defense Les Aspin and other top Administration officials have said that "the ball is in North Korea's court," meaning it must either concede or face economic sanctions that would choke off its last supplies of oil and other vital goods.
But after weeks of consultations in Japan and South Korea, Mr. Clinton's senior advisers have recommended a shift in strategy: giving in a bit and making clear what other benefits the North might receive for each step along the road to a full accounting of its nuclear weapons project.
 
Several Aides Have Doubts
 But several Asian and American officials interviewed here during the last week say they have serious doubts the softened approach will be any more successful than other efforts during the past two years to negotiate with the North's enigmatic government.
They also fear that Mr. Clinton may be about to set an awkward precedent that could come back to haunt future efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons: rewarding a nuclear renegade for merely fulfilling its minimal obligations as a signer of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
"It is our last real chance," said a senior South Korean official. "If nothing happened in the next few weeks, we will have to start with the sanctions."
North Korea was absent from the meetings here last week because it is one of the few countries in the region that is not a member of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. But its presence was felt anyway, as a lurking threat that could wreak havoc on the booming prosperity of the world's fastest-growing region, either by striking out at its neighbors or by collapsing politically.
 
The Unstated Asterisk
 Containing North Korea was the first topic when Mr. Clinton met Japan's Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa. Every time Mr. Clinton or any other leader here talked about the need to build a post-cold-war "community" in the Pacific, a daily incantation since officials from the organization's 15 member countries first began landing here a week ago, the North was always the unstated asterisk.
South Koreans talked about the need to "gradually bring the North back to the world community." It is the shorthand phrase for avoiding their nightmare, a collapse of the North Korean Government that would leave South Korea with a multibillion-dollar bill for feeding and reindustrializing its enemy of five decades. The Japanese spoke of the need to prevent both missile attacks and a huge flow of North Korean refugees to Japan, both terrifying scenarios in the eyes of many officials.
Such concerns about pressing North Korea too hard, prompting it either to strike out blindly or implode, lie behind the new strategy.
While the Administration has in recent weeks greatly toughened its tone concerning the North, the new strategy is to dangle more carrots, rather than brandish the stick of immediate economic sanctions.
In low-level discussions through North Korea's mission at the United Nations, the United States has suggested it would abandon its annual military exercises in South Korea as soon as the North permitted International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors to resume their regular surveys of the nuclear complex at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of the country's capital.
The Pentagon has been willing to give up the expensive military exercises for some time. But surrendering it now would mean acceding to one of the North's demands in return for resumption of inspections that the North had permitted until this past summer.
Just last spring the United States was characterizing those inspections as totally inadequate, saying that far more intrusive surveys -- including a "special inspection" of a nuclear dump site -- were needed immediately.
"We've put the special inspection on the back burner for now," an Administration official said, "just to get the talks going again." He was referring to a so-called third round of talks between senior State Department officials and the North Koreans, which were supposed to take place in September. The United States said at the time that it was useless to meet because the North had yet to fulfill commitments it made in July at the second round of talks in Geneva.
 
Diplomatic Recognition Sought
 At a third round, the United States is expected to outline a path toward improved relations, in which the North would open up its nuclear sites in return for nearly simultaneous rewards, from Western economic aid to steps toward diplomatic recognition, the goal Mr. Kim's Government seems to covet most. If the North agrees, the United States and its allies will hold off on seeking economic sanctions.
What both the Americans and South Koreans fear is that their hand will be forced by Hans Blix, the Director General of the international energy agency. A month ago, Mr. Blix said monitoring devices at Yongbyon would run out of film and batteries by the end of October. That seemed to set a Nov. 1 deadline for the North, after which Mr. Blix would have to declare he could no longer guarantee that nuclear material was not being diverted to the weapons project. But when the date came, Mr. Blix softened his position. Meanwhile, American officials said their intelligence agencies reported no major nuclear-related activity.
But Mr. Blix cannot hold off much longer without undermining the credibility of the monitoring agency. When he declares, in the agency's lingo, that "the continuity of inspections has been broken," American and South Korean officials say they will have no choice but to seek action by the United Nations Security Council.
American officials have conducted lengthy studies to see if there would be any way to take out North Korea's military ability with a pre-emptive strike but have concluded that they have almost no viable military options.
That was confirmed today by Mr. Christopher, who said on the ABC News program "This Week" that the size of the North Korean Army and its proximity to the border should discourage "too easy an analogy" with Israel's pre-emptive strike on an Iraqi reactor in 1981.
At the center of much of the back-room diplomacy on the issue here was China, the closest approximation of an ally that North Korea has left. Both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa of Japan urged President Jiang Zemin of China to press the Communist Government of Kim Il Sung for quick concessions.
 
China's Influence in Doubt
 In fact, many doubt how much influence China still holds over the 81-year old Mr. Kim.
The real purpose of the continued talks with China, both Korean and American officials say, is simply to convince Beijing that the West has made every reasonable diplomatic effort to resolve the nuclear standoff before resorting to sanctions.
That way, they hope, the Chinese will not feel compelled to stick by their ostensible ally should the issue soon go to the Security Council and will abstain instead on the question of imposing sanctions rather than vetoing such a move.
"I think the Chinese will at a proper time cooperate on sanctions," Mr. Christopher said on "This Week," adding: "We need to exhaust diplomatic means. That's what all the countries in the region want us to do, Korea, Japan and China."

HEADLINE: U.S. Unions Back Shorter Week, But Employers Seem Reluctant

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Many American labor unions are also promoting reduced workweeks, usually of 30 or 35 hours, as a way to spread work to people who would otherwise be laid off.
A Democrat in Congress, Representative Lucien E. Blackwell of Philadelphia, introduced a bill last month in the House calling for a Government-mandated 30-hour week, but his proposal so far has gathered little steam. 
 In the view of union leaders, a "shorter workweek" is one that permits workers to earn the same total wages, or nearly as much, as they earn for working the standard 40 hours. Relatively few people -- postal workers, airline pilots and some construction, newspaper and telephone company workers -- have jobs that meet that criterion.
 
Fewer Hours, Fewer Dollars
 Many more people work fewer hours, in effect shorter weeks, but for correspondingly lower pay. The Bureau of Labor Statistics says the largest group consists of 6.2 million part-timers, 5 percent of the total work force of 120 million. Some people work shorter weeks of four instead of five days, but the workdays are 10 hours long.
Even when American businesses are expanding and find that they need new workers, employers resist taking them on, whatever the duration of the workweek.
The reason is that many American employers, unlike most in Europe, pay all or a large part of their workers' health benefits; hiring more workers means higher health care costs.
To avoid such costs, employers have been stretching the workweek, not cutting it back. Since the last recession ended more than two years ago, the average factory worker's overtime has jumped, to 4.3 hours a week in October, the highest level on record.
Over the years, some large employers have adopted shorter weeks only to abandon them. Medtronic Inc. in Minneapolis, a billion-dollar company that makes heart valves and pacemakers, tried short weeks in the 1970's but then dropped them, in part because of complications they caused in the company's customer relations. Customers sometimes found that the employees they were accustomed to dealing with were off for the day.
 
'A Noble Experiment'
 "It was a noble experiment that didn't last more than two years," said Dick Reid, a company spokesman. These days, Mr. Reid said, Medtronic managers are encouraged to accommodate workers with flexible hours -- letting them start two hours earlier than others, for example, and leave two hours early. "But everyone's on 40 hours," he said.
Advocates of shorter workweeks think they may have a way to induce more companies to adopt them. Mr. Blackwell and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. propose to require employers to pay workers twice their regular hourly wages for overtime, compared with 50 percent more now.
That, they say, would push the businesses' cost of overtime beyond the cost of a shorter week.

HEADLINE: American Rejects Request for Mediation

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
American Airlines rebuffed a request by its striking flight attendants' union yesterday for emergency mediation to help settle their standoff that began on Thursday.
The decision means that travel through the busy Thanksgiving holiday period is likely to remain difficult for tens of thousands of passengers. 
 American executives also pledged to passengers to fulfill roughly a third of the airline's flight schedule this week. They issued an apology to consumers, offered $100 vouchers to some of those who are inconvenienced and hammered time and again on the economic pressures that they said were forcing them to let the strike continue, despite the damage it was doing to American's finances and public image.
Robert L. Crandall, American Airlines' chairman, said the union's suggestion of a Presidential Emergency Board to mediate was unacceptable because, "a mediator always splits the difference," and American could not afford to budge from the contract it has offered attendants.
He also said such a board might be "politically oriented." The three board members would be chosen by President Clinton, who relied on labor's support in his election, but who won passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement over the strong opposition of labor.
If American had agreed to request a Presidential Emergency Board and one was granted, the attendants would have been ordered back to work under their prior contract. The board's decision, however, would not necessarily end the dispute. The board would take 30 days to review the issues and offer recommendations. The two sides could then take another 30 days to ponder the suggestions, after which they could reject the proposal and start another strike.
Although the mediation board was the starting point of separate news conferences by American and its attendants yesterday, each side also used its meeting to flex its muscles in the test of wills.
Mr. Crandall suggested that the flight attendants' strategy of striking for only 11 days would backfire to some degree, despite the fact that American will be unable to train new recruits in time to replace the striking attendants. Specifically, he said American planned to operate with at least 4,000 fewer flight attendants by the time the strike ends. Although roughly that many are not working now because of leaves of absence and vacations, the 4,000 posts would be eliminated based on seniority.
"Everybody is not coming back to work, in any case," he said.
The flight attendants countered that they have received promises from American's pilots and mechanics unions that they would not work with permanent replacements. That warning raised the specter of more labor strife even if the flight attendants end their strike next Monday as scheduled.
The company and the union have offered differing estimates of the walkout's impact. The union says the strike is being honored by at least 95 percent of the flight attendants, while Mr. Crandall said that by yesterday more than 17 percent had returned to work.
 
A Portion of Flights
 To help ease at least some concerns of American's customers, the airline said that it now had a better idea of what it would be able to accomplish this week after being caught off guard initially by the numbers of flight attendants who joined the strike.
Passengers in different cities will see very different levels of service. At La Guardia Airport in Queens, 45 percent of the planes scheduled for the week would carry passengers, and 53 percent of the service will be delivered at Kennedy Airport, American said.
Dallas-Fort Worth, the airline's headquarters, will get 73 percent of its advertised flights. In Chicago, American will fly 12 percent of its schedule, 77 percent in Miami, 35 percent in Los Angeles, 61 percent in San Juan, 7 percent in Nashville and 9 percent in Raleigh-Durham.
 
Informing Passengers
 For those passengers who cannot be accommodated on American or other airlines, American said it would either give them a refund or honor their ticket at no charge at any time during the next 12 months, even if the ticket was bought with the understanding that it was nonrefundable.
It said that any American passenger who could not make one of the scheduled flights between Tuesday and the end of the strike next Monday would get, besides a refund, a $100 voucher for travel on American any time during next 12 months.
Mr. Crandall also said that, starting Saturday night, the airline began calling those passengers who have reservations on upcoming flights, and it is trying to give them status reports of those flights at least 24 hours before their flight departs. He added the airline could not provide this service in recent days because it did not know which flight attendants planned to strike or cross picket lines.
"We have done a much better job of keeping our passengers fully informed," Mr. Crandall said.
 
Customer's Complaint
 At least one American passenger said he wished American had had better information about its flights.
Andrew Plesser of Great Neck, L.I., said yesterday he booked a flight 10 weeks ago to leave last Saturday morning to St. Thomas for a vacation with his wife and two children. He was told by his travel agent Friday that the flight was scheduled to leave as planned. He checked himself Friday night and learned that the flight was canceled.
He then rescheduled to go to San Juan on a flight that was supposed to leave yesterday morning at 9:20 A.M. He called Saturday night to confirm, and again at 6 A.M. yesterday morning. He and his family took a taxi to the airport, only to be met curb-side at the airport by an American employee who told them the flight was canceled.
"The children were crying and it was a very disappointing experience for all of us," Mr. Plesser said.
Although thousands of passengers are facing similar disappointment, there may be some consolation after the strike ends, or perhaps before. Some industry analysts have speculated a fare war may in the offing.
"Obviously this strike is going to take its toll on the company's earnings," said Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers. "Whether there is a settlement or there is no settlement, American will most likely offer deeply discounted fares to win the customers back."
The strike has cost the airline at least $10 million per day, Mr. Crandall said. He also said it would create a loss for the year, a year in which it was expected to turn its first profit since 1989.

GRAPHIC: Photo: American Airlines passengers waiting to check in yesterday at Miami International Airport. The company refused to agree to emergency mediation to end the strike by flight attendants, apologized to customers and restated the economic pressures it said were forcing it to let the strike continue. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ukraine's Hedging on A-Arms Angers Russia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Russia has reacted angrily to Ukraine's partial and highly conditional ratification of a major nuclear-arms treaty, saying Ukraine's decision to retain 58 percent of its 1,650 warheads could destabilize "the entire system of international relations, especially in Europe."
The decision, made by Ukraine's Parliament on Thursday, was also a severe embarrassment to the Clinton Administration, which has thus far failed to persuade the Ukrainians to abide by their President's commitment to become a non-nuclear state. 
 Ukraine is the world's third-largest nuclear power, although its missiles and warheads are said to be under the control of the Russian Strategic Rocket Forces, which alone can launch them.
 
Parliament Sets Conditions
 In the Parliamentary vote, lawmakers ratified the 1991 Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start 1, but set strict conditions, including security guarantees and additional foreign aid of $2.8 billion to $5 billion, according to Ukrainian officials. Parliament also refused to keep President Leonid M. Kravchuk's promise, made in 1992, to join the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as a non-nuclear state, citing the need for a deterrent against Russia.
President Kravchuk criticized Parliament, saying in a statement this weekend that Ukraine should get rid of weapons "we cannot use or fully control." He said he would resubmit the entire issue to a new Parliament due to be elected on March 27, and he accused the West of lacking the will "to act together with Ukraine in the period leading up to ratification."
Parliament has retreated a long way from Mr. Kravchuk's commitments. The lawmakers interpreted Start 1 to mean the destruction of only 36 percent of Ukraine's 176 intercontinental missiles and 42 percent of its approximately 1,650 warheads. The West has interpreted compliance as the destruction of all 130 six-warhead SS-19 missiles, which would leave Ukraine with 46 modern SS-24 missiles and an estimated 416 warheads on bombs and cruise missiles.
Still, Mr. Kravchuk called the vote "an important first step" toward disarmament.
In Washington, the State Department reacted with quiet exasperation, saying in a statement on Friday that the Ukraine's decision could "seriously delay" or even block enactment of Start 1. Until that pact is in effect, a sweeping follow-up that would cut United States and Russian nuclear arsenals by two-thirds is dead.
Western diplomats here were more scathing, saying Washington was "becoming fed up with Ukraine" because Mr. Kravchuk had not lobbied more vigorously on the issue. The diplomats added that severe pressure on the Ukrainian economy could destabilize politics even further, strengthening those who want to use the weapons to "blackmail" the West for aid.
Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, in a blunt statement on Saturday, said, "This is creating an extraordinarily serious situation for the entire system of international relations, especially in Europe." Mr. Kozyrev said Ukraine's decision was "very disturbing" because it raised questions about all arms-reduction agreements.
 
Speaking in Defense
 The Ukrainian Ambassador in Washington, Oleh Byelorus, told the Itar-Tass news agency today that the vote "is explained by the fact that Ukraine, as a new, independent state, faces unique problems."
Prime among them, he said, is the threat to sovereignty posed by those in Russia who refuse to recognize Ukraine's ownership of Crimea, for example. For Ukraine, he said, the weapons serve as "a powerful means of deterrence" against Russian attempts to raise territorial claims against Ukraine.

HEADLINE: European Airlines End Talks

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Just seven months after embarking on ambitious negotiations aimed at a merger, four European airlines called off their talks today, citing irreconcilable differences over what strategy to adopt in the United States.
The four international carriers -- Swissair, Scandinavian Airline Systems, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Austrian Airlines -- had sought to establish a jointly owned company to integrate their routes, eliminate overlapping sales forces and become more competitive in an increasingly difficult global airline market. 
 But after a meeting today in the Netherlands, the airlines issued a statement saying they had terminated their talks. They said the decision stemmed from the fact that "the airlines continue to hold fundamentally different views over a U.S. partnership."
 
 
Unable to Agree
 KLM had insisted that its partner in the United States, Northwest Airlines, in which KLM holds a 20 percent stake, should be chosen. But Swissair, which owns 5 percent of Delta Air Lines, had argued that Delta would be a stronger partner. S.A.S. also has an American alliance, with Continental Airlines.
"Notwithstanding the fact that satisfactory progress was made on other major issues, the partners unfortunately had to conclude that the selection of a U.S. partner could not be made," the statement said.
In Minneapolis, Northwest's president, John Dasburg, said that "other prospective members were not prepared to participate in a partnership in which the KLM-Northwest alliance might provide the center of gravity."
The clash underscored the increasingly global nature of the airline business. Clearly, the four potential partners in the proposed European venture believed the alliance would not succeed without a strong and unambiguous alliance with an American company.
The idea of bringing two American carriers into the consortium was considered but rejected, executives said.
 
Partnerships Seen as Essential
 Partnerships between European and American carriers have increasingly come to be regarded as essential to greater efficiency, lower prices and smoother connections on trans-Atlantic travel. These regional links have also been a focus of the airline policy set forth by the American Transportation Secretary, Federico F. Pena.
British Airways, the largest and most successful airline in Europe, has a 24.6 percent stake in USAir. Other European carriers are scrambling to strengthen their positions ahead of full European deregulation planned for 1997 that would allow, for example, the German airline Lufthansa to fly between Paris and London, a route currently dominated by French and British carriers.
It was not clear what pressure, if any, Delta, Northwest or Continental had put on the four European airlines to insure that they were not dropped in the proposed merger, which was code-named "Alcazar," after the Spanish-Moorish word for a four-sided fort.
Under the proposal disclosed in April, Swissair, S.A.S. and KLM would each have owned 30 percent of the new carrier and Austrian Airlines 10 percent. The four airlines, which would have had combined annual sales of about $13 billion and a 20 percent share of the European market, are all traded on European stock exchanges, but are partly owned by governments.
The abandonment of the talks left open the question of what new alliances, if any, the four airlines would pursue.
All four are considered among the best-run European carriers, but, in the view of several analysts, they lack the critical mass to be truly effective in the evolving world airline market. KLM had previously sought a merger with British Airways, but those talks collapsed over an ownership dispute.
 
 
Air France's Losses
 Air France, which is state-owned, had said it would lose more than $1 billion this year and recently backed down in a clash with employees over proposed layoffs. It is desperately seeking a new plan to cut its large losses.
Lufthansa, after severe losses last year, has recently returned to profitability, but is also looking to shore up its position before European deregulation takes effect. Alitalia of Italy has also said it will consider an alliance, and it is known to have held talks with Air France.
Aside from the increasing competition in Europe, and the effects on air travel of a long recession, European carriers have been involved in an ever-tougher price war on trans-Atlantic routes as the three big American airlines -- American, United and Delta -- increase their services to Europe.

Executive's Role
 By Bloomberg Business News
 COPENHAGEN, Nov. 21 -- Jan Carlzon, a former chief executive of Scandinavian Airlines System, said today that he would not return to the airline that he ran for 12 years. Mr. Carlzon stepped down from S.A.S. in September to work on putting together the so-called Alcazar partnership, the proposed merger of S.A.S. and three other European airlines that was scrapped today.
Mr. Carlzon said that he did not know what he would do next. "I'm less worried about my own future than I am about the future of the airlines involved," he added.
Jan Reinas, who replaced Mr. Carlzon in October as S.A.S.'s chief executive, said he would continue with cost-cutting measures.
 Tage Andersen, the chairman of S.A.S., said the company would not rule out job cuts as a way to save money.

HEADLINE: For Bradys, A Gamble On Gun Bill Pays Off

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
On the morning after, James Brady slept in. But his wife, Sarah, was up and reveling in the late-night Saturday turnaround victory in the Senate for the gun-control measure that she and her husband had labored to pass for more than five grueling years.
"It was like a Dewey-Truman story," Mrs. Brady said in a telephone interview this morning. 
 Mrs. Brady's reference to Harry S. Truman's remarkable eleventh-hour comeback victory over Thomas E. Dewey in the 1948 Presidential election was apt. The bill had been pronounced dead on Friday -- and again as late as Saturday afternoon -- by both lawmakers and analysts. Then it suddenly was revived in a legislative and emotional roller-coaster ride for the Bradys.
The signs for the legislation had been positive this year, and the bill passed the House on Nov. 11. But the Bradys said that all last week, while awaiting Senate action, they had been had been feeling "lurkey," a Bradyism that rhymes with "turkey" and means an ice-water feeling in the heart.
 
A Tumultuous Week
 "It's just been a week of so many highs and lows," Mrs. Brady, who heads Handgun Control Inc., a national organization of gun-control advocates, said this morning. Her husband was still asleep, recuperating from a late-night news conference with Senator Howard O. Metzenbaum, a strong supporter of the Brady bill.
The bill is named for Mr. Brady, the former Presidential press secretary who was critically wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan. He has had to use a wheelchair ever since.
The Brady bill would require a handgun buyer to wait five working days while the dealer checked whether the person was eligible to own one. Current law prohibits the sale of firearms to felons, fugitives, the mentally incompetent, minors, drug and alcohol abusers, and illegal immigrants.
 
A Change in Climate
 It was probably a changed social and political climate as much as anything that allowed the bill's passage. Since Mrs. Brady began to lobby for a gun-control law seven years ago, there has been an explosion of gun-related violence in the nation. Legislators are now more sympathetic to gun controls than in the past, particularly in light of recent polls that indicate crime and violence have become the top concern of Americans, ahead of the economy and unemployment.
Even so, for weeks before the votes in Congress, the Bradys pitched phone calls with the intensity of combat soldiers, shoring up supporters and wooing fence sitters. But the Bradys have not been simply lobbyists; rather they have been crucial strategists in the gun-control movement. This morning Mrs. Brady was savoring one of several gambles they took -- the decision to strip the Brady bill out of the overall crime package in which it had been trapped for several years.
That shift let the Senate overwhelmingly approve a $23 billion anti-crime package on Friday that bans assault-style firearms and provides money to help local governments hire 100,000 new police. It also allowed the Brady bill to be separated from controversies within the crime bill and to stand or fall on its own merits.
 
Taking the Hard Way
 "It just feels so good to know that the legislative strategy of keeping the bill separate worked," Mrs. Brady said. "A lot of people thought we should have taken the easy route and put it in the crime bill, but that would have made it too easy for our opponents. We felt strongly that the American public, which supports this bill, ought to have the chance to see who was opposed to it."
On another tactical question, one House member said that during the crucial last minutes of the vote last week James Brady argued persuasively that backers of the Brady bill should support it, even though the bill that emerged included an amendment that would cause the legislation to expire after five years.
"Jim's argument was persuasive that we should vote for the bill with the amendment," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. "He said we've got to keep this alive, even if it has parts we don't like."
The Bradys' bleakest moments came on Friday and Saturday, when it seemed that they would see a repeat of 1991, when the bill, then part of an anti-crime package, failed. On Friday, proponents twice failed by three votes to get the 60 required to cut off a Republican filibuster.
At a Saturday afternoon press conference, Mrs. Brady blamed Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, and the "N.R.A. Republicans" for the slim hope of getting the bill passed.
"I'm just really angry this time," Mrs. Brady said in a later interview. She said that gun-control advocates had the votes to pass the bill this year, but that Mr. Dole had made the bill an issue of party solidarity instead of one of public safety.
In the end, party solidarity broke.
 
'Full-Court Press'
 "I think the country was ripe and wants this badly," said Mrs. Brady, who attributed the filibuster to the National Rifle Association's "full-court press the last couple of days."
The Bradys believe that the measure's five-day waiting period can help slow the proliferation of guns. They argue that even a superficial background check, for instance, would have warned a Texas pawnshop owner that John Hinckley Jr., the man who shot Mr. Reagan and Mr. Brady, had recently been arrested for trying to carry a shotgun aboard an airliner.
Mrs. Brady became involved in the fight to control handguns before her husband did, but not as an immediate consequence of Mr. Brady's shooting.
In 1985, while the Bradys were visiting her husband's hometown, Centralia, Ill., their son Scott, then 5 years old, crawled into a family friend's pickup truck and spied what he took to be a plaything on the seat. It was a gun.
 
'Don't Do That, Scott'
 When he picked it up and pointed it at his mother, who also thought it was a toy, as she climbed in beside him, she recalled admonishing him: "Don't do that, Scott. Don't ever point a gun at anyone, even a toy."
Then she realized it was a gun -- a loaded, .22-caliber pistol, like the $29 gun Mr. Hinckley had used four years earlier to shoot her husband.
"My blood just boiled," said Mrs. Brady. "My husband had been shot, and here my child was with a gun."
Mrs. Brady said she picked up the phone, called Handgun Control Inc. and has been passionately involved ever since.
"I thought, 'We've got to go on the offensive,' " she said in a recent interview.
"And you got fairly offensive," quipped her husband.
 
Formidable Opponents
 In the years since that jarring experience with their son, Sarah and Jim Brady, who is vice chairman of the National Organization on Disability, have emerged as formidable opponents of the N.R.A. And the Bradys will not disappear from the fray even after the legislation they have championed becomes law.
"We've got a full agenda," said Mrs. Brady, speaking about her organization, which offers an education program for young people on gun violence and is pressing to reform the procedures for licensing gun dealers.
Illustrating how simple it is to become a legal dealer in firearms, Mr. Brady told some recent visitors, "If you've got 10 minutes and $10, we could make you all dealers."
