HEADLINE: In Fairfield County, Small Companies Renew Job Base

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 16

 BODY:
When Robert Thomson set up a computer software company a dozen years ago, he placed it here, near what he hoped would be his prime market: the Fortune 500 companies that flocked to this leafy suburb after leaving gritty New York. For much of that time Mr. Thomson's IMRS Inc. thrived along with those mammoth companies.
These days, though, as companies like General Electric, Union Carbide, and Champion International have undergone painful layoffs, IMRS continues to expand and prosper. 
 After three relocations within Stamford, the company, which began with a handful of workers, now employs about 450 people. And rather than cutting back, IMRS is still expanding its work force at the rate of 20 to 25 percent a year. It already threatens to outgrow the space it leased just two years ago.
Those gains are beginning to pay off on a wider scale. While the rest of the New York regional economy remains bogged down, Fairfield County appears to be coming to life once again. This time, though, it is not the lumbering elephants, but companies like IMRS -- younger, nimbler and more willing to take risks -- that are leading the way. In fact, several other young companies, like the rapidly growing Oxford Health Plans of Norwalk, have already become major employers.
Statistics suggest that a turnaround has begun in Fairfield County. Housing permits are up 36 percent as of September 1993, compared with a gain of 7.6 percent for Connecticut as a whole. Retail sales rose almost 10 percent in the first few months of the 1993, versus a decline in the Hartford area and more meager gains elsewhere.
 
Renewed Fairfield County
 More important, about 40,000 more people say they have jobs now than said so at the end of 1992, even though major employers are still shaving payrolls. Most of the newly employed apparently joined recently established companies or went into business for themselves.
For much of the New York metropolitan region, the lesson is becoming clear: Rather than continuing to chase the big-name businesses that once provided secure employment, the region must increasingly count on vigorous smaller companies to rebuild its shrunken job base.
The old days are fading fast. Fairfield County -- even more than surrounding areas like Westchester County and northern New Jersey -- long ago staked its economic future on the security offered by the large, well-established corporations that found its safe, woody atmosphere so appealing. Those prospects no longer look so comforting.
"We've been a headquarters-driven economy, so the downsizing of corporate America has been particularly acute for all of us," said Christopher Bruhl, president of the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut, speaking of the entire New York region.
"In Fairfield," he said, "a more diversified local economy is coming to our rescue. As the national economy slowly improves, our growth is being generated from a variety of smaller, newer sources, not just one or two big engines."
Except for one or two major corporate relocations -- the Witco Corporation and Dun & Bradstreet being the principal examples -- almost all the companies acquiring office space in Fairfield County in the last few years have been relatively modest in size. And in contrast to the 1970's and 80's, a significant number are homegrown.
Such major employers as U.P.S. and Bowater have recently abandoned the area. Even so, office vacancy rates, while still high at roughly 20 percent, are finally starting to drop.
Connecticut's Gold Coast entered the recession early as Wall Street hunkered down after the October 1987 stock market crash and the commercial real estate market across the nation collapsed. Bolstered by renewed prosperity in the financial industry and an avoidance so far of the huge blows suffered elsewhere by military contractors, the county is outpacing other parts of the region.
 
Lessons for Others
 Admittedly, Fairfield is different. Its entrenched wealth and reputation as a cushy WASP haven insulated it from the worst ravages of the economic downturn in the Northeast. The area, says Edward Deak, an economist at Fairfield University who provides the Connecticut forecasts for the New England Economic Project, is also "more national and international in its business outlook."
Still, the emergence of vigorous new enterprises here holds important lessons for other parts of the New York region. Westchester, for example, will continue to suffer shocks from the retrenchment of I.B.M. With the end of the cold war, Long Island can no longer depend on Grumman and related defense businesses. In Connecticut, the insurance industry centered around Hartford is most likely to experience the same type of downsizing and corporate "re-engineering" that has already hit banking.
"Our classic economic base is maturing," said Joseph J. McGee, Connecticut's economic development commissioner. "We need to encourage a new, more entrepreneurial base."
Independent analysts support those views.
"Different places within the vast New York economic complex will have different destinies," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "But one thing that unites them all is that they are going to be much more dependent on the dynamism of smaller, more creative companies if they are to flourish."
IMRS, which produces sophisticated financial management software for use on networks of personal computers, starkly illustrates the point. Indeed, as big companies have sought to cut costs, IMRS has been one of the chief beneficiaries of the drive for savings.
"Our clients are big, multinational firms with more than $1 billion in sales," said James A. Perakis, IMRS's president and chief executive officer, who joined the company in 1985. "As they started to look for ways to cut back, one of the first targets they focused on was their costly mainframe computers and the extensive data processing departments that ran them."
IMRS software helps fill the void. In the midst of the recession, its revenues have jumped from $12 million in 1989 to $61 million for the fiscal year that ended last June. It now has about 1,300 corporate clients and is adding customers at the rate of 300 per year. More than a third of its sales are abroad, mostly in Europe.
Few other software companies are around. Despite the isolation, Mr. Perakissaid he was committed to remaining in Fairfield County.
"There isn't a local talent pool of computer scientists, but it is not a problem finding good people," he said. "This is a very nice place to live for white-collar workers." The corporate atmosphere is informal and most employees are relatively young. An attractive profit-sharing plan means that not many are tempted to leave. Some of the professionals at IMRS even live in Manhattan and reverse-commute, most by train, to Stamford.
The company is already starting to look for a new building in the area with space for at least 500 employees. Mr. Perakis said the campus-like working environment so popular in suburban office parks was vital. "We are not a 9-to-5 business," he said. "If someone, male or female, works on a project until 9 or 10 at night, I want to be sure they can safely walk to the parking lot and drive home."
Oxford Health Plans, which runs an unconventional managed health care network in the New York region, provides another example of the area's shifting economic fortunes. Founded by Stephen F. Wiggins in 1984, when HMO's were widely disdained here, the company's membership rolls have soared from just 11,000 in 1987 to more than 200,000 today. Aimed at small business and professionals as well as the Medicaid population, it is the fastest growing health plan in metropolitan New York.
Mr. Wiggins, 37, is a transplant from Minnesota, where HMO's are extremely popular. He moved to the area a decade ago to work as a Wall Street investment banker. After just three months, he quit.
"I hated the commute," he said. "The truth is I started the company because I wanted to find a way to work close to home."
As managed care has gained adherents in the New York region, Oxford has added jobs rapidly. In less than a year, it has gone from about 350 employees to 700.
But high wage rates, expensive housing costs and relatively low unemployment make it more difficult to recruit employees for an array of basic service jobs. Nor has Oxford, even with a generous profit-sharing plan, had much success recruiting seasoned executives from big companies willing to start over at a lower salary.
"We rely mostly on very young managers," Mr. Wiggins said. "The corporate types often are unable to reboot to a new system."
For all the difficulties, though, Mr. Wiggins remains convinced that his business belongs here, close to his customers. "When we drove out here from Minneapolis, my wife cried all the way to Chicago," he said. "I promised her we wouldn't become Easterners. But I guess maybe we have."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
After Wagner's Death, A City's Hope Darkens

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
FRANK E. HORNSBY JR., deputy executive director of the San Antonio Housing Authority, explained the other day how programs begun under Senator Robert F. Wagner's New Deal legislation were being adapted to today's needs.
"At Alazan-Apache Courts, a 1,000-apartment project built in 1940, we've just begun a family self-sufficiency program," he said. "To get in, people have to sign a five-year contract to get training or education to get a job. They pay rent up to 30 percent of their income. Eventually they own their own unit. 
 "Here the density of public housing is all low-rise -- mostly two-stories -- for families. For the elderly, we built a high-rise in 1965 and from the git-go we contracted with private agencies to provide social services, a nutrition program and meals."
On San Antonio's west and south sides, a coalition of 28 congregations has, according to its lead organizer, Sister Pearl Ceasar, "basically changed the political face of San Antonio." Also the physical face. The 20-year-old organization, Communities Organized for Public Service, has helped bring $750 million in public works to low- and moderate-income neighborhoods, housing, job training and an educational partnership that guarantees high school graduates a scholarship to local colleges.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Senator's grandson, was visiting San Antonio last weekend to study those programs for a book he was writing with Julia Vitullo-Martin. He was contemplating the future of American cities. But immobilized by a severe flu, he never left his hotel room. He died a week ago at 49, leaving the future to others.
Mr. Wagner inherited from his father, a three-term Mayor of New York, an appreciation for the democratic process as a brake on precipitate decision-making. To be sure, he was a procrastinator. But he also believed that the best response to some problems is to let them percolate and eventually solve themselves.
For America's cities, though, the threats were too daunting, and time was too short. Failed approaches needed to be re-evaluated or discarded. Successes needed to be replicated.
"He believed that we are in a footloose information economy with profound implications for the cities," said Ms. Vitullo-Martin, his collaborator on the book and who, with her husband, visited San Antonio's urban innovations while Mr. Wagner was ailing.
"The criteria by which people decide where to live are going to change," she said. "All the quality-of-life issues which may have seemed minor in prior years are tremendously important. Cultural factors -- opera, ballet, publishing -- are one of the things that cities have to offer. City governments have to keep their taxes competitive. That isn't determined only by their needs but by what other jurisdictions are charging. Bob was grappling with that a lot and Rudy Giuliani is going to have to grapple with that a lot, too."
Mr. Wagner, who was a deputy mayor, chairman of the City Planning Commission and president of the Board of Education under Mayor Edward I. Koch, was poised to play such a role in the Giuliani administration. It might have been even larger, because he was Mr. Giuliani's contemporary and because the gaps are greater around a Mayor-elect who has never held elective office and lacks the institutional memory and sagacity that Mr. Wagner embodied.
"He was doing some conceptual adventuring for the book," said his mentor, Dr. Julius C. C. Edelstein, the vice chancellor emeritus of the City University of New York. "For Giuliani, he was invited to be, and was prepared to be, a major intellectual resource. There is no one else even remotely able to fill that role."
Mr. Wagner, said Henry Stern, another close friend, "would have been Giuliani's Talleyrand."
Mr. Wagner's optimism had waned since 1987, when he capsulized the report of his Commission on the Year 2000 in its title: "New York Ascendant." Since then, he and Ms. Vitullo-Martin wrote, "While the urban crisis has its harrowing aspects, today's is not the crisis described in the 1960's and early 1970's. Apocalypse is not the danger; the danger is an ongoing gradual decline worsened by general national indifference."
The three critical challenges for Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Wagner wrote, are: "New Yorkers desperately want a sense that the city has a future. New York City government has to be restructured if it is to provide adequate services and live within its means. And all New Yorkers have to feel part of the process."
A pivotal number of New Yorkers probably were swayed to vote for Mr. Giuliani on the strength of Mr. Wagner's endorsement, delivered persuasively in a television advertisement as he struggled for the words to justify his defection from the Democratic Party.
"I'm not sure we would have won without the combination of him and Koch," said David Garth, Mr. Giuliani's media strategist. "Bobby's commercial gave Koch's credibility."
Now, some New Yorkers who voted for Mr. Giuliani on Mr. Wagner's advice may feel deprived. With victory, the dominant emotion was supposed to have been hope as a new administration dawned. Instead, it is mourning in New York.

HEADLINE: Consumers Spur the Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Consumer spending has become the principal source of strength for the economy lately. And even though it is a cautious sort of spending, coming mainly from people who had postponed big purchases since the 1980's, some economists say the "pent-up demand" is so large that satisfying it could bolster the economy into mid-decade.
Unlocking the demand has taken a while, in the face of continued layoffs and widespread uneasiness over job security. But increasingly, consumers have ventured again into the marketplace, mainly to make big purchases: homes, cars, refrigerators and other appliances and furniture. 
 "What is going on now is a change in the willingness of people to buy," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center. "Anxiety over jobs has tempered their buying. But low interest rates and falling prices have made consumers believe that now is a good time to buy."
 
 
Shopping Bias
 As the Christmas season approaches, American shoppers are displaying a distinct bias. While their spending is growing at a faster rate, on average, than their incomes, the rate of consumption has been pulled up mostly by people who are finally replacing old cars and by young families buying and furnishing their first homes, in the belief that mortgage rates and home prices may be at or near the bottom.
Retailers report heavy traffic in shopping malls and stores in recent months, but actual outlays for clothing, toys, cosmetics, books and a great variety of other "soft goods" have not shown much increase, according to Commerce Department data.
Consumer spending began to rise, slowly at first, in the summer of 1992. That was when the recovery from the last recession took hold, said Robert Wescott, a senior economist on President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "Consumer spending gets delayed until people really believe a recovery is in progress," he said.
But the new consumption is not showing up evenly across the population. Much of the buying involves higher-income households, earning more than $40,000 a year, often from two earners who have reduced old debt and can borrow again, said Florence Skelly, vice chairman of DYG, a market research firm. By comparison, the median income of all American households is $28,000.
Mr. Curtin added that many of these buyers had loosened up in the belief that the economy was no longer in immediate danger of a new recession that would bring more layoffs.
Some, including Edward A. Brennan, chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, give partial credit to the Clinton Administration for the rise in buying. "The new Administration is very active, and that activity has released some energy among the public," said Mr. Brennan, who describes himself as a staunch Republican. "There is much more traffic in the stores."
Reflecting these currents, outlays for personal expenditures -- not only merchandise but also a great variety of services -- rose by $261 billion from July 1992 through last September, while income available to spend rose by $222 billion, the Commerce Department reported. The great thrust of the spending was for cars and for all the appliances, furniture and electronic gear that go into newly built or purchased homes.
"We are finally seeing this pent-up demand come forth," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "People perceive that the economic recovery has stuck, although it is a sluggish one. They don't have the incomes to support heavy spending, but they are drawing down savings, refinancing homes at lower mortgage rates and taking profits from mutual funds and the stock market to make purchases."
With this cash, as well as new installment loans, car and truck sales have risen to an annual rate of 14.5 million, higher than at any time since the 1980's, but still below the 15 million units that the auto industry considers an "average" year and below the record 16.3 million in 1986. About 25 percent of these sales are in the form of leases, an increasingly popular purchase method that allows the cautious buyer to avoid a large down payment.
Feeding these sales is the average age of the autos and trucks owned by Americans: a record 8.1 years, compared with 5.6 years in the 1970's.
More than six million vehicles are owned by people who have postponed the purchase of a new car, and now some of those people are buying and more are likely to do so in the next year or two, said Wynn Van Bussman, a Chrysler Corporation economist. But the purchases are coming mostly from people with incomes above $40,000, according to Mr. Van Bussman. People earning less are increasingly more reluctant to buy, reflecting their insecurity about jobs.
 
 
Sharp Contrast
 Similarly, as home sales rise, spending for the appliances, furniture and furnishings that go into homes has jumped by more than 10 percent in the 12-month period that ended in September. That is in sharp contrast to outlays for services like dry cleaning, haircuts, lawyers and entertainment. They remained almost unchanged from the previous one-year period. And spending on clothing in the latest year grew at only half that rate.
Home sales are not included in the Commerce Department's personal consumption data, but single-family- home construction in the third quarter reached its highest level since 1986. Home sales are rising as young families migrate from renting to ownership.
"This activity is not dependent on job growth, and that is of key importance," said David F. Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders. "You are talking about people who have jobs and who have been sitting in rental housing, waiting for the right moment to buy."
Low mortgage rates have stimulated the market, and if they should rise, that might cut activity, Mr. Seiders said. Administration officials agree. They argue that low rates have been the critical factor in the entire revival of consumer spending. The hope is that consumer spending will generate more jobs to supply the purchasing, and as employment rises, there will be more consumers with higher incomes.
 
 
'Start of the Process'
 "It is typical of recovery periods that consumption runs ahead of income growth," said Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "That can't happen forever, but it is the start of the process."
Mr. Van Bussman offers a slightly different view: Low interest rates on loans are only part of the story. They have been low in the past, without raising sales. That is partly because 14 percent of all car sales are to people over 65. For some of them, who are retired, the benefits of lower loan rates are offset by less income from interest payments on their investments.
What's more, as car sales rise, Mr. Blinder's job-creation cycle might kick in only slowly. As Chrysler, for example, made its factories more efficient, employment declined to 89,196 people in March from 91,491 in September 1992. Since March, Chrysler has been adding third shifts and hiring, but has added only a net total of 772 people -- still below the 1992 level.
"Where the hiring should come is in companies that supply us, but we don't know yet if that is happening," Mr. Van Bussman said.

HEADLINE: Head of Dance Group to Receive Cultural Honor

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins today will bestow New York City's highest cultural honor on Arthur Mitchell, the founder, artistic director and president of the Dance Theater of Harlem.
Mr. Mitchell, 58, who is also to receive the Kennedy Center Honors on Dec. 5, is 1 of 13 people, including the playwright August Wilson and the philanthropist Brooke Astor, who will be recognized by the Mayor in an awards ceremony at Gracie Mansion. 
 A protege of George Balanchine and star of the New York City Ballet, Mr. Mitchell left that company in 1968 to form his own group. The Dance Theater of Harlem quickly became recognized as one of the world's premier dance troupes. In the last year, the group has staged a comeback from a financial crisis that saw it lay off much of its staff for six months in 1991.
Mr. Mitchell will receive the Handel Medallion, which was created after a 1959 festival marking the 200th anniversary of the composer's death. Past recipients include Marc Chagall, Benny Goodman, Sidney Poitier, Isaac Bashevis Singer and John Lennon. Recipients from the dance world have included Martha Graham, Alvin Ailey, Agnes de Mille and Robert Joffrey.
Mrs. Astor will receive the Eleanor Roosevelt Medallion, given since 1984 to recognize work in the field of human rights.
Mr. Dinkins will present the Mayor's Award of Honor for Arts and Culture to Mr. Wilson; Louise Bourgeois, a sculptor; Rene Buch, artistic director of the bilingual theater company Repertorio Espanol, and Gilberto Zaldivar, the company's producer; Irene Diamond, president of the Aaron Diamond Foundation, a philanthropy; John Duffy, president and director of Meet the Composer, which awards musical grants; Moe Foner, director of the Bread and Roses Cultural Project of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees union; Robert Kotlowitz, senior fellow of the Freedom Forum Media Studies Center at Columbia University, and John Kwo Wei Tchen, the director of the Asian-American Center at Queens College.
The Mayor's Award was initiated in 1976, and recipients are chosen by the city's Advisory Commission for Cultural Affairs.
The Mayor will give a special award to George Seuffert, leader for more than 60 years of the George Seuffert Band, which is known for its free concerts in public parks.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Protesters scoff as the fur industry begins a national campaign.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
WINTER is coming. If you cannot tell by the temperatures, check out all the magazines and television stations advertising fur coats. Fur is flying everywhere, from the first national campaign ever produced by the Fur Information Council of America.
The $1.25 million campaign includes full-page, color presentations in a variety of national publications, including Vogue, Vanity Fair, Town & Country, Harper's Bazaar, Essence and Newsweek, and television commercials in 70 cities. 
 The overt message is a simple one: Fur is back as a fashion statement; faux furs are faux pas. Implicit are the more subtle factors that reflect an improving economy, the repeal last summer of a 10 percent luxury tax on items that cost $10,000 or more and a gamble by the industry that fur is politically safe again.
"We're up," said Etta O'Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Flemington Furs in Flemington, N.J., referring to the company's advertising budget this year. "And so is everybody else in the industry."
But talk about flying fur. Behind the models, stylish furs, lavish settings and stronger budgets is the simmering battle between the fur industry and animal rights activist groups like the Fur-Bearers in Vancouver, British Columbia, people who not only do not buy furs, but also do not buy the argument that the industry is all that robust.
Protest groups say that the council's advertising campaign is nothing more than propaganda aimed at convincing the public that furs are fashionable again after several seasons in which retailers pushed faux fur as an alternative.
"Just a marketing gimmick," Cathy Liss, the executive director of the Animal Welfare Institute in Washington, said of the current industry campaign. "It's an attempt to pull the market out of the dumps."
That argument, in turn, draws fire from fur industry officials who contend that the protesters can only perpetuate their own existence by protesting. "There's a consumer backlash against them," said Karen Handel, a spokeswoman for the council. "People are tired of their antics."
Around and around it goes, with each side offering statistics to verify and quantify its position. Ms. Handel said the council, which represents 50 retailers in the United States, 2 fur auction houses and a group of Scandinavian fur producers, only embarked on the current advertising campaign because business had improved.
"We can't make up the sales figures," she said.
The campaign was devised by Steve Gold Inc., an agency in New York. Steve Gold, president of the agency, said that in addition to the campaign being the biggest ever from the council, it represented the first time various factions of the industry have united to promote themselves.
Would that not represent, at least in part, a political response by the industry against charges by the protest groups of inhumane treatment of animals?
"No, no," Mr. Gold said. "This is totally driven by marketing strategy. The fur industry has seen an improvement in sales at retail. If that wasn't the case, you would never have seen this campaign. Seeing the light at the end of the tunnel has made this possible."
Sales figures collected by the council show that a four-year downward trend from 1987, when sales reached $1.8 billion for a second consecutive year, began to turn around last year. In 1992, sales grew by 10 percent, to $1.1 billion, and the council said it expected that figure to improve this year.
But some of the protest groups said they wondered how that was possible. The Animal Welfare Institute and the Fur-Bearers, among others, contend that the number of animals trapped had declined in recent years -- to fewer than 7 million last year, from 28 million a decade ago, said Michelle Clausius, the executive director of the Fur-Bearers.
To those organizations, fewer pelts mean fewer products. "The numbers speak for themselves," Ms. Clausius said of the figures for trapped animals. "That kind of decrease hardly constitutes a comeback."
And the bleat goes on. On Sept. 30, eight members of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, including Kate Pierson of the B-52's rock group, were arrested after they marched into the offices of Vogue magazine and pasted anti-fur stickers on the walls. The model Christy Turlington recently posed for a billboard in the nude behind a sign that says, "I'd rather go naked than wear fur."
This Friday, the group plans several activities in New York, including an anti-fur parade.
"I'm so sick of what's politically correct or not correct," said Ms. O'Sullivan of Flemington Furs. "We still get protests, but I think the public refuses to take it any longer."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
PC Magazine Is Mirroring an Industry's Success

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
No one could accuse PC Magazine of talking down to its readers.
Twice a month, the magazine serves up an editorial diet rich in computer jargon and technical acronyms. Readers squeamish about descriptive passages loaded with "GUI accelerators" and "Type 3 bitmaps" are well advised to go elsewhere. Its stock-in-trade is comparative product testing, sometimes more than 100 offerings in an issue, each graded, measured and charted, page after page. Even its editors call it a "nerd's magazine." 
 Clearly, PC Magazine is not for everyone. Yet its seemingly parochial focus on the innards of personal computers has proved a winning formula and given it a surprisingly large audience, making it one of the great publishing success stories of recent years.
The magazine's circulation has nearly doubled in the last five years, to more than one million, and advertisers have flocked to it in droves. Its issues average 500 pages, bloated with ads.
 
 
$281 Million in Revenues
 Last year, PC Magazine was the ninth-largest magazine in the United States in revenues, which were estimated at $281 million -- way ahead of mainstream business magazines like Business Week, Forbes and Fortune. The annual calculations, by Folio magazine, are not exact, mainly because of the widespread practice of offering advertisers discounts from the standard page rates. But analysts say PC Magazine's size and leadership in the industry are not in doubt.
The rise of PC Magazine since its founding in 1981 reflects the explosive growth of the personal computer business, from its garage-shop origins little more than a decade ago to a $70 billion-a-year industry today.
"The success of PC Magazine shows that there are vast numbers of people who are deeply interested in this technology," said Michael J. Miller, the magazine's editor in chief. "And people need help in trying to keep up with it, because the personal computer business is the fastest-moving industry that the world has ever seen."
So far, industry changes have worked to the advantage of PC Magazine and the other computer magazines. Computer Publishing and Advertising Report, a newsletter in Wilton, Conn., estimates that ad revenues in the flourishing field have increased 90 percent in the last five years.
Leading personal computer makers, like International Business Machines Corporation, Compaq Computer Corporation, Apple Computer Inc. and Dell Computer Corporation, have taken turns in going through tough times in the price wars of recent years. Yet in good times and bad, they have had to keep advertising to fight for sales.
With computers on virtually every office desktop, the number of people making their own decisions about what model to buy has soared, and many of them are regular computer-magazine readers.
"The trade magazines have an enormous influence on people's buying decisions," said Ray Freeman, a vice president of the IBM Personal Computer Company, who oversees its advertising programs.
The big winners have been the two private companies that dominate the computer publishing field, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company and International Data Group. Besides PC Magazine, the leading Ziff-Davis titles are PC Week, Computer Shopper, PC Computing and Macweek. The top publications in the International Data Group stable include PC World, Macworld, Computerworld and Infoworld.
 
 
Two Wealthy Rivals
 The boom in computer magazines has certainly enriched the two men who own the rival publishing groups. William B. Ziff Jr., who earlier this month retired as chairman of Ziff Communications Company, the corporate parent of the publishing company, is worth roughly $1.5 billion, Forbes magazine estimated. In its most recent list of the 400 richest people in America, Forbes estimates that Patrick J. McGovern, the chairman of International Data Group, was worth $500 million.
Yet if the history of the computer industry is any guide, no franchise is assured. Any business that does not adjust quickly to change is headed for trouble, a fact of life in the computer industry that should apply as much to publishers as to manufacturers.
And the publishers do face challenges: slower growth this year, a broadening of the computer market to less-sophisticated home users and technological changes ranging from big shifts in computer use to the challenge of electronic publishing in a market whose young, affluent and technologically savvy readers should be the first to embrace electronic distribution.
 
 
The Strong Get Stronger
 The slower growth caused by a soft economy and a consolidation among personal computer makers, analysts say, is winnowing some of the 300 computer magazines and newspapers as advertisers become more selective.
"But the strong publications are getting stronger, and that trend should continue," said Sheila Craven, president of Adscope Inc., a research firm in Goldendale, Wash., that tracks high-tech advertising.
In the first nine months of this year, for example, PC Magazine's total ad pages slipped more than 2 percent, to 5,005 pages, but its ad revenues increased more than 9 percent because of higher prices, Adscope estimates. For the 12 leading forums for computer advertising, ad pages increased 2 percent and revenues rose 14 percent in the nine months, according to Adscope.
Still, even Ziff-Davis has not been immune to the slowing of growth in the industry. Last June, it shut two magazines, PC Sources and Corporate Computing. PC Sources, a monthly started in 1990, was directed at the mail-order computer business. Once a specialized niche, the mail-order business has become mainstream, with I.B.M., Compaq and others shipping computers directly to customers who typically order by calling "800" phone numbers. The market no longer required a specialized mail-order magazine, Ziff-Davis executives said.
Corporate Computing was an ambitious Ziff-Davis effort to move beyond its traditional strength in personal computers into industrial-strength computing, which might include mainframes, minicomputers and work stations, as well as PC's working in tandem.
 
 
From the Technical to the Silly
 Started in June 1992 and called "The Magazine of the Re-engineering Age," the monthly was praised even by rivals for its editorial quality. It was aimed at a more general audience of managers and addressed big technical subjects like moving off mainframe computers and using electronic mail systems. John Cleese, the English comic actor, wrote an irreverent column on management.
A year later, Ziff closed the magazine. "We underestimated the speed at which corporate computing was decentralizing and moving to the desktop," said Ronni Sonnenberg, president of Ziff-Davis publications in America.
In short, the Ziff explanation is that the market was moving into its bailiwick -- the desktop world -- even faster than it had imagined.
At International Data Group, however, the failure of Corporate Computing is viewed as evidence that Ziff will have trouble moving beyond its mainstay, magazines that cater to the stand-alone desktop market. Companies increasingly want their computers, large or small, linked by sophisticated networks that let workers anywhere in the world work in teams. International Data has more publications that focus on big corporate computing and, with publications in some 60 countries, it has a stronger international stance than Ziff.
"The computer industry is going global and toward enterprisewide computing," said Kelly Conlin, president of International Data's marketing services division. "The market is moving our way."
 
Power to Influence Consumers
 Perhaps. But PC Magazine still commands the attention of today's biggest computer-literate audience, and product judgments made in its Manhattan offices can sway sales trends in the industry. Slender, bespectacled and intense, Mr. Miller, the 34-year-old editor, is an unabashed enthusiast of the technology his magazine promotes.
"I love computers," he said. "I live for this stuff -- I admit it."
The magazine pioneered the use of comparative product testing in personal computers, and its continuing edge in giving readers head-to-head product ratings explains its top spot among computer magazines. Its multimillion-dollar testing lab is behind glass doors, filled with rows of modern gray tables that house 68 work stations for putting every imaginable variety of machine and software program through its paces. Each product is tested according to scripts that run 20 to 200 pages, to make the trials as accurate and consistent as possible.
 
 
'It's Nerds' Disneyland Here'
 "It's Nerds' Disneyland here," observed Jay Munro, a project leader at the testing lab.
Like many of his 110-member staff, Mr. Miller has thoughtful views on broader subjects like the role computers will play in the coming information highway or the way technology is changing work patterns. None of this is likely ever to appear in PC Magazine.
"We're not a reporting organization or a news operation," he explained. "It's the lab-based product testing that makes PC Magazine what it is."
PC Magazine's leading rival, PC World, a monthly owned by International Data, takes a somewhat different approach -- less technical and intended for a more general management audience.
"Our readers don't really care about the underlying technology," said Philip Lemmons , the editor in chief of PC World. "They want to know what they can grab and get immediate benefit from."
PC World's audience is also a large one, with a circulation of more than 900,000. And its research shows that three-fourths of its readers do not read PC Magazine.
Over the last year or so, PC World has done general articles on problems in the industry, like a lengthy piece on repetitive stress injuries suffered by keyboard users and an article on fraud by some mail-order computer marketers.
"Most industry magazines haven't written about things that might inhibit people from buying PC's," Mr. Lemmons said. "But we've done critical stories."

HEADLINE: Betsy Garrison, Avery L. Krut

 BODY:
Betsy Garrison, a vice president for Lowe Direct, a New York-based advertising agency, and Avery L. Krut, a partner in Catalyst, a company that designs and manages economic redevelopment projects, were married yesterday. Both work in Los Angeles. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Penthouse in New York.
Mrs. Krut, 43, the daughter of Charles C. Garrison of Falls Church, Va., and the late Janice White Garrison, graduated from Roanoke College. Her father is a senior accountant for the Student Loan Marketing Association, the Federal loan program known as Sallie Mae, in Washington. 
 Mr. Krut, 33, the son of Rabbi Chaim Krut of Flushing, Queens, and the late Esta Elstein Krut, graduated from Queens College, from which he also received a master's degree in social research. His father, who is now retired, was a budget administrator for the service departments of New York City Technical College.

LENGTH: 588 words

HEADLINE: A Dangerous Deficit Bill

 BODY:
The House votes today on a superficially seductive bill that would knock about $100 billion off the deficit without raising taxes. No wonder its sponsors -- Timothy Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, and John Kasich, Republican of Ohio -- are close to attracting enough votes to pass their bill.
But Congress would do grave damage if it passed the Penny-Kasich bill. Most of the cuts it proposes are needed to meet existing budget targets as well as to pay for health care reform and the Administration's strategy of investing in education, training, research and infrastructure. So if the bill passes, Congress will be forced to hit the higher deficit targets by making additional cuts elsewhere, shredding, for example, an already-tattered safety net for low-income families. 
 Congress already faces a disheartening need to cut discretionary programs. Even if it threw President Clinton's entire investment plan into the garbage heap, Congress would still have to cut $15 billion in discretionary spending over four years to meet the deficit targets adopted last summer.
Putting back the Administration's investment program raises the total to $50 billion. And last week, the Senate passed an expensive crime bill that would up the ante by $20 billion. That means Congress must find some $70 billion over four years to meet its existing deficit target before it can even begin to consider raising those targets.
The Penny-Kasich bill would pile on more problems. About $30 billion of its cuts are in discretionary spending -- cuts that could have been used to make up the shortfall. And the bill proposes $20 billion in cuts the Administration was already counting on to hit existing targets. By diverting these funds to pay for additional deficit reduction, the bill would make Congress's task that much harder. Congress would be forced to trim programs that Mr. Penny and Mr. Kasich didn't dare to touch -- such as those focused on the poor.
There's also an ominous problem with their proposed entitlement cuts of $50 billion, mostly in Medicare. Mr. Clinton has proposed more than $100 billion in Medicare cuts himself to pay for his health care reform. If the Penny-Kasich bill claimed the money, it would go for deficit reduction instead -- forcing Mr. Clinton to attach a huge tax hike to his health bill. Bye-bye health reform.
Mr. Penny and Mr. Kasich deserve praise for identifying sensible, even courageous ways to cut spending, each of which would hurt a special interest. Their bill would rein in agriculture subsidies, prune Congressional retirement benefits, raise the retirement age for Federal employees and eliminate the Interstate Commerce Commission and other outdated agencies.
But the responsible way to proceed isn't to pass the bill. Congress has already adopted rational deficit-reduction targets. And they are strict. The targets require, for example, that nondefense discretionary spending -- everything from the F.B.I. to national parks -- be held constant, after accounting for inflation, over the next four years.
First, Congress needs to make enough cuts to hit those targets. Then it needs to cut further to pay for vital initiatives like health care reform, crime prevention, education, worker training and scientific research.
Only after doing that would it make sense for Congress to choose whatever is left of the Penny-Kasich cuts for additional deficit reduction. High jumpers clear the cross bar at low heights before raising it another notch or two. So should Congress.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Three Clintons

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Last week, we saw three Bill Clintons in action: the thin-skinned politician, the maturing President and the simplistic pitchman.
It began with an outburst of self-pity. At the end of an interview with William Greider and Jann Wenner of Rolling Stone magazine, a Clinton nettled by questions about his ideological firmness blew up: 
 "I have fought more damn battles here for more things than any President has in 20 years," he blustered, "with the possible exception of Reagan's first budget, and not gotten one damn bit of credit from the knee-jerk liberal press, and I am sick and tired of it, and you can put that in the damn article."
Warming to his whining, he boasted of his early leftward lurch: "Look what I did. I said the wealthy would have to pay their fair share, and look what we did to the tax system. . . . Did I get any credit for it, from you or anybody else?" He then switched from Johnson Treatment to Nixon self-delusion: "Do I care if I get credit? No."
Oh, but he cares so much: "And you get no credit around here for fighting and bleeding. And that's why the know-nothings and the do-nothings and the negative people and the right-wingers always win. Because of the way people like you put questions to people like me."
So shut up, you radic-libs; your mean questions are making your only President blubber all over his new Oval Office carpet.
After this puerile display of petulance, a quite different Clinton made his appearance. As a Roosevelt Roomful of media biggies gathered for a Nafta-eve briefing, the President seemed to just wander in before the Administration briefers.
His easy command presence made you feel that a pro was in charge of the country. When his aides came in (on cue, but seemingly late) he mock-chastised them for keeping us heavy hitters waiting: "You mean you let these guys talk to each other?"
Clinton then sat down for 10 minutes of serious questioning on Chinese trade and human rights, explicating policy with sophistication. He knew he had Nafta's passage in his pocket, the result of wheeling and dealing in the grand tradition. He would use this victory to impress the Asian leaders in Seattle and -- as part of a "triple play" -- use the North American and Asian groupings to leverage a lowering of European tariffs.
That was impressive. The second Clinton had a foreign economic strategy, the support of Republicans, and was prepared to risk the wrath of Labor in leaning on Democrats to stick in his linchpin. His underrated White House armtwisters -- the firm of Daley, Emmanuel & Paster -- delivered for him.
But then, in Seattle, yet another Clinton emerged.
To deal at the highest level with China after Tiananmen Square, three great facts must be understood. First, China and the U.S. share an interest in stopping nuclear spread, especially to the rogue regime in North Korea. Second, China's economic boom depends on continued U.S. purchases. Third, the next generation throughout Asia looks to us to induce Beijing to let its new economic freedom spill over into political rights.
However, asked about resuming summit relations without some progress on human rights in return, Clinton's sloppily prepared answer was: "I don't think that you ever lose anything by talking to someone, as long as you're honest."
What simplistic nonsense. In diplomacy, "talking to someone" -- especially after a crushing of democracy -- has a great value to the ostracized perpetrator. When the Soviets sought a summit with Nixon in the 70's, Henry Kissinger made them pay a price in prepared concessions before a meeting. Jimmy Carter could not condone the invasion of Afghanistan by "talking to someone." Not even Sinophile George Bush could instantly resume regular relations after Tiananmen.
If Clinton was determined to make a pre-emptive concession, he could have said: The time was ripe to express my conviction -- face to face with Chinese leaders -- that free markets go hand in hand with human rights.
At least that would have dealt honestly with reality and offered hope to dissidents. But in his eagerness to avoid offending the sensibilities of the Chinese president, the third Clinton -- naive or deceptive -- insulted the intelligence of every American.
Whining, inspiring, oversimplifying -- which Clinton will emerge next year?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Small Powers Also Deserve Respect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
W. Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, has appealed to opinion makers and Congress to keep making a distinction between the immediate and the important when dealing with the "less strategically significant questions" of small countries that are ripping themselves apart like Somalia and Haiti. He might also include Angola, Armenia, Bosnia and others. 
 The distinction between the immediate and the important incorrectly associates the security issue of small nations in internal turmoil with the immediate but unimportant, compared with "the most fundamental questions" of areas of greater strategic importance to us, like Russia.
In an American policy of engagement, based on democratic principles and pragmatic application of American power, there is no escaping responsibility for the security problems of small countries. The big strategic issues will be those like demilitarization of Russia and countering strategic weapons proliferation from China. But democratization and defense of more than 100 small countries are issues of the first magnitude.
Small country security issues are of first importance to the security of most large countries, particularly when the small countries ripping themselves apart are on the borders of the large countries and involve ethnic or religious groups. Don't forget that most of the great power wars were initiated by disputes in small states within their competing spheres of influence -- Bosnia in 1914, Czechoslovakia in 1938, Korea in 1951, Kuwait in 1990.
The best efforts of the nuclear powers at counterproliferation of weapons of mass destruction are unlikely to be completely successful in denying desperate small countries, rich drug cartels and crime syndicates access to nuclear weapons.
The increasing number of small country security crises affecting the national security of the great powers means that there must be a wider choice of policy options than costly and often futile armed intervention or withdrawal into military and economic isolationism.
Fortunately there are examples of small countries that have successfully resolved their internal conflicts and defended their independence against much stronger neighbors without themselves becoming threatening to others. Slovenia, Finland, Switzerland and Costa Rica are such good examples. Perhaps Estonia and Israel soon may be.
The Clinton Administration cannot evade or postpone responsibility for a viable and consistent foreign policy and security strategy concerning small country conflicts by arguing that policies concerning great powers are more strategically significant. An effective foreign and defense policy will regard both as important and address both seriously and simultaneously.
 
CLARK ABT
Director, Defense Technology Conversion Center, Boston U.
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: Provide Work Again In New York City Parks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York City's parks offer a challenge for Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani and his new commissioner of parks: Put maintenance first. Hire the unemployed. Make parks labor-intensive. Provide work for all. 
 The most urgent need in our parks today is to make parks labor-intensive, to put men and women on the grounds, whom the public will see and respect. These workers must also be supervised by men and women working on the grounds. Nothing like that has happened for years.
To make parks labor intensive will not only improve the maintenance of our parks, but will also help New York maintain its position as a great tourist center. Perhaps most important, it will increase public safety, the major concern throughout our city.
In a very real sense the Parks Department increasingly has a dual role, not only to maintain the parks, but a social responsibility to give employment to men and women, unskilled, untrained and uneducated, who have no possibility of gainful employment in the private sector or in any other public agency.
Many of these, in fact, are the very people who built our parks a century ago.
 
ROBERT MAKLA
Brooklyn, N.Y., Nov. 12, 1993

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 METRO DIGEST
 
GOOD NEWS ON UNEMPLOYMENT SPENDING
New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania stand to reap tens of millions of dollars from a revamping of the Government survey from which unemployment rates are calculated, according to Federal and state officials. The extra money would result mainly from the states' greater share of the billions of Federal money spent on training, job placement and various other programs tied in some way to the severity of unemployment in a state or locality. Since the total pool of aid is more or less fixed, other states would lose. New York might also gain disproportionately from an extension of emergency unemployment benefits, which are triggered by rate of unemployment. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
CABDRIVER KILLINGS LEAVE EMPTINESS
Rene Rodriguez, who is 7 years old and proud of learning to rhyme words, insists that he does not keep going to the window to look for a father who never comes. His 10-year-old sister says he does. When the father died behind the wheel of his livery cab in central Harlem in March 1992, he left behind a wife and three children and not much else. He was one of 186 cabdrivers killed in the last five years. The fundamental equation is that $75, the average take in a livery cab robbery, is worth a driver's life to the ones who kill them. But to the families of those slain, almost always poor immigrants, the loss is incalculable. A1.
 
ANOTHER OFFICER COMMITS SUICIDE
An off-duty New York City police officer killed himself in an Atlantic City hotel, the eighth to commit suicide this year, the police said. The dead officer, Frank Astralla, 24, was a three-year veteran assigned to the 104th Precinct in Woodside, Queens. His suicide was the fourth by a uniformed member of the New York Police Department since Oct. 30, which has prompted Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly to call for increased suicide efforts. B3.
 
GIULIANI GIVES SOME SUPPORT TO MAYOR
After a week of jousting between Mayor David N. Dinkins and his successor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor-elect offered a bit of an olive branch to Mr. Dinkins, saying that he was willing to support the Mayor "in any tough decisions" so long as "problems not be made worse." Mr. Giuliani also gave his support to the Mollen Commission, formed to investigate police corruption. But he reiterated his request for the Dinkins administration to refrain from making long-term deals before leaving office, referring specifically to contract talks with the city's sanitation workers. B3.
Thirteen people, including Arthur Miller, head of the Dance Theater of Harlem, and the philanthropist Brooke Astor, will receive New York City's highest cultural honor. B6.
The death of Robert F. Wagner Jr. deprives Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani of an important voice on urban issues. Metro Matters, B3.
 
REGION
 
AIDE ATTACKS ROLLINS'S CLAIMS
The campaign aide responsible for building support for Gov.-elect Christine Todd Whitman among minority voters has vehemently denied Edward J. Rollins's account of a conversation they had about countering Democrats' efforts to gain the support of black ministers. The aide, Lonna Hooks, said she was never told to offer the ministers any money or to suggest what they should say from the pulpit. Instead, she said, her efforts to win black voters to Mrs. Whitman involved bringing Mrs. Whitman to meet black community leaders and ministers and arranging for her to talk with delegates to the annual meeting of the N.A.A.C.P. During this time, she said, the Florio campaign was largely ignoring black voters and their concerns. A1.
 
ADOPTIVE PARENTS SHARE EXPERIENCES
Six years ago, Lisa Kearney wrote down on a slip of paper the reasons why she could not keep her son, to remind herself in moments of weakness. "I wasn't ready," she said. Her child's adoptive parents could offer him many opportunities, she felt. Such exchanges of curiosity and experience were the purpose of the 13th annual conference of the Adoptive Parents Committee, which drew 2,000 people to the State University of New York at Purchase. Adoptive parents and those who thought they wanted to be shared their experiences and talked about the hardships and joys of the adoptive process. B4.

HEADLINE: Touching Nerves in Newsrooms;
Resignation Reflects Vulnerability to Claims of Bias in Coverage

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILLINGBORO, N.J., Nov. 16

 BODY:
The resignation of William Newill was only sketchily mentioned last week in the pages of The Burlington County Times, the suburban daily newspaper where he had been editor for nine years.
Behind the bland announcement was a story that touches nerves in many American newsrooms. On one level, it is about white editors of small newspapers who run stories critical of local black officials. On another, it is about the vulnerability of these editors to charges of bias in their coverage because they have no black editors or reporters on their small staffs.
 
Absences Criticized
 It all started in late September when the 40,000-circulation afternoon paper published a front-page article about Assemblywoman Priscilla B. Anderson, a black Republican whose district covers western Burlington County, across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. 
 Under the headline "Dems Hit Anderson for School Absences," the article followed up on assertions by Democrats that she had missed 59 working days in one school year at her $50,000-a-year job as a high school guidance counselor in Trenton to spend time on her $35,000-a-year role as a freshman legislator. An editorial several days later took Mrs. Anderson to task for "double-dipping at the taxpayers' expense" and called for a change in a 1966 law authorizing unlimited paid leave for legislators who work for the public schools.
Some black civic leaders in Willingboro, where blacks make up about 60 percent of the 36,000 residents, cited the article as representative of what they called the newspaper's negative portrayal of blacks. They suggested that bias among its editors was reflected in the all-white composition of the news staff.
The Rev. Morris Baxter, the pastor of the Cathedral of Love in Willingboro, who is black, said he was convinced that the original article about Mrs. Anderson was intended "to scandalize the reputation of the only black woman in the Legislature."
"They wouldn't print it if it was against a white man," he said.
At a rally on Oct. 23 attended by 250 blacks, a boycott of the paper was proposed and subscription cancellation forms were distributed. Mr. Baxter did not say how many people took part in the boycott, but he said it was effective in forcing Mr. Newill's resignation.
 
A Defeat and Its Aftermath
 Mrs. Anderson and other Republican candidates in the legislative district, nominally a Democratic stronghold, lost the Nov. 2 election, and there were more suggestions among some local blacks that she had been done in by The Burlington County Times's decision not to endorse her candidacy on its editorial page.
Mr. Newill said he took the heat as part of the price of covering a hard-fought political campaign. But he was not prepared for what happened next.
Sandra C. Hardy, a co-owner of the Calkins Newspapers of Levittown, Pa., which owns The Burlington County Times and five other suburban newspapers in Pennsylvania and Florida, arranged for a peacemaking meeting between Mr. Newill and several black businessmen at a Willingboro restaurant on Nov. 8.
Before the meeting, Mr. Newill recalled, and in front of three black employees who work in other departments of the newspaper, Ms. Hardy upbraided the editor and instructed him to apologize to a group of blacks upset over the matter "for any misunderstandings."
Mr. Newill, 46, who had spent his entire journalistic career in Calkins newspapers, said he defended the accuracy and legitimacy of the coverage and refused to bow to Mrs. Hardy's demands. The next day, he submitted his resignation.
 
The Issue of Accountability
 "The issue was never race or gender," he said in an interview this week. "It was accountability of a public official, and public officials are not exempted from accountability because of race or gender."
He also said newspapers could not serve the public interest, including the interests of black residents, if the threat of being labeled as biased by unhappy black politicians forced editors to shelve accurate stories that reflected badly on the officeholders.
Still, as he telephoned friends in the newspaper business to check out job openings, he worried if a charge of "racial insensitivity" against a white newspaper editor was enough to doom a career.
Grover J. Friend, the president of Calkins Newspapers, said in a statement, "It is the policy of Calkins Newspapers not to comment on personnel matters."
Ms. Hardy did not reply to several telephoned and written requests for interviews.
Ms. Hardy, one of three sisters who own the chain, is one of seven members of the executive committee of the Newspaper Association of America, which represents publishers and marketing executives of 1,250 newspapers in the United States. She is also the vice chairwoman of the association's committee on diversity, a panel that encourages wider minority hiring in the industry.
 
Some Black Support
 Mr. Newill was not entirely consoled by the support of other prominent blacks in the Willingboro area who said that in his nine-year tenure as editor, The Times provided a fair and honest forum for black views.
"I haven't found them to be racially insensitive at all, and I doubt they set out to treat Priscilla Anderson any different from white politicians," said Roosevelt Nesmith, the president of the Burlington County chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. for 15 years. "I've found Bill Newill to be open and receptive to diverse views."
The Rev. Edwin Ellis, the pastor of the United Methodist Church of the Good Shepherd in Willingboro, who is black, said he has sometimes quarreled with the paper's news judgment on the types of stories placed on the front page. "But I hear white pastors at our clergy association meetings make the same comment," he noted.
So far, the news staff of The Times has been fairly mute about Mr. Newill's sudden departure. Ralph Siegel, the paper's State House correspondent, who wrote the original article on Mrs. Anderson's paid absences, said he feared the episode might have a chilling effect on future coverage. "The race card has been played to full effect," Mr. Siegel said, "and the immediate concern to me as a reporter was whether the paper was flinching in some way from its news coverage."
He and other staff members said management had assured them, however, that no change in journalistic standards was contemplated and that no groups or individuals were to be given special treatment.
 
An Ideal With Some Tarnish
 Willingboro, in the view of many who live in this middle-class township, comes close to a textbook ideal of integration. A small 300-year-old community founded by Quakers, it was briefly renamed Levittown after Levitt & Sons began building tract houses here four decades ago, causing the population to climb from 852 in 1950 to a peak of 43,380 in 1970. Black families began buying homes in the 1960's, and after initial white flight, the population stabilized. Many black newcomers hold white-collar jobs in Philadelphia, work for the state in the capital, Trenton, just 20 miles north, or are on the military payroll at the Fort Dix Army base and McGuire Air Force Base.
But some highly publicized murders involving blacks, both here and in Burlington City, have heightened tensions, including a case now being tried in the county seat, Mount Holly, in which Charles Williams, a black former convict, is accused of the execution-style killing of the manager of a McDonald's in Burlington City.
Mr. Ellis of the United Methodist Church of the Good Shepherd said the replaying of these and other negative images of blacks encouraged suspicion about the newspaper's motives. He said there was also a feeling that the story on Mrs. Anderson's dual jobs would not have run had she been a white politician. "After all," he said, "she didn't break the law."
 
Questions of Balance
 Mrs. Anderson said in an interview that she had never accused the newspaper of racism, although she acknowledged that she did not disassociate herself with those who did.
"What upset me was, the paper singled me out for criticism while it endorsed two educators running for the Legislature in other Burlington County districts who happen not to be Afro-Americans," said Mrs. Anderson, a former Mayor and Council member in Willingboro. "They did not attempt to balance the story by writing about their absentee records."
As for Mr. Newill, he acknowledged that he had not hired any black reporters or editors in recent years.
He said in his defense that budget cuts ordered by management permitted him to hire only one news staff member in 18 months, and that was a reporter he had previously laid off because of the economic downturn. He said he had attended job fairs and taken other steps to recruit minority journalists and had been constantly outbid by larger newspapers, which dangle before a talented prospect twice the $22,000 starting wage he can offer. Several black college students have worked at the paper as summer interns, Mr. Newill said, but those who stayed in journalism took jobs with city newspapers.
Neil Foote, the minority affairs director of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington, said he heard from suburban editors all the time about obstacles to minority recruiting.
"For it to be successful, diversity has to be a priority set by top management," he said. "The policy and the money to implement it has to come from high up."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 25, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the resignation of an editor at The Burlington County Times in New Jersey referred incompletely to the background of an article published there. The theme of the article was Democrats' criticisms of Assemblywoman Priscilla B. Anderson, a Republican, because of her attendance record at her job as a high school guidance counselor. The Democrats based their criticism on an article published by The Times of Trenton in June about the attendance records of Assemblywoman Anderson and other legislators who are also educators.

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
CNN and MTV Hanging by a 'Heavenly Thread'

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Ever since Prime Minister Li Peng signed State Council Proclamation No. 129 last month banning the purchase or possession of satellite dishes by ordinary Chinese, millions of people on the broadcasting and receiving ends of the television business in Asia have been trying to determine whether Mr. Li will risk the draconian steps necessary to enforce the order.
So far, no police officers have been sent to start ripping dishes off rooftops, but the Government is talking tough. Many in Beijing feel the Politburo has invested too much of its prestige to back down. 
 "The large majority of Beijing dish owners will have to tear their dishes down," said Wei Dangjun, a spokesman for the Ministry of Radio, Film and Television, whose Minister, Ai Zhisheng, is known for his zeal in attacking the "spiritual pollution" infecting China from the West.
"Most owners have already broken rules by installing their dishes without application," Mr. Wei said in an interview. "Those that didn't listen to orders prohibiting installation," he said, "and then didn't listen to orders to disassemble, we will punish according to relevant laws."
The most compelling test of this latest crackdown is whether it is too late. The thought-control officials in China's old guard may find that the genie of the information explosion has been out of the bottle too long.
In the Fang Village neighborhood of south Beijing, even the apartment buildings that house retired officers of the dreaded public security bureau are wired up for satellite programming from the United States, Britain and Hong Kong.
Inestimable millions of Chinese have already been swept into the information era by foreign newspapers that have arrived with the flood of foreign business people and through television programs arriving via the "heavenly thread," which is the literal translation of "satellite antenna" into Mandarin Chinese.
While there are an estimated 500,000 satellite dishes in the country, because of cable hookups on apartment buildings the Government estimates that there are 15 million subscribers to multichannel systems that import English-language programs.
 
A Sense of Crackdown
 The announcement of the ban coincided with a conference in early October on state security attended by Mr. Li and President Jiang Zemin. It concluded that "hostile forces outside our country have never stopped endangering the safety of our country" using "all means to infiltrate, split and damage us."
The ban also followed the decision of the International Olympic Committee to award the 2000 Games to Sydney, Australia, a crushing setback to the Chinese leadership.
The order banning satellite dishes contributed to a sense of crackdown in the capital this month. Two prominent journalists have been arrested: Xi Yang, a reporter for the large Hong Kong daily Ming Pao, and Gao Yu, a mainland reporter who was detained days before she was to leave for an academic year at Columbia University.
For several tense weeks, tens of thousands of Chinese who have bought the dishes from private and state-owned companies, including from the People's Liberation Army dish factory, have been hoping that this order will simply go the way of previous threats to enforce the ban.
The companies marketing the dishes have suddenly taken a low profile, though purchases are still possible, as one Beijing resident discovered last week.
"Hello, I would like to know if you still have any satellite television dishes available in your store?" the resident first asked in a telephone call.
"No, haven't you heard about the new regulations?" the clerk asked. "We're not allowed to sell them now."
The same day, the caller visited the department store and approached the salesman at what had been the satellite antenna service counter.
The man behind the counter seemed to be speaking on a different frequency. If the customer really wanted a dish, he said, it could be arranged for the equivalent of $650, including installation.
The fact that the Government is moving deliberately to enforce the ban reflects the struggle in the leadership between those who believe China should continue to open up to Western influences and those who believe China's economic boom can be sealed in a cocoon of Communist ideology.
Satellite dishes have become a way of life in China in the last two years. Even as the Clinton Administration complains that China is jamming Voice of America broadcasts, the same Chinese leaders appear helpless as millions of Chinese tune in to the Star TV network.
Star TV is the Hong Kong-based communications company that beams its five-channel menu -- including the BBC and CNN news, sports and MTV music videos -- into 4.8 million Chinese households.
In July Rupert Murdoch bought 63.6 percent of Star TV and has identified the mainland as his largest future market.
"Some leaders have installed satellite dishes with public funds," complained one Government worker who insisted on not being identified and who owns a $570 dish and receiver. "It's the authorities who have the power to do whatever they like. We are the victims."
As reported in People's Daily, the penalties for failing to take down the dishes will be anywhere from $900 to nearly $9,000. This does not include the cost of the dish, which would be confiscated.
At the ministry, Mr. Wei said he did not know when the decision would be made to start tearing hardware off rooftops.
"We await specific measures from above," he said.

HEADLINE: Europe Backs Offer to Yugoslavs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The European Community recommended today that sanctions against Yugoslavia be suspended if it persuaded Serbian nationalists in Bosnia and Herzegovina to accept an international peace plan.
"Together with the United States, we have an understanding that this is the right approach," said Foreign Minister Pieter Kooymans of the Netherlands at a meeting of his counterparts. 
 The recommendation, which already has the conditional backing of the United States, now awaits approval by the United Nations Security Council, European Community officials said.
But Yugoslavia's Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, called the plan "a step back" because it talks of suspending, not lifting, sanctions.
And the proposal was denounced as a "political ploy" by Momcilo Krajisnik, a spokesman for the self-styled Bosnian Serb parliament, said a report by Tanyug, the Yugoslav news agency.
 
Enticement to Yield
 The idea of easing sanctions against Yugoslavia was raised by France and Germany at a meeting of community Foreign Ministers in Brussels on Nov. 8. Under the plan, the enticement of suspended sanctions would push Yugoslavia to encourage Bosnian Serbs to yield more land to Bosnia's Muslim-led Government.
The suspension of sanctions on goods and services that have no military application is under study, community officials said. But the community will not support the final lifting of all sanctions until a peace plan is signed settling ethnic disputes across the former Yugoslavia, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain said.

HEADLINE: Dean Witter Gets Entry to Mastercard

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Ending one of the most bitter battles in the credit-card business, Mastercard International said yesterday that it would allow the rival Dean Witter, Discover & Company to sponsor a Mastercard credit card.
In a compromise, Dean Witter would offer the card jointly with an existing Mastercard member, Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C. They will split the expenses and the revenues of the product, which will be introduced early next year. 
 Mastercard and Visa International, which are both nonprofit associations of banks, had moved to prevent Dean Witter from issuing cards with their brands because its Discover card is a prime competitor. If Dean Witter, which was recently spun off from Sears, Roebuck & Company, was able to join the card associations, it would be able to gain access to competitive information, the associations have contended.
Dean Witter had sued Visa to challenge its exclusion on antitrust grounds, and it won a jury trial last year. The case is being appealed. In February, Mastercard sued Dean Witter, which countersued over essentially the same issue.
Dean Witter said it would withdraw its lawsuit against Mastercard as part of the agreement announced yesterday. Moreover, the companies agreed that if Dean Witter won the suit against Visa, it would also be allowed to join Mastercard and issue cards without Nationsbank.
If that happened, Dean Witter would have the right to buy Nationsbank's part of the credit-card program. Nonetheless, while this may be a short relationship, it allows Nationsbank to expand its small credit-card business.
"We have the opportunity to provide good service to customers and make a profit for our shareholders, even if it is for a limited period of time," said G. Patrick Phillips, president of Nationsbank's financial products group.
The bank has an unusual proportion of its balance sheet in government securities, and it has been aggressively looking for ways to move the money into higher-yielding loans.
 
Low-Interest Appeal
 The new credit card will not use the Dean Witter, Nationsbank or Discover brand names and will not be aimed at either company's existing customers. It will be called "Prime Option" and is meant to appeal to consumers who want a low interest rate.
"There is very little overlap in customers with the Discover Card," Philip J. Purcell, Dean Witter's chairman, said. "People are attracted to the Discover card because it is a no fee, cash back bonus; that's not the same as a low-interest-rate card."
Under the card's terms, customers pay 9.9 percent interest for the first two months after a purchase, but then the rate rises to the prime rate plus 9.9 percent. (Currently, the prime rate is 6 percent). This structure is meant to take advantage of the gap between the intentions of consumers to pay off their credit-card bills quickly, and the reality that most run balances for long periods.
The card will not have an annual fee, and customers will not incur any interest charges if they pay their bills in full every month. Mr. Purcell said that Dean Witter was developing other credit-card products to appeal to other market segments that will each have separate brand names.
Under Nationsbank's arrangement with Dean Witter, the two companies will share marketing costs and revenue from the credit-card program. Nationsbank will make the credit-card loans, although it has the option to sell some of them to Dean Witter. Dean Witter will provide the customer service and operations from its bank in Utah, MountainWest Financial. The companies declined to discuss the details of their financial arrangement.
The arrangement is not the first between Dean Witter and Nationsbank. Last year, the two formed a joint venture to put full-service stockbrokers in Nationsbank's 1,800 branches. Mr. Purcell said he approached Nationsbank with the credit-card idea several months ago.
Hugh McColl, Nationsbank's chairman, has said he would be interested in buying Dean Witter if its stock price was lower.
Although Mastercard's decision to cooperate with Discover is controversial among banks, Alex W. Hart, Mastercard's president, defended his action, saying it relieved the association and its members of the expense of litigation and the potential for significant damages if the suit were lost.
The move could be another coup for Mastercard, which has reversed its long decline in market share by aligning itself with aggressive nonbanks including A.T.& T. and General Motors.
Many analysts wonder whether Dean Witter's entry into the bank card business is a precursor to bringing the Discover brand under the Visa or Mastercard umbrella. This would allow the company to eliminate its network of separate relationships with merchants that accept its card, although Discover executives say they do not want to do this.
After spending $1 billion to start Discover, Dean Witter has issued more than 27 million accounts. While the business has become profitable, it had a return on equity in 1992 of 16.3 percent, far lower than most bank credit-card programs.
