HEADLINE: Dow Falls 23.76 Points In Selloff

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Concerns over rising interest rates and a weakening bull market pushed stock prices down yesterday and intensified fears that American stocks might be facing new downward pressures.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.76 points to close at 3,670.25, after tumbling more than 40 points in the morning. But even more troubling, market traders said, was that the number of stocks falling in price outnumbered those gaining by a margin of about 7 to 2 -- an indicator of broad market weakness. 
 Trading was dominated yesterday by a continued rise in long-term interest rates, which made the stock market skittish because rising rates are a sign of possible future inflation and a threat as investors move their money from stocks into higher-yielding bonds. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to the highest level since Aug. 12. [Page D18.]
 
 
Gloom From Overseas
 In addition, the trading day opened to gloomy market news from overseas as stock prices fell sharply in Tokyo. [Page D2.] The slide continued as trading shifted to Europe.
But in the United States, market analysts saw yesterday's market drop as confirming their view that the bull market was continuing to show signs of fatigue. It has been more than 36 months since the stock market has dropped by more than 10 percent, the general benchmark for a significant correction. This has been the longest run-up without a 10 percent correction since the Dow Jones index was created in 1897.
"This is a sick stock market now," said David Shulman, a market analyst with Salomon Brothers. "This is a liquidity-driven market, and higher interest rates will take liquidity from the stock market."
 
 
A Growing Slump
 Stocks had been mostly lower for the previous four trading sessions. And many analysts said that gains on Friday were propped up by "buy" orders from program traders. When those orders did not appear yesterday and the news from overseas was bad, stocks fell sharply in early trading.
Analysts, however, said yesterday's market performance reflected larger issues at play. Rising interest rates have raised questions about the strength of the economic recovery, which has been fed by low interest rates. In addition, rising interest rates could affect the flow of money into stock mutual funds, which have swelled -- helping to push up stock prices -- as investors search for higher yields.
"If those money flows diminish into the mutual funds and the market, we're in trouble," said Michael Metz, a market analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "We're beginning to see the signs of a correction that will bring the market down by 10 percent before it runs its course."
The market is weaker than what the Dow suggests, analysts say, because the index consists of blue-chip stocks, which are generally slower to fall in price than the stocks of middle- and lower-tier companies.
 
'The Market Is Tired'
 "The market is tired, and it's oversold," said Larry Wachtel, a vice president at Prudential Securities Inc. "For the 1,700 stocks that declined, it was a horrendous day. And we've been seeing more of these days when you have more than 1,500 stocks declining. That's a signal of real weakness."
Donald Kimsey, a technical market analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, said: "The underpinnings of the market have been weakening for some time. If you look just at the Dow, you think that everything is O.K. But the increase in the number of declining shares has been going on for a while now."
On a percentage basis, stocks on the Nasdaq market and the American Stock Exchange were hit even harder yesterday, a sign that smaller and medium-size companies have been suffering the most. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 13.43, to 738.13, and the American Exchange fell 7.10, to 460.88. The smaller emerging stocks have generally led the market during the bull rally and are now most vulnerable to declines as the market turns down.
"Across the board, a lot of damage was done," said John Schraff, an equity trader with Daiwa Securities. "There's selling everywhere."
 
 
Drops in Technology and Casinos
 Industries that were particularly hard-hit yesterday were high-technology stocks, led by Motorola and Hewlett-Packard. Cyclical stocks, including Caterpillar and Deere, fell, as did casino stocks like Mirage Resorts and Circus Circus Enterprises.
Among the most actively traded shares was Paramount Communications, which rose 2 5/8, to 79, after Viacom Inc. said it would extend its tender offer until midnight tomorrow. Merck declined 1 1/2, to 33 5/8, after it appeared the company would get more stock and less cash from an impending merger.

STOCKS PLUNGE IN EUROPE
 PARIS, Nov. 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- European stock markets plunged today, driven lower by fears that Wall Street could suffer from rising interest rates in the United States.
The Paris bourse slumped 3 percent, while the Frankfurt stock market fell by 2.3 percent. The London exchange was down 1.2 percent, affected partly by nervousness ahead of the British budget, due on Nov. 30.
Analysts said today that European markets remained due for a correction. In local currency terms, the German, French and British markets have all risen more than 30 percent in the last year. With the end of the year approaching, brokers are more inclined to cash in their gains.
The rises on European markets have been fed mainly by gradually falling interest rates. But in recent weeks, concern has been mounting that a stronger-than-expected recovery in the United States may lead to mounting inflation and higher interest rates.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Continue Their Slide

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury sold $17 billion of two-year notes yesterday as bond and note prices continued to dive.
The price decline pushed the yield on the 30-year bond up to 6.38 percent, its highest level since Aug. 12. In the last three trading days, the price of the bond has plunged more than 2 1/2 points, with the yield jumping almost a quarter of a percentage point. 
 There was no major economic news yesterday but traders said that the market had broken some important price levels recently and that movement had added to the downward momentum.
 
Seeking Patterns

 
 A lot of traders make buying and selling decisions based on a careful examination of trading patterns. When the price of a security breaks below a level that had been expected to hold, selling can follow quickly.
Traders also said that a number of them were unwilling to hold any positions for long because a sudden decline in the market could eat into the profits they have already made this year. This wariness is adding to selling pressure, even when there is no new economic or political developments to drive the market.
The prospect of a Treasury auction yesterday and today also influenced the market, traders said.
The underlying reason for the selling remains the fear that the economy is picking up pace in the last three months of the year. The concern among many is that this rate of growth could carry into next year. If it does, traders are concerned about two things.
One is that inflation, which has been at a rate of less than 3 percent this year, could begin to rise faster. Second is a fear that the Federal Reserve would respond by quickly raising its target for short-term interest rates; that target has been 3 percent for more than a year.
 
Widespread Effects
 The fear of rising inflation, which reduces profits from fixed-income securities, would hurt longer-term maturities, like the 30-year bond. The fear of a Fed increase in short-term interest rates makes short-term Treasury securities less attractive.
But many analysts argue that any new data should not be a surprise that pushes prices lower and yields higher. "There is basically not much to drive the market down now but momentum," said David Munro, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics.
He said there is little risk of much more of a selloff, because data for the first part of next year will show that the economy is slowing to a growth rate of about 3 percent rather than the 4 percent or more forecast for the fourth quarter of 1993.
In late trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond was down 24/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.38 percent, from 6.33 percent Friday. The price of the three-year note was off 4/32 with the yield up to 4.59 percent from 4.55 percent.
Because of the holiday-shortened week, the Treasury held two auctions yesterday, the regular sale of three-month and six-month Treasury bills and the monthly sale of two-year notes. The market will be closed on Thursday for Thanksgiving and trading will end about 2 P.M. both tomorrow and Friday.
 
No Surprise at Auction
 The auction of two-year notes went as expected, traders said, and did not seem to have a major impact on the market. The high yield at the auction of two-year notes was 4.27 percent. All the notes are awarded at the same price and yield.
The Treasury will auction $11 billion of five-year notes today. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the yield for that issue was at 5.23 percent, up from 5.17 percent Friday.
In the bills auction, the three-month bill was sold at an average discount rate of 3.14 percent, up from 3.11 percent a week ago, and the six-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 3.30 percent, up from 3.26 percent a week ago.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of two-year notes and of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Lock In Their Recent Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar retreated against the German mark and was mixed against other currencies yesterday as traders locked in profits from the dollar's recent rise.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7040 German marks, from 1.7146 late Friday, but it edged up to 108.47 Japanese yen from 108.45 yen. Trading was light as the market began to wind down for Thanksgiving and the end of the month. 
 Gold prices, meanwhile, were mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery gained 20 cents, to $378.50 an ounce.
The mark strengthened against the dollar and other currencies after Germany reported a 6.8 percent rise in its money supply through October.
"It perhaps dashed some of our hopes of another German rate cut in the near future," said Stephen Flanagan, a Paine Webber vice president.
 
An Interest Rate Trade-Off
 Lower interest rates might give the sluggish German economy a lift, but would probably cause the mark to fall in value, since German-denominated deposits would offer a lower return to investors.
Many investors sold dollars to collect profits on the rise against European currencies.
The dollar strengthened against the Italian lira after Italy's dominant parties were crushed in mayoral elections. The neo-Fascist party and leftist candidates scored important gains in the balloting, seen as a dress rehearsal for general elections next year. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1,680 lire, up from 1,678 on Friday.
Further political disintegration in Italy, which is reeling from a huge corruption scandal, could make it difficult for a government to win agreement on economic policy.
The British pound, rose in New York to $1.4760, from $1.4729 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared those with late Friday, included: 1.4945 Swiss francs, down from 1.5050; 5.9205 French francs, down from 5.9465, and 1.3276 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3268.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Fall 3.1%; Anxiety Grips Market

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's failure over the weekend to issue a clear commitment to reinvigorate the deteriorating Japanese economy sent the stock market here into a fearful dive today, with the closely watched Nikkei index of 225 issues plummeting more than 3 percent.
With Japanese investors' self-confidence eroding by the day, the Nikkei fell from the start and accelerated in the afternoon. At the close it had lost 556.35 points, or 3.1 percent, for its second worst day of the year and with few prospects of a recovery anytime soon. The market will be closed Tuesday for a national holiday. 
 The market index has now lost a steep 15.2 percent since early October, which means tens of billions of dollars in value have been erased from portfolios in a few weeks' time.
 "It's anxiety turning into fear," said Robert Sasaki, the head of stock-index futures trading here for Jardine Fleming Securities.
Analysts said that the recent slide had been brought about by the Government's mishandled sale of shares in the East Japan Railway, or JR East, the country's largest passenger railroad, after a long period in which big new issues of shares were prohibited.
The price of JR East shares rose nearly 60 percent on the first day, Oct. 26, but ever since has tumbled steadily, with trading halted several times because of the intensity of the selling.
"They have egg all over their faces for that," said Geoffrey Barker, head of research at Baring Securities (Japan). "That really hurt sentiment."
Despite the positive outcome of the summit meeting of Pacific Rim leaders in Seattle last week and the passage of a landmark political reform law here, the sentiment of investors was not improved. They are looking for just one thing -- evidence that the Government takes seriously the deepening economic gloom after a two-year recession and intends to do something about it.
Mr. Hosokawa had a big chance on Friday, when an advisory commission offered suggestions for altering the tax system. Many investors had hoped that the Prime Minister would seize the opportunity to propose a large cut in income taxes, which could provide a quick lift to one of the most depressed areas of the economy, consumer sentiment.
Mr. Hosokawa elected, however, to defer a decision on tax changes. His action reinforced gloomy views that the Government does not appreciate the seriousness of the economic difficulties. Many private economists are now forecasting that the economy will actually shrink this year, taking a toll on corporate profits, the financial health of the banking system and Japan's industrial vigor.
 
 
'Nothing Solid'
 "We'd hoped that the talk of taxes might do the trick, but there was nothing solid," Mr. Barker said.
The tax commission recommended a reduction in income taxes, but also suggested that the Government should increase its consumption tax, a kind of sales tax. That would all but negate any positive impact from the income tax cut, economists said.
"It's the fundamentals," said Tim Hayashida, an analyst here with Merrill Lynch & Company. "We've had constant delays in the expectations for an economic recovery. There's no reason to be in this market yet."
Mr. Sasaki said that many large investors were selling stock-index futures because of the expectation that the market had so little potential for rebounding. Those futures sales, he added, were forcing other investors to sell stocks, pushing the market lower.

HEADLINE: Museum as Cultural Anchor: The Studio at 25

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
When the Studio Museum in Harlem opened its doors in a rented loft in 1968, most black artists were being excluded from gallery and museum shows, and only a handful -- among them Romare Bearden, Jacob Lawrence and Elizabeth Catlett -- had gained national or international exposure. That number has grown exponentially, as has the number of institutions collecting black art, and the museum, which is regarded by many in the art world as the premier fine-arts institution of its kind, has been instrumental.
Two current exhibitions at the museum illustrate its defining missions: to provide studio space for black artists and to exhibit their work. One is "The 25th-Anniversary Exhibition: Recent Acquisitions and Selected Works from the Studio Museum in Harlem Collection," which includes works by Bearden, Ms. Catlett, Emma Amos, Melvin Edwards, Sam Gilliam, Serge Jolimeau and Alvin Loving. 
 The other is "From the Studio: Artists in Residence, 1992-1993," which features works by Bob Rivera, a sculptor; Michelle Talibah, a painter, and Nari Ward, a multimedia artist, all of whom are in the artists-in-residence program, which has been going on for 25 years, as long as the Studio Museum has.
Faith Ringgold, who has received considerable acclaim for her painted story quilts, says that an exhibition at the Studio Museum is the "ultimate rite of passage for black artists in America and probably in the world."
 
Nearly 1,500 Works
 The museum began as an idea of the Junior Council, a volunteer group of the Museum of Modern Art. It was envisioned as a place where good black artists would exhibit and one that would enhance the Harlem community's involvement with the cultural life of the city. In 1982, it moved from its rented space above a luncheonette and liquor store on upper Fifth Avenue to its permanent home in a turn-of-the-century building, donated by the New York Bank for Savings, at 144 West 125th Street. The building is home to galleries, a museum shop, archives, workshops, artists' studios and the museum's permanent collection, which now consists of nearly 1,500 works by black artists from the United States, Africa and the Caribbean.
"Once I had a show there, things began happening," Ms. Ringgold said. "It kind of said to New York, 'Come on and look at Faith Ringgold' and people started looking at me in a whole different kind of way."
Marcia Tucker, the founder and director of the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, said of the Studio Museum: "It has not only done some extraordinary historical shows and recouped bodies of work that simply had been lost, but it has also introduced really, really important artists to the rest of the art world.
"Studio is one of the really great treasures of New York City's cultural life."
 
Relevance Questioned
 Yet the director of the museum, Kinshasha Holman Conwill, says that its relevance has to be defended and redefined now more than ever, because many of the ideals of the 1960's are being dismissed or trivialized.
The avowed interest in cultural diversity, she said, "has raised the question as to whether or not we as Americans, in and out of the art world, are really interested in pluralism, separatism or tokenism."
"We at the museum are interested in pluralism," Ms. Conwill said, "but one of my concerns is that many of our colleagues seem to be interested in the other two. In a pluralistic society, the voices of all of that society's people have to be given their due."
The challenge for the Studio Museum, she said, "is to articulate the vision of African-American artists both historically and currently, on its own terms and in the larger context of American and world art."
 
A Help or a Ghetto?
 For all its accomplishments, the Studio Museum's devotion to the art of black Americans and the African diaspora leaves it open to criticism that like other specialized museums it segregates or ghettoizes the very artists it wants to help move into a cultural mainstream. Mrs. Conwill calls that view a "myth" not borne out by the museum's record.
Ms. Ringgold agrees. "I don't think anybody can deny that African-American artists need a place that they can principally call their own," she said. "If not, what are we going to do, sit around and wait until racism disappears and we all have shows at the Modern, the Metropolitan or the Guggenheim? We have to have a place where we can show ourselves to ourselves in a way that is strong and wonderful. That's not ghettoizing."
Ms. Tucker, the New Museum director, recalled a recent conference of museum professionals in Germany where, as she put it, "the head of a quite large museum said 'Why do we really need a black museum, when artists like David Hammons are showing all over?" Mr. Hammons was an artist in residence at the Studio Museum from 1979 to 1980.
Ms. Tucker, whose museum is also noted for helping to bring along little-known artists, said: "There's a kind of colonializing impulse that says if a major museum shows the work of an African-American artist, they discovered the artist. They neglect the fact that the artist had a residency at Studio, was shown at Studio and was supported by the curator, director and educational staff at Studio."
 
Into the Schools
 Just as important to the museum is the role it plays as a cultural anchor in Harlem. It regularly presents workshops for children, as well as seminars that explore issues important to blacks. For nearly 20 years, its Cooperative School Program has been sending professional artists to Harlem's public schools to help children develop an appreciation of the fine arts.
"It's crucial that the museum see itself as part of Harlem," said Charles E. Inniss, who was the museum's first director and is now its chairman. "I don't think one can thrive without the other. For you to have a good business environment, for there to be economic development in a place like Harlem, you need a cultural fabric that strengthens the quality of life. It is appropriate for the Studio Museum to be right where it is."
The development of an endowment and funds for both acquisitions and the museum's physical plant are seen as critical to the Studio Museum's ability to flourish. Economic support comes from a number of sources: major contributions have been made by the city, the National Endowment for the Arts, the Ford Foundation, the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund, the National Arts Stabilization Fund, the American Express Company and Philip Morris. But Mrs. Conwill says the museum's status as a community-based institution has hurt it.
There is a perception that such institutions are less significant, she said, and therefore, "must not need that much money."
"We are a $3 million operation," she said. "Fully staffed we have 50 employees and generate thousands of dollars each year in part-time employment and consultancies. We have had major capital programs of over $1 million, but for years we've been thought of as community based, so the attitude is, here is $250, $500, $1,000."
"Institutions like ours have played a major role in defining what American culture is, and that's not done cheaply," Mrs. Conwill said. "The real challenge for the next period is getting supporters at all levels to understand that the ante has gone up on what it takes to produce and build quality programs, collections and publications."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kinshasha Holman Conwill, director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, with works by Serge Jolimeau. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Harold E. Varmus;
Out of the Lab and Into the Bureaucracy

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
HAROLD E. VARMUS, the new director of the National Institutes of Health and therefore one of the most powerful figures in science, is a man with many weighty matters over which he can mull.
He can worry about the slide in government financing for scientific research, or the wretched state of science education in America. He can dwell on the demoralized condition of the institutes themselves, where many of the clinics and laboratories are dangerously decrepit and where charges of racial discrimination and sexual harassment have been flying. He can fret over choosing the perfect director for one of the most politically sensitive of the new divisions at the N.I.H., the Office of AIDS Research. 
 Dr. Varmus can ponder all these great issues, and he has been doing so with considerable zeal over the past few months, but at the moment his mind has fastened onto something much merrier.
"Data!" he crowed happily. "Can you believe it? Real data!" He held up a piece of X-ray film displaying a ladderlike pattern of black smudges, the evidence of gene activity. "My lab just sent it to me this morning," he said, referring to the laboratory he left behind at the University of California at San Francisco, where he was (and still is) professor of molecular virology, biochemistry and biophysics. "It's the best thing I've seen all day."
The experimental result in Dr. Varmus's hand is more than a pleasant distraction from the details of his new career as administrative potentate. As a scientist who won a Nobel Prize in 1989 for fundamental research on the genes that cause cancer, as a scientist who has spent the last 25 years surrounded by the paraphernalia of molecular biology -- flasks, petri dishes, test tubes, scintillators and centrifuges -- Dr. Varmus needs to keep discovering new things about how nature works.
"It's a drug," he said. "It's an addiction. It's a craving. I have to have it."
"One of the most difficult things for me right now is that my lab is in California and I'm here," he added. "I'm not getting my daily fix." For that reason, Dr. Varmus plans to set up a small laboratory at the N.I.H., staffed by just enough graduate students, technicians and postdoctoral fellows to supply him with his data buzz and still allow him to stay focused on the enormous task before him: running and in a sense reinventing the organization that is the lifeblood of the nation's biomedical enterprise. The Senate confirmed Dr. Varmus in a smoothly perfunctory voice vote early Saturday morning.
Dr. Varmus will be 54 years old next month, but he has the build of an athlete, staying slim with the long, hard runs and bicycle rides for which he is renowned among his peers. His hair is thinning but still dark, and his small, impish face looks perpetually amused. Coming from California and academia, Dr. Varmus has yet to adopt the gray-suited ways of Washington, and he keeps his tie slung carelessly over the pole in his office coat closet, not far from his sweaty workout clothes. He arrives at the N.I.H. in the wake of the former director, Dr. Bernadine Healy, who alienated a number of scientists and politicians with her argumentative style and who was asked to leave her position last June. He arrives as though buoyed on clouds of glory, acclaimed for his scientific achievements, his quickness of mind, his Jeffersonian love of learning and culture that variously alights on poetry, theater, music, performance art, the study of ancient Chinese oracle bones, the study of war memorials.
"Whatever crosses his path receives the advantage of his wonderful intelligence," said Dr. Diane Middlebrook, professor of English at Stanford University and author of an acclaimed biography of Anne Sexton. "I'm used to being around the large egos of major scientists, but Harold, though he has a strong sense of himself, has a genuine curiousity that is not mediated by a desire to be self-aggrandizing."
Not only is Dr. Varmus the first Nobel laureate to head the institutes, he is also one of the few scientists who can claim training on the other side of the great intellectual divide, having earned his bachelor's degree in English from Amherst College and a master's degree in English literature from Harvard University.
Dr. Ira Herskowitz, a professor of genetics at the University of California at San Francisco, said, "Harold is a passionate information junkie, and this is going to serve him very well in his new job, where he'll have to assimilate tremendous amounts of information."
Basic researchers hope that as one of their own, Dr. Varmus can help shore up their declining fortunes and morale. The percentage of grants submitted to the N.I.H. that are financed has slipped from about 40 percent 20 years ago to at best 15 percent today. However, Dr. Varmus admits that given the current economy, he is unlikely to persuade Congress to substantially increase the institutes' $11 billion budget any time soon. What is more, although he will happily trumpet the triumphs of pure research, he knows that his constituency now is much broader than bench scientists alone, encompassing clinicians, epidemiologists, psychologists, practitioners of alternative medicine and the like. And before he can push through new programs, Dr. Varmus is likely to need time to master the role of supreme bureaucrat, a job for which his background has hardly prepared him.
Some groups have expressed concern that Dr. Varmus is so fixated on basic research that he could undo their recent successes in getting Federal funds earmarked for the study of particularly diseases. Frances M. Visco, president of the National Breast Cancer Coalition, a lobbying organization based in Washington that recently persuaded Congress to allocate $210 million of the military budget for, oddly enough, breast cancer research, said scientists have had their way too long. "The scientific community historically has been making decisions about how to spend research money without any oversight," she said. "We're saying, you're not going to be able to do that anymore. We're saying, let's focus on breast cancer. It's time we do that.
"We're concerned that Dr. Varmus may be opposed to our principles."
 
Breast Cancer Research
 However, Dr. Varmus, who was on the scientific panel that advised the Army on how best to spend its $210 million, said he felt the two camps were closer than Ms. Visco seemed to think. "They didn't want the money to just go into mammography studies or drug trials," he said. "They wanted it to go into a basic understanding of breast cancer. And we asked that applicants for money be able to convince reviewers that what they're doing is related to breast cancer," even if their project is studying cell division in yeast.
Dr. Varmus pointed out that his mother died of breast cancer 23 years ago, a loss that helped inspire him to study a virus that causes breast cancer in mice.
He has been somewhat less persuaded by recent calls for an increase in financing for the behavioral and social sciences. "I begin with the premise that behavior is an incredibly important element in medicine," he said. "People's habits, their willingness to quit smoking, their willingness to take steps to avoid transmission of H.I.V., are all behavioral questions.
"But what I'm looking for are new ideas, real discoveries. When I read about genetics, I see breakthroughs every day. And while I'm trying to learn more about behavioral science, I must say that I don't feel I get tremendous intellectual stimulation from most of the things I read."
Beyond pitching for hard science, Dr. Varmus has many plans for the institutes proper: filling vacant positions, recruiting bright young scientists to spend their most energetic years at the Government campus, rebuilding facilities like the huge clinic where experimental trials are carried out, a structure that engineers say may collapse in the next few years without an expensive overhaul.
 
Administrative Squabbles
 In addition, he has conflicts to resolve, including charges by some employees that they have not been promoted because of their race or gender. Also festering are debates over the Women's Health Initiative, a large study launched by Dr. Healy and designed to explore the impact of diet, nutritional supplements, exercise, estrogen replacement therapy and other factors on women's long-term health. Many researchers feel the $66 million study is too disorganized and badly conceived to yield meaningful answers, and Dr. Varmus hopes in the near future to convene a panel to decide which parts of the trial should be kept and which modified or discarded.
How well Dr. Varmus will fare in his new position, or how much he will like it, is unclear. Friends talk about his phenomenal energy, his ability to work tirelessly, to exercise ferociously, to recover from a very serious biking accident near the San Francisco campus in a handful of days and return fearlessly to his old biking habits. His colleagues and students talk of how much they enjoy working with him, how attentively he follows everybody's experiments.
He is also extremely competitive and determined to win. "Occasionally, when new postdocs would come to the lab, Harold would ask them if they liked to run," said Dr. Bruce Bowerman, an assistant professor of biology at the University of Oregon in Eugene who studied under Dr. Varmus. "If they did, he'd invite them out for a run with him, and if he could run faster, he'd leave them far behind. He relished showing up younger runners."
Yet Dr. Varmus has relatively little administrative experience, except managing his lab of 25 people, and he has not been known for his diplomacy, a skill that would seem essential for dealing with Congress. His sister, Ellen Varmus Bloch, said her brother went into research rather than clinical medicine because "he's not one with a whole lot of bedside manner," adding, "He's very honest, forthcoming and smart, but he doesn't have much patience for whining."
Dr. Leon Levintow, a professor emeritus of the University of California at San Francisco and the former chairman of Dr. Varmus's department, said that when he talked with Dr. Varmus about the N.I.H. position, he wondered whether his old colleague could hide his feelings well enough to thrive in Washington. "In the past, Harold made no bones about the fact that he's impatient with ignorant attitudes," said Dr. Levintow. "But he said he recognizes the importance of being politically savvy, and he's cultivated that talent."
If suppleness of response is a key to political success, Dr. Varmus has demonstrated his adaptability throughout his career. His father was the state physician for Jones Beach in New York, a job that sometimes included the unpleasant task of declaring people dead from drowning, and his mother was a psychiatric social worker. Growing up in Freeport, L.I., Dr. Varmus assumed he would be a doctor. But he developed a passionate interest in literature, and as a teen-ager thought he would be happy as a literary scholar. At Harvard, he changed his mind. "I saw my friends in medical school seeming to be more engaged with the real world," he said. "That provoked a sort of jealousy, and I decided to go to medical school after all," earning his medical degree from Columbia University.
In part because he is married to Constance Casey, an editor and writer and now the assistant editor of the book review section of The Washington Post, he has stayed very much immersed in the world of literature, attending plays and poetry readings and reading widely. The couple have two sons, Jacob, a junior at the University of Iowa, and Christopher, a junior in high school.
An opponent of the war in Vietnam, Dr. Varmus wanted to avoid being drafted, so he performed his public- service obligations by joining Dr. Ira Pastan's laboratory at the N.I.H. in 1968, studying bacterial biochemistry. From there Dr. Varmus went to the University of California, beginning as a postdoctoral fellow to Dr. J. Michael Bishop, a molecular biologist, and swiftly rising up become his collaborator.
The two won their Nobel Prize for the discovery that the body holds within it genes, called oncogenes, that through a few simple biochemical alterations, become fomenters of cancerous growth. The detection of oncogenes transformed the study of cancer almost overnight, and laboratories around the world continue to explore how these genes work in their healthy configuration, why they sometimes turn renegade and how the mutant genes can be counteracted to block malignant growth. He also has worked on genes that help shape the developing brain, and on the insidious mechanisms that viruses use to infiltrate human cells.
Dr. Varmus thrived as a scientist, but as the years passed he became increasingly interested in science policy, joining committees and government panels. He also became hungry for a career switch. "I'm doing this in part because I have a certain restlessness," he said. "I loved what I was doing but I can see that life is not infinite. Twenty-three years, same house, same job. I was ready for a change."

HEADLINE: Government Finds Wider Gap on Financing of Pensions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The gap between promised retirement benefits and the money set aside to pay for them widened by 31 percent in 1992 among the companies with the 50 largest underfinanced pension plans, the Government reported today.
The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation's annual list showed the underfinancing grew to $38 billion, $31.7 billion of which is guaranteed by the agency. The 1991 gap, or difference between pension liabilities and assets, was $29.1 billion. It was the fifth straight annual increase. 
 "These results underscore the need for pension funding reforms and provide additional evidence that current law is not working," said Martin Slate, executive director of the pension insurance agency. "The Clinton Administration has reforms now before Congress to strengthen the law and to improve pension security."
 
Possible Changes
 The proposed overhaul would speed sponsor contributions to underfinanced plans and enhance the agency's authority to require compliance, increase insurance premiums for plans considered most at risk and require that plan participants be given information that is easily understood.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has estimated that underfinancing for all private businesses grew from $27 billion in 1987 to $45 billion in 1992, putting the benefits of millions of workers and retirees at risk.
The pension agency, which is financed by payments from businesses, already faces a $2.7 billion deficit. Despite the deficit, Mr. Reich and other officials contend the agency is not near the kind of crisis that led to the savings and loan bailout. They say the responsibility for the programs is spread over years so the agency can continue to pay benefits for a long time.
Most pension plans are fully financed, the agency said, adding that those with gaps are concentrated in the automobile and steel industries.
The agency said underfinancing in 1992 increased primarily because of falling interest rates on investments used to finance retirement plans. But it also said that pension contributions by many companies did not keep pace with growing liabilities because of weaknesses in current law.
 
The Effect of Lower Rates
 "With interest rates declining, companies should have been contributing larger amounts to their pension plans to keep their liabilities manageable," Mr. Slate said. "Our reforms will require it. We want to make sure that workers receive the benefits for which they have worked."
Seven companies kept pace with the growing liabilities and, in some cases, reduced their underfinancing in 1992, the agency said.
The Chrysler Corporation, for instance, reduced its gap by more than $3 billion through additional contributions beyond those required. The LTV Corporation cut its underfinancing by more than $700 million.
Still, the agency said the auto industry, with an $18 billion gap, represented 57 percent of the total underfinancing in the 50-company list, while steel companies, with a nearly $7 billion total deficit, accounted for 21 percent.
Twelve companies on the 1991 list were removed from the 1992 list. Ten were removed because of improved financing or because the amount of underfinancing was less than the lowest amount listed. Another, Sharon Steel, terminated its five underfinanced plans.
 
A Dissenting View
 The National Association of Manufacturers has criticized the annual list, saying it creates unnecessary anxiety. It says many companies have legitimate reasons for underfinancing their plans, including newly negotiated union contracts and worse-than-expected investment returns.
Indeed, inclusion on the list does not reflect on a company's financial health nor necessarily mean an employee's benefits are in immediate jeopardy, the agency emphasized.
"Many companies on the list are strong and will be able to fund their pension plans," Mr. Slate said. "However, to better prepare themselves for retirement, participants should know more about their plans' funding and P.B.G.C.'s guarantees."
The Ravenswood Aluminum Corporation was at the top of the list for the second consecutive year, with $100 million in guaranteed liabilities, $11 million in assets and $89 million in unfinanced guaranteed benefits. That meant a financing ratio of 11 percent compared with 12 percent in 1991.
The Unisys Corporation was at the bottom with $2.9 billion in guaranteed liabilities, $2.7 billion in assets and a financing ratio of 95 percent. Unisys was not on the 1991 list.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Leo Burnett Plans More Layoffs in U.S.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Leo Burnett U.S.A. of Chicago said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 200 of its 2,200 employees in the United States by the end of the year. The layoffs will be in addition to an early retirement package being offered to about 20 employees. 
 James Jenness, group president of Leo Burnett North America, attributed the layoffs to "changing client needs and a push to operate more efficiently in today's difficult economic environment." Though Burnett generally shuns large-scale layoffs, even after losing accounts, this is the second time in six months that employees are being let go. In May, 52 employees were dismissed in what had been the biggest layoffs since 1983.

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup: House Fends Off Effort To Trim Budget Further;
More Money Backed For the Unemployed

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The House tonight passed by a vote of 320 to 105 and sent to President Clinton a long-delayed bill to provide an extra 7 to 13 weeks of unemployment benefits for about a million long-term jobless who had exhausted their basic 26 weeks of benefits. 
 The 13 weeks of benefits would be available to workers in states with the highest rates of unemployment. Currently, workers in Alaska, California, Rhode Island and West Virginia would be eligible for the longer benefits. The measure, which would cost $1.1 billion, has been pending since legislation authorizing the last batch of emergency benefits expired Oct. 2.

HEADLINE: New York Urged to Shift Cost of Fighting Shore Erosion

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 22

 BODY:
People who live near the shore would pay more in taxes and fees to help protect New York's coastline from storm damage under a plan released today by a state task force.
Local governments and private citizens who would benefit most from coastal anti-erosion projects would be asked to pay more of the cost. The current formula, in which the state pays 70 percent and localities 30 percent for certain projects, would be changed to a 50-50 split. 
 The task force hopes that such a shift would make local officials more resistant to coastal development, since protective measures would have a greater impact on local taxes.
The recommendations are outlined in a final draft report by the Governor's New York City-Long Island-Westchester Coastal Erosion Task Force, established on Jan. 15 after the northeaster of December 1992, which battered the state's coastline with high winds, heavy rain and severe tidal surges. The storm caused almost $1 billion in damage on the coast of New York.
The task force was directed to provide short-term and long-term recommendations on ways the state could best prepare for coastal emergencies.
Some homeowners in particularly vulnerable areas could be asked to pay surcharges on their property taxes. And beachgoers and boaters would pay higher parking and docking fees to help local governments finance the dredging of channels and rebuilding of beaches.
"The study marks the first serious policy discussion in 30 years of what the state should do about its beaches," said Gerald Stoddard, a member of the task force and president of the Fire Island Association, a homeowners' group. "It presents some hard but fair choices."
The study offers three approaches, ranging from a laissez-faire policy, in which nature would take its course with little or no interference by the state, to a policy of preserving the shoreline as it now stands.
The panel, without expressing a preference, stressed the benefits of a middle-of-the-road approach, in which heavily developed areas would get the most protection, while sparsely developed areas would be left, in effect, to nature's whims.
The laissez-faire approach is not without costs, the study warned, since the cost of repairs and the long-term economic impact of a hurricane or heavy storm could be far greater than the cost of preventive measures.
Last December's storm, the 11th such storm to sweep across New York's coastal waters since 1888, generated winds of hurricane force. The sustained storm surge lasted for two days, pushing tides 15 feet to 25 feet above normal, flooding barrier islands, tearing down seawalls and severely eroding bluffs along Long Island Sound.
The coast of New York has also been damaged by 22 hurricanes, the last, Hurricane Bob, on Aug. 19, 1991.
The task force noted that headlands and peninsulas, with their broad views of the sea, attract more development, but are also more vulnerable to storm damage. Portions of New York's coast have been intensely developed for many years, the report noted, but development has spread significantly in the last 40 years, altering major shoreline areas beyond the city.
Left alone, these areas are not inherently hazardous, but they become so when development occurs without regard to the natural coastal process, the report said. The report also cited the damage done by an increase in tourism in the most vulnerable areas.
With this in mind, the task force suggested that the state and local governments use a combination of measures to restore and maintain the shoreline.
Intensively developed areas would have the highest priority for capital projects. Such areas include Coney Island and Rockaway in New York City, and Long Beach and Bayville in Nassau County.
These projects would be conducted in cooperation with the Army Corps of Engineers. The Federal Government would provide about 50 percent of the cost, with the state and local governments splitting the difference.
Second priority for state protection would go to public parks. The amount of maintenance would be based on a cost-benefit formula. For example, Orient Point Beach State Park could receive state funds to repair its entrance road, but not to restore a wide beachfront off the road.
 
Flexible Strategies
 Fred W. Thiele, the Southampton Town Supervisor, said he generally agreed with the task force's conclusions but objected to any formula that increased the local cost of government.
He said that state and Federal policy had created many of the coastal erosion problems, "so it's unfair of them to come along and ask us to pay for their mistakes.'
The public will be able to comment on the proposals at public meetings Nov. 30 in the Lennox Room at Bethpage State Park and in the Alliance Room at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Both meetings begin at 7 P.M.

HEADLINE: Wider Gap In City Budget Is Projected

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Offering his final projections for New York City's budget, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday that his successor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, would face a projected gap of $1.73 billion in the budget he must have outlined by January, about $450 million more than projections only three months ago.
The widening gap reflects not new or unexpected costs but rather the effects of a number of decisions to stop counting on revenues that require outside actions, like the assumption by the state of the city's share of Medicaid costs. 
 Mr. Giuliani's budget advisers have expected a shortfall, but the projected increase in the budget gap for the fiscal year beginning next July underscored the huge difficulties Mr. Giuliani faces as he tries to enact new policies and balance the budget.
"We think that there may be a fiscal crisis coming next year that may require unusual and decisive steps," said Richard W. Schwartz, the deputy executive director of Mr. Giuliani's transition.
 
$281 Million Reserve
 In making his quarterly adjustments to the city's financial plan, Mr. Dinkins said his administration had succeeded in balancing this year's $31.5 billion budget and had even left a reserve of $281 million -- higher, he noted, than any reserve at this point in the fiscal year since 1986.
"We've made every effort to see to it that they have as much help as possible," Mr. Dinkins said.
But the projections for next year's budget, the first Mr. Giuliani will prepare, have worsened significantly since August, when the administration anticipated a shortfall of only $1.27 billion.
Of the $455 million in increases, the administration included, for example, $135 million in spending on schools, including money for the installation of metal detectors, that were approved only for this year's budget but would be needed again.
It also opted not to include $131 million it had hoped to receive from a state takeover of the city's Medicaid costs that was proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. That proposal is stalled in the State Legislature.
The financial projections, announced at City Hall by Mr. Dinkins and his budget director, Carol O'Cleireacain, underscored the growing difficulties of balancing the city's budget. The projections showed that the city's budget gap would grow to $2.5 billion for the fiscal year 1996 and $2.7 billion for 1997, unless corrective measures are taken.
Although the economy is expected to improve steadily, the city's tax revenues are not expected to grow as fast as spending at least until 1997, according to the budget report prepared by Ms. O'Cleireacain's office.
"The economy is just not growing fast enough to catch up with expenditures," said the First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel.
Mr. Dinkins succeeded in balancing this year's budget -- as the law requires -- without making any more of the sharp cuts he ordered in July under pressure from fiscal monitors and Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency.
 
Increases in Overtime
 The administration had faced a deficit of $295 million in this year's budget, largely because of increased overtime for firefighters and police officers, increases in the number of people on welfare and a decline in parking ticket revenue.
Mr. Dinkins's budget office also removed from its revenue projections an estimated $55 million from the sale of the Off-Track Betting Corporation, which has not occurred. In the mayoral campaign, Mr. Giuliani described the inclusion of revenues from a sale of OTB that had not yet taken place as a gimmick Mr. Dinkins had used to balance the budget.
Speaking to reporters after a meeting at the Harlem Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Giuliani repeated that criticism and complained that the Dinkins administration had done nothing to deal with the perennial shortfalls in the city's budgets.
When asked about his remarks, Mr. Dinkins responded angrily.
"The campaign is over," he said. "The poetry has ended. It's time for prose. This is government. And I have tried every way I know how to work with the incoming administration."
 
Increase in Welfare Spending
 Mr. Dinkins and his aides dismissed suggestions that the timing of the adjustments after Election Day was in any way political. Mr. Dinkins, for example, said the decision to remove the revenues from a sale of OTB because "we don't expect to achieve it this year."
Likewise, Mr. Steisel said, the decision to remove $131 million the city hoped to receive from the Medicaid takeover was made when it became clear that the Legislature would not take up the issue in its special session.
In addition to counting the one-time education costs and eliminating the expected windfall from a state takeover of Medicaid, several other factors accounted for the rise in next year's budget gap. They included an increase of $67 million in spending on welfare and other social services and $42 million for teachers' salaries as part of the contract reached with the United Federation of Teachers that takes effect in January.
Mr. Dinkins and his aides underlined the point that most of the projected increases had either been mandated by contracts or by state or Federal law.
 
Declines to Suggest Cuts
 Only $30 million of the increase was "discretionary spending" that the Mayor has control over, including $11 million in benefits to unmarried domestic partners of city workers that Mr. Dinkins approved earlier this year.
"These adjustments are essentially technical, accounting or the lack of state action," Mr. Steisel said. "They do not indicate any laxity or loss of control of the budget. It's not like we shifted problems because we were inefficient or mismanaged, into fiscal year 1995."
Mr. Dinkins declined to discuss what cuts he would have made, saying, "The people did not re-elect me." He suggested one potential savings: eliminating the 20 minutes police officers are given to dress and wash up at the start of their shifts, which could save an estimated $40 million.
"I can't do that," Mr. Dinkins said. "Maybe he can."
Neither Mr. Giuliani nor his aides specified yesterday how they would try to close the $1.7 billion gap.

HEADLINE: A Teen-Age Pall at the Mall;
After-School Gatherings Please Youths but Are Worrying Many Others

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 22

 BODY:
On the days Joel Rosario goes to school, he heads over to the Chapel Square Mall in the late afternoon to hang out with his friends and to meet girls. When he doesn't go to school, Mr. Rosario says he goes there even earlier.
Mr. Rosario, 16, is one of hundreds of teen-agers who congregate in the downtown New Haven mall every afternoon and have created a prickly public relations problem for the mall. 
 Fearing that the teen-agers were scaring off other customers, the mall's management this month proposed banning teen-agers from the mall in the late afternoon.
Around the city, negative reaction was so swift and overwhelming that the idea was quickly abandoned. But experts say the proposal reflects an increasing problem in urban malls, which rely on an image of order and security to attract wary suburbanites.
 
A Nationwide Problem
 Malls across the country face the same situation, said Robert J. McGuire, a former New York City Police Commissioner and president of Kroll Associates, one of the largest private security companies in the world. He said that most malls were not designed to control the large numbers of teen-agers "that have made malls their downtown" and that many are considering increased security and curfews to insure that older shoppers feel safe.
Mr. McGuire said one mall was considering "piping in Beethoven instead of hard rock" to discourage teen-agers from hanging out.
In the case of the Chapel Square Mall proposal, everyone from the teen-agers to the Mayor said it was discriminatory and aimed largely at minority-group members.
 
Staying Out of Trouble
 "They've got to be kidding," Mr. Rosario said. "They can't keep us out of the mall. We're the biggest customers in here. Where else would we go? At least this way we're not hanging out on the streets."
Cherie Lee, 16, a junior at Wilbur Cross High School, said the idea of keeping teen-agers out of the mall was silly. "Kids come here to stay out of trouble and to shop," she said. "They would only be hurting the kids and hurting themselves if they kept us out."
Store owners agreed. "The kids are our main market; the only way we can survive is to cater to them, not restrict their access," said Stephen Watson, the owner of Elm City Subs and the president of the mall merchants' association. "You don't want hundreds of kids loitering around, but you also don't want to chase away your main customer base, either. We've got to find a better way to deal with this."
The plan to restrict teen-agers was presented to school officials, city officials and the police after one teen-ager shot another outside the mall, but it has been abandoned as infeasible, said Martin Fortes, the vice president and general manager of the 70-store mall. He said it had been conceived as a way of expanding on a policy of the mall's management company, the Rouse Company, to keep students out of malls during school hours.
"But our biggest problem is not during the school day," he said. "It's the hours after school when a lot of kids come here to hang out. Frankly, the response we got on the proposal was not favorable, so now we're looking at other ways to deal with the problem, such as more security and a stronger police presence."
Cathy Lickteig, the vice president and director of corporate public affairs for the Rouse Company in Columbia, Md., said: "The problem of kids coming into malls after school and hanging out between 3 and 5 is not unique to the Chapel Square Mall. It's happening in urban malls all over the country." She added, however, that it would violate company policy to limit the access of teen-agers.
Assistant Police Chief Melvin Wearing said the Police Department had advised mall officials that such a plan was unworkable.
"We told them we didn't think it was possible because of the legal implications," Chief Wearing said. "You can't keep people out. That's not the way to deal with the situation at all."
 
Sales Are the Problem
 Matthew Nemerson, the president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, said the mall's greatest problem was not teen-agers, but diminishing sales -- which are down by about one-third because of the recession and the closing of Macy's, which was considered the mall's anchor, in June.
But patrons and employees said they did not feel safe in the mall. They said that drug-dealing went on outside and across the street at the New Haven Green and sometimes spilled over into the mall, and that teen-agers often congregated in crowds that harassed shoppers.
"I've been coming here since it opened, but I don't feel safe here anymore," said Pattie Hardy, 38, of New Haven. "It's gone way downhill in recent years, and the senior citizens especially don't like to come anymore. My father will only come in the morning, and I don't like coming myself, but sometimes I can't avoid it." But Ms. Hardy said she didn't think restricting teen-agers was the answer. "That would be a violation of their rights," she said.
But several employees at the mall supported the idea of restricting teen-agers. "They need to do something, and fast, because it's a very dangerous place to be," said a sales clerk who spoke on condition of anonymity.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Seeker of Mystery Takes Stock of Suburbs

BYLINE: By Jonathan Rabinovitz

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR, N.J.

 BODY:
IT was a dark and stormy night. As the wind whistled through the trees, the lights in the spacious Victorian and colonial homes beckoned with the promise of warmth and shelter.
A blue Volvo station wagon slowly cruised the street, its driver speaking in a hushed voice as he cautioned that this neighborhood, one of the most desirable in Montclair, was home to unhappy secrets. 
 "I see families murdered all the time here," said Jon Katz, the man behind the wheel.
You might take this statement with a grain of salt because Mr. Katz is a mystery writer and the creator of Doubleday's Suburban Detective Mystery series.
But what others dismiss as the daily tribulations of two-career couples and their children, this writer sees as tragedy. In the case of the murdered families, Mr. Katz was referring to divorce, not homicide, which has ravaged the neighborhood.
For Mr. Katz, mystery writing is largely a cover for his trenchant, almost anthropological, musings about suburbia, and he abounds with theories about the daily rituals here. He delights in talking about the significance of a teen-ager turning back the visor of his cap on entering a mall, or why so many mothers use four-wheel-drive Jeeps to pick up their children ("Battle-wagons to negotiate the difficult terrain of suburbia," he says).
"Raising kids is the only industry in these towns," he explained, and the suburban baby boomers have an all-consuming desire to "create the best place for children to live in the history of the planet." This struggle for perfection takes its toll, and "no one is looking at its effects," he said.
The crimes in Mr. Katz's books are imagined, but he intends them to be the ultimate nightmares of every suburbanite. And the inspiration, he readily admits, comes from his life in Montclair, a town he adores.
In his first mystery, "Murder by Station Wagon" (Doubleday: 1993), the child-obsessed parents of the fictional town of Rochambeau, N.J., are gripped by mass hysteria after the apparent murder-suicide of two honor students. It is left to the mild-mannered Christopher (Kit) Deleeuw, an unemployed bond trader who has opened a detective's office above a mall, to car pool his way (in a Volvo, of course) through a tangle of suburban anxieties and solve the case.
Although the book revels in the fictional town's neuroses -- from a retiree in love with his power mower to a mother who follows her son's school bus in case he suddenly needs her -- it has been embraced by Mr. Katz's neighbors. A local book store has sold more than 400 hardcover copies, and when he walks his white Labrador, Julius, people run up to him with ideas for killings in future books.
On a recent afternoon, over a sugar-free strawberry Jell-O at his favorite diner, Mr. Katz, 46, said he had feared he would have to leave when the book came out. "But they've just laughed at it," he said. "They wanted to read fiction about their own lives."
A balding, affable Teddy-bear of a man, Mr. Katz has lived here nine years with his wife, Paula Span, and daughter, Emma. His day is filled with writing, chores and child care. One friend has dubbed him the "Prince of Rides," because he shuttles some 15 children to ballet classes, music lessons and soccer games.
His writer/househusband persona, however, is a universe away from his previous life as an executive producer for "The CBS Morning News," a job he quit ("I was about to be fired anyway," he says) so he could watch his daughter grow up. Even today, he is better known as a media critic for Rolling Stone magazine than for "Death by Station Wagon" and a previous novel, "Sign Off."
Still, a Hollywood studio is considering making Mr. Katz's detective, Kit DeLeeuw, into a television hero, and the deal with Doubleday calls for at least three books in the series. The second ("The Family Stalker") is due out in March and his third ("The Last Housewife") is almost done.
Initially, some publishers rejected Mr. Katz's proposals, skeptical about the "sensitive male" private eye and the suburban setting. One critic questioned if Rochambeau was too benign a place to hold readers' interest.
Such criticisms cause Mr. Katz to bridle.
"The suburbs are riveting," he insisted.
"I've seen families fall apart. There are unemployed men trying to piece together their world, kids dealing with alcoholism and extramarital affairs, and working mothers who choke back tears as they walk out the door in the morning and their 2-year-old cries for them to come back.
"Having kids is this incomparable drama," he said, and in Montclair "these upper-middle-class parents are terrified by the idea that they could mess up."
"All of this," he remarked, "is white-knuckled stuff." And it is, perhaps, the stuff of great mysteries.

HEADLINE: China Stiffs the President

 BODY:
Braving criticism by human rights activists and their supporters in Congress, President Clinton held out the hand of diplomatic compromise to China's President, Jiang Zemin, in Seattle last Friday. What he got in return was an unyielding lecture on China's hard-line positions.
Nobody realistically expected China to announce dramatic changes in its human rights, arms sales and trading policies on the spot. But by failing to reciprocate Washington's carefully planned package of good-will gestures, Beijing confounds the Administration's efforts to reverse an alarming slide in U.S.-China relations. 
 Washington took the initiative to repair relations in September, shortly after imposing sanctions over the Chinese transfer of missile technology to Pakistan. Talks over trade issues were going nowhere and Beijing had made no significant progress toward the human rights goals Mr. Clinton had made the basis for renewing its favorable tariff status next year.
Without surrendering basic principles, Washington softened its tactics -- toning down its rhetoric on human rights, loosening restrictions on sales of military technology and ending four years of punitive restrictions on meetings between high-level officials.
The idea was to take more account of Chinese considerations of "face." The Administration replaced unilateral demands for Chinese concessions with offers of dialogue. And it gave priority to issues already covered by Chinese laws or bilateral agreements.
The highest-profile gesture, to citizens in both countries, was Mr. Clinton's personal meeting with Mr. Jiang, held on the sidelines of the Seattle economic summit meetings. But given China's obsession with issues of "face," it was strange that Mr. Jiang offered no gestures of his own to protect Mr. Clinton's political position.
Even so, Friday's meeting was not wasted. Each side had a useful opportunity to learn exactly what was on the other's mind. If, over the coming weeks and months, China begins to respond substantively to America's main concerns, relations will surely warm. But by rejecting the President's outstretched hand, Beijing once again undermined its supporters in this country and armed its critics.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Waiting for China

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Sometime in June we and they will find out what President Clinton was able to accomplish in Seattle.
Results on the economic agenda, the President's hopes for a great Asian-Pacific-American trade zone, will take a lot longer to judge -- years. 
 But by June we who live in freedom and they who live in Chinese prison cells for asking for freedom will find out whether the President will get action from Beijing on Washington's modest human rights proposals.
By July 3, 1994, the President has to announce whether the Communists are treating Chinese political prisoners and the captive nation of Tibet with any greater sense of decency.
If not, he is bound by his own signature on an executive order to cancel China's privilege of paying lowest available tariffs on exports to the U.S. -- a privilege extended to most nations. That is the expressed desire of Congress.
In Seattle, the President concentrated publicly on his vision of a united economic future. Fair enough -- that is why he invited the heads of government to come and talk.
But I am told by officials I trust that the President did not gloss over the human rights confrontation when he met Jiang Zemin. He put it all before the Chinese President.
The U.S. requests are: Release sick political prisoners. Tell the world how many Chinese freedom fighters rot in the cells of the politically damned; what are their names? Stop torture as a routine form of penological administration. Allow international inspection of prisons. End prison and forced labor as a cost cutter in foreign trade. And talk seriously with the Dalai Lama about easement and hope for Tibet.
Mr. Jiang did not give an inch. But American specialists hope that he carries the message clear: This White House does not want to lift the tariff privileges but means business and will do so if Beijing fails to move.
Now, there are ways for Washington to get out of that, like accepting symbolism and promises. But unlike his predecessor, Mr. Clinton did put it straight to the Chinese. There is no reason to assume now that he will wiggle out of his word.
But trusting the President does not mean being stupid about Beijing. Americans act as if the Communists are dim-witted children. All we have to do is talk in a loud clear voice so they will understand. Then, offer them cookies, to swallow with the human rights medicine.
That is what the U.S. is doing now -- releasing a cookie high-tech computer, talking about selling cookie components for a nuclear plant.
The Communists are not fools. They scream that talking human rights to them is gross interference. But they know that is hogwash. They have signed on to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the U.N. Charter, which make human rights the business of the world. And they know that none of America's human rights requests touch the tiger-teeth laws and police power that are the basis of their control.
Yet they grab the cookies and throw the medicine on the floor. They believe rule by fear will lessen total control, and won't chance it.
Interesting about dictatorships: with the largest army on earth, and economic boom, still the Communists tremble at the thought of human rights. No, no fools.
And they do not believe the U.S. really means business. Why should they, when the U.S. did not follow through before and now offers a new batch of cookies?
Beijing knows too that the U.S. business community is against making rights progress a condition of trade with China.
I gaze in fond wonder at my business friends, virtuosi of a money piano I don't know how to play. The profit motive fuels the world. But used to help build up dictatorships it has flooded the engine with war and death, from Hitler to Tojo to Saddam.
Nobody asks for "isolation" of China -- that's a straw herring. The human rights community -- Americans in every part and party of the U.S. -- simply says that when we do business with a government that rules by torture and slave labor, we do not have to give the best possible terms. That seems particularly reasonable when the torturers already sell us $20 billion more than they buy.
Mr. Clinton is giving Beijing every chance. He waits to see if his new approach works. So do we and they.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: HOUSE, 255 TO 175, VOTES TO RESTRICT CAMPAIGN SPENDING

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Weighing public demands for campaign reform against the high cost of seeking re-election, House members today approved a change in campaign finance laws that includes voluntary limits on spending and the first public financing of Congressional campaigns.
No one can say with certainty what impact the measure will have, but if enacted it would represent the first effort to limit the advantages of incumbency since 1974, when Congress regulated political contributions in the wake of the Watergate scandal. 
 The Senate has already passed a very different measure that eliminates political action committee contributions and does not include public financing. But public pressures are building on the two chambers to reconcile their differences and enact a campaign finance bill next year.
 
Dunce Cap and Clown Nose
 The 255-to-175 vote came largely along party lines: voting for the bill were 232 Democrats, 22 Republicans and 1 independent; voting against were 24 Democrats and 151 Republicans.
Later this evening, the House finished its year's work by handing President Clinton another budget victory, defeated an effort led by freshmen members to cut the deficit far more deeply than his plan would. [Page B8.]
The vote on campaign financing came after a raucous debate, during which Representative Robert L. Livingston, Republican of Louisiana, brought the spirit of Mardi Gras to the House floor by putting on a dunce cap and bulbous clown nose to make fun of the Democrats. Shortly afterward, Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, split his gavel when banging it in a futile effort to quiet the large New York delegation.
All the fireworks reflected the fact that every House member cares deeply about campaign donations, which they spend enormous amounts of time collecting. The measure would limit candidates to $200,000 in contributions from political action committees, which are cooperatives that pool campaign money for special interests. It sets a voluntary spending maximum for House campaigns at $800,000, and as an incentive to abide by the limit, it promises candidates who accede to the measure up to $200,000 in vouchers to buy advertising. The limits would apply to the total raised or spent in primary and general election campaigns.
But the bill would not take effect until Congress enacts separate legislation to finance the vouchers, which would probably be financed by taxes on campaign contributions as well as voluntary checkoffs on tax returns.
It is not yet clear how much of an impact the bill would have on campaigns, since the limits would be voluntary and subject to exceptions, and there is no way of knowing how many candidates would accept them. In some campaigns, candidates would gain political points from voters by accepting the limits; in others, candidates facing expensive primary races would probably choose not to accept a spending limit of only $800,000.
The median winning House campaign in 1992 cost $462,843, but candidates often spent more in cities and other places in large television markets, where campaign commercials are expensive. Winners spent as much as $4 million. Representative Tom Downey of Long Island spent over $1 million and lost.
"I have a firm conviction that very important, significant, meaningful campaign finance reform legislation will be enacted," said Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who expressed confidence that a compromise could be reached in a Senate-House conference committee next year.
"For the first time we will have elections and not auctions to the highest bidder," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of Manhattan, who cosponsored the legislation.
 
'Important Step Forward'
 Some campaign-reform advocates say the limits could help stem the rise in campaign costs, which have risen well above the inflation rate in recent years. "The House of Representatives has taken a very important step forward," said Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause. "The key to the House-passed campaign finance bill is the substantial clean resources that are authorized for House candidates in the form of communications vouchers to match small contributions."
The Democratic bill was passed after members rejected by a vote of 263 to 173 a Republican alternative that would have eliminated political action committees and required that the majority of campaign funds originate from the district a candidate is running in. It would also have forbidden the use of "soft money," contributions that go to party organizations and are not subject to contribution limits or strict reporting requirements.
The debate on the floor was highly partisan, touching on the contentious legal issues that arise from proposals to limit expressions of support for political candidates. But the speeches centered on Democratic contentions that Republicans want to maximize the influence of individual millionaire donors and Republican assertions that Democrats want to protect the influence of what they called "politically correct" political action committees.
"Even pretending that $200,000 in PAC money is somehow a limit is absurd," said Representative Peter G. Torkildsen, a Massachusetts Republican. "That would be the same as telling a mass murderer that he would be limited to 200 murderers per year in the interest of reducing crime."
Democrats said that for all the faults of PAC money, at least it was easily identified by the news media and political opponents. Because such donations often become a campaign issue, the Democrats argued, voters can reject candidates they believe are beholden to special interest money.
"If you eliminate PAC's," said Mr. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat, "all you do is drive the money trail underground."
From all the partisan bickering emerged a rare exclamation of frankness from Representative Karen Shepherd, a Utah Democrat. "We are all experts on what serves us best and serves our parties best," she told her colleagues, "but not necessarily what serves our country best."
The most important part of the House bill creates a voluntary spending limit of $600,000 for House candidates, which increases to $800,000 in cases where candidates win closely contested primaries or if the candidate must compete in a runoff election. Those caps would be set in 1992 dollars, and indexed for inflation.
The bill would also prohibit candidates from taking more than a total of $200,000 during an election cycle from individuals who each contribute over $200. The limits on large individual and PAC contributions would be lifted when candidates face opponents who make personal contributions of loans of more than $50,000 to his own campaign. The spending limits would also not apply to candidates whose opponents do not accept the voluntary limits and who raise or spend more than $150,000.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies yesterday about the House vote on a deficit-reduction proposal overstated the share of freshmen House members who supported the plan. Fifty-five percent of the freshmen backed the proposal, not 75 percent.
