HEADLINE: U.S. May Dilute Earlier Threats To North Korea

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
A day before President Clinton meets South Korea's President to discuss the standoff on nuclear inspections in North Korea, South Korean officials said they feared the Administration may be pursuing too conciliatory a policy.
Mr. Clinton said today that he intended to seek an endorsement from President Kim Young Sam for a "new approach" to encourage North Korea to comply with international regulations.
He gave no details, but South Korean officials indicated that they worried that the revised strategy might be too conciliatory. 
 Mr. Clinton spoke at a news conference with President Fidel Ramos of the Phillipines. At the talks with Mr. Ramos, a year after the last United States troops left the Philippines, Mr. Clinton sought to emphasize steps to ease frictions that accompanied the forced withdrawal.
Administration officials said the new strategy toward North Korea would offer inducements to encourage openness, giving less emphasis to a standing threat of economic sanctions. They said South Korean reservations were based on the concern that Washington's policy mirrored too closely a North Korean request for a "package solution" of economic, military and political benefits in return for compliance on nuclear inspection.
A senior State Department official said tonight that the South Koreans wanted to talk about the timing and extent of any rewards offered. But, he said, "at the end of the day we'll be able to work something out."
Mr. Clinton said his weekend meetings with the leaders of Japan, China and other Asian countries at a forum on Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation in Seattle had added to his determination to end the impasse caused by North Korea's suspected development of nuclear weapons.
"It was obvious to me that no one in the region wants North Korea to become a nuclear power," he said, "so we're going to do everything we can, in close consultation with the countries most affected in the region, to try to find a resolution to this."
The meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Ramos reflected the White House's increased attention on Asian issues. It was the first meeting between the leaders since the withdrawal of the forces, and they went out of their way to call for a new partnership.
As a gesture of good will, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Ramos agreed to work toward a treaty allowing extradition of criminal suspects. The absence of such an accord has added periodically to tensions, and the men described it as a symbol of a friendship they said remained crucial.
The closing of the last United States base, at Subic Bay, drew the curtain on an era that began with the capture of the islands from Spain in 1898, and caused frustration among Navy officials unable to find an alternative home base in the Pacific.
But at the news conference at the White House this afternoon, Mr. Clinton emphasized that the closing "has not changed the basis for continuing cooperation between our two nations."
And Mr. Ramos, whose Government has already transformed Subic Bay into a bustling free-trade zone, said a partnership should "be anchored more firmly than ever before on the benefits that both our nations derive from our economic relationship."
 
Getting Past an Anachronism
 Mr. Ramos, a former Defense Minister who succeeded Corazon Aquino as President 18 months ago, made clear he had no regret about the decision to force the American withdrawal. He called the basing of United States aircraft, troops and naval vessels in the Phillipines "an arrangement that belonged to the cold-war era."
Mr. Clinton was quick to echo Mr. Ramos's descriptions of the bases as anachronistic. But he was also pointed in his praise of Mr. Ramos for permitting a visit by a United States ship and allowing a joint exercise by American and Filipino troops.
Mr. Ramos, a 1950 graduate of West Point, told an audience at the Center for Strategic and International Studies earlier in the day that a United States engagement in Asia was necessary "to insure that no power dominates the region."
He also had lunch at the White House today with Vice President Al Gore, in part to talk about the environmental problems facing his country.
 
Hope for Kidnapped American
 Mr. Ramos also referred to Charles Walton, a language scholar from Philadelphia who was kidnapped by Muslim extremists eight days ago from a remote island 600 miles south of Manila.
Mr. Ramos said the investigators charged with securing Dr. Walton's freedom were being led by Vice President Joseph Estrada, and he expressed hope that the scholar "will be recovered safely very soon."
Mr. Ramos came to Washington at the end of a two-week tour of the United States to promote investment. He is to return to the Philippines on Tuesday aboard a newly purchesed Boeing 747-400 airliner that will land at the former naval base in Subic Bay to call attention to its conversion to a free port.

It was yesterday, not this coming Friday. A report about the meeting appears today on page A16.

HEADLINE: STRIKE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES;
Airline Strike Ends as Clinton Steps In

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Striking American Airlines flight attendants decided today to end their walkout after President Clinton took the unusual step of brokering an agreement between the union and the airline to submit the labor dispute to binding arbitration.
Mr. Clinton announced the end of the impasse at an afternoon news conference that began barely 20 minutes after the airline and the flight attendants signed off on a plan that was put together by top Administration officials in just a few hours. He said the resolution, which puts the contract dispute before a mutually agreed-upon arbitrator, was intended to allow Thanksgiving holiday travel to return to normal. 
 "I want to encourage all the people involved in the American Airlines family to now return to work together without any bitterness and with a spirit of mutual respect as they attempt to work through these issues through binding arbitration," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Very Direct Actions
 "This company and its employees are a very important part of the American economy," he added, "a very important part of the airline sector that has been troubled for the last couple of years and that is a very important part of our high-tech future."
Mr. Clinton's actions today -- which included personal telephone calls to the chairman of American Airlines and the president of the flight attendants union -- were the most direct steps the White House has taken to influence the outcome of a work stoppage since President Reagan dismissed striking air traffic controllers in 1981. President Bush refused to intervene in an Eastern Airlines strike in 1989 and gave his approval to Federal intervention in a freight-rail strike in 1992 only after Congress passed a law calling for such action.
The White House took pains today to avoid having it appear that Mr. Clinton was taking sides in the dispute, saying he had merely "facilitated" talks between the two parties and had neither threatened to impose a solution nor suggested remedies for the underlying issues in the strike.
 
Joy and Disappointment
 But airline officials said Mr. Clinton brought the weight of his office to bear on the airline in arguing the case for binding arbitration, an approach that had been favored by the union.
"He's the elected leader of the country," said Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, at a news conference in Dallas. "For any citizen or any company or any union to say 'No, I won't do that' to the President requires an awfully good reason."
Union officials immediately hailed the action as a victory, but Mr. Crandall said he was disappointed; arbitration would mean splitting the difference, he said, a sacrifice that American could not afford. On Sunday, he rejected a request from the flight attendants' union for emergency Federal mediation.
Mr. Clinton said he intended only to get the airline flying again in advance of the Thanksgiving holidays. American officials said the flight attendants had not formally returned to work this evening but were holding meetings to arrange a smooth return on Tuesday. Judy Milne, a member of the executive committee of the flight attendants union, said all union members were to be back at work on Tuesday.
One Federal transportation official said: "Our principal interest all along was to mitigate the impact to the traveling public going into the holiday weekend. We don't want to establish the precedent that we are involved in every labor negotiation."
The talks brokered by the White House moved rapidly and were concluded within hours, with much of the real dealing done by aides to the President. Mr. Clinton was drawn into the direct discussions when Bruce Lindsey, a senior adviser who acts as a troubleshooter for the President, pulled him out of a midafternoon meeting with President Fidel Ramos of the Philippines to make the telephone calls from the Oval Office.
 
'Their Agreement
 "This was not our agreement, this was their agreement," said a senior Administration official who was involved in the talks but insisted on anonymity so Mr. Clinton's remarks would not be overshadowed. "We simply helped facilitate the discussion, and there were no discussions of the ultimate terms of any labor contract. That will have to be determined between the parties and by arbitration."
Mr. Clinton spoke separately to Mr. Crandall, the airline chairman, and Denise Hedges, the head of the flight attendants' union, and said afterward that both sides had agreed to binding arbitration.
American Airlines' dispute with its attendants was touched off by disagreements over its proposed contract. American offered to raise the salaries of attendants with 14 years or more experience to $36,430 in four years from the current $32,745. The flight attendants felt that raise was insufficient, particularly because American wanted attendants to pay for more of their health care coverage.
The airline also wanted more control over staffing levels on planes. The contract with the union, for example, now requires four attendants on a Boeing 727, regardless of how many passengers are on board. American wanted to lower that level to the minimum of three attendants required by the Government on trips when a plane is less than full.
The union members hailed Mr. Clinton's actions during an exuberant rally and news conference near Dallas this afternoon.
As hundreds of flight attendants chanted "Thank You, Bill," Ms. Hedges praised Mr. Clinton's "thoughtful and timely intervention."
"We owe a lot to the fact that we have a Democratic Administration that understands the value of working people and the role that labor unions play," said Robert Clayman, the negotiating counsel for the union.
Mr. Crandall said, however, that he had agreed to arbitration only because of the nature of the request.
"It is clearly unusual for the President to intervene in a matter of this type," Mr. Crandall said in a letter to American employees. "In view of his national responsibilities, we think his requests are entitled to great deference."
 
Potential Travel Nightmare
 "Although we prefer a different approach, we are anxious to put our airplanes back in the air and put our people back to work," Mr. Crandall said.
Donald J. Carty, American's chief financial officer, said: "I don't think there's any question we don't like it. We don't like it at all."
American officials said they would fly 60 to 70 percent of scheduled flights on Tuesday and 85 percent of its flights by Wednesday, the day before Thanksgiving.
Mr. Crandall said the strike would have "a dramatic adverse impact on the fourth quarter" profits for the airline. Some analysts have estimated that American was losing from $10 million to $25 million a day during the strike.
The five-day walkout had also threatened to become a transportation nightmare during the busiest weekend of travel in the year, and officials from the Departments of Transportation and Labor, who had been monitoring the situation since before the strike began, urged the White House to step into the fray today.
In persuading Mr. Crandall to submit to arbitration, Mr. Clinton got American to back off from its threats to replace the striking workers. Mr. Clinton's intervention may also help him win back friends in the labor movement who were alienated by his vigorous support for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"I really think we won," said Shari Hoff, a flight attendant who had been preparing to head to the picket line when she heard the news on television and attended the Dallas victory rally. "Crandall said he wouldn't agree to arbitration, and Clinton made him do it."
"I think the Government always has a role in trying to get the parties to talk to each other," a senior Administration official said today. "And that's simply all we did today."
 
Power to Appoint Board
 Mr. Clinton, like any President, has the power under Federal law to declare a transportation emergency if labor disruptions are thought to interfere with interstate commerce or to deprive a region of essential services. After an emergency declaration, the President must establish a Presidential Emergency Board to mediate the dispute.
White House officials said that such steps were neither contemplated nor deemed necessary to resolve the American standoff.
"If either side at any point had said 'No,' that would have been the end of it," one official said.
The White House began monitoring the labor situation at American last Tuesday when Christine Varney, the White House official who acts as liaison among Cabinet secretaries, started meeting with Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena. Aides to the officials concluded over the weekend that White House intervention would be needed, and Mr. Pena advised Vice President Al Gore of the situation on Sunday evening.
Mr. Lindsey began making phone calls on Monday morning, making contact with lawyers for American and with Ms. Hedges. After a meeting among Mr. Lindsey, Robert Rubin of the National Economic Council and a senior policy adviser, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton was notified and was a half-hour late for his news conference with President Ramos as details were worked out.
The President's intervention differs from Mr. Reagan's actions with the air traffic controllers in one significant way. The controllers were striking against a government agency, the Federal Aviation Administration, which is illegal, and the flight attendants were striking against a private company.
In 1966, President Lyndon B. Johnson intervened when the International Association of Machinists struck against five airlines, idling 35,400 workers and resulting in the longest and costliest strike in in national history at the time. The union had previously rejected agreements recommended by the White House but accepted a plan worked out with the aid of Labor Secretary James J. Reynolds.
President Harry S. Truman intervened in more strikes than any other President this century, including rail and coal strikes in 1946, and sent troops to keep steel mills open during a 1952 strike because of military needs in the Korean War.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 25, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about President Clinton's intervention in the American Airlines strike misidentified James J. Reynolds, a Johnson Administration official who intervened in a strike in 1966. He was an Assistant Secretary of Labor and then Under Secretary of Labor; he was not the Labor Secretary.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeking To Consolidate Bank Agencies

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today outlined a plan to create a single agency to regulate the entire banking industry, saying that dividing the job among four agencies no longer made sense.
The four agencies were created over the last several decades in response to various changes in the banking industry. But the face of the financial industry has changed drastically in recent years, as banks and savings and loans have expanded the services they offer consumers, consolidated over state lines through mergers, and responded to increasing competition from nonbank companies. 
 As a result, regulatory functions have increasingly overlapped, with some banks and savings and loans, for example, facing examinations from inspectors from two agencies at the same time. And with four agencies holding various positions on banking policy, some large banking companies have "shopped" for regulators who would be most approving of their various plans.
The Administration contended today that such overlap and lack of coordination and the resultant inefficiency were becoming increasingly costly to taxpayers.
"It just makes no sense to have four separate agencies, overlapping, often in conflict, in charge of our financial institutions," the Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, said.
The current system "was designed for another time that long since has passed," Mr. Bentsen contended. "We've got to get rid of the inefficiencies in our Government."
The industry is now regulated by the Comptroller of the Currency, which is responsible for national banks; the Federal Reserve Board, which regulates bank holding companies; the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits at savings and loans and banks, and the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates savings and loans.
The Administration's plan calls for the tasks of examining the books of banks and savings and loans and regulating their financial safety to be assumed by a single new independent agency, the Federal Banking Commission.
The Federal Reserve would continue to control the nation's money supply, setting interest rates and influencing the course of the economy, but it would lose regulatory power over the nation's biggest banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would continue to insure deposits, and the states would continue to be the primary regulators of the banks they charter.
 
 
Fed Reaction
 The heads of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Office of Thrift Supervision, both part of the Treasury Department, endorsed the proposal. But the Federal Reserve issued a statement saying it should continue to play a regulatory role.
The Administration called the banking changes the latest step in what the White House likes to call "reinventing government."
Although the changes would have little direct effect on how consumers do business with banks, the Administration contended that it would lower the costs of credit, one of its economic priorities.
"What we have now slows up the economy, adds to the costs of those financial institutions, and they, in turn, pass it on to the consumers, to the checking accounts, to the interest rates on loans," Mr. Bentsen said in an Op-Ed page article today in The Washington Post.
Congressional leaders, who had urged the Administration to come up with a proposal to match those that have been presented for months in Congress, supported today's plan.
 
 
'Quite Promising'
 Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, said it "sounds quite promising" and said he was pleased that the new agency would be independent of the Treasury Department.
But there were signs of unease in the industry and among the agencies that regulate, and to some extent nurture, the banks.
In its statement, the Fed said its "hands-on role in banking supervision is essential to carrying out the Federal Reserve's responsibility for the stability of the financial system and is vital for the effective conduct of monetary policy.
"While the board recognizes the overlaps in bank supervision that have emerged in recent years, it is essential that any proposal for change preserves the important benefits of the current system," it said.
 
 
'Very Reasonable'
 At a news conference, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, Frank N. Newman, acknowledged that the Fed held this view, but called the Administration's proposals "very reasonable."
"The Federal Reserve would have a seat on the board, and through that seat on the board, the Federal Reserve would have access to all the materials associated with the examination of every institution that will be of interest to them," Mr. Newman said.
"They would go along with the examiners of the Federal Banking Commission in examination of a number of the particularly major institutions who play large and important roles in the payment system, and the Federal Reserve would also continue to prescribe regulation for and, as appropriate, examine compliance with those regulations for participation in the payment system," he said.
Mr. Newman spoke to reporters under a Treasury Department policy that he not be identified. The New York Times declined to attend the briefing under those conditions, and obtained a text of his remarks independently.
 
 
Some Reservations
 Ed Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the largest banking group, the American Bankers Association, said that most banks seemed to want to simplify the regulatory system, which they largely pay for through Federal fees.
But he said the bankers continued to have some reservations about how the change, which would have to move through Congress, would affect different segments of the diverse industry.
Proposals to simplify bank regulation are nothing new. In 1991, when Congress last revamped the main banking law, the idea came to nothing, as the regulators and their industrial constituents could not agree on a single approach.

HEADLINE: Sour End to Strong Year

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The 103d Congress more or less ended a productive first session today, but on a note of ill will that made it clear that the legislative paralysis of recent years had been diminished but not vanquished.
Many bills that President Bush had vetoed became law with the signature and backing of President Clinton. But party divisions were raw and obvious during the budget battle in the summer and clear again today as minor differences held up a popular gun control measure. Democrats sought to trap the Republicans into blocking it, or giving up ignominiously. [Page A21.] 
 But despite those divisions, Congress passed a half-trillion-dollar, five-year deficit cut, about half of it in tax increases, and approved a measure to end trade barriers with Canada and Mexico. It passed one significant domestic initiative of President Clinton's vision of new Democratic policy, the national service bill, and started on others, like one to prepare youths for the work force.
Finally, it began to grapple seriously with the gravest domestic problem it has tried to solve since civil rights: the high cost and diminishing availability of medical care.
Early on, the new President relied exclusively on Democrats -- and sometimes they fought him over issues like his efforts to allow open homosexuals to serve in the military. Solid Republican opposition killed his package of spending measures meant to stimulate the economy, and his budget just passed without a single Republican vote. But his liaison with Capitol Hill improved as he went along, and in the fall he worked increasingly with Republicans, relying on their votes to clear the North American Free Trade Agreement over Democratic opposition and courting them to help on health care.
Still, most of senators and representatives headed home today aware that the public gives neither them or President Clinton the credit they feel they deserve, and today's snappish denouement of a Senate session, due to conclude next Tuesday, suggests why.
 
Small Differences
 In between interminable quorum calls and recesses, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, tied the Senate up short of final action on the gun control measure, which would impose a five-day waiting period for gun purchases.
The deadlock was striking because the substantive differences between Republicans and Democrats were slim. Instead, the dispute seemed to revolve largely around differences in party and pride. Mr. Dole complained that Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the Judiciary Committee chairman, "tried to rub our nose in it" by gleefully scrapping concessions that allowed Republicans to back the bill on Saturday night. And the phrase "Republican filibuster" tripped readily from Democrats' lips as they sought to portray the minority as the friend of irresponsible gun owners.
Still, some lawmakers feel pretty good about the year's work. An upbeat appraisal came from Senator Patty Murray of Washington, a freshman Democrat, who said that when they realized the Senate had acted on crime, the deficit, family leave and national service, "people at home will say, 'This affects me.' "
She added, "And I can't think of a lot of things Congress has done in the past decade that a normal, average family would say, 'This affects me.' "
 
'Historic' Not Hype
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said: "I believe that this has already been a very significant Congress, and if and when, as I believe we will, pass comprehensive health care reform, I believe we will be entitled to the already much overused word of historic in describing this Congress."
Of course Democrats liked what was passed better than Republicans did.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, chairman of the House Republican Conference, was among the most scathing today in a commentary on Democratic policy starting with the tax increases of the deficit measure and continuing through Monday night's rejection of another five-year budget cutting measure for $90 billion. "The President and his team in Congress have been completely consistent throughout the year," he said. "They started the year trying to raise taxes and fighting off the Republican effort to stop that, and they finished the year thwarting the Republican effort in the Kasich proposal last night to cut spending. And nothing really that went on between the beginning and the end really changed their fundamental position on raising taxes and raising spending."
Mr. Dole put it more simply, calling the legislative product of this session in scope and spending, "A little too much, I think."
 
President Is Encouraged
 Not too much for President Clinton, who exulted today over the help he had had from Democrats and sometimes from Republicans. He boasted that this was only the second time in 60 years that a President had not vetoed a single bill, the last case being Richard M. Nixon in 1969.
The quick academic view was generally positive. Charles O. Jones, a professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin and a student of the Carter Administration, called it a decent first year for Mr. Clinton and the Congress. "If they haven't dealt with it, they have at least set it up for next year," he said. "It's been a high-wire act, often."
He added that the critical difference between Mr. Clinton's approach and that of the last Democratic outsider, Mr. Carter, was that Mr. Clinton "is perfectly willing to play let's make a deal. That was downright offensive to Carter."
But Thomas Mann of the Brookings Institution said that while Congress might appreciate that effort to win votes, the public did not because of the "anger and contempt for the political process." He said "What is a normal political process is seen as somehow tainted and demeaning."
Not only Mr. Clinton but also the Democrats in Congress had something to learn. His party suddenly found itself not just with a President who would sign their pet bills, but with a President they were obliged to support, and also with the responsibility that goes with the power to pass laws and not just score political points. They could not expect vetoes to bail them out.
 The single biggest change in the Congress was the fact that 24 percent of its members were freshmen. Some had hoped to change the rules overnight and to change the way things are done in Congress, like by slashing spending and speeding up procedures. In the Senate, five new women members often stuck together and had an impact.
But in the House their impact came more in providing votes for Mr. Clinton's proposals. Speaker Thomas S. Foley found the 66 new Democrats solid supporters of the leadership. He said they cast more gutsy votes than freshmen might be expected to offer. "They don't cast knee-jerk, quick, convenient votes," he said.
Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky of Pennsylvania, the freshman who cast the most inconvenient vote of all, the decisive 218th for Mr. Clinton's budget bill, said today: "I don't want to be here just to stay here. I think a lot of members vote to stay, rather than to change things." Her proudest moment, she said, was not that crucial budget vote but "the opportunity to have my name attached to increased funding for breast and cervical cancer research."
Representative Eva Clayton of North Carolina, the president of the Democratic freshmen class, said: "The freshman class is not monolithic in its views. What they do hold in common is their seriousness of being players."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Legislative Record"
 
Family Leave -- Congress gave President Clinton his first legislative victory when it passed the family-leave bill to guarantee workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for medical emergencies and births.
 
Voter Registration -- After breaking a Republican filibuster in the Senate, Congress passed a bill that directs states to provide voter registration forms in motor vehicle offices, military recruiting stations and welfare offices.
 
Economic Stimulus -- Using a filibuster, Senate Republicans defeated the President's plan to stimulate the economy.
 
Budget Deficit -- By the narrowest of margins, Congress approved the President's plan to reduce the budget deficit by $496 billion over the next five years and raise individual and corporate income taxes, gasoline taxes, and Medicare and Social Security taxes by about $220 billion over the next five years."
 
Trade -- Legislation was approved that would put the North American Free Trade Agreement into effect starting Jan. 1, 1994, gradually abolishing nearly all trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
 
National Service -- The plan is the first of Mr. Clinton's campaign promises to be enacted into law and is intended to encourage volunteerism and create a corps of volunteers who would get living allowances and up to $10,000 in education grants.
 
Flood Relief -- Congress enacted legislation to provide $6.2 billion to help areas hurt by this summer's flooding in the Midwest.
 
Campaign Finance -- The House passed a bill that includes voluntary limits on campaign spending and the first public financing of Congressional campaigns. The Senate's bill calls for voluntary spending limits but does not include public financing and eliminates political action committee contributions. The bills are in a Senate-House conference committee.
 
Civil Servants -- Legislation passed that would lift many restrictions on political activity by Federal employees.
 
Supercollider -- Despite the President's support for the program, Congress voted to terminate the $11 billion Superconducting Supercollider project, which is one-fifth complete.
 
Space Station -- Congress decided to continue financing the project.
 
Crime -- The Senate passed a broad $23 billion anti-crime package whose leading provisions would add 100,000 police officers to the nation's streets, build a network of high-security regional prisons and create more boot camps for young offenders. The House took another tack and approved measures that would add 50,000 police officers over five years, expand drug treatment in prison and offer gang members counseling, drug treatment and recreation. The bill are ina conference committee.
 
Gun Control -- The House and Senate passed different versions of a bill calling for a five-day waiting period to buy a handgun. The House has passed a compromise version, but the compromise is stalled in the Senate.
 
Abortion -- Congress again approved an amendment restricting Federal payments for abortions although in a slightly modified form. The new language allows the use of Federal money for abortions in cases of rape and incest as well as when the life of the pregnant woman is in danger. Legislation to prohibit most state restrictions on abortions lost momentum and appears to be dead. Congress approved a measure making it a Federal crime to bomb, burn or block access to abortion clinics; the measure also makes it a Federal crime to shoot or make threats of violence against doctors and nurses who perform abortions. The two versions of the bill are in conference committee.
 
Mining Law -- The House passed a bill that would charge an 8 percent royalty on revenue from mining on public land in 12 Western states and eliminate the ability to take title. It would also tighten environmental controls on miners and force them to repair any damage they do. The version of the bill passed by the Senate is much less comprehensive. The bill are in a conference committee.
 
Grazing Fees -- Unable to break a filibuster by Western Senators, Congress abandoned efforts to increase grazing fees and impose other range overhauls on Federal land, expecting the Administration to do it by regulation. (pg. A21)

SECTION: Section D; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
From the Ashes, a Plus for a Utility

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALEM, Mass.

 BODY:
The New England Power Company burns a lot of coal at its waterfront power plant here: 2,400 tons a day, day in, day out, year round.
Because about 10 percent of coal is unburnable sand and shale -- what one executive calls "prehistoric dirt" -- the result is about 300,000 tons of coal ash a year that must somehow be removed. That is a quarter of a ton of ash a year for each residential electricity customer. 
 The simplest answer to the problem is simply to bury the stuff, and that is largely what is done now. But landfill sites, particularly in the Northeast, are becoming increasingly scarce and expensive.
So New England Power has joined with Separation Technologies Inc., a small technology development company in Needham, Mass., to try to convert the ash into useful products. These products have the potential for cutting the company's fuel costs as well as making money by providing an additive for cement.
 
The Advantages of Ash
 Pure coal ash is good for cement. It is known as a "pozzolanic" material, one that resembles the volcanic ash from Mount Vesuvius. Ancient Romans used it to improve the quality of mortar in their construction, some of which still stands. The fine particles of silica and alumina improve cement's strength and resist penetration by water and salt.
When water penetrates concrete and freezes, it expands and breaks some of the cement bonds that hold the mixture of sand and gravel together. Chloride ions from the salt that is slathered on roads each winter move through these cracks and corrode the steel reinforcement bars in roadway concrete, explaining why most highway bridges need to have their decks replaced every 20 years or so.
As it comes from a utility's boiler, however, coal ash is anything but pure, with 18 percent to 19 percent contamination by unburned carbon. And as utilities are forced by clean-air laws to install burners that reduce emissions of oxides of nitrogen gases, the quantity of unburned carbon is expected to nearly double.
That much carbon troubles cement makers and users. Concrete used in areas with frequent periods of freezing weather is deliberately mixed with tiny bubbles of air -- about 8 percent of total volume -- to provide space for expansion and contraction of the other components. But the unburned carbon acts like activated charcoal, absorbing the bubbles and producing less durable material.
 
Early Testing
 To deal with the disposal problem and to create a useful material, the two companies are beginning an effort to separate the ash into carbon-rich and carbon-poor streams.
In early testing on Venezuelan coal burned at the Salem Harbor Station, ash with an 18.5 percent carbon content was separated into one product with an 83.7 percent carbon content and a second with only 2.97 percent carbon.
The process has been tested by Separation Technologies in small-scale operations, but the installation at Salem Harbor is the first commercial-scale application of the technology. Equipment is being installed and large-scale testing is scheduled to begin after Thanksgiving and continue for about six months. "Ash is not trash" is the slogan on T-shirts worn by project members in warmer weather.
If the separation works as planned, it will have a double-barreled economic impact. The carbon-rich material has more than 50 percent of the energy value of the original coal, and can be fed back into the boilers to decrease the need for fuel or used as a carbon black substitute in making plastics.
The carbon-poor stream can be sold to cement makers at $10 to $15 a ton, as long as the carbon level is held under 3 percent, said R. Peter Calvert, New England Power's chief fuel planner, who is managing the project.
There is a ready market for low-carbon coal ash, said Steven S. Madden, general manager of Pozzolanic International in Albany, which trades ash. The silicon, aluminum and iron oxides in ash, he said, enhance the chemistry of portland cement, the most common form of cement, by reacting with unwanted byproducts.
"There are more markets than there is salable ash," he said, adding that most ash from smokestacks is not of cement quality.
Mr. Madden said that if the separation technology worked as billed and produced ash of consistent quality, even more demand would develop, both in domestic and overseas markets. He said ash could replace from 15 percent to 40 percent of the portland cement used in concrete.
 
The Wheat From the Chaff
 The separator, 30 feet long and about 6 feet wide, or bigger than two pickup trucks, takes advantage of a simple fact: carbon conducts electricity while the inorganic components of the ash do not.
The separator, in essence, divides the wheat from the chaff. Indeed, the technology is applicable to other forms of dry separation, such as wheat flour from bran particles in certain grades of processed wheat.
As the ash particles rub against each other in the hopper leading to the separator, the carbon develops a positive charge and other materials develop a negative charge.
The charged particles are fed into the machine, where they encounter an electrical field. The positively charged carbon particles are attracted downward to the negative electrode, while the others flow toward the positive electrode. They do not have far to go because the two electrodes are only about one-fourth of an inch apart.
Nevertheless, the particles do not reach their destinations. Belts headed in opposite directions -- and moving at 50 to 100 feet a second -- sweep the particles away from each other and into separate hoppers. As a result, a particle is inside the separator for less than one second.
 
A Nonstop Operation
 The machine is intended to operate continuously to process the hot, dry ash removed from the plant's exhaust by electrostatic precipitators.
Because the coal is reduced to talcum-powder fineness before being burned, 85 percent to 90 percent of the ash generated at power plants is retrieved from stack gases. The coarser bottom ash, recovered from under the boilers, is used as a feed in cement kilns rather than as a substitute for cement.
According to Charles E. Parker, the president of Separation Technologies, the process has environmental benefits. Not only does it reduce the utility's bills for disposing of ash and buying fuel, but to the extent that ash substitutes for portland cement, the process also reduces overall energy consumption in the region.
Cement production is highly energy intensive. Kilns are heated as high as 2,700 degrees Fahrenheit for long periods, consuming large amounts of fuel.
Mr. Calvert of New England Power said that about three million tons of cement were used in the Northeast each year, providing an ample market for ash if the quality could be maintained. He has a strong incentive to find markets for the material: the company's landfills will be full in five years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: R. Peter Calvert, left, and Ernie Kallander of the New England Power Company touring the carbon-separating system for converting coal ash into useful products such as an additive for cement. (Evan Richman for The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "Recycling Coal Ash"
 A system to be testd at a New England Power Company plant removes unburned carbon from coal ash to increase the value of the separated products. As the ash is fed into the separator, positively charged carbon is attracted toward a negative electrode while other particles move a short distance toward a positive electrode. Belts moving in opposite directions carry the materials away from eachother for storage and reuse. (Source: Separation Technologies)

HEADLINE: U.S. and Seoul Differ on Appeal To North Korea on Nuclear Sites

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The United States and South Korea agreed today to hold out to North Korea a package of inducements if it allows some inspections of its nuclear sites and resumes discussions with South Korea. But the two longtime allies could not agree on exactly what the offer should contain.
At a meeting at the White House today with President Clinton, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea expressed some reluctance to go along with an earlier American proposal to offer the North a suspension of an annual American-South Korean military training exercise, called "Team Spirit," saying he felt that this might make him look too eager to meet one of the North's principal demands. 
 President Kim told American officials that it was politically important to him that any such decision on military maneuvers be announced out of Seoul and that it be announced only after the North has met the two conditions: basic inspections and resumption of talks.
 
A Strained News Session
 "I think this matter of suspending Team Spirit exercises should be dealt with on its own," said President Kim, at a somewhat strained joint news conference with President Clinton.
American officials said that they would outline a "package approach" to the North Koreans through a low-level diplomatic channel in New York on Wednesday. Although the specific military or diplomatic inducements remain to be worked out, the approach marks an abandonment of the countries' previous strategy of holding out small specific rewards to North Korea for small specific steps toward opening its sites to inspections.
Administration officials said that the policy they had followed since North Korea announced its withdrawal from the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons last March had produced no benefits.
But today's announcement seemed to fall short of the detailed "new approach" President Clinton had promised. American officials said the two leaders had to spend a great deal of time simply working out the broad language that they would use to describe their general strategy.
 
North Korean Proposal
 North Korea was calling for a deal in which the United States would offer to cancel the annual Team Spirit exercise in return for an agreement by Pyongyang to allow international inspectors to resume monitoring its nuclear sites.
Instead Mr. Clinton, after his meeting with President Kim, was only ready to say that if the North moves first, the United States and South Korea will respond with a "thorough and broad" package.
Mr. Clinton said: "They are the ones, after all, who are out of line with international law and their own commitments. So we can't make any decisions about what we would do until we see what they do. That's all we are saying today."
The President added that the United States and South Korea were "prepared to discuss with North Korea a thorough, broad approach to the issues that divide us, and once and for all resolve the nuclear issue, but we cannot do that in the absence of a dialogue between North and South Korea, and while there is still growing doubt about the continuity of safeguards."
 
Servicing of Cameras
 An immediate goal of the United States and South Korea is to persuade North Korea to allow the International Atomic Energy Agency to replace film and batteries in cameras it has stationed at important nuclear sites in North Korea. Both the film and batteries are about to wear out, if they have not already done so, nearly blinding the world to North Korea's operations.
Mr. Clinton said that if North Korea permits the agency to replace its inspection equipment and resumes discussions with South Korea over nuclear weapons on the Korean Peninsula, "the door will be open on a wide range of issues, not only with the United States but with the rest of the world."
Administration officials said that they and the South Koreans were likely to offer the North Koreans suspension of the military exercise, a commitment by the United States not to attack North Korea with nuclear weapons as long as it abides by the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons, a commitment to roll back American troop deployments in South Korea and, in time, possible economic and diplomatic relations between the United States and North Korea.
 
Regular Inspection of Sites
 But American officials stressed that North Korea would not only have to agree to the resumption of limited monitoring, but also to permit regular inspections of other nuclear sites that for now have been off-limits to international monitors. There is no great optimism in Washington that this new approach will prove any more successful than the previous one. But the option of asking the Security Council to impose sanctions on North Korea has been blocked for now by the strong reluctance of both China and Japan.
American officials complained that first the South Koreans told them that they were being too weak on the question of North Korea's nuclear program, and then, after the Administration toughened its approach, the South Koreans said that they were being too aggressive and should offer the North more concessions.
"This is a work in progress," said one Administration official. "The South Koreans are in flux because on the one hand they don't want the North to get a nuclear weapon. But they are very nervous about imposing sanctions that could prompt the North into terrorism or an act of war, or, equally bad, would lead to a collapse of North Korea, and South Korea would have to foot the $1.2 trillion bill to rebuild the place. So that's why they want to be firm but to keep diplomacy alive."
Senator Richard Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said he believed Mr. Clinton had been put in a difficult position by the South Koreans. "They're saying to us: be firm, but not too firm," he said.
But Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, said he feared conciliation undermined the credibility of the system intended to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
"The step of taking the North Koreans to the Security Council offers the best hope of a good solution, and it's the step that Mr. Clinton doesn't seem to want to take," Mr. Milhollin said.
"If the worst thing that happens when you break the rules is that you get to negotiate, it's not much of a system," he said.

HEADLINE: Like the U.S., Western Europe Steps Up Its Trade With Asia

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 23

 BODY:
During a week in which the message from Washington and Seattle was that United States foreign policy has been too Eurocentric and must concentrate more on Asia, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany was quietly touring China and concluding contracts to sell about $4 billion in German goods to Beijing.
"It was obvious that the Chinese want intensified contacts with Europe," said Lorenz Schomerus, a senior Economics Ministry official who accompanied Mr. Kohl on the trip, which brought a contract for Siemens to build the Guangzhou subway and agreements for other German companies to build power and steel plants. 
 Mr. Schomerus added: "And our feeling is that, like the United States, Europe must step up its dialogue with the countries of Asia. We have no reason to feel threatened."
 
Europe's Trade With Asia
 Indeed, while much was made in the United States last week of the fact that its trade with the Pacific rim members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group exceeded United States trade with the European Community, far less was heard of Europe's huge exports to Asia.
In fact, European Community exports last year to the Pacific rim members of the economic forum totaled $96.2 billion, exceeding the community's $95 billion in exports to the United States, according to German Economics Ministry figures.
Total European trade with these countries amounted to $249 billion, well above the $206 billion in European trade with the United States.
These statistics and the economic success of the Kohl visit to China underscore a point made repeatedly by European officials in response to last week's comments from President Clinton and other United States officials about the merits of Asia in an age when foreign policy is about trade: all three emerging economic blocs -- Europe, North America and Asia -- need each other, and none would have anything to gain from a trade war with the others.
In general, the Clinton Administration's apparent tilt toward Asia -- backed up by a barrage of statistics about changing immigration patterns in the United States, the importance of United States exports to Asia and the speed of economic growth in China -- has been viewed in European capitals as having more to do with hype and negotiating ploys than with a fundamental shift in strategy. The statements surrounding the meeting of leaders of the 15 member nations of the Asia-Pacific forum on an island off Seattle over the weekend.
"The thinly veiled U.S. threats about having Asia as an alternative to Europe if world trade talks fail are absurd," said a French Foreign Ministry official, referring to the negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "It's as if France said it no longer cared about the United States because most of our trade is with other European Community countries."
Francois Heisbourg, the former director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said: "In the medium term, it is far from clear that a convergence of interests exists between the Americans and the Asians, particularly China.
"But in the short term, the United States has tilted the balance of forces in its favor for world trade talks by putting on a show of Asian camaraderie."
 
The Importance of GATT
 Indeed, in case this point about the GATT negotiations was lost on the Europeans, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, made it explicit. "We trust our partners in Geneva will take careful note of this solidarity and unity of purpose of APEC members," he said.
France, whose conflicts with the United States over agriculture and movie subsidies have been a main cause of the long GATT paralysis, showed little immediate sign of being impressed.
Prime Minister Edouard Balladur said there would be no GATT agreement if Washington did not make concessions on farm trade, and Interior Minister Charles Pasqua criticized President Clinton for being "sure of himself, dominating and a little irritating."
But for all the posturing ahead of the Dec. 15 deadline for the GATT negotiations, there is also a growing sense in Europe of the importance of a trade accord to insure that tensions between the community and the United States do not worsen, leading to a real weakening of the NATO alliance and an even greater focus by Washington on Asia.
Reflecting this uneasy sentiment, Bonn's General Anzeiger newspaper declared in an editorial today: "Europe is no longer the navel of the universe. The new world order, made fun of so far because nobody knows what it is, is taking shape. It is a world that has more than one center, and it is up to the Europeans not to withdraw but to find their place in it."
In this sense, the meeting in Seattle has clearly focused European minds on the fact that East Asia has become a real contender in economic and political terms. It seems certain that Germany, with its strong free-trading sentiment, will now put great pressure on France over the next three weeks to insure that a GATT accord is reached.
The alternative could be bleak for Europe's relations with Washington. President Clinton has now stated clearly that "more than ever our security is tied to economics," and has compared the past role of NATO during the cold war to the potential future role of the Asia-Pacific group in an era when trade, not military might, matters most. All this could play against trans-Atlantic ties, which have been cemented by a military alliance that is now in some disarray.
"The domination of geoeconomics over geopolitics has been formally declared by the United States," said Dominique Moisi, the deputy head of the French Institute for International Relations. "So without a GATT agreement, you could have an awful lot of unraveling."

HEADLINE: Bleak Romanian Economy Growing Ever Bleaker

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Bundled up against the icy cold of an unseasonably early winter, Victoria Uleia shopped at Bucharest's thinly supplied outdoor market, splurging on cheese but not meat.
Mrs. Uleia, a well-paid accountant until she retired four years ago, says she is incomparably worse off financially than she was when the most brutal Communist regime in Eastern Europe collapsed. She is glad Communism is gone, she said. But, she added, economic conditions do not have to be as bad as they are. 
 "It's a period of searching and we haven't found the way," the 54-year-old widow said. "The people in power keep us going backward because they are afraid of losing their political and economic advantages."
Many economists agree. Four years after Communism was swept away in Eastern Europe, few economies sparkle. But nowhere is the situation as bleak as in Romania, where the successors to Nicolae Ceausescu have balked at reorganizing the most industrialized economy in the region.
 
The Long Shadow of Ceausescu
 The President since the overthrow and execution of Mr. Ceausescu has been Ion Iliescu, a senior figure in the Ceausescu Government. Prime Minister Nicolae Vacaroiu and many other Cabinet minesters were also Ceausescu officials.
Mr. Iliescu said in a recent television appearance that his Government had made significant strides toward a market economy. But afterward, one of his ministers rebutted him, saying economic reform had not even started.
"The Government is slow on privatization because it represents the big industries," said Dan Pascariu, the chairman of the Romanian Bank of Commerce. "The Government still thinks of restructuring as a political concept rather than an economic or business one." He said two moves this year in the right direction -- the removal of price controls and the introduction of a value-added tax -- were not enough.
A Washington-based Western economist who visits Romania said, "For one reason or another, every effort to bring in a market ecomomy has been subverted."
 
A Nervous Search for Loans
 With inflation now running at more than 200 percent and the value of currency plummeting, the Government faces the worst possible situation: an economic crisis caused by four years of inaction and an increasingly restive population. On Nov. 18, about 50,000 demonstrators marched through Bucharest protesting the economic deterioration.
Thus, with its back against the wall, the Government intensified negotiations with the International Monetary Fund this month, seeking $500 million in loans.
The Finance Minister, Florin Georgescu, returned from Washington this month saying an agreement had been reached. But Washington officials said that there was no agreement, and that even if details could be worked out soon, it would be toward the end of winter before an agreement could be signed and money disbursed.
 
Measuring 'Quality of Life'
 The deterioration is reflected in many indicators. The World Bank, for example, conservatively estimates that most Romanians spend about 80 percent of their income on food.
According to a professor of sociology, Catalin Zamfin, who is the deputy head of the Government Quality of Life Institute, about 20 percent of Romanians live below the poverty line; many are parents with children.
The Health Ministry announced this month that infant mortality had started to climb again, after dropping since 1989. The data show that more infants are dying in Romania than elsewhere in Europe: the 1992 infant mortality rate rose 3 percent, to 23.4 per 1,000 live births; the average rate for Europe, including the former Communist countries, was just over 10 per 1,000.
One of the main reasons the I.M.F. has refused to lend money is the Government's failure to reorganize industry, whose workers, often idle but still on the payrolls, provide Mr. Iliescu with much of his support. Unemployment is 9.5 percent, an artificially low figure that illustrates that restructuring has not started, according to Commerce Bank.
 
The Absence of Foreigners
 Because there has been no restructuring, privatization of the productive sector is practically nonexistent. At the same time, production has fallen by almost 50 percent; still, many state companies get Government credits even though they are bankrupt.
A fairly typical example is the steel mill at Calarasi, in eastern Romania. In the 1980's, the Ceausescu Government only managed to get 80 percent of the plant completed. But 5,000 workers are employed there, turning out about 300,000 tons of steel annually, a dismal output by world standards.
A Western steel trader visited the plant recently because he was interested in buying cheap steel. But instead of being offered a sale, he was presented with an improbable request for $25 million to help complete the plant.
The Government's reluctance to move on the economy, combined with the corruption associated with doing business in Romania, has resulted in comparatively little foreign investment: just over $600 million since 1989, according to Government data. This compares to $5 billion invested in neighboring Hungary, a country of half the population but where a comparatively liberal Communist Government in the 1980's gave investors a headstart.
 
Winter May Be Very Cold
 Romanians face a precarious winter. With foreign currency reserves low, there are concerns about whether the Government can pay for energy imports from Russia. People said their apartments were warmer during recent freezes than during the Ceausescu period, when heating systems were often turned off to conserve fuel. Even so, doctors walk around hospitals in dressing gowns to keep warm, and some apartment dwellers said it was normal for them to wear their overcoats inside.
If an agreement with the I.M.F. is reached, Romanians are bound to feel even more pain for the sake of long-term economic health.
For people like Mrs. Uleia, who could afford to travel to the United States in 1988 to visit her sister but cannot even dream of such an extravagance today, the suffering is endurable if the future holds promise.
"I'm convinced in time it will be better," she said. "Then I will have something to look forward to." But whether the Government and the country's industrial workers share her long-term view is another question.

HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
South of the Border, the Trade Deal Was a Breeze

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23

 BODY:
As the Mexican Senate prepared to cast its decisive vote on the free trade agreement that will join this country with the United States and Canada in the largest trading bloc in the world, a wall of dark suits rose on Monday night by the telephones in the Senate cloakroom.
"He's the President of Austria," a senator moaned into the receiver, apparently meaning that nation's Foreign Minister, Franz Vranitzky, who was in town on a visit. "I cannot not go to the dinner." 
 To the legislator's left, another of the people's representatives was debating with his wife over who would send a driver to pick up the children. Farther down, a third senator, balding and bespectacled, was trying to hang up.
"I send you many kisses, my love," the man said, but the amount seemed to be insufficient because the caller would still not hang up.
 
'A Done Deal!'
 If the senators were less than fully attentive to the speeches that were droning on in the somber, wood-paneled chamber a few feet away, that was perhaps to be expected.
Their verdict on the constitutionality of the trade accord may have been the most momentous decision made in years by the upper house of the Mexican Congress. But with only three opposition-party representatives seated among the 64 high-backed chairs and one of them a supporter of the agreement, the only real question was how many of the governing party's 61 senators would still be around or awake when it was finally taken. The vote, just after 11 P.M., was 56 to 2.
Instead of suspense, what the vote did seem to raise were some further questions about the extent of public debate and democratic choice that have attended Mexico's ratification of the trade pact.
"This was a done deal from the beginning!" thundered Pablo Gomez, a leftist politician who had just finished thundering to an audience of other leftist politicians, poor housewives and curious bystanders who gathered in the plaza outside the colonial Senate building for what was billed as an "alternative" debate.
"Nobody has ever told us what effect this treaty will have on jobs, on the trade balance, on economic growth," Mr. Gomez said. "In the United States, that is all you talk about!"
The Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari clearly saw such aspersions coming.
No sooner had the United States House of Representatives voted last Wednesday night to approve the agreement than Mr. Salinas began preparing a Mexican Al Gore. On Thursday, the Mexican leader dispatched his combative, Yale-educated trade secretary, Jaime Serra Puche, to challenge the leftist leader Cuauhtemoc Cardenas to debate the accord on live television.
Mr. Cardenas, a longtime critic of the trade deal who is known neither for his verbal agility nor his decisiveness, called a news conference on Friday to give his answer but then did not. Finally, at a rally on Saturday to open his campaign for next year's presidential election, Mr. Cardenas said he would debate -- but only with Mr. Salinas.
So was at least official responsibility for the economic future of North America remanded to the pinkish colonial building at which Mexican senators tend to arrive after big power breakfasts that usually last until about 11 A.M. (They rarely go to lunch, it should be noted, before 2 P.M.)
It is imprecise to say, as many Mexicans do, that their senators do nothing; some of them seem to work quite hard. It is just that there is very little of substance for them to do.
 
The Sinecure Is Sovereign
 In theory, Mexican senators do the sort of things that senators do in other countries with a division of powers: write federal laws, review budgets, approve presidential trips abroad. But in practice the Government is so dominated by the executive branch that laws are written in the ministries, the budgets pass almost unchallenged and the President tells the Congress when he travels abroad; he doesn't ask.
On the majority side, 14 Senate seats are reserved for the graying dons of the Government-affiliated union alliance, the Confederation of Mexican Workers. The remaining 47 sinecures, which come with estimated annual salaries of $85,000, are filled by party leaders and important ministers.
As Monday's session got under way, the majority leader who is also the deputy head of the workers' confederation, Emilio M. Gonzalez, shooed away a pack of Mexican reporters, telling them amiably: "You know that here in the chamber I don't work. That is my rule."
In a country where there is no such thing as writing one's congressman and many people don't even know who their representatives are, governing-party legislators are accountable mostly to the President. And at a breakfast on Aug. 16, Mr. Salinas was widely reported to have chastised his 61 senators for allowing "one single opposition senator" to best them routinely in debates.
 
Were Mexicans Sold Out?
 The President's windy nemesis, Senator Porfirio Munoz Ledo, was having a field day on Monday.
Mr. Munoz Ledo, who converted to the cause of Mr. Cardenas after once having served as President of the ruling party, promised to limit himself to "some of the most notorious falsehoods" of the Government's case. He then went on at considerable length to accuse the Salinas administration of having sold out a poor and unprepared nation to enter in an American plan dating back to the Trilateral Commission.
"That is called being a traitor!" a Government partisan shouted from the gallery. But Mr. Munoz Ledo was undeterred.
"Today I will not exhort you to vote your conscience," he said. "I know what you will do and I know why you will do it. Today I exhort the country, my compatriots, to organize with me a line of national resistance against the country's deliverance to foreign powers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Today I exhort the country, my compatriots, to organize with me a line of national resistance against the country's deliverance to foreign powers," said Senator Porfirio Munoz Ledo of Mexico. He descended from a podium at the Senate Monday after denouncing the free trade agreement. (Francisco Mata Rosas for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pressure for a Decision on Coliseum Site

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
It has been nearly nine years since Mortimer B. Zuckerman won the right to replace the Coliseum, a building much maligned by architecture critics, with a gleaming new mixed-use complex on Columbus Circle. Today the old Coliseum still stands, and the fate of the site, which occupies prime real estate near the southwest corner of Central Park, seems as uncertain as ever.
Now, however, the Dinkins administration, in its waning days, is moving to compel the developer to build on the site or forfeit his deposit. 
 Mr. Zuckerman's company, Boston Properties , is under contract to build a 2.1 million-square-foot complex of offices, apartments, restaurants and stores at the site. The developer, who also owns The Daily News, says the terms are not realistic in today's depressed real-estate market, and he wants to renegotiate the $338 million price and build in two phases.
For months the city has squabbled with the Metropolitan Transit Authority, which owns the site, over whether to give Mr. Zuckerman more negotiating room, or whether to force him to close on the transaction within 90 days or forfeit a $33.8 million deposit. The M.T.A. has indicated that it is not amenable to major revisions in the original agreement, while the city has been more receptive to changes.
But now, as the clock ticks down on the Dinkins administration and the issue remains unresolved, the city has told the M.T.A. that it was ready to join forces and require that Mr. Zuckerman close on the project under the original terms. That has not happened yet because the city's Economic Development Corporation is trying to get the M.T.A. to make it partners in any future plan for the site if Mr. Zuckerman does not build there, said Carl Weisbrod, the corporation president.
"It was in our view that if an agreement could be worked out that could be agreeable to all parties, that would have been best," Mr. Weisbrod said yesterday. "The current paralysis is an unacceptable situation."
 
No Reversal
 It may be in Mr. Zuckerman's interest if the M.T.A. and city do not find common ground soon on who would share the spoils of one of the most attractive parcels of land in midtown. Mr. Zuckerman's paper, The Daily News, endorsed Rudolph W. Giuliani for mayor.
If the city and the M.T.A. do come to terms and issue a closing notice before the end of the year, Mr. Guiliani would be unable to reverse the decision, an M.T.A. spokesman said.
"The clock starts ticking when the notice is issued," said John Cunningham, an M.T.A. spokesman.
Nearly from the moment Mr. Zuckerman unveiled his plans for the Coliseum site, the city was hit with a barrage of lawsuits attacking the project. Community residents, environmentalists and others argued that the project was too big. Not only was Mr. Zuckerman delayed by the lawsuits, but in 1987, he also lost his main office tenant and partner when Salomon Brothers backed out. The collapse of the real-estate market has kept the project under a cloud.
But the last legal obstacle to the project was put aside in September 1992 when a Federal Appeals Court said that the development would not violate Federal Clean Air rules. Since then the city, the M.T.A. and representatives of Mr. Zuckerman have been struggling to complete the deal.
 
A Council Hearing
 Last week the City Council's committee on economic development called on all parties to explain why the project was still in limbo.
Edward H. Linde, president of Boston Properties, told the Council panel that it was committed to developing the property, had a prospective tenant for the office building and could start construction late next year. (Alan A. Lascher, a principal with Weil Gotshal & Manges, confirmed that the law firm is negotiating with Boston Properties for as much as 500,000 square feet of space if a new office tower is built. The firm's lease in the General Motors Building at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street is up in 1998.)
Saying that the legal delays were not the fault of Boston Properties, Mr. Linde pressed his case for renegotiation.
"We would be burying our head in the sand if we did not recognize that the environment facing us today is significantly different than the environment in 1989 when the most recent version of Columbus Center was approved," Mr. Linde said.
In response to a question from a Council member, Mr. Linde hinted that Boston Properties would sue the city and the M.T.A. if the company were forced to forfeit the $33.8 million deposit.
For its part, the M.T.A. told the Council that since 1992, it had tried to negotiate a new arrangement with Boston Properties that would provide what the agency considered to be a fair monetary return on the Columbus Circle site.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Squeeze Play by Big Aluminum

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Few companies would pass up a chance to wish away a big competitor. And apparently, the American aluminum industry is willing to do just that -- even if it means losing a big customer while they are at it.
All five publicly traded producers of aluminum have seen their stocks move up in recent days, as much as 10.5 percent. Investors are anticipating that Western countries will coax reluctant aluminum producers from the Commonwealth of Independent States to curb production to help stem a world glut of the metal. 
 But investors, and perhaps the aluminum companies busy lobbying in Washington for help, may not be thinking sufficiently hard about some of the consequences of getting what they wish.
For one thing, the United States is a big supplier of a key raw material for the troublesome aluminum from Russia and other former Soviet republics. Cutting back aluminum production from Russia also means less profit for American companies.
As the former members of the Soviet Union have stopped using their own aluminum for fighter planes and missiles, they have been accused of flooding the world's commercial metal markets with their products, helping drive down prices.
Yesterday, aluminum prices on the spot market were quoted at 47 cents a pound, half what they were in early 1989, before the fall of the Berlin wall helped end the cold war.
 
A Call for Rollbacks
 On Thursday, the large American producers called on the Russian contingent to voluntarily roll back production 35 percent, to 2 million metric tons, from 3.1 million metric tons a year and to bring exports much closer to the 1989 levels of 250,000 metric tons a year, down from the current annual tonnage of 1.6 million.
Why the Russians would agree to put so many countrymen out of work just to make the Americans, Norwegians, Europeans, Canadians and Australians happy is unclear, even though some of their plants are outdated and unsafe.
And why Washington would mount a costly rescue of the American producers in a tough economy with an ambitious domestic agenda facing it remains unclear. But that is precisely what many investors seem to be predicting.
"The only reason I can think of for the strength in the aluminum shares is speculation that these government-to-government negotiations prove fruitful," John C. Tumazos, a metals analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said.
The Russians remain open-minded, as evidenced by their participation in talks that reconvene on Dec. 1 and 2 in Washington among several aluminum-producing countries. The head of a Russian aluminum trade group also suggested recently that Russia would help with any worldwide cutbacks, but would resist efforts to force it to bear most of the burden.
But a big rollback in Russian production would crimp Russian purchases of alumina, a whitish powder that is vital in making aluminum.
The Russians are believed to buy at least half their alumina from foreign suppliers. Estimates of their yearly alumina purchases run upward of $400 million a year.
And while the aluminum market has been unkind of late, alumina has been a huge moneymaker. The stock of Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, has moved up 5.3 percent since Thursday's saber-rattling, and the company made $36 million in profits in the third quarter from its half interest in an alumina producer, Alcoa of Australia.
That was 3.4 times Alcoa's companywide profits, according to Charles A. Bradford, a metals analyst at UBS Securities. The quarter was no fluke. Alumina profits, he said, also accounted for 84 percent of second-quarter profits and 103 percent of first-quarter profits.
"The point is, if the Russians and Western producers cut their operating rate, that will make alumina much worse as a market," Mr. Bradford said.
Because Alcoa has been among the most vocal champions of a Government-sponsored solution to the oversupply problem, investors may wonder what Alcoa is thinking.
Privately, Alcoa officials contended that if any Western company was vulnerable to a drop in alumina sales, it would be Kaiser Aluminum, not Alcoa, the industry leader and low-cost producer. Alcoa, they say, sells very little directly to the Russians. What is more, they say, the company has locked customers into contracts that will guard it temporarily from any slump in price.
Mr. Bradford of UBS said he agreed that Kaiser, shares of which have climbed 10.5 percent since Thursday, had more to lose. But that conclusion still ignores that any drop in demand for alumina will probably depress alumina prices and eventually hurt all alumina producers, Alcoa included.
"Eventually, Alcoa may come out ahead, but it may get hurt in the short term," said Mr. Bradford, who has placed a "hold" on all aluminum stocks except Reynolds Metals, which he is recommending because it has a loyal domestic clientele and sells little alumina on the open market.
The intrigue is enough to make one wonder what would have happened if Isaiah, the biblical prophet, had lived after Adam Smith.
Instead of being thankful that former enemies had laid down their arms, political leaders might have had to contend with the consequences of swords being beaten into plowshares. The plowshare makers would be furious with the makers of swords for dumping their surplus metal on the market and killing their profit margins. What a bummer.
