HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Market Bill Is Passed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
It took more than two years and came with little fanfare. But around 2 A.M. yesterday, the House of Representatives gave the final approval needed to pass the bond market legislation proposed in the wake of the Salomon Brothers Treasury scandal in August 1991.
The bill, which was passed by the Senate on Monday night and is expected to be signed by President Clinton, would make some important changes in the regulation of the $2.4 trillion Government securities market. 
 Under the legislation, Government securities brokers and dealers in the Treasury market would have to follow sales practice rules. Similar rules now apply to brokers in the stock and municipal bond markets. These rules include suitability standards, which require that a broker determine that a security being sold to a customer be appropriate for that customer's needs and financial status.
 
Rules From the N.A.S.D.
 The new rules would be written and enforced by the National Association of Securities Dealers and the bank regulatory agencies. Under the present law, the N.A.S.D. is prohibited from writing such rules for the Government securities market.
A second change is new authority for the Government to get reports on holdings of Treasury securities from big players in the market, including hedge funds and others outside of the circle of primary dealers, who are the main bidders in the Treasury auction process.
This power will be used when the Treasury is trying to determine if there is a shortage of a certain Treasury security in the market that could lead to the manipulation of the price. Such a so-called squeeze could be natural -- that is, legal -- or it could be illegal.
Taken together, the changes do not add up to a major overhaul of the Treasury market or the addition of much new regulation that is being opposed by the industry. But the change from the Bush Treasury to the Clinton Treasury probably made the final version a little more far- reaching.
 
Some Changes Already in Place
 Many of the biggest changes in how the market is watched day to day and the operation of the Treasury auction were made with administrative moves by the major regulatory agencies almost two years ago. Some changes, like a redesigned and public bidding process in Treasury auctions, rather than secret bidding, are still being developed.
Most of the changes in the new law were included as recommendations in a January 1992 report on the Salomon scandal. The report was made jointly by the Treasury, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
But all the recommendation did not have the support of all the agencies. For example, the Treasury Department during the Bush Administration wanted veto power over the sales practice rules. The Federal Reserve Board said there was no need for such rules.
Several other changes are included in the legislation:
*The rule-making authority granted to the Treasury in the Government Securities Act of 1986 is extended permanently.
*It becomes a clear violation of the law for a person to make false or misleading statements in bidding in any Government securities auction.
*The anti-fraud authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission over the Government securities market is strengthened.
*All Government securities brokers and dealers are required to provide the exact record and timing of transactions if the S.E.C. needs the data for surveillance or enforcement purposes.
One provision not included in the law was authority sought by the S.E.C. to allow it to mandate, if it deemed necessary, better dissemination of secondary market price data in the Treasury market.
 
'Important New Protections'
 "I am particularly pleased that we were able to agree on significant reform of the Government securities market that responds to the lessons of the Salomon Brothers and related scandals," said Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance and the principal House author of the bill. "This bill will enhance market surveillance and enforcement and provide important new protections for investors."
Heather L. Ruth, the president of the Public Securities Association, said the new legislation was a "balanced approach to regulation in this market."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen also applauded the legislation.
In August 1991, Salomon admitted to submitting illegal bids in the Treasury auction of the Government's securities. The scandal led to the resignation of the top management of the firm, millions of dollars in fines and a long struggle by Salomon to regain its footing on Wall Street.
Among the key policy changes announced in early 1992 was the Treasury threat to combat any "acute, protracted" shortage of securities in the market -- a squeeze -- by immediately issuing new securities to relieve the shortage, whether it was natural or illegal. The Treasury first used this policy with the 10-year note at the November 1992 auction and did it again with the auction of the 10-year note this month.
There is debate in the market over whether the Treasury will reopen the current 6.25 percent 30-year issue because of signs of a serious shortage there.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Market
 Prices jumped and yields fell in the Treasury market yesterday, ending at least for a day the sharp selloff in the bond market.
Traders said the market had sold off more than it had to, given the economic outlook, and was bouncing back a little. The success of the Treasury's five-year note auction also helped.
The price of the 30-year bond rose one point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.31 percent, from 6.38 percent on Monday. The price of the three-year note rose 6/32 as the yield dropped to 4.52 percent from 4.59 percent.
In the five-year-note auction, the high yield was 5.20 percent, up from 4.81 percent in October and the highest since July. But in trading after the auction, the yield fell to 5.14 percent in the when-issued market, which meant that a lot of dealers who bought the new note could have made a nice profit in the afternoon.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Says City's Slump Is Ending

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, said yesterday that New York City was beginning a slow, uneven recovery after a four-year slump that cut far deeper than elsewhere in the nation.
"This report is good news, if only because the bad news is finally ending," said Mr. McCall. His conclusion that the downward economic drift had reached bottom echoed the views expressed by many of the city's economists and business leaders in recent months. 
 "The city still has a long way to go," Mr. McCall said. "There are still a lot of businesses hurting."
But his report, assessing conditions in several major industries, found reason for optimism that the recovery will accelerate next year.
 
Little Comfort for Next Year
 The state report, prepared by Rosemary Scanlon, who joined Mr. McCall's staff in October after serving the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as chief economist, said that construction of homes and industrial buildings should pick up because of low interest rates. An improvement in the weak economies of Europe and Japan should bolster the city's international business, the report predicted.
The report was released only a day after advisers to Mayor David N. Dinkins released new fiscal projections that the city faced a $1.73 billion budget deficit next year -- $450 million more than had been expected. And while providing evidence of some economic improvement, Mr. McCall's report offered little comfort to Mr. Dinkins's successor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose aides have predicted a fiscal crisis next year.
"Clearly, if the economy's getting better, then the city's getting better," said Mr. McCall, who served as president of the city's Board of Education before being named state comptroller. "But the recovery in the city will be slow."
The study found some economic factors that are improving and some that remain mired in a slump.
While unemployment in the city has improved since January (when it reached 13.4 percent), the October rate of 10.3 percent indicated a sudden worsening in the job market. In September, unemployment was 8.7 percent.
Even without the rise, the city's rate would be higher than that of the nation, which has been less than 7 percent of late.
But the report said the city's rate of inflation, which averaged 3.1 percent first 10 months this year, was virtually identical to the 3.0 percent for the nation. Thus, the report said, "the inflation premium of doing business in the city," which has discouraged business expansion for decades, has been eliminated.
Among the city's best economic performers, the report said, are companies providing services in health care, social service and finance. Leading the list is the securities industry, where salaries and bonuses continue to soar (as they have for three years) and employment is expanding.
On Wall Street, where the report said pay averages more than $100,000 a year, the job ranks have expanded by 4,900 since April 1992, and the prosperity seems certain to generate increased retail sales and other economic improvment.
"The securities industry has thus far been the driving force in the city's move toward economic stability," the report said.
It found little evidence of revival in the tourism industry, however. Although hotel occupancy in the city improved slightly first nine months of the year, to 67.7 percent from 67.2 percent, room rates at the hotels continued a four-year decline and passenger traffic through the three major airports serving the city declined slightly.
Among the most serious economic problems, the report found that 1.1 million people, or 15 percent of the city's population, were receiving public assistance in September. That was the highest number since Federal public assistance was instituted in the 1940's. And it represented a 25 percent increase since June 1989.
Among the glimmers of improvement, the report said, are the battered commercial real-estate market, where leasing increased 8 percent in the first half of the year, vacancy rates have fallen slightly, and rental rates, which had plunged since 1988, have leveled off.
Mr. McCall said he expected the signs of slow recovery to become more widespread next year. "I am cautiously optimistic that there is light at the end of the tunnel," he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Recover Slightly As Dow Climbs by 3.92

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Stocks yesterday recovered some of the losses suffered in Monday's sharp selloff, as investors were buoyed by a rally in the Treasury bond market and Britain cut its base lending rate.
"The market reaction was a snapback from the beating that interest-sensitive stocks have taken in the last few days," said John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president of Advest Inc. "It reflects the feeling that the Fed won't be obliged to raise short-term interest rates." 
 All three major stock market indicators rose, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 3.92 points, to 3,674.17, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks up 1.90, to 461.03 and the Nasdaq composite index up 8.69 points, to 746.82.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange declined to 261.6 million shares, from 280.1 millin shares the previous day, presumably because some traders had left for the Thanksgiving Day holiday.
However, the Dow Jones transportation index declined 17.95 points, led by AMR, the parent of American Airlines, off 3 1/2, to 65 1/8; Delta Air Lines, off 1 1/2, to 57 1/2, and UAL, the parent of United Airlines, off 2 1/2, to 136 1/2. Airline analysts noted that President Clinton's intervention in settling the four-day strike by American's flight attendants, which ended on Monday with an agreement to arbitrate the dispute, helped to push down prices of the major airline stocks.
 
Lower Interest-Rate News
 But it was lower interest-rate news that captured much of the attention of investors during the day, prompting many people to move money from bonds to stocks in expectation of higher returns. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.31 percent, from 6.38 percent on Monday, its highest level in more than three months.
And the Bank of England dropped the rate that is equivalent to the discount rate in the United States, the interest that the Federal Reserve charges member banks for loans, to 5.5 percent from 6 percent.
Among the interest-sensitve stock groups that benefited from these developments were electric utilities and banks. Among the utilities, Philadelphia Electric advanced 3/8, to 28; Long Island Lighting gained 3/8, to 24 3/8, and Commonwealth Edison increased 1/2, to 28 3/8.
Both regional and money-center banks were strong. Fleet Financial was up 1/2, to 30 1/2, and Bank of Boston was up 1/4, to 21 5/8, while BankAmerica rose 1 3/8, to 42 5/8, and Citicorp rose 1 1/4, to 35.
Strength was also evident among international oil issues, with analysts noting that a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could result in action to reduce production in order to stabilize prices in the crude oil market. British Petroleum's American depository receipts advanced 1 7/8,, to 61 1/2, and Royal Dutch increased 1 3/4, to 102 3/4.
Microchip stocks were firm as well. Micron Technology was up 4 1/4, to 43 3/4; Intel was up 1 3/8, to 58 7/8, and Texas Instruments was up 3, to 64.
Other big gainers included Circus Circus, which picked up 1 to close at 32 3/4 after it reached an agreement to build a riverboat casino near New Orleans; Starbucks, which advanced 1 1/2, to 23 after Paine Webber raised its rating of the gourmet coffee company to "attractive," and Avecor Cardiovascular, which gained 1 1/8, to 9 7/8, after receiving approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a blood oxygenator device.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Pact at USX Would Bring Pay Increases

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23

 BODY:
A tentative labor agreement between the United Steelworkers of America and USX-U.S. Steel Group Inc. would give union members pay increases, guarantees against layoffs except in case of disaster and representation on the company's board, the union said today.
The union's negotiating committee voted overwhelmingly this morning to recommend that members employed at U.S. Steel, the largest United States steel company, approve the agreement. 
 No date has been set for the voting. The union's current contract with USX expires on Jan. 31.
It was only after this morning's vote that the union released details of the agreement, which runs for five and a half years and resembles agreements it reached last summer with other major steelmakers, including the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the National Steel Corporation and Inland Steel Industries.
 
 
'A New Day'
 The contract would be effective on Feb. 1, 1994, and expire on July 31, 1999, the same time that the union's contracts with the other large steel companies expire.
"This contract represents the start of a new day in relations between the company and its workers," said Andrew Palm, chairman of the union's negotiating committee with USX. The contract covers 15,000 workers in four states.
In exchange for gains by the union, the contract covers a longer period than normal and includes a provision that would allow USX to reopen it under certain conditions, with binding arbitration if the parties were unable to reach agreement.
The contract also includes a wage increase of 50 cents an hour effective on Feb. 1, 1996, and bonuses of $5,000 over the life of the agreement to offset the effects of inflation, additional bonuses totaling $2,000 to be paid prior to a reopening and a further bonus of up to $1,000 in 1996 if company profits reach $300 million in 1995. Before the increase, the average hourly pay of union members was $14 to $15, excluding benefits.
Shares of USX-U.S. Steel Group rose 12.5 cents today, closing at $35.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
With hopes that casino gambling will soon follow, Philadelphia developers plan retail centers.

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
A 42-ACRE retail center is under construction on the Delaware River waterfront here, amid signs that future development on adjacent properties may include casino gambling in shoreline buildings, on piers and aboard ships.
The developer of the retail project, the Rubin Organization Inc., is building more than 250,000 square feet of retail space, two restaurants and parking at its Pier 70 Plaza project. Years ago, the land was occupied by the shoreside buildings that served the piers beyond. Rubin, based in Philadelphia, has reportedly sold options on four piers at the edge of its property to Capital Gaming International, a casino operator. Rubin would not comment on the sale. 
 Pier 70 Plaza sits alongside the riverfront dividing Pennsylvania and New Jersey. It fronts on Columbus Boulevard, south of Tasker Street, about a 10-minute drive from downtown. It was once home to shipping and storage operations, but it sat vacant for more than a decade. The six-lane Columbus Boulevard remains a truck route to the port, but also provides the gateway to a two-mile stretch of restaurants, bars and shops, bracketed at the north and south by working ports.
 
Spring Openings Planned
 The tenants at Pier 70, Wal-Mart and Sam's Warehouse Club, will open stores of 129,000 square feet each, and the Home Depot is building a 135,000-square-foot store. All are expected to open by next spring, said Douglas Grayson, the development director for Rubin.
Rubin has planned other retail projects at former industrial sites -- one at a vacant Sears, Roebuck & Company warehouse in northeast Philadelphia and another at the former Baldwin Locomotive plant, which is a 20-minute drive from the waterfront.
The Mayor of Philadelphia, Edward G. Rendell, has supported waterfront development, but his stance has raised opposition. Local 1776 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union argued, for example, that "category killer" stores -- so called because they dominate a retail category -- are unsuited to the waterfront and will divert business from other stores in the area.
Mr. Grayson estimated the value of the Pier 70 Plaza project to be $30 million. The Delaware River area has become a magnet for retail development despite years of planning for high-rise residential and office buildings that were never built, he said.
 
Commercial Support
 "A lot of the properties down there are in the hands of commercial speculators," Mr. Grayson said. "You can't anticipate what the market's going to do. The market -- and the city -- has supported commercial development instead of industrial, whether for retail or casinos."
On an parcel adjacent to the Pier 70 Plaza, another Philadelphia company, Tower Investments, had planned a competing retail center with Builders Square and PACE Membership Warehouse, but it never materialized. Tower's first project in the waterfront area was a 150,000-square-foot strip center and theater complex on Columbus Boulevard -- still called Delaware Avenue by Philadelphians despite a 1991 name change by the City Council.
The waterfront area boomed when access to Interstate 95 was improved with new ramps to and from Columbus Boulevard, and about 80 acres of land was rezoned for commercial development instead of industrial use. Retailers like the Pep Boys, the auto repair retailer, and Silo, an electronics chain, are considering opening stores in the area to serve southern New Jersey and Philadelphia.
 
Prepared to Wait
 Yet Tower appears ready to wait for the possibility of riverfront gaming operations, in what casino analysts tout as a premier location midway between New York and Washington.
Mayor Rendell's support has fueled speculation that state approval will follow in a few years. Gov. Robert Casey opposes gaming, but several 1994 gubernatorial candidates have given developers enough hope to merit selling options on land to gaming companies.
Still, casino development is hardly certain. In late October, State Senator Vincent J. Fumo, a Democrat from Philadelphia who is a leading proponent of casino gaming, said he would support only ships for gaming after Atlantic City casino owners challenged a Pennsylvania gaming proposal.
Mr. Fumo said the Philadelphia waterfront had limited space for new construction and existing hospitality businesses should be protected from the kind of development in Atlantic City, where giant buildings with casinos, restaurants and hotel rooms attracted visitors only to a single area of the city.
Philadelphia officials view gaming as an extension of the tourist economy tied to the Pennsylvania Convention Center, which opened downtown in June. The type of gaming and the locations are undecided.
The critics of casinos said they opposed bringing them to the city because Atlantic City was a 90-minute drive away and had regular train service to Philadelphia. Other sources of competition for waterfront sites are the Delaware River Port Authority and the Philadelphia Regional Port Authority, which want the sites used for cargo and trucking.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower After U.S. Treasury Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly lower yesterday after seesawing against the Japanese yen in anticipation of a Treasury Department report. Some traders mistakenly thought that the report would indicate a shift in United States policy toward the Japanese currency.
Many investors bought dollars and sold yen early, expecting that the Treasury Department would abandon what some have called its "strong yen policy." But the department, in its semiannual report to Congress on exchange-rate policy, merely said exchange rates should follow the economy, rather than being manipulated by governments. 
 "The market was expecting way too much from these comments," said Mike McKeever, an assistant vice president at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York.
The dollar shot up over 109 yen early yesterday. "The market got ahead of itself," said Robert Ryan, a vice president at Bank of New York. But after the report was released, the dollar retreated to 108.38 yen in late New York trading, down from 108.47 yen on Monday.
Traders believe United States officials "talked up" the yen earlier this year in order to reduce the American trade deficit. A stronger yen could help close the trade gap by making Japanese imports more expensive, and United States exports to Japan cheaper.
Meanwhile, gold prices dropped yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery lost $1.20, closing at $377.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $377 an ounce, down $1.
The British pound also scored against the dollar after the British Government lowered base lending rates by half a percentage point, 5.5 percent. In New York, the pound ended at $1.4855, up from $1.4760 on Monday.
While the British rate cut lowers the return for investors in sterling-denominated deposits, it was seen as a boost to the ailing British economy. In addition, sterling rallied because the interest rate cut was expected to be Britain's last for some time, while Germany was expected to continue cutting its rates, according to Amy Smith, senior currency strategist at the IDEA analytic service.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sotheby's Chief Is Leaving As Auction Sales Rebound

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Sotheby's Holdings Inc. announced yesterday that Michael L. Ainslie, its president and chief executive, was stepping down and would be replaced by Diana D. Brooks, the president and chief executive of its worldwide auction division.
Mr. Ainslie, 50, who joined Sotheby's in 1984, is leaving the top post as the auction business shows signs of breaking out of a three-year slump that battered the company's balance sheet. 
 He will remain chairman of Sotheby's international realty division and a member of the company's board of directors and executive committee. He is also the third-largest shareholder in Sotheby's, with 1.26 million shares.
Ms. Brooks, 43, has risen steadily through the ranks since 1979 and had been considered by many analysts as the heir apparent at the world's largest auction house. She is best known for her success in heading its operations in North and South America in the late 80's.
 
'Doing a Terrific Job'
 She has been doing a terrific job," said Terrence J. McEvoy, vice president of research at Janney Montgomery Scott. "It would have been surprising if she hadn't gotten it."
The rebound in the auction business has buoyed the company's stock in recent weeks. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Sotheby's closed at $15, unchanged, on volume of about 152,000 shares. The stock had fallen as low as $10.75 over the summer.
Sotheby's fall sales of Impressionist and modern paintings, European furniture and jewelry all yielded strong prices, helping to inspire the overall auction market.
Revenues at Sotheby's, which is based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and is also involved in art-related financing and luxury real estate, dropped from $441.9 million in 1989 to $224.9 million in 1992. Income plunged in that period from $112.7 million to $4 million.
For the third quarter of 1993, the company reported a loss of $12.7 million on revenues of $24.6 million, compared with a loss of $13.2 million on revenues of $26.2 million in the third quarter of 1992.
 
Time to Move On
 Mr. Ainslie, who will officially give up his post on March 31, 1994, said in an interview that he had committed himself to staying about a decade at Sotheby's. After guiding the company through the last three rocky years, during which he cut costs by $50 million, he felt it was time to move on, he said.
"I came in 1984 just as the company was coming out of the last art market recession," he said. "I benefited greatly from the fact that the market was recovering but not strong across the board. Now we are at a very similar point in the art market cycle. Frankly, I feel the next generation of leadership and management should have that same prerogative."
Ms. Brooks said one of her biggest challenges would be to insure that Sotheby's continued to adapt to a rapidly evolving international market that was being buffeted by disputes over trade barriers and value-added taxes.
"The art world has become extremely complex," she said. "The amounts of money are much bigger. The export issues are much greater. This is a much tougher business than it was a decade ago."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Tumble Sharply As OPEC Is Seen Faltering

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell sharply yesterday on the perception that OPEC oil ministers, meeting in Vienna, have lost their ability to control prices.
"I have never seen the market sell off like this while the cartel was in conference," Peter Beutel, an energy analyst with Brody, White & Company in New York, said. "Normally the market treats OPEC with a little more respect than that." 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for January delivery sagged 47 cents, to $16.63 a barrel.
Other energy futures prices fell as well. December heating oil plunged 1.25 cents, to 50.33 cents a gallon; December unleaded gasoline dropped 1.06 cents, to 44.57 cents a gallon; January natural gas fell 0.44 cent, to $2.352 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Crude prices fell despite a warning from Gabon's Energy Minister, Jean Ping, the outgoing president of the 12-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, that oil prices were "dangerously" low and that producers must take whatever action is necessary to raise them.
 
'Back Against the Wall'
 OPEC "has got its back against the wall," said Tom Bentz, director of energy trading at Quantum Financial Services in New York.
He said it would take at least a 3 percent cut in OPEC's current production of 24.5 million barrels a day to get a market response.
"The question is," Mr. Bentz said, "even if they make the cuts, will the market go up?" He said demand was lackluster and supplies were more than adequate.
The average price of an OPEC price marker -- a basket of crude oil prices monitored by the organization -- skidded on Monday to $14.70 for a 42-gallon barrel. That OPEC benchmark is at its lowest level in more than three years and far off the group's target of $21 a barrel.
The market was also under pressure from news that Tariq Aziz, Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, said he would remain in New York as long as necessary to reach an agreement with the United Nations on conditions that would allow Iraq to resume oil exports.
"The market seemed to be saying very clearly that Iraq is in charge of its own destiny and OPEC is not," Mr. Beutel said.
Elsewhere on the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum fell on worries about declining demand from Japan, a major consumer of the metal for jewelry and pollution-control systems. January platinum fell $6.80, to $374.10 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Behind a Glamorous Image, Flying Working Class

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The corporate stylebook so strictly decrees the proper image of flight attendants, from head to heels, that they have a wry saying about the requirements of their jobs: "You've got to be willing to go anywhere -- and to cut your hair."
And along with the cheerful smiles and starched shirts, the attendants say they are expected to be accommodating, even obedient. 
 "We're seen as 'nice girls,' not to be taken seriously," said Rebecca Denmark, a 33-year-old flight attendant, who walked the picket line in the strike against American Airlines, which ended on Monday with both sides agreeing to binding arbitration. "And we are nice. But there comes a time when you can't be a wimp any longer. You have to stand up and say, 'Enough!' "
As the flight attendants returned to work today, the scene at gate 23 inside Stapleton Airport here looked like a joyous family reunion.
 
Working-Class People
 If the strike has changed the way airlines view flight attendants, it has also changed the way they see themselves.
The image of what used to be called stewardesses, leading lives of glamour and jet-setting, has changed sharply in the many years since the mystique of air travel has vanished for ordinary Americans. For all the trips to Paris and Hong Kong and San Francisco, these are working-class people, including some who say they are paid so little that they qualify for food stamps.
But despite the demanding travel and rules, the complaints from passengers, and dissatisfaction with the wages -- which can start at $16,000 a year -- most flight attendants say they love their jobs.
"The schedules are flexible, the pace can be exhilarating and you can live wherever you want," said Ms. Denmark, an avid hiker and skier, who lives near the mountains in Boulder. "And if you're married, and your spouse gets transferred, you can just take your job to a new city."
 
'Addicted to the Flexibility'
 Carolyn Albers, who graduated from Southern Methodist University in 1986 with a degree in economics and finance, took a job as a flight attendant on a lark, figuring she would stay no longer than two years.
But now, eight years later, Ms. Albers, who is 29 years old, said she had become "addicted to the flexibility," a schedule that allows her to take off a week at a time without dipping into her vacation.
Because of her job at American Airlines, she has friends in London and can take in a play there on the 24-hour layover. On trips to Honolulu, she can spend at least an afternoon at the ocean.
"And I look at my friends in business jobs," she said, "grinding away every night until 6:30, not making any big money, and this job doesn't look so bad."
But there are sacrifices. As her family in Texas gathers for a turkey dinner on Thanksgiving, she will be serving drinks on a plane to Hawaii and reminding passengers to keep their seats in the upright position.
American says its wages and benefits are competitve. And while some flight attendants complain about rules on hair and shoe heels, John Marucci, a spokesman for American, said, "They certainly haven't scared off the thousands of people who applied for these jobs during the strike."
Flight attendants are paid for hours in the air, from the time the cabin door closes until it opens again, but not for the hours spent waiting between planes. They average about 75 hours in the air a month, but that could mean being away from home 15 days in that period.
 
Cereal and Peanut Butter
 During the waiting time, they receive $1.50 an hour for expenses, hardly enough for a big dinner out. Many flight attendants carry boxes of cereal and jars of peanut butter inside their travel bags.
It is not uncommon for four or more flight attendants to share an apartment.
And for those with children, the days away from home pose a particular problem, since a full-time nanny would probably cost as much as a flight attendant earns.
"My neighbor watches the kids, and my sister-in-law, and my mother-in-law," said Cynthia Ecker, a 37-year-old flight attendant who lives in suburban Denver and has a 2-year-old son and an infant daughter.
And the long-distance telephone calls home are expensive. "Being without my kids is the hardest thing about this job," Mrs. Ecker said. "There are days when I'll see a baby on board, and I'll just start crying."
Flight attendants are no longer required to be single and under 32 years old, but they must still be slender. A 20-year-old woman who is 5 feet 4 inches can weigh no more than 130 pounds. The rules allow women to gain a few pounds as they age, but not many. When that same woman is 34, she can weigh no more than 135 pounds.
On board, flight attendants typically wear flat shoes. But as they walk through the airport, they are required to wear heels. During the six-week training session, they must be willing to change their hair styles to the liking of the company, and are given guidance on the application of makeup. If a supervisor spots an unsightly pimple, flight attendants say, they can be pulled off a jet without pay.
And while there are no stated requirements of physical beauty, one flight attendant, Cindy Lutz, chuckled, "We do all look an awful lot alike, don't we?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I look at my friends in business jobs, grinding away every night until 6:30, not making any big money, and this job doesn't look so bad," said Carolyn Albers. The eight-year American Airlines flight attendant packed her bag at her home in Denver for her first flight since the strike. (Brian Brainerd for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Strike Is Called Victory For Women, Not Unions

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton's intervention Monday in the strike by flight attendants at American Airlines represented a breakthrough for working women, rather than a victory for organized labor, union leaders said today.
The airlines, more than most industries, are thoroughly dominated by well-paid men, both those who run them and those who fly the planes. Through the years, flight attendants, most of them women, have been forced to settle for less than the airlines' male employees -- less pay, inferior benefits, more inconvenient working arrangements and indignities including rigid dress and weight codes and lectures on how to be nice. 
 American Airlines flight attendants earn an average of $23,000 a year, both the company and the flight attendants union acknowledge, which is about 20 percent of the pay of the average American Airlines pilot. Even American's baggage handlers, most of them men, earn more than flight attendants.
Women also make up almost half -- 46 percent -- of the workforce, but few have been admitted to its leadership in either management or unions. Of the 35 members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s policy-making executive council, three are women, and only Lenore Miller of the 80,000-member Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union in New York is a union president.
In this dispute, American's 21,000-member Association of Professional Flight Attendants, some of them single mothers, resented management's frequent assertions that labor costs were more responsible for the company's financial woes than the debt and other costs it amassed in expanding the airline in the 1980's.
 
Aversion to Confusion
 And the attendants recoiled from management's plan to throw more confusion into their already complicated work schedules. Randy Edwards, a spokesman for the attendants, said the members recognize American's need to reduce its staff to sustain its business.
But the attendants said they feared brutal levels of layoffs and work-procedure changes, citing an example of a Boeing 767 flying to Europe. The Federal Aviation Administration requires the airline to provide a minimum of five attendants. But Mr. Edwards said American routinely flew with 10 or 11. Attendants could sign up for several extra positions, and the airline recruited the rest from attendants assigned to a reserve pool.
He said reservists are on two-hour notice to report for flights and are thus unable to plan their days with any certainty. Now, he said, American wanted to eliminate the fixed extra slots and rely on reservists for all attendants beyond the required five. Mr. Edwards said the result would be fewer attendants and a much larger reserve pool.
Rather than submit, the women all but shut the airline down, stunning a management that miscalculated the depth of resentment against it and forcing it to agree to submit the dispute to an arbitrator, just a day after its chairman, Robert L. Crandall, publicly rebuffed the attendants' call for arbitration.
 
Airline Sought Talks
 "The real heroes of this are the flight attendants," said Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the largest union in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Mr. Carey said he respected the attendants' refusal to yield even when American began hiring permanent replacements.
A senior Administration official revealed today that Mr. Crandall had initiated the contact with the White House, apparently because he recognized how much the strike was hurting the airline. The official said Mr. Crandall called the White House to suggest arbitration, and then Mr. Clinton called Mr. Crandall to confirm the plan.
"Crandall got his chestnuts pulled out of the fire for him," said Rex Hardesty, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. spokesman.
Today, American denied rumors that Mr. Crandall would resign. American issued a statement at a news conference at its headquarters in Fort Worth that quoted Mr. Crandall as saying, "Nothing can be farther from the truth." The statement also said that Mr. Crandall believed he had the total support of the board of directors.
 
Heavy Economic Toll
 The airline acknowledged that the attendants' strike took an enormous toll. After three years of losses, the company had been making money this year -- $143 million through the first nine months. The cost of the strike, said Marty Heires, a spokesman for the airline, "is going to be some big numbers." He added: "It's going to be enough to force a loss for this year. The flight attendants certainly did a good job of disrupting things."
But Mr. Heires took issue with those who interpreted the dispute in terms of the relative power of men and women. "It's not that the attendants are a weaker group," he said. "It's that the pilots pose a greater threat because they can immediately put the airline out of business." The time needed to train new attendants, normally nearly six weeks and reduced to 10 days during the strike, is much less than for training a pilot.
Early in the five-day strike, American's pilots considered joining the attendants' walk-out. But Denise C. Hedges, president of the attendants union urged them, instead, to stay on the job and picket in sympathy with the strikers during their time off.
"It was our own battle," Ms. Hedges said. "The battle was for respect, and that's what we'll carry away from this for the rest of our careers. I asked, 'Please don't strike with us.' "

HEADLINE: In California, a Lab for the Brady Bill, The Debate on Guns Has No Winner

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23

 BODY:
As looting and violence spread during last year's rioting, there was a near-riot at Art's Guns in suburban Canoga Park as scores of panicked people discovered they could not buy quick self-protection because of California's 15-day waiting period on gun sales.
At the same time, rioters were breaking into gun stores and pawn shops throughout Los Angeles and carting away what officials now estimate were thousands of weapons of all sorts. 
 It is an object lesson that Randy Linkmeyer, the proprietor of Art's Guns, puts forward when asked about the effect of waiting periods like the five-day hold on handguns included in the Brady bill, which is stalled in the Senate.
"Waiting periods don't work," said Mr. Linkmeyer, expressing a view common among gun owners. "Common criminals don't come into gun stores to buy their guns."
 
Waiting Period for Decades
 Or as Steve Helsley, a spokesman for the California office of the National Rifle Association, put it, "Waiting periods have to do with the good guys and crime has to do with the bad guys."
California has had some form of waiting period for decades, and its current 15-day wait, requiring a background check for the purchase of both handguns and long guns, is the strictest of any in the 22 states that now mandate a delay.
Its laws have made the state something of a laboratory during the years of debate over the Brady bill, which would be the first major Federal gun legislation in 25 years if enacted.
But like virtually everything else in the national struggle over gun control, California's experience has been far from conclusive and has provided ammunition for those on both sides of the issue.
"California has been studied extensively, and there is simply nowhere that we are able to point to a decreased crime rate as a result of restrictions on gun sales," said John Stoos, executive director of Gun Owners of California, a pro-gun lobbying group.
 
Effect Called 'Staggering'
 But backers of the waiting period, like Comdr. David Gascon of the Los Angeles Police Department, point out that the state turns down more than 5,000 applications for gun permits each year because the buyers are felons or mental patients or have been convicted of certain violent misdemeanors.
"The numbers, I think, are staggering," said Commander Gascon, a spokesman for the department, which like many police departments around the country strongly advocates gun control. "Those guns are being kept out of the hands of people who have the potential to really cause tremendous problems in our society."
Among applicants rejected last year after a check of state and Federal computerized crime files and mental health records were people who had committed 37 homicides, 102 sex crimes and seven kidnappings. On the other hand, opponents of the waiting period say, some of the rejections were mistakes and were reversed on appeal.
The background checks, carried out by the state Attorney General's office, involve filling out a document when buying a gun. The gun store then sends the information to Sacramento for a computerized check. Gun buyers return to pick up their guns 15 days later.
The state turned down 5,763 applications last year for permits for both handguns and long guns, but it approved the legal purchases of 553,845 firearms, said Denise Davis, a spokeswoman for the state Attorney General's office.
Some ineligible buyers beat the system by using false identification or by asking friends to buy guns for them. And as for the uncounted firearms that continue to flood the streets through theft or black market sales, Ms. Davis said, "They don't tell us when they go buy illegal weapons."
Indeed, said Rick Swanston, a Los Angeles homicide detective who supports the waiting period for whatever limited effect it may offer, "Most guns involved in crimes are not registered guns."
Commander Gascon acknowledged the huge black market in illegal weapons and said of the gun law: "Everyone has to realize that this is just one small piece of a large mosaic effort that we are trying to make to provide for safety and security in our society. There are always ways to get guns, and what we are doing is scrambling to try to reduce that."
At B & B Sales in North Hollywood, one of the area's biggest gun stores, where human silhouette targets decorate the walls along with posters for high-firepower movies like "The Wild Bunch," both salesmen and customers complained of being targets in a national controversy.
"They have to show the people that they are doing something about crime," said the store's chief executive, Bob Kahn, speaking of what he called a "socialistic" government in Washington. "So what do they do? 'Ah, the Brady bill is going to solve all our problems. Taking away guns is going to solve all our problems.' "
Here on the front lines, he said, the picture is more complex. The convenience store across the street has been held up so many times that people here call it the "Stop and Rob." And during the riots 18 months ago, B & B, like Art's Guns, was thronged with customers desperate to defend themselves.
"We had 200 people in the store waiting as much as three hours to purchase ammunition," Mr. Kahn said. Because of the required waiting period, collectors were passing around weapons to friends and neighbors.
Since then, he said, sales of weapons for self-defense have increased, partly fueled by a sense that illegal firearms have proliferated. "It's scary," he said. "You can buy anything on the street; you can buy heavy weapons."
He added, the riots very much on his mind, "What are you going to do when people with superior firepower come and attack your business or your home and law enforcement doesn't do anything about it?"
 
Guns as Collector's Items
 This week, there was a holiday feel to Mr. Kahn's showroom, with its orderly wall racks of long guns and attractively lighted glass cases of pistols. Signs reminded customers that because of the waiting period they must buy any Christmas weapons by Dec. 8.
"Some people collect porcelain; some collect guns," said a salesman as he rubbed a soft cloth over one of the semiautomatic handguns that, along with certain short-barreled pistols, are the most popular sellers these days. "For me, if you want to make me happy, buy me a gun."
Carroll Shelor, a 43-year-old college economics professor who said he already owned four guns, was here just for the pleasure of it, not to buy, he insisted, though he could not take his eyes off a Sig P-230 .380 caliber semiautomatic pistol, selling for $399.
"Sometimes I just get the itch to buy a gun," he said. "Guns are well-machined and they're fun to play with. To men, to some of us, they are kind of like jewelry, in a sense. They look good and they feel good, and they do appeal to that primal fantasy."

HEADLINE: The City's Budget: Better and Worse

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins's final report on the New York City budget shows him leaving office with a perfect score -- four balances in four years. Expected post-election spending cuts will not be needed to balance this year's books, he says. But in the same report he warns of looming deficit problems much larger than he estimated last summer.
So much for that perfect score, and welcome to City Hall, Mr. Giuliani. 
 Yes, Mr. Dinkins has balanced the budget every year. And it hasn't been easy, what with ever-increasing demands for city services, a crushing and persistent recession and unhelpful tightness in state and Federal aid. Moreover, he is not leaving an immediate crisis like the one he faced in January 1990, when plunging revenues forced him to make drastic spending cuts in his first month. With admirable restraint, he now resists temptation and pressure to inflate spending as he bows out.
Mayor-elect Rudolph Giuliani should be genuinely thankful his start-up will not be burdened by crisis frenzy, but he still must deal with coming deficits. Budget-balancing has been a precarious art in the Dinkins years -- one year at a time, never resolving the long-term problem of matching the city's spending with its revenue potential. As a consequence, Mr. Dinkins now sees $6.9 billion of red ink in the next three years, compared with the $5.1 billion he foresaw only three months ago.
Having lost the election, Mr. Dinkins could afford to publish more unvarnished facts about the city's fiscal dilemma than if it were still his to cope with. Thus his new projection of larger future deficits is roughly in line with existing forecasts by outside experts who keep close watch on the city's accounts, where previously he pretended the outlook was less dour than they said.
Forewarned by this consensus, Mr. Giuliani knows the dimensions of the problem he faces. Perhaps this information will even seep through to Albany, where his fellow Republicans have blocked the city's pleas for more help.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Time to Pull Up Your Socks, Puerto Rico

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I applaud your coverage of the referendum in Puerto Rico, I disagree with the premise of "Puerto Rico Chooses, for Now" (editorial, Nov. 16), that Congress has a responsibility to act on the results of that vote. Given a historical chance to define a permanent relationship with the nation of which they are citizens, the people of Puerto Rico chose not to decide and to cling to an arrangement that is not only colonial in nature but that is also inherently unsustainable. 
 The Federal Government is spending billions of dollars in direct transfers and on special tax provisions to prop up the Puerto Rican economy. While the expense was worth it when Puerto Rico was a strategic and ideological counterbalance to Cuba, that justification is no longer present. In an age of budget deficits and diminishing spending the taxpayers of the 50 states will no longer tolerate spending billions of dollars on people who do not pay Federal taxes.
Already this year Congress voted to begin phasing out the Section 936 program, which encourages United States corporations to relocate in Puerto Rico. Yet the people of Puerto Rico seem unwilling to face reality. Instead, they choose to accept the fallacy fed them by pro-commonwealth leaders that not only will they be able to keep their benefits but also that Congress will grant them additional benefits and even give the Puerto Rican government greater say over how Federal funds are spent than the state governments have. All this, without their assuming any of the responsibilities that citizenship normally entails.
One day they will find Congress has decided for them and declared the Republic of Puerto Rico. Standing with their empty pockets hanging out, wondering what went wrong, they will have no one to blame but themselves.
 
LESTER APONTE-PARSI
Redondo Beach, Calif., Nov. 16, 1993

HEADLINE: While We Lock Up More People, Street Violence Only Grows

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is dismaying when someone with the obvious intelligence and erudition of John DiIulio Jr. seriously proposes in "Save the Children" (Op-Ed, Nov. 13) that more police and jails, in whatever concentration or configuration, can help alleviate the crime problems of our cities. 
 It is as if he were unaware of the history of the last 20 years in which this country spent tens of billions of dollars on increasing its imprisoned population by 500 percent without any appreciable effect on the social disorder in our midst.
In New York, for example, the number of state inmates rose from 12,500 in 1973 to more than 64,000 today while the levels of lawlessness and drugs on our streets have only intensified.
The primary reason for the failure of the "lock 'em up" approach is that it is primarily a reactive strategy that comes only after the crime is committed and the damage is done. What is needed is more resources for the kinds of preventive measures, new and proven, that have been largely neglected by government since the early 1970's and that address the fundamental social and economic causes of criminal behavior.
Economic development programs that provide viable jobs, successful street academies that keep teen-agers in school, Head Start programs that support families and provide early childhood education and drug programs that treat people's criminogenic addictions would do much more to stabilize communities and save the children than any law-enforcement tactic.
Mr. DiIulio acknowledges that more police and jails are "Band-Aid" responses. In that case, let us turn to more potent remedies, ones that deal directly with the basic social and economic deficiencies plaguing our cities.
 
ROBERT GANGI
Executive Director, Correctional
Association of New York
New York, Nov. 15, 1993

HEADLINE: Up for Auction: The Cooking Tips Of a Duchess

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
JUST when we thought they'd been totally forgotten, they're back.
Amy and Joey? 
 No. Wallis and Edward.
You remember them, Wallis Warfield Simpson, the Baltimore divorcee, and Edward VIII, the King of England. Also known as the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.
For a time they were the world's most romantic couple. Fifty-seven years ago next month, the English-speaking world huddled around radios to hear Edward, who had just quit the throne, intone in a reedy voice that he could no longer carry on "without the help and support of the woman I love."
She was often characterized as a relentless social climber and he as a rather dim bulb. But to millions of people trapped in the grip of the Depression, people who had nothing, the spectacle of someone who had everything giving it up for a woman was immensely romantic.
Why was he so crazy about her?
Could it have been her cooking?
Don't laugh. On Dec. 10, Sotheby's in New York will offer for sale "My Personal Cookbook" by, yes, the Duchess herself. The manuscript, for that is as far as the project got, is part of a collection of Windsor memorabilia being put up for sale by the auction house. Sotheby's hopes to make some $8,000 on the cookbook alone.
Interested in whipping up a Gateau Egyptian? The recipe is here. A fresh Salade Russe, perhaps? The Duchess will guide you, step by step.
Never mind that Gateau Egyptian is a sponge cake slathered with blackberry jelly, or that Salade Russe is carrots and peas with mayonnaise. How often does one get to eat something dreamed up by a duchess?
The recipes, such as they are, come sandwiched between reminiscences of girlish culinary adventures back in Baltimore and heart-warming glimpses of ducal domesticity in Paris, New York and other Windsor watering holes.
"When we're in Florida," the Duchess confides, "I enjoy lap lunches in the car." There was a supermarket next door to her reducing salon and, she says, "I cannot resist it."
"Regularly," she goes on, "I find myself buying a package of cold meat, salami usually, smoked cheese, biscuits and a cellophane bag of striped peppermint balls, upon which I lunch happily during my ride home."
The Duchess pulled together this culinary potpourri sometime in 1958. It began as a series of articles for The American Weekly, a Sunday newspaper supplement. At one point the Duchess acknowledges that The Weekly's "home economists" tested all her recipes and worked "long and hard" to simplify them.
In many instances, she said, these experts suggested "canned, frozen and bottled products, available in American supermarkets," which could save "time and energy." Just like the stuff she picked up in Delray Beach, Fla.
As all dedicated Windsor watchers will recall, Wallis and Edward kept a home in the Bois de Boulogne in Paris and a country place, the Moulin de la Tuilerie, about two hours southwest of the city at a town called Gif-sur-Yvette. They had a French chef and a kitchen staff, their own gardens and access to the best French markets.
Here is the Duchess of Windsor on that beneficence. "I wonder often," she ruminates, "if American housewives appreciate their good fortune in having so many excellent frozen foods? In France, these foods are few and expensive. Inevitably this must change -- when electric refrigeration becomes more general.
"In our household," she continues, "I have waged a long fight in behalf of frozen foods. When I used to suggest to our cook that he make more use of our freezer, he would protest, 'Why, Madame? I have only to walk six blocks to get something fresh.' "
There are fanatics who travel to France for the butter. Experts can tell the source of a kilo of butter by looking at it. Any respectable Parisian merchant who deals in butter, eggs and cheese will offer 10 or more different types of butter. Yet, the Duchess, apparently inured to France's bounty, was happy to get her butter shipped in from overseas.
"Dearest Anita," writes the Duchess from her country place. "I can't thank you enough for the five tins of butter. Please tell us how much I owe you for it -- I cannot accept it as a present really, otherwise I could never ask you to send us any more."
The Duke involved himself in the project, scratching out a word here, adding one there, occasionally doing minor damage to the Duchess's already shaky grammar.
She wrote: "All new dishes, incidentally, are served first to the Duke and me when we dine alone."
He made it: "All new dishes, incidentally, are tried out first by the Duke and I when we dine alone."
But he was not a dedicated food person, preferring more intellectual pursuits. "I have a collection of cookbooks," she discloses, "which I read as avidly as the Duke, who will never shake the sand out of his shoes, reads the National Geographic."
It would appear that the worldly Mrs. Simpson was eager to show the Prince, whom she called David, her domestic side early on. Preparing to write her articles, she came across "a folder of recipes tied together with a bit of pink cord, the cover of which was marked 'Salads. Nov. 1934.' "
"This," she writes, "I had fixed, at the Duke's request, for his cook at the Fort, his country house at Sunningdale. The cook, I suspect, was not too pleased at a woman 'interfering.' But I can still see David's warm smile."
Turning philosophical -- or perhaps just planning ahead -- she muses, "It is not a simple matter for any bachelor to run a house, even though he be a Prince with a staff to serve him."
Edward was the Prince of Wales when they met. He became Edward VIII on the death of his father, George V, and Duke of Windsor after his abdication.
In later years, the ducal pair often gave buffet suppers. "The buffet," she wrote, "is the most fun party."
A typical Windsor buffet included a cold lobster mousse with Sauce Liberal, hot curried eggs, the old dependable Salade Russe and the tricky Gateau Egyptian.
The Sauce Liberal may have had something to do with the fun.
The Duchess's recipe:
"Mix into good mayonnaise enough catsup to colour the mayonnaise a pale pink. Add Worcestershire sauce, lemon juice and heavy fresh cream to taste.
"Lastly, add a good quantity of gin."
 
Three Recipes Fit for a King
 Following are three recipes, exactly as written, from "My Personal Cookbook," by the Duchess of Windsor.
 
 Sole Demi-Deuil
 (Sole in Half Mourning)
Poach fillets of sole in white wine with juice of lemon.
Place in oven for 10 minutes in a Pyrex dish.
Make a cream sauce with: 750 grams of butter, 50 grams flour, 1/4 liter milk, 1/4 liter heavy cream, 1 juice of lemon, 1 yolk of egg and some of the sole bouillon.
Place the fillets of sole on a long dish, cover with cream sauce, and recover with caviar the surface. Place around the fillets tartelettes of caviar. Serve very hot.
 
Avocado Pears Tahiti
Cut the avocados in half, allowing one half to a person.
Remove pit.
Fill center with rum slightly flavored with brown sugar.
Serve on ice.
 
 Gateau Egyptian
Make a light sponge cake that is fairly deep.
Scoop out the center.
Cover the outside of the cake with cold blackberry jelly. It is sometimes advisable to melt the jelly first so it will spread smoothly.
Fill the center with whipped cream flavored subtly with vanilla.
When ready to serve, pour hot blackberry jelly over the whole.

HEADLINE: 2 Large Companies Make Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Two blue-chip American corporations -- Philip Morris, the tobacco and food company, and NCR, the computer unit of A.T.& T. -- announced yesterday that they planned to cut their payrolls by a total of as many as 21,500 workers, or as much as 8 percent at Philip Morris and 15 percent at NCR.
To be sure, the two cutback announcements are separate cases, but both underscore corporate America's determination to remain competitive through retrenchment, despite a gradually improving economy. 
 Philip Morris Companies Inc. is under pressure to pare back as sales from its old-line business of cigarettes erode in the face of health concerns and changing life styles. Company officials announced a plan yesterday to eliminate 14,000 jobs in the next three years. [Page D17.]
The NCR Corporation is struggling to reduce costs as it moves to advanced microchip technology. NCR officials said yesterday that an early retirement program would be offered to 25,000 employees, or nearly half the company's work force, to achieve a cut of 7,500 jobs. [Page D17.]
 
Goal of Increased Productivity
 Yet the rationale behind the moves at Philip Morris and NCR is similar in key respects. Both companies are making the cuts in the name of streamlining, faster decision-making and increased productivity -- doing the work with fewer employees. And the job losses will be across-the-board, as likely to hit white-collar management staff as blue-collar factory workers.
"These are strategic or structural cutbacks, and not really related to the economy," said Eric Greenberg, director of management studies at the American Management Assocation, a management-education organization. "And that's why these cutbacks are continuing even though the economy is getting stronger."
Indeed, the seemingly relentless wave of big-company cutbacks is likely to continue. "I don't see that we're at the end of this yet," Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said. "It's a fact of economic life."
 
Much Attrition Inevitable
 In an interview, Mr. Reich said that despite an economy that has added 1.4 million jobs since the start of the year, much attrition of employment at large companies was inevitable.
Two forces prompting the trend, Mr. Reich said, are increased global competition and the advance of computer technology, which has reduced the need for layers of middle management in large corporations because much of their role was gathering, analyzing and dispersing information -- tasks made easier and less labor-intensive by personal computers.
As a third reason for cutbacks, Mr. Reich cited increased pressure on corporate boards by big institutional investors. In the last two years, the big investment funds, like employee pension funds, have prodded several poorly performing companies to make changes in their top management, including those at General Motors and I.B.M.
"Chief executives are under the gun today more than ever before to eke out greater profits and cutting the payroll is the easiest way for an executive to try to increase short-term profits," Mr. Reich said.
 
Job Creation 'A Low Priority'
 Even within the business community, there are critics of such work force cutbacks. Corporate America's penchant for slicing payrolls, they say, is a management fad that began logically enough but has been carried to extremes, like the takeover frenzy of the 1980's.
"Job creation is being given a low priority by a lot of corporate executives today," said Robert Tomasko of Arthur D. Little Inc., a management consulting firm. "Now what you're applauded for is doing work with fewer people."
While lifting productivity should be management's goal, Mr. Tomasko and other analysts caution that cutting the payroll can backfire, by lowering employee morale. The intent of most so-called downsizing or re-engineering programs is to help reduce bureaucracy and foster a more entrepreneurial environment. But a work force fearful of the next round of layoffs, analysts warn, is not apt to take risks or become more creative.
"Fear is not the handmaiden of innovation," Mr. Reich said.
 
Shrinkage at Big Corporations
 The payroll shrinkage at big companies is a trend that has been underway for years. Employment at the Fortune 500 industrial companies reached a peak of 16.3 million people in 1979 and has since declined steadily, to 11.8 million last year.
Employment growth has come instead from small companies, whose additions to the nation's work force typically come in small increments of a few at a time, little noticed but significant in the aggregate.
"The jobs that are created get a lot more attention than the cutbacks," Steven Davis, an economist at the University of Chicago's graduate school of business, said. "Maybe our economy doesn't adjust to these cutbacks as well as we'd like, but the American economy is generating new jobs all the time and it does adjust."
Still, the big-company cuts have contributed to the numbers of people, often from 35 years old to 50, who are having difficulty finding jobs. Mr. Reich noted that the number of people permanently laid off has climbed since 1986 to 2.2 million, and the number of people unemployed for six months or more is higher now than in late 1991, when the economy started to come out of recession.
"These cutbacks at big companies have clearly added to our endemic problem of structural unemployment," he said.

HEADLINE: Cool, Astute Leader Takes Flight Union to Victory

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 24

 BODY:
As Denise C. Hedges steered into the parking lot of a hotel where the press anxiously awaited her, the engine of her corroded 1985 Renault died. As president of the 21,000-member union of American Airlines flight attendants, she had a news conference beginning in minutes.
But there was no panic, no curses, no pounding on the steering wheel. "Would you push me into that parking space?" Mrs. Hedges asked her two passengers, as calmly as if she had been following the flight attendants training manual. Then she went on to a meeting with the press that came off as smoothly as beverage service in first class. 
 Whether it's a showdown with Robert L. Crandall of American Airlines, the industry's toughest executive, or any other crisis, more than two patient decades of experience as a flight attendant have taught Mrs. Hedges how to respond.
In Denise Hedges, organized labor has a new face very different from that of the traditional, smokestack union boss. The service economy places most of its servants beyond the orbit of the shrinking factory unions. No wonder that, as labor leaders call to congratulate Mrs. Hedges, many also ask her advice.
 
Some Good News
 "They demonstrated that there is a payoff to organizing," said Frank H. Joyce, a spokesman for the United Auto Workers. "All the news is not bad."
Once President Clinton brokered an agreement between striking attendants and American Airlines management on Monday to submit their dispute to arbitration, Mrs. Hedges found that preparing for further talks and getting her members back to work after their five-day walkout left little time to give lessons to other unions. Today, she met with Mr. Crandall, the airline's chairman, and the leaders of the airline's other unions, joined them in issuing a letter urging calm and then rushed to catch a flight home to see her husband and three children in Colorado Springs, Colo., for the first time in about a month.
But once Mrs. Hedges, 46, catches her breath, she is likely to have pointers like these:
First, keep the public on your side.
When Ronald Reagan fired the striking air traffic controllers in 1981, many travelers cheered his determination to keep the airports running. When the machinists pursued their strike against Frank Lorenzo's Eastern Airlines in 1989, few travelers mourned the airline's eventual demise.
But Mrs. Hedges never made her union's strike a personal vendetta against Mr. Crandall. Even off the record, her language is no stronger than for, say, someone back in 28F who refuses to restore his tray table to its full upright position.
Publicly, Mr. Crandall was left griping about the airline's high costs while union members pointed to grueling schedules and an average pay of $23,000. Few travelers were outraged at the flight attendants for walking off the job at the airline's busiest time of year; instead, more seemed to vent their anger at the airline itself.
 
No Bubbleheads
 Flight attendants, you see, are trained to be nice. No end of novels and films portray them as bubble heads, but many, including Mrs. Hedges, have college degrees (Southern Methodist University, anthropology). And in any popularity contest, who wouldn't put flight attendants way ahead of airline executives and labor lawyers?
Second, know your members.
Mrs. Hedges became president of a badly divided Association of Professional Flight Attendants in April 1992 on a platform of ending the power struggles among union factions whose quarrels were often as much personal as substantive. Then she rallied her members for a first-ever strike -- which threatened to cost them their jobs -- by talking their issues: pay, scheduling, staffing and health benefits.
"She understands flight attendants," said Alan Fahringer, a member of her negotiating team. "They are people pleasers. They like to fix things. They don't like to argue. Flight attendants don't really want to be mad at their boss."
 
Lack of Faith
 Third, let management underestimate you.
American Airlines did not begin to train replacements until Monday, five days into the strike. "They felt we couldn't pull a strike off," Mrs. Hedges said. "They thought the organization wasn't solidified."
Ninety percent to 95 percent of American's flight attendants stayed off the job, the union said. The airline said the strike cost it $10 million to $15 million a day. Some planes, without cabin attendants, flew empty; other flights were simply canceled.
Jane G. Allen, American's chief negotiator, said that 30 percent of the attendants showed up, but added, "It was more than American predicted." She said the company held back from training replacements to avoid antagonizing the attendants and other unions, but now has some regrets.
"We felt our reward for acting in good faith was a strike of a level that inconvenienced our customers," she said. "It certainly would have been better for our customers if we'd had thousands of replacements on the property."
 
Enhanced Rapport
 Ms. Allen said that facing another woman across the negotiating table improved rapport, "but it certainly didn't help on the issues."
And finally, make new friends, especially in Washington.
Mrs. Hedges and her aides have spent months quietly arguing their cause, sometimes a step ahead of American's lobbyists. By the time the President called her on Monday, she knew that he supported her on the need for binding arbitration. Mr. Crandall, American's chairman, has dined at the White House, but this was a Democratic Administration, and one that had just left its labor allies smarting in defeat on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The only public signs of tension that Mrs. Hedges permits herself are her Marlboro Lights, and these she tries to avoid before the cameras.
 
Family Help
 Her husband and three children have also helped ease the strain, and sometimes offered counsel. After her union's board and members had voted to let her call a strike, she hesitated, then phoned her 17-year-old daughter, Dawn. "The members have put their faith in you," her daughter told her. "You're not in it alone.
In her 23 years as an American flight attendant, Mrs. Hedges has held several union offices; some have restricted her flying time. But she had to resume flying full-time, signing up for as much extra duty as she could manage, when her husband, a computer-software engineer in the defense industry, suffered a spell of unemployment. She continued flying until March 1992, the month before she became president at a salary of $48,000.
She met her husband, Dave, in Stamford, Conn., where she grew up and returned, teaching as a substitute to supplement her flight attendant pay. When she began working for American nearly a quarter-century ago, pregnancy, marriage or a 32d birthday meant mandatory retirement.
Now a flight attendant can make a career of it, Mrs. Hedges said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Denise C. Hedges, left, president of the American Airlines flight attendants' union, in the office of the Association of Professional Flight Attendants yesterday in Dallas. She greeted Janet Wallace, a flight attendant, after meeting with the leaders of the airline's other unions. (Mark Graham for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: S. C. Tsiang, an Economist, 75; Helped Guide Taiwan's Economy

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
S. C. Tsiang, an emeritus professor of economics at Cornell University and a principal architect of Taiwan's economic miracle died on Oct. 21 in Chicago. He was 75
He had suffered a series of strokes, his family said. 
 Sho-chieh Tsiang, a naturalized American citizen, was born to a wealthy diplomatic family in Shanghai in 1918.
He studied economics at the London School of Economics in World War II and returned to China briefly to teach and work in the Chinese Central Bank. When the Communists came to power in 1949, Professor Tsiang fled to the United States, where he joined the International Monetary Fund.
 
Persuaded Taiwan on Exports
 He helped shape the modern theory of how open economies work in a global framework. In the 1960's, he was a professor of economics at the University of Rochester. In 1969, he joined the faculty at Cornell and remained there until retiring in 1985. He was a pioneer in the theory of money flows and exchange-rate markets.
But his great life's work lay in persuading the Taiwan Government in the 1960's and 1970's to adopt a free-market export-led strategy that eventually helped turned Taiwan into one the world's miracle economies.
In the 1960's, when trade protection and self-sufficiency were the vogue in the developing world, Professor Tsiang promoted reliance on foreign trade. And at a time when many economists thought that governments in poor nations had to weild a heavy hand, Professor Tsiang favored low taxes and argued that markets should determine interest and exchange rates -- precisely what economists advocate in Eastern Europe today.
"My father was an iconoclast," said his daughter Grace Tsiang, an economist at the University of Chicago. "He was advocating policies contrary to the Keynesian consensus of the time."
Fond of quoting Mencius and other Chinese philosophers, Professor Tsiang's favorite parable -- which he used to express his laissez-faire views of economic development -- was the story of the impatient farmer who was so determined to make his crops grow that he tugged and tugged on his sprouts until he pulled them out of the ground and killed them. The good farmer, by contrast, cultivated his crops and then let them alone to grow.
 
Led Taipei Institute
 After retiring from Cornell, Professor Tsiang served as president of the independent Chung-Hwa Institute for Economic Research in Taipei until becoming ill about a year ago.
Robert Lucas, an economist at the University of Chicago, said: "He was an extremely soft-spoken, scholarly man, the last person in the world you'd think of arguing with government officials. But he was forceful in a quiet way. He had a lot of inner confidence."
Professor Tsiang is survived by his wife, Hsi-tsin Tsiang, three daughters, Katherine Mino, Christina Shorr and Grace Tsiang, and five grandchildren. A memorial service was held in Taipei on Nov. 16.
