HEADLINE: Councilman's Mayoral Victory in Atlanta Is a Break With the Past

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 24

 BODY:
City Councilman Bill Campbell won the runoff election for Atlanta mayor on Tuesday, swamping his opponent and becoming the first black mayor in 20 years with neither deep roots in the city's civil rights community nor celebrity status drawn from it.
Mr. Campbell, a 40-year-old lawyer, defeated Michael L. Lomax, the former chairman of the Fulton County Commission, by 48,600 votes to 18,155, or 73 percent to 27 percent. Mr. Campbell had come within 800 votes of winning outright in the Nov. 2 general election. 
Even though Mr. Campbell never trailed in polling before the general election or runoff, the gap between him and Mr. Lomax in the final tally was wider than most observers had expected. Some political analysts attributed the large margin more to the negative public image of Mr. Lomax, who is also black, than to the positive image of Mr. Campbell.
Mr. Lomax, a former English professor and the administrator of a chain of funeral homes, said Tuesday night that his campaign had been hurt by his unfair image as a tax raiser. As chairman of the county that includes much of the city of Atlanta, Mr. Lomax in 1991 oversaw a property reassessment that sent some tax bills soaring, but the reassessment was required by law.
 
Lamenting Tax Image
 "I could not get away from that issue," Mr. Lomax told supporters, "and it provided a noise level which I could never break through."
William H. Boone, a professor of political science at Clark Atlanta University, said many black voters consider Mr. Lomax aloof. They also remain angry at him for his short-lived, negative campaign against Mayor Maynard H. Jackson in 1989, Professor Boone said. Blacks make up 68 percent of the city's voters.
Referring to the wide margin of victory, Mr. Campbell said at a victory celebration on Tuesday night, "I never would have imagined that we would have the mandate that we have tonight." He said he was not sure he could fill the shoes of predecessors like former Mayor Andrew Young and Mayor Jackson, who did not seek another term.
"But if I can make Atlanta a safer city," Mr. Campbell added, "if I can improve the schools, provide better economic development, then people may say I've been a good mayor as well."
During the campaign, Mr. Campbell hammered home a message of reducing crime, holding the line on taxes and making government more efficient. At the same time, he skillfully countered attacks from Mr. Lomax, who tried to link him to corruption at the city's airport. A council member and a former council member have been indicted and a businessman has been convicted in a scheme involving kickbacks from vendors at the airport.
After his defeat, Mr. Lomax's political future is in doubt after 14 years in public life, but supporters like State Representative Tyrone Brooks predicted that he would return to public life.
Professor Boone said Mr. Campbell, who had represented a downtown council district since 1981, now faced the daunting task of winning the confidence of the city's largely white business establishment. Mr. Campbell, unlike Mr. Lomax, is largely an unknown to the business leaders.
The fact that Mayor Jackson endorsed Mr. Campbell and was among his most vigorous supporters would help some, Professor Boone said, who added, "But in large measure he will have to show them on his own on such things as administration of the troubled airport, keeping his promise not to raise taxes, cutting crime and addressing the city's infrastructure problems."
Alan Secrest, a political consultant and pollster who worked for the Campbell campaign, noted that the victory was one that drew from racially and economically diverse groups in the city and as such would have a unifying effect. That, he said, "gives Bill Campbell the wind at his back" as he prepares to take office on Jan. 3.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Campbell, center, being congratulated by supporters on Tuesday night after winning the runoff election for Mayor of Atlanta. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Now Turns to Soothing the Europeans

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
After weeks of declaring that the United States would increase its attention to the fast-growing markets of Asia and Latin America, the Clinton Administration is trying to mend fences with Europe.
In what could be viewed as the diplomatic equivalent of sending roses after a spat, Secretary of State Warren Christopher invited a group of European journalists in for interviews on Monday in which he stressed the crucial role Europe still has in American foreign policy. Though he did not retreat from earlier statements that Washington is at times too focused on Europe, Mr. Christopher, sounding like the lawyer he is, said he did not mean to "derogate" Europe. 
 Europe, Mr. Christopher told the reporters, "remains at the center of our concerns and our alliances."
The invitations to the eight journalists were made last week even as President Clinton and Mr. Christopher attended a meeting in Seattle of leaders of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and stressed that America's most important trade ties were across the Pacific, not the Atlantic.
Even before the Pacific summit meeting, Mr. Christopher had suggested in an interview that Europe's importance in world affairs was diminishing and that Washington had been too "Eurocentric" in its foreign policy. "Western Europe is no longer the dominant power in the world," Mr. Christopher said in an interview last month.
Mr. Christopher's comments caused a storm across the Atlantic -- at least if headlines are any guide. And while unapologetic about them on Monday, he tried to soothe ruffled feathers, reminding the journalists that Mr. Clinton is due to visit Europe at least three times in the first seven months of 1994.
"I wouldn't exactly call it a charm offensive, but it was an attempt at reassurance," said Jurek Martin, the Washington bureau chief of The Financial Times of London, who attended the interview session for newspaper and magazine reporters.
"For months they've been saying that Europe is almost irrelevant," said another reporter. "That message has been received so much in Europe that it has come to the point that it is damaging their policy. I guess they figured it's time to do some kind of gesture."
The gesture comes a week before Mr. Christopher is to travel to Brussels for the semiannual meeting of the North Atlantic Council, the political arm of NATO, and to Rome for the meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The interviews marked the first time that either the President or Mr. Christopher had sat down for an extended session with reporters from Europe.
The journalists said the Secretary had also gone out of his way to be diplomatic. He declined, for instance, to criticize Germany for reportedly shipping nuclear technology to Iran. And despite the differences with France over world trade talks in Geneva, he told the reporter from Le Figaro that America's relationship with France is "so much broader" than disagreements over trade.
 
Europeans Deny Any Rift
 For their part, European diplomats are eager to knock down any idea of a rift running across the Atlantic or of shrinkage in Europe's economic importance to America. A Western European diplomat said that despite the statements about how much more trade moves across the Pacific than across the Atlantic, if one removes Canada from the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the figures are comparable. And as an Administration official said, the United States is running a modest trade surplus with Western Europe.
A diplomat said direct American investment in Europe is $239 billion. Direct United States investment in Asia Pacific forum countries -- again, once Canada is removed -- is $78 billion.
Still, in his talk with the European journalists, Mr. Christopher reiterated that the Administration sees the potential growth in American trade as coming from Asia and not Western Europe. "The primacy of opportunity for the United States in Asia is a statement of fact," Mr. Christopher said.

HEADLINE: Mubarak and King Hussein End a Chilly Standoff

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov 24

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak met officially with King Hussein of Jordan today, formally ending a three-year rift that began when the King refused to support the coalition effort to drive Iraqi occupiers out of Kuwait.
"I am happy to be here to visit Egypt and return as we were so we can discuss the important issues in this delicate period," King Hussein told reporters after the meeting. 
 The visit, the first official meeting between the King and the President since the days immediately after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, was held to discuss the peace talks with Israel. But its significance stemmed from the fact that the two pro-Western leaders once again agreed to work together on regional issues.
Senior Egyptian officials said Mr. Mubarak is working behind the scenes to bring a reconciliation between the Jordanian and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who has demanded an apology from King Hussein for his pro-Iraqi stance during the Persian Gulf war.
Asked if his meeting meant that normal relations had been resumed between Jordan and Egypt, King Hussein said, "Yes, this is my feeling."
 
'There Is No Problem'
 The President agreed. "There is no problem as long as there are visits and contacts," he said. "I think normal relations are necessary. Our contacts have never been cut and coordination continued. As you remember, the Egyptian Foreign Minister visited Jordan several times and there is no problem."
The meeting was one more step toward Jordan's readmittance into the camp of pro-western Arab states. Jordan, like Egypt, is battling to contain Islamic fundamentalism. Amman also desperately needs backing by Western nations like the United States, which briefly suspended economic aid to Jordan following the gulf war.
The resumption of good relations with Egypt may further the King's push to build bridges with the gulf states, which still feel betrayed by Jordan's support of Iraq in the 1991 war.
Saudi Arabia, which once gave Jordan $500 million a year in aid, is still withholding aid and has closed its markets to Jordanian produce, and Kuwait has rebuffed all efforts to open negotiations with King Hussein.
 
'Saudis Willing to Listen'
 "The Saudis are at least willing to listen," said a Western diplomat who follows the negotiations. "But for the Kuwaitis it is personal. They have written off the King."
The Egyptian and Jordanian leaders shifted uncomfortably when they first sat for photographers on either end of a couch in the presidential palace. But after the talks they appeared more relaxed. The King left for Amman immediately after the meeting.
In August 1991 the Jordanian Government issued a paper explaining its role in the war. The paper excoriated Mr. Mubarak for leading the Arab coalition that sent drove the Iraqis from Kuwait, saying he had sabotaged a peaceful solution to the crisis. The accusations triggered angry retorts between the two governments.
Relations began to thaw a year ago when the King visited Cairo after an earthquake and briefly met the President informally. The King also backed away from his previous support for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and issued a statement calling on Iraqis to establish a democracy.
As the peace talks between Israel, the Palestinians and the Arab states gained momentum, Mr. Mubarak and King Hussein began to consult by telephone, aides said. The phone contacts led to today's meeting.

HEADLINE: U.N. to Expand Street Patrols in Mogadishu

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Nov. 24

 BODY:
With bandit attacks on civilians becoming more frequent, United Nations military officials have agreed to put more soldiers on the streets to protect their workers despite misgivings that their presence might provoke confrontations with Somali militiamen.
Officials from the political and military wings of the United Nations in Somalia agreed today that, whenever available, armoured personnel carriers should escort civilian personnel. 
 "It's been discussed at high levels and decided that we need more military helping civilians," said Jonathan T. Howe, the United Nations special representative to Somalia.
The decision was the first acknowledgement that the capital has become increasingly treacherous since soldiers have stopped patrolling. At the urging of the United States, United Nations forces have adopted a lower profile while efforts to calm and rebuild the city through diplomacy are under way.
While a cease-fire between United Nations forces and the militia of Mohammed Farah Aidid has brought greater security for peacekeepers, civilians are increasingly plagued by bandit attacks.
On Tuesday an American with the United Nations aid mission was shot and wounded when her unmarked vehicle was set upon on the road to United Nations headquarters. Two weeks ago an American United Nations worker, Kai Lincoln, was shot and killed by bandits trying to steal his car.

HEADLINE: Lima Journal;
Dictator? President? Or General Manager of Peru?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Pen and paper at the ready, Peru's mathematician-turned-President likes to make quick calculations. For an American visitor Tuesday night, he calculated that Peru's toll of 22,000 dead in 13 years of civil strife equals 250,000 dead in the United States.
"I am sure that with so many dead in your country, people would have demanded emergency measures," said President Alberto K. Fujimori, who seized emergency powers and shut down courts and Congress last year in the name of fighting Peru's Maoist guerrillas. 
 "You have to live in this mess of problems to understand," he said. "It is harder to understand in Washington than in Ayacucho," the cradle of the Shining Path guerrilla movement.
Twenty months after the "Fuji coup," Peru has a new Congress, a new Constitution and a monthly inflation rate that is lower than Chile's. Guerrilla violence has sharply declined, and Abimael Guzman, the Shining Path leader, is in a jail cell pleading for peace talks
Peru's 55-year-old President, now one of Latin America's most popular -- and most criticized -- politicians, said he had no regrets.

 
Here Comes Charm
"There is no question about the legitimacy of this Government," said Mr. Fujimori, who won a close referendum vote last month on his new Constitution. It was the third round of voting in the country since the April 1992 coup, a fact that Mr. Fujimori likes to cite when critics describe Peru as a dictatorship.
Although American businessmen are now packing Lima hotels to explore investment opportunities, some officials in Washington are reluctant to forgive a President who dissolves a Congress.
To bridge the gap, Peru's President has dusted off the American English he learned 20 years ago as a graduate student in mathematics in Wisconsin and has opened a campaign to charm skeptics and detractors.
Just last week, the President said in an interview in the Presidential Palace, he took Lewis Preston, president of the World Bank, by helicopter to a Quechua Indian town that had been controlled by guerrillas until last year.
"We just went in without any soldiers," he said with a chuckle. "We can go a lot of places now without security."
Now Mr. Preston is backing World Bank loans for a two-year, $500 million public works spending program. Half the money is to be channeled to impoverished Andean highland areas like Ayacucho.

 
Next Objective: U.S. Congress

President Fujimori's next target is a delegation of American Congressmen expected to come here in January. English-language videotapes extolling the achievements of Mr. Fujimori's two-year-old Government are stacked on a side table in his office.
Human rights groups charge that Peru's human rights record has been abysmal since Mr. Fujimori abolished procedural safeguards in the 1992 coup. The Peruvian military is suspected in mysterious "disappearances" in several towns and villages; accused prisoners are often held incommunicado.
"I am a very patient man," said the President, when asked about American congressional objections to human rights violations here. "With the Clinton Administration, we do not have many misunderstandings."
The trail to Mr. Fujimori's office leads down drafty, semi-lit corridors that testify to Peru's political and cultural tensions and diversity -- Spanish colonial carriages gathering dust in a corner; a neo-Versailles "Golden Room" decorated in the 1930's; a modern mural depicting ancient Indians sacrificing captives.
Departing from the pomp and flourish of his predecessors, , Mr. Fujimori received his visitors at the head of a board room table in a spare office, without any advisers present.
Dressed in a dark blue business suit, the 55-year-old President described himself as the country's "general manager."
"The person who manages the state is me," said Mr. Fujimori, when asked if he was "a loner." Two of his goals are to be re-elected in 1995 and to steer Peru into the North American Free Trade Agreement in the late 1990's.
"I make 50 telephone calls a day," he said, adding that he detests cabinet meetings and state dinners.
Two hours of free-ranging conversation were interrupted only by telephone calls from his daughter, who needed help with her school homework in an adjoining office.
But Mr. Fujimori seemed less relaxed when prodded about his Government's progress in investigating the July 1992 slayings of nine students and a professor from Cantuta University in Lima who were suspected of being members of the Shining Path.
Human rights campaigners charge that an army commando unit carried out the slayings under the orders of Mr. Fujimori's national security adviser, Vladimir Montesinos.
"Cantuta will be cleared up," Mr. Fujimori said tersely. He said that some soldiers had been arrested, including an army major, Martin Rivas.

 
Authoritarian, and Proud of It
The President seems nonetheless to take pride in his reputation as an authoritarian.
During the talk, he leafed through the text of an interview with him published this month in a Brazilian news weekly, Istoe. The headline read: "For President Fujimori, Other Latin American Countries Will Follow Peru's Example -- and Traditional Democracies Will End Up in the Garbage Heap."
"Even if the media give the news in a way that is not positive, I feel that people are very sympathetic to Peru's Government," said Mr. Fujimori, who has visited Bolivia, Brazil, Chile and Paraguay since July. "I sense this in several South American countries."
Informed that 43 percent of the respondents in a recent Brazilian opinion survey said that democracy was not "fundamental," Mr. Fujimori replied, "In countries with political and social instability, where people are tired of manipulation by politicians, they look at Fujimori as a man who broke the establishment with one blow."

HEADLINE: When Security Becomes a Struggle;
Demand Is Acute as Neediest Cases Fund Begins 82d Appeal

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
A year ago, Anthony G. Brown and his son, Charles, shared a spacious two-bedroom apartment with a terrace on the top floor of a brownstone in the North Bronx. The $700-a-month rent was comfortably within Mr. Brown's reach as a presentations specialist, a clerical job at the brokerage firm of Shearson Lehman Brothers, where he had worked for two years.
Then came a corporate downsizing and another dip in the Northeast's relentless recession, leading to a pink slip for Mr. Brown in November 1992. Regular income gave way to spotty checks from temporary jobs. Within months, the roomy apartment was a memory, replaced by four rooms in public housing. 
 By the end of April, Mr. Brown learned that he and his son would lose even their modest rooms unless they came up with $270 for two months' back rent.
"Thinking about getting my hands on $270 was like thinking about $5,000 used to be," Mr. Brown said, shaking his head. The eviction notice put them less than 72 hours from being homeless.
For Mr. Brown, who had been employed all of his adult life and was within three credit hours of completing an associate's degree at night school, "It was unthinkable."
He added, "I wasn't the kind of person this sort of thing was supposed to happen to."
 
Men With Empty Attache Cases
 Mr. Brown, 31, had found himself among a growing number of New York City residents who once seemed, on paper at least, to be a safe distance from poverty and homelessness but now appear with greater frequency at overburdened social-service agencies. As the count of the city's needy has grown to nearly 1.1 million, agency officials say, more have middle-class roots.
"Every morning, men are leaving middle-class neighborhoods with an attache case empty except for a bag lunch, because they don't want the neighbors to know they're unemployed," said Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
Increasingly, entry into the ranks of the newly poor has been marked by eviction notices. In 1991, the Community Service Society of New York provided emergency money to rescue 224 tenants from eviction, and turned away 200 more when its money ran out. Last year, the agency stopped 143 evictions, and 415 cases went begging. This year, there was only enough money to block 115 evictions, and 919 cases were turned away.
"We've seen people going from $600- and $800-a-month apartments to rooms, and they can't even afford the rooms," said Sanford Lewis, an administrator who helps oversee the society's eviction-prevention program. "Now we are also seeing people who are five and six months behind, while it used to be only one or two months of arrears a couple of years ago."
Karen Norden, a social worker for the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, said requests for help at her agency grew 40 percent from July 1992 to June 1993, and a "good portion" of the 1,350 pleas involved people who had lost their jobs or seen their hours drastically reduced after years of steady employment.
"They've never been in this situation before and they just don't know what to do," she said.
Such anecdotal evidence comes on top of statistics showing a 7 percent increase in the number of homeless families in city shelters; a similar rise in those depending on public assistance, and an 8 percent increase in demand for food stamps.
In the midst of this cycle, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 82d annual appeal on Sunday. The campaign will collect donations to be given directly to seven of the city's largest charities, including the Community Service Society and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.
 
A City of Extremes
 The Neediest Cases appeal was born in 1912. Then, as now, New York was a city of striking extremes of wealth and poverty. On Christmas Day in 1911, that contrast troubled Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The Times, after he gave a beggar money for shelter and new clothes.
Mr. Ochs decided that if his readers were made aware of the depths of the city's poverty, they would be eager to help. The next year, The Times published an article with the headline: "Santa Claus, Please Take Notice! Here are New York's 100 Neediest Cases." Within a few months, 117 contributors gave $3,630.88, which was distributed to three social-service agencies.
This year's campaign is particularly crucial, say the directors of the charities aided by the fund, because donations from other sources have not kept pace with inflation and an increase in demand in the last three years.
The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, which receives Neediest Cases Fund money through the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, suffered a 10 percent loss in support last year and has cut two of five staff positions over the last two years. The Children's Aid Society, another Neediest Cases-supported agency, has a deficit of $4.8 million due to declines in donations and government programs.
Indeed, charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund have faced a double-edged sword: while the number of people seeking help has risen, the number who can afford to give has fallen.
"Those who are employed are sitting on a ledge, precariously," said Megan E. McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.
 
Tens of Thousands Benefit
 "It is a wonder that we did as well as we did" with fund raising, she added. While nearly 14,000 people sent money to the Neediest Cases Fund last year, the total collection was 12 percent less than in the previous year, a decrease of about $615,000.
"The impact of this decline is severely affecting those battling the hardships of life in our city: homeless immigrants, hungry, abused and abandoned children, the destitute elderly, AIDS victims fighting to stay alive, and a fast growing category of families being evicted for nonpayment of rent because of job loss," said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Foundation, which pays for all administrative costs of the campaign. "We appeal to the generosity of our readers to help ease their distress."
The money collected during the campaign, which in previous years has come from donors around the world, will help ease the lives of tens of thousands around the city. In the past it has provided everything from small gifts during the holiday season, such as a word processor for an honors student in Washington Heights, to more enduring help, such as support for a program in Brooklyn that has helped hundreds of destitute mentally ill people prepare to enter the job market. It has helped social agencies reunite families after they were separated in the shelter system. It has trained grandmothers to become mothers again as more of them assume responsibility for their children's children. And, as in the case of Mr. Brown, it has kept people off the streets.
By the time Mr. Brown received the notice of eviction, he had found a new, full-time clerical job, but the entry-level salary was simply too low for him to hold his home together.
"There was a moment of panic," he said. "And there was a lot of frustration."
 
Working Toward Security
 But with the help of the Community Service Society, the worst did not happen. The society, which has helped New York City's neediest for nearly 150 years, covered Mr. Brown's debts, helped him negotiate the housing court system and provided him with budget counseling to insure that he would be able to keep up.
As a result, Mr. Brown was able not only to keep his small apartment, but to start working his way back to security. In January, he will begin classes to finish his degree at Hostos Community College in the Bronx. And he recently completed an eight-week course to be certified as a medical assistant.
Mr. Brown knows he still has far to go. He said his first concern was to provide for his adopted son, who recently turned 21, during the holidays and then to work as hard as he can to get them both away from the projects.
"Where we used to live, you could sit on the porch, talk to people. Here, you can't think of that," he said. "Around here, one slip-up can mean a lot for a kid his age. My goal is keeping him on his feet."

HEADLINE: NCR Says Its Intention Is to Be 'Competitive'

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
Struggling with brutal price competition at home and sluggish markets overseas, A.T. & T.'s NCR Corporation stepped up its effort yesterday to reduce costs by trying to cut its work force by 7,500 people.
The computer company, based in Dayton, Ohio, has said it intends to reduce its worldwide work force of 51,000 people by as much as 15 percent and hopes to do it through voluntary leaves rather than layoffs. 
 "We must have a competitive cost structure," said Jerre L. Stead, NCR's chief executive. He said the cutbacks were part of a broader effort to trim layers of management and be more responsive to customers.
"We are putting decision-making authority closer to the customer," he said.
 
Cuts Deeper Than Contemplated
 The cuts are deeper than those contemplated earlier this year, when NCR decided to shut two plants. Last month it offered early-retirement incentives to about 5,500 employees.
The cutbacks come as the company struggles with shrinking profit margins throughout the computer industry and with sluggishness in the economies of Europe and Japan, where NCR does much of its business.
Under the program announced yesterday, about 25,000 employees with more than a year of service will be eligible for $5,000 lump-sum payments and other benefits if they decide to leave by Feb. 11. Company officials said they could not predict how much the cutbacks would cost until they learned how many people would accept the offer.
NCR has been taking a bruising all year, which company officials attribute largely to intense price competition and tight margins.
NCR suffered a $49 million operating loss in the quarter that ended Sept. 30; the year before it had a $50 million profit. In the second quarter, earnings plunged 73 percent, to $27 million, and the company ran a $20 million loss in the first quarter.
NCR's poor 1993 performance has already dragged down earnings at A.T. & T., shaving what might have been a 15 percent gain in earnings if NCR had held steady to just 10 percent. That is something of an embarrassment for A.T. & T., which acquired NCR for $7.5 billion in a hostile takeover more than two years ago.
But industry analysts believe NCR remains fundamentally healthy because it decided several years ago to shift from traditional mainframe and minicomputers toward "open" networks of linked computers.
"What I see happening is NCR restructuring into a new kind of business," said Berge Ayvazian, an analyst at the Yankee Group, a market research firm in Boston. "It's necessary for NCR to be well positioned in the 1990's."
Others contend that NCR has already made many of the right strategic moves.
"It's very well positioned," said Michael Elling, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "It's not like I.B.M., with a sick mainframe business."
NCR has been struggling with at least two problems. One is that revenues from traditional mainframe computers have been falling faster than sales from the newer "3000" family have grown. For the most part, revenues in this area have come from long-term maintenance contracts, which have been dwindling as old systems are replaced.
In the third quarter, NCR said its service revenues declined by 8 percent while sales of computer products climbed by 4 percent. Over all, revenues in the third quarter slipped 2 percent from a year before, to $1.67 billion. NCR's annual sales are just over $7 billion.
A second problem stems from intense price competition, particularly in desktop and laptop computers. Mr. Stead said the far tighter profit margins were forcing the company to be more cost-conscious.
Finally, the company has suffered from sluggish business overseas, which accounts for nearly half its sales.
Mr. Stead predicted that NCR would turn a profit in the current quarter, which is usually the company's best of the year. But Mr. Elling of Oppenheimer said he did not believe it would complete a full turnaround until the second half of 1994.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Surge 2% to Record

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The economy's manufacturing sector gained fresh momentum in October as orders for durable goods surged 2 percent, to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.
It was the third consecutive rise for these big-ticket items, which range from lathes to yachts, providing a likely continuing source of strength in 1994 that analysts expect will cushion retrenchment by consumers. 
 A second Government report today showed that new unemployment claims edged up just 1,000 last week, considered a quite satisfactory performance in holding nearly all of a 20,000 improvement in the preceding holiday-shortened week. The total number of people collecting benefits fell by 89,000.
Separately, auto makers reported that sales of domestically built vehicles rose 20.5 percent in mid-November. [Page D5.]
"Everything's moving along pretty well," said Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist for A. G. Edwards & Sons, the St. Louis-based brokerage house. Nearly all the figures published so far for October, including retail sales and housing, have shown accelerated growth. Factory employment ended a slide that began last winter.
Predictions for total output in the final 1993 quarter now typically approach 4 percent. One very large investor, George Soros, said today while taping an appearance on John McLaughlin's PBS television program "One on One" that gross domestic product would soar during this period at a rate of "6 percent plus."
Yet even as consumers step up spending, their mood remains cautious as they face tax increases, health care overhaul and lingering uncertainty over jobs. Today, the University of Michigan told subscribers that its consumer sentiment index eased to 81.2 in mid-November from 82.7 for October.
With income growth sluggish, consumers have gained spending power by refinancing mortgages. However, Kathryn Eickhoff, a New York consultant and former chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget, said the kicking in of tax increases would help cut the annual growth rate in the gross domestic product to 2.5 percent to 3 percent in the first three months of next year.
Still, today's figures on durable goods orders make it less likely that the economy will repeat last year's post-holiday skid from a 5.7 percent burst in the October-December quarter to a gain of just eight-tenths of 1 percent in the January-March period.
"You can look a little further ahead," Ms. Eickhoff said, referring to what are now record levels in durable goods for both orders and shipments. The October orders, $135.8 billion, surpassed by $1 billion the preceding peak in December 1988.
Although the October orders were paced by a 5.5 percent jump in transportation equipment, with automotive goods and aircraft more than offsetting a decline in shipbuilding and tanks, the rise was exceptionally broad. Eight of the 10 major industry groups had increases, the department found.
 
 
Excluding Transportation
 And excluding the volatile transportation sector, new orders gained nine-tenths of 1 percent, the fifth consecutive increase. By contrast, orders fell on this basis for three of the first five months of the year.
There was also a 4.4 percent advance for nonmilitary capital goods, such as machine tools, a widely watched indicator of corporate investment plans. Aircraft and parts accounted for much of this but the gain was still 1.5 percent with aircraft excluded.
Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary, said in a statement that this indicated that "the economy's productive capacity is rising along with the increase in demand for goods."
Over all, new nonmilitary orders climbed 2.7 percent, with industrial machinery and equipment up 1.3 percent, electronic and other electrical equipment up eight-tenths of 1 percent and primary metals up three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
 
Orders Data 'Encouraging'
 Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, called the orders figures "encouraging" and noted that while shipments rose only a scant one-tenth of 1 percent, far less than in August and September, they nevertheless set a new record.
For the year to date, new orders are running 8.3 percent ahead of the comparable 1992 pace while shipments are 7.8 percent ahead, the report also showed.
Unfilled orders for durable goods eased four-tenths of 1 percent in October, to $426.7 billion, the lowest level since June 1988. This was the eighth consecutive monthly decline and the 27th in the last 32 months.
The weakness in backlogs, however, is concentrated in military and civilian aircraft, economists at C. J. Lawrence observed.
The orders gain for September was revised upward, to 1.1 percent from the seven-tenths of 1 percent the department initially reported.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed Despite Data On Factory Orders and Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against other currencies yesterday in light, pre-holiday trading.
Currency traders said the market shrugged off a report of a record high in orders to factories for durable goods in October. Another Government report said only 1,000 newly laid-off workers filed first-time applications for unemployment insurance last week, better than expected. 
 "There was a limited reaction," said Randolph L. Donney, director of capital markets research at Pegasus Econometric Group. "We're in sort of a holiday market."
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 108.17 Japanese yen, from 108.38 yen on Tuesday. But it rose to 1.7035 German marks from 1.7022 marks.
Gold prices, meanwhile, were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery closed at $377.20 an ounce, off 10 cents.
 
 
'An Icing'
 The dollar's advance against the mark was restrained by comments by the head of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer. He said the bank should be cautious about further cuts in interest rates.
"It's put an icing on the idea that the Germans were going to accelerate" the rate cuts, said Angelo Evangelista, a vice president at Bank of Boston.
Lowered interest rates might give a lift to Germany's ailing economy, but could drive the mark lower, since deposits in German marks would earn less.
Currency traders said the Bank of Canada intervened in the markets to support the Canadian currency after it tumbled following newspaper reports that Canada's budget deficit was going to be greater than expected.
Late yesterday, both the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Dominion Bond Rating Service Ltd. lowered their ratings on Ontario's long-term debt. But once the expected downgrades were announced, the Canadian dollar firmed. In New York, the United States dollar rose to $1.3303 (Canadian) from $1.3266 (Canadian).
"It was the anticipation of the downgrades that really hurt," said Margaret Kudarauskas, a foreign exchange specialist at Technical Data.
Meanwhile, the British pound rose to $1.4880 from $1.4855.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of Domestic Vehicles Rose 20.5% in Mid-November

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 20.5 percent in mid-November, a sharp increase from the corresponding period a year ago and a robust rate that presaged even stronger sales through the early part of next year.
Sales of cars built in North America rose 16.4 percent, to 183,320, for the period Nov. 11-20, while sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, rose 26 percent, to 146,489. Total vehicle sales were 329,809, up from 273,717 during the corresponding period last year. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 7 million, the same as the rate for early November, but up considerably from the 5.9 million rate a year earlier.
"The size and the breadth of the increase are quite encouraging," Tom Webb, an economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said.
Wendy Needham, automotive analyst for Smith Barney in New York, said she was looking for an improved rate of sales during the next six months. "It's clear now that the slowdown last summer had to do with availability," she said. "When vehicles are available, people buy them."
The General Motors Corporation, the No. 1 producer, increased its sales of domestic cars by 17.6 percent, to 78,955, and sales of light trucks by 25.3 percent, to 53,531. The star of G.M.'s car divisions was Chevrolet, which posted a 33.7 percent increase. The laggard was Cadillac, whose sales fell 26.2 percent because of a slow model change-over for its Deville.
G.M.'s full-size pickup trucks gained more than 25 percent compared with the corresponding period last year. Even G.M.'s mini-vans, which had been slow sellers, enjoyed a sales rise.
The Ford Motor Company reported an 8.4 percent gain in car sales, to 48,376, and a 39.3 percent gain in light-truck sales, to 50,842.
The Chrysler Corporation reports its sales only on a monthly basis.
 
Japanese Sales Also Rise
 Japanese auto makers also benefitted from the increased demand.
Sales of the Nissan Motor Company's cars built in North America rose 48.5 percent, to 7,387, in the period and sales of the company's North American light trucks rose 59.9 percent, to 4,340.
The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a 29.7 percent increase in car sales, to 10,073, while light-truck sales rose 38.6 percent, to 3,528.
The Honda Motor Company said car sales rose 3.9 percent, to 10,520.
The Mazda Motor Corporation posted car sales of 2,968, a gain of 1.6 percent from last year. Mazda's light-truck sales were 1,649, compared with 181 a year ago.

HEADLINE: High Hopes for Low Interest Rates

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Despite a recent upturn in interest rates, many economists and market analysts believe that the United States has entered an era of rates far lower than in the 1980's that is likely to last for many years -- thanks to a host of forces ranging from an inflation-fighting Federal Reserve to a slow-growing world economy.
"We really are in an environment of lower interest rates," said Joel L. Prakken, an economist at Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a forecasting firm in St. Louis that predicted the sharp decline in rates earlier this year. "We call it, 'Back to the 60's.' " 
 Even though long-term rates have jumped nearly half a percentage point in recent weeks, they remain appetizingly low to middle-aged baby boomers, many of whose first mortgages were about 12 percent. While current interest rates -- with a long-term Treasury bond rate of about 6.3 percent -- are not unusually low in a longer historical perspective, they are low enough to be a benefit to the economy.
To be sure, the only certain thing about interest rates is that they will not stay where they are today. Some forecasters expect rates to edge down again. Others, like James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, say long-term rates will rise some more, as they often do when an expansion progresses and inflation picks up. Mr. Annable, one of the most bearish forecasters on interest rates, looks for long-bond rates to average about 7 percent next year.
More certain, according to most forecasters, is that short-term rates, which are at 30-year lows, will rise as the economy keeps growing.
What is striking, however, is that almost no one expects a return any time soon to the days of double-digit interest rates and spiraling inflation. For now, both bears and bulls predict rates will move up and down in a far narrower band, roughly 5 to 7 percent, than they did for most of the 1980's, when they fluctuated between 8 and 14 percent.
"You'll have plain vanilla interest-rate fluctuations," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist and portfolio manager of the Dreyfus Corporation. He said rates could as easily go up as they could go down in the immediate future. "But you won't repeat the bear market from 1979 to 1981, which was the bond equivalent of the Great Crash in the stock market of 1929 to 1932," he said. "The 1980's were the aberration, not 1993."
Most people agree that rates like those many of their mothers and fathers paid on their home and business loans would be golden, not just for the would-be owner of a split-level house or a Range Rover, but also for the economy. Low rates, in particular low inflation-adjusted rates, tend to favor investments from college educations and computers to highways and houses. Just about everyone from President Clinton on down believes that more investment is needed to raise American standards of living.
Economists expect rates to remain lower than during the 1980's because they do not expect either inflation or credit demand to surge during the 1990's.
Take inflation. There are few signs of inflationary pressures in the economy. The Consumer Price Index has risen at an annual rate of only 3 percent in the last year, and the Blue Chip consensus of economic forecasters expects the index to rise at about the same rate next year.
Unemployment is inching down, and capacity utilization is edging up slowly. The dollar has been drifting up. Oil prices are not expected to soar in a weak world economy. Europe and Japan are still slumping and are not expected to generate increases in commodity prices.
 
 
Importance of Expectations
 More important, most people now say they believe that inflation will stay low, which should hold down speculative pressures, like higher wage demands and price increases.
A quarterly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia shows that inflation expectations have fallen steadily over the last decade. Business executives polled in the survey predicted that the consumer inflation rate would be running at only about 3.5 percent 10 years from now. That is in sharp contrast to the predictions made in 1981, when inflation was in the double digits, and executives predicted a consumer inflation rate of more than 8 percent for the next decade.
"What's really different is that people's expectations have genuinely switched from a high-inflation world to a low-inflation world," said Christina Romer, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley who has studied interest-rate trends over the last century. "As long as we stay in a world of low inflation, there's no reason for long-term rates to shoot back up."
Most economists give much of the credit for the change in expectations to the Federal Reserve and the credibility that it has built as an inflation fighter during the reigns of Paul A. Volcker, who became the Fed's chairman in 1979, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman since 1987.
 
 
The Fed Shows the Way
 "Obviously, the Federal Reserve isn't omniscient and perfect, and there are political considerations that impinge on monetary policy," said William Poole, an economist at Brown University and a member of the Shadow Open Market Committee, a group of prominent monetarists who track Federal Reserve policy. "The market understands lots of ambiguity in the data, but it has a lot of confidence that the Fed will sort the data out and move interest rates appropriately."
The second broad reason that rates will remain low, economists say, is that the world economy is not going to boom during the 1990's. As a result, credit demand is likely to remain moderate.
"One of the reasons rates got as high as they did in early 80's, is that credit demand was tremendously strong," Mr. Hoey said.
Real long-term interest rates -- the component of interest rates other than inflation -- are now about 2.5 percent, about half of what they averaged during the 1980's. And the current thinking is that they will stay down.
 
 
A Rise Would Reflect Growth
 Robert J. Barro, a Harvard economist, said that even if real rates began to move up, it would be a sign that a booming world economy and new technologies were creating an abundance of investment opportunities. But he said he did not expect that would be the case in coming years.
Private credit demand is likely to grow at a more moderate pace than in the 1980's, many economists predict. Many consumers struggled with heavy debt payments during the recent economic downturn. And although consumers have recently increased their borrowing, they are not relying on debt as aggressively as they did in the 1980's. For one, people are not looking at house purchases as hedges against inflation, and there is a reduced tendency to buy as much in housing as possible.
Charles I. Clough Jr., the chief investment strategist of Merrill Lynch & Company, notes that the bulk of the baby-boom generation, who bought houses during the 1980's and early 1990's, will be leaving the high borrowing years.
One of the biggest users of credit is the Federal Government. When the Federal deficit was growing, the expectation was that it would keep expanding. As a result, real long-term interest rates became very high. After budget cuts and tax increases by the Bush and Clinton Administrations, however, many people now expect the deficit to shrink relative to the size of the economy.
 
 
Debt Has No Dominion
 Similarly, corporations are still recovering from the debt hangover of 1980's and are not eager to accumulate debt. Because of a bull market in stocks, companies have been able to finance expansion by selling shares. Further, the sectors that typically use lots of credit, like commercial construction, are relatively weak.
In the rest of the world, there is little indication of a credit boom. When the Berlin wall fell, "the expectation was that there was going to be an investment boom in former Communist countries," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist of Regional Financial Associates. "That view has shifted because of the uncertain political environment."
Can the new era end faster than the consensus expects? Certainly.
"There is a tremendous tendency to understate the volatility of rates," Mr. Hoey said. "It's an economic boom causing inflation. Or it's a currency plunge. Or it's an oil price shock."
For now, however, many economists are betting that such episodes are either unlikely or short-lived and that the benefits of low rates will continue to bolster the economy.

HEADLINE: Adoptions That Lack Papers, Not Purpose

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
NATHAN AND JANET RILEY married three years ago and immediately took a little boy named Charles Johnson 3d into their home in Philadelphia. The Rileys are now learning about P.T.A.'s, French-horn lessons and temper tantrums -- the realities of raising a son. They fret over private concerns when the child, Mr. Riley's great-nephew, is out of earshot: are they hugging him enough? Should they say "I love you" more?
There were no legal papers, no social workers, no Government involvement when the newlyweds informally adopted Charles in a long-accepted practice of African-American life. Mr. Riley said he just knew that it was his job to raise the boy to manhood. 
 The 12-year-old, now in a program for gifted children at a public school, was growing up tragically on Philadelphia's gritty streets, the child of a convicted felon who recently died in prison and a crack-addicted mother. In his mother's care, the reedy-slim boy would be found begging for food with a metal can on street corners or huddled like dumped trash in abandoned buildings with no doors, windows or lights, Mr. Riley said.
"I knew I needed to raise him as a strong young black man and teach him moral values, honesty, integrity and how to resist peer pressures," said Mr. Riley, 38, who is a medical coordinator for a mental health agency in Philadelphia. "It was something that came natural. He's a part of my family and a part of my blood."
For black families across America, informal adoption can range from the grandmother's rearing grandchildren to the kindly church lady taking in abandoned children to the acquaintance who is drafted to be a "play sister" or "play uncle."
Amid the public discussion of the deficiencies in many black families, informal adoption has often provided the seeds of family rejuvenation. From its origins in African collective societies through the slave trade and the migration of blacks from the South to Northern cities, the practice has endured.
Though many other ethnic groups have a tradition of taking care of relatives in need, many sociologists and child-care advocates say informal adoption is as distinctive to African-American culture as jazz.
"It is part of our culture," said Robert B. Hill, a black sociologist at Morgan State University in Baltimore, who has written extensively on the practice. "We say so few positive things about black families, and this is a trait that most blacks have experienced."
Mr. Riley and his wife, Janet, who is a dental technician, have never seriously considered a formal adoption. Mr. Riley said that he had never seen a need for the Government to get involved and that if legal difficulties occurred, "we'll cross that bridge when we get to it."
Informal adoption runs in his family. Mr. Riley has a 53-year-old sister, a nurse's aide, who is raising four grandchildren. Because of their parents' involvement with drugs, the children were taken in by their grandmother despite her financial troubles.
Mr. Riley's late mother was known as Mom Riley in their north Philadelphia community. "She was a mother to everybody," Mr. Riley said. "She would take them home to get something to eat and get them clothes from Goodwill."
Compared with whites, blacks are informally adopted at a higher rate, figures show. Dr. Hill, working with census data, found that in 1970, 25 percent of all black households had three generations living in them; in 1990, that figure had risen to 40 percent. A typical situation finds a grandparent caring for a teen-age mother and her child. The corresponding figure for white households rose from 20 percent to 30 percent, Dr. Hill said. He also found that among blacks, the practice is more common among low-income groups.
Dr. Andrew Billingsley, a sociologist who specializes in black family issues at the University of Maryland at College Park, cited Government statistics that he said showed that of the estimated one million black children in this country who do not live with a biological parent, nearly 800,000 have been informally adopted, usually by a grandparent. The remaining 200,000 are in the child-welfare system, which includes foster care and orphanages.
Marjorie Valleau, a spokeswoman for the New York City Human Resources Administration, acknowledged that the practice is a longtime tradition and said she did not know of any legal problems. "It's an admirable practice because certainly it keeps children with relatives and close family friends," she said, "and that's 100 percent better than putting children with strangers." But Ms. Valleau strongly recommended that individuals consider legal guardianship as a safeguard for the children in dealing with schools, hospitals and other bureaucracies.
As someone who was informally adopted, John Henrik Clarke, a historian and a professor emeritus at Hunter College in New York, did not blink when he met a man who introduced him to his seven mothers in Accra, Ghana, earlier this year. "He said, 'This is my mother, this is my senior mother,' and he called everybody else in his mother's age group his mother," Dr. Clarke said.
When Dr. Clarke, 78, was growing up in Columbus, Ga., he was taken in by a black cook, Rosa Lee, with whom he worked in the home of a white family. His mother had died, and he did not get along with his father's new wife. He moved into Ms. Lee's home at age 14 and stayed there until he was 18.
For Dr. Clarke, who taught for 17 years in Hunter College's department of African and Puerto Rican studies, the experience of informal adoption set a challenge for him. "I felt the responsibility that I owe something out there," he said. "I trained a generation of Ph.D.'s. My students have been ambassadors, engineers, doctors. And this is from a poor kid from a sharecropper's family?"
Dr. Clarke said he is heartened every time he travels the thousands of miles to West Africa, to which many American blacks trace their roots, and sees the connection between the way he grew up and the way that "family" is a large-scale community enterprise there. In this country, he added, "a lot of people see it as the right thing to do."
"Some see it as the Christian thing to do," he continued, "but a lot of things we do are African, and we're not aware that it's African unless we go to Africa."
During the slave trade, blacks were forced to redefine family when parents and children were sold and separated. During the great migration of blacks to Northern industrial cities in the early 1940's, informal adoption was an accepted way to leave children behind as their parents sought a better life for their families.
Dr. Clarke said cultural differences as well as inequalities under the law made people reluctant to get the Government involved in issues as intimate as that of what makes a family. "We just didn't think we would be treated properly or that the other group would understand the nature of our culture," he continued. "We didn't trust adoption agencies because there weren't that many, and the city agencies didn't understand the structure of black family life."
The tradition has persisted, though Dr. Clarke and others who have studied it have varying opinions on whether it is as pervasive as it once was. Some suggest that drug abuse, teen-age pregnancies and a shortage of affordable housing, among other things, have caused informal adoptions to increase.
Others believe that while the practice is an entrenched feature of black family life, its occurrence among nonrelatives has diminished in recent years because of a poor economy, concerns about Government oversight and fear caused by increased levels of violence.
"There's been a real decline in the level of trust in general and maybe an unwillingness to extend oneself beyond the immediate family," said Katherine McFate, associate director of social policy at the Joint Center for Political Studies in Washington, a research institute that focuses on black concerns. "The community controls are not there the way they were."
When blacks began to move from segregated communities in large numbers as a result of civil rights gains, the sense of community also may have been diluted, Dr. Billingsley said, adding, "Progress has a downside to it."
In Columbia, S.C., Annette Pou returned from a weekend vacation several years ago to find an unfamiliar 12-year-old girl living in her family's home. The girl, Joy Goodwin, and her mother, a friend of Ms. Pou's mother, had been evicted from their house and had moved in.
Ms. Goodwin, who is now 24, has never moved out of Ms. Pou's life. She followed her "big sister" every step of the way from South Carolina to Brooklyn, where they share an apartment.
In the black enclave where they grew up together in Columbia, neighbors knew each other's name, attended school together and went to church together on Sunday. And no one thought twice when strangers became a part of the family, said Ms. Pou, 29, a receptionist at the New York City Department of Environmental Protection.
A custom like informal adoption should be preserved because it fosters a sense of belonging, said Mary Connolly, a psychotherapist who lives in the Bronx. "If we had more of it, we'd have fewer problems, less mental illness, less separation, not as many dropouts," continued Mrs. Connolly, who has been "taking in" children for most of her adult life.
Years ago, Mrs. Connolly raised a nephew from age 6 to 16 because of family troubles in his home. She also took in his 11-year-old sister when she came to New York from North Carolina to run track in local tournaments. The niece stayed until she was 20.
Now 50, Mrs. Connolly rushes home every night to care for Arikka Noid, 5, who calls her Mommy. She is looking for a full-time baby sitter for the first time in her life, is mulling over choices of elementary schools for the child, now in kindergarten, and is proud to be the oldest member of the parents' advisory council at the school. But privately, she is worried about growing too old to care for the girl.
Mrs. Connolly and her husband, Martin, a real estate agent, had never wanted a child of their own. But it never occurred to Mrs. Connolly not to take in Arikka when the child's mother died in a car accident five years ago. Arikka is the daughter of Mrs. Connolly's nephew. Mrs. Connolly said she and her nephew, 25, who lives in North Carolina, agreed that since she is more mature and settled, she would be the person to raise Arikka.
"It was the way I was brought up," said Mrs. Connolly, who as a child, along with her entire family, moved in with her grandmother in North Carolina when her father died. "It was the responsibility of the family when someone was not available, you just take over."
Though Mrs. Connolly is kept on the move (and a little winded) as her little charge races about the house, she does not mind following in the girl's footsteps. "I'm the only mom she's got and I couldn't love her more."
 
 
Relatives as Foster Parents
 GOVERNMENT agencies around the country are increasingly placing children with relatives in kinship-care foster programs, which sociologists like Dr. Robert B. Hill at Morgan State University in Baltimore call "formalized informal adoptions."
Of the 48,086 children in New York City's foster-care system, 20,571 are cared for by relatives. But some families shun the kinship-care program because of concerns about Government intrusion, said Marjorie Valleau, a spokeswoman for the city's Human Resources Administration.
A caretaker who is receiving public assistance benefits would get increased benefits in a kinship program but would also be subject to more Government oversight, including visits from caseworkers, fingerprinting and background checks for abuse and neglect, Ms. Valleau said.
Caretakers who are receiving public assistance but are neither legal guardians nor relatives can still get Government benefits, Ms. Valleau said, including food stamps and Medicaid, under a home-relief program.

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD;
A Jewel-Box Library Dream

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

 BODY:
"IN Russia, it's an old saying," said Vicky Nicholas. "If you really hate someone, you tell them, 'May you renovate your apartment every hour.' "
Vicky and David Nicholas had a one-bedroom apartment to divide by two professional adults and three grown children who visit frequently. Cleverly, they employed the power of words rather than numbers to solve the problem. 
 Ignoring the practicality of using a small spare room in their Chelsea apartment as a guest bedroom, the pair instead created an intimate library for themselves that enlarged the apartment by opening the imagination. Giving themselves exactly what they wanted, instead of precisely what they needed, turned out to be an excellent renovation strategy: they maximized space by making the most of its emotional content.
If all happy families are alike, what makes them happy differs. For Mrs. Nicholas, a Russian emigre and a physician, and her husband, David, a printer, it was the thought of a private library, as carefully constructed as a literary description: rich woods, glass-fronted bookcases, brass knobs, faded tapestry, a beautiful desk and a low plush sofa that one could stretch out on while reading, as though in a rowboat that someone else was rowing. A country-house room, an elegant scene from Chekhov. Say dacha.
Like fiction, the Nicholases' library is completely invented. What was there was nothing: a standard co-op conversion had left them a 9-by-15-foot box, an acrobatically high ceiling, the architectural detail of an amnesiac's childhood home.
The Nicholases had friends who had built a library, improbably, in an apartment hallway. They recommended their architect, Joan Dineen.
Mrs. Nicholas has a strong, friendly face and manner, taste and opinions -- strong like black Russian tea. "I had a little apprehension," Mrs. Nicholas recalled about working with an architect, especially "the idea that someone will come and tell me what has to be done."
Renovation began like a story told to the therapist: they just wanted some bookshelves, that was all. Mrs. Nicholas had moved into her future husband's apartment four years earlier with many boxes of books. Ms. Dineen realized from their discussions that what actually intrigued them was the relaxing refinement that a room of books represented. So they let the books, and the boxlike room, become the plan for a library.
With the addition of woodwork but no structural changes, Ms. Dineen designed a classic European "cabinet," a small, well-appointed room where one traditionally conducted family business and which served as a place for personal things.
Ms. Dineen and the Nicholases agreed on cherry wood. "It was a compromise between walnut and mahogany," Ms. Dineen said. "Cherry is lighter, but still rich."
A wall of cabinetry encases the room's two windows: there are glass-fronted bookshelves between them, with built-in storage drawers below those; deep wood grills beneath the windows mask heating and air-conditioning units. The depth of the cabinets gives the windows deep reveals and broad sills, which enhance the room's snug quality. Opposite the window wall, Ms. Dineen refitted existing closets and drawers with new doors that matched the bookcases.
The height of the room, 10 feet, suited the purpose and character of a library. But wall moldings and ceiling detail had been stripped away in the original conversion. Ms. Dineen designed a cornice with a clean Gothic line and curve that recalled famous libraries like Horace Walpole's at Strawberry Hill. The cornice completes the cabinet effect; its lowest element also serves as a picture rail.
Ms. Dineen worked with a familiar team: Tamas Banovich, a Hungarian sculptor and former woodworker and furniture maker, as contractor, and Harvey Talent, a cabinetmaker whose work Mr. Banovich admired.
Installing a room's worth of cabinetry is roughly like building a ship in a bottle. "Measuring is the most important part of a job like this," Mr. Banovich said. "Within two feet, the ceiling dropped three-eighths of an inch. A cornice is a rigid thing. It's already built. So I had to go up into the structure and lift the ceiling for two feet."
The Nicholases appreciated Mr. Banovich's meticulousness; Mrs. Nicholas said there was a sympathy between her and Mr. Banovich because both are from Europe. And because the couple wanted craft, they were willing to wait for precision.
The library took six months, from hello to goodbye. Because the quality of materials and the care of the work were important -- Mr. Talent used solid cherry rather than veneer, and drawers that slide on wooden grooves rather than on standard hardware runners -- the woodworking and cabinetry alone, including the cornice, came to about $20,000. But for the Nicholases, the expense was relative, as it is for many apartment owners today: it was part of a larger decision to stay put and personalize what they had, rather than to buy something larger.
It cost about another $14,000 for Mr. Banovich to fit the preconstructed pieces into place, adjusting minutely as he installed -- essentially a second cabinetry job -- and to treat the wood and finish the rest of the room, including wiring, walls and floors. The ceiling had to be rewired and replastered so that the couple could hang a 19th-century lamp of bronze and New England sandwich glass, the size and shape of a samovar, that serves as the room's centerpiece. Ms. Dineen's fee, in addition, was about 15 percent of the total.
Still, cost was monitored closely. Ms. Dineen gave them choices involving design, quality of materials and levels of finish at each step, as did Mr. Banovich. For example, walls that weren't wood were coated not with paint but with integral plaster, which contains pigment (in this case a grayish-green) and which produces a textured effect, like aged fresco, when troweled. The walls were then waxed; they now have the smoothness of old, faintly marbled leather -- a nice reference to book binding. The cost of the choice: about $2,000.
Mrs. Nicholas accompanied Ms. Dineen on shopping trips to places like the Decoration and Design Building, where she chose a velvetlike sofa fabric called Ibisco, which resembled old tapestry (by Voghi from Ian Wall, $89 a yard). At P. E. Gurein, she chose brass cabinet knobs -- not the $350 ones, but $35 brass-plated Baldwins instead.
Finished, the library sets off its collection of unusual things as beautifully as a jewel case. The couple found a German desk at a 10th Street antiques shop, a lean-limbed, modern-looking transitional piece, from Empire to Biedermeier: that is Mrs. Nicholas's study. The fringed settee is a convertible sofa: that is the guest room.
But it's that indefinable thing in the air, like the smell of old books, that's now the rarest thing in the room: a sense of being peacefully in place, literally contained in one's own thought.
"I come home and sit in there and marvel," Mr. Nicholas said.
Mrs. Nicholas added, "I could never imagine that you could build something like this."
 
Specs
 IN renovation, hindsight often provides the best foresight. But unfortunately for many people, a costly renovation is undertaken only once. Tamas Banovich, Vicky and David Nicholases' contractor, had general advice for people who are considering a such a renovation.
Be aware that the likely cost overrun of any job could be as high as 20 percent: set yourself an initial budget that is not at the strained end of what you can afford. The time to be budget-conscious is in the design stage. A modest design done well will be more beautiful and less heartbreaking than an elaborate design executed poorly. Inferior materials, bad workmanship and cut corners will show -- and cost money to fix later.
Mr. Banovich believes in early cooperation between a contractor and architect or designer. He said that clients sometimes distrust an architect's recommending a contractor, thinking they should invite bidding later on. But a contractor who reviews designs and decisions at an early stage will help insure that the design will be buildable and as economical as possible. A contractor can also help a client understand the costs involved in choosing a design and in realizing it.
Mr. Banovich, like the architect, Joan Dineen, gave the Nicholases choices at each step -- in large decisions like wall treatments, but also in simple things like wall switches and doorknobs. They could choose something expensive or could use those junctures as places to save money. He also gave the couple the opportunity to correct things that had been done poorly in the apartment's previous conversion. When a wall or ceiling was opened, he pointed out the poor wiring. Mr. Banovich thinks it sends a good signal to a client if a contractor begins with more questions than promises.
Mr. Banovich has found that people sometimes begin work before they're ready. Don't start before all the materials, hardware and other elements have arrived on site, he cautions. If you draw up a contract with a longer preparation time, you can shorten construction time, which is usually more costly.

HEADLINE: Peru's Peasant Victims Still Need Help

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Signs of economic recovery in Peru have drawn the world's attention. While no one should begrudge Peru prosperity, given its travails, which have been marked by political violence and surging poverty, a too-speedy return to the rhetoric of economic recovery (as opposed to that of imminent collapse) masks the human toll of 13 years of war.
Today, Peru has more internal refugees than any other country in the hemisphere, calculated by humanitarian aid groups at 600,000. The majority are peasant women and children who have fled both Government-sponsored terror and the terror of the Maoist Shining Path rebel movement. As recently as last August, a Shining Path attack in jungle communities around Santa Rosa de Shiriari cost 62 lives and forced 700 Ashaninka Indians, along with settlers from the mountains, to flee. 
 The international community must look at Peru not only as an investment opportunity. There is an urgent need to assist the forcibly displaced with food, medicine, shelter and, above all, protection from both Government repression and Shining Path attacks. So far, the Government has done nothing, preferring to ignore the victims of war in the interest of keeping social spending at shockingly low levels (in part, to keep up the payments on the foreign debt that make it attractive to business).
Half of Peru's population of 22 million now lives in extreme poverty. Among the poorest are the internal refugees, who are suffering significantly higher levels of infant mortality, disease, and malnutrition than the poor in general.
If democracy is to return to Peru -- and prosperity with it -- an international effort to help the internally displaced, including those who wish to return to their burned-out villages, is urgently needed.
Returnees, some of whom have already reclaimed the heights above Ayacucho, are willing to stake their lives. We should back them with concrete aid as well as pressure on the Government to rebuild their homes, invest in agriculture, and encourage the return of civilian (not military) rule to areas now under emergency decree. Without such efforts, the Peruvians who have paid the highest price for their country may be left out of the augured "boom." They deserve better.
 
ROBIN KIRK
Durham, N.C., Nov. 16, 1993
 
The author has written reports on Peru's internal refugees for the Washington-based United States Committee for Refugees.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Assignment: Bring Asia To the Amex

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that Lisa S. Y. Sun, a lawyer, had been appointed managing director of the exchange's newly created Asia division.
Her job will be to generate new listings on the Amex from among emerging Asia-based companies. The exchange trades 900 stocks; of those, 27 are issues of foreign companies and only 2 are of Asian companies. 
 Securities analysts said such a venture had the potential to increase trading volume on the exchange and would help investors who want to take advantage of growing economies in the Pacific Basin.
But United States securities regulations, which require the disclose of more financial information than in other countries, have often deterred foreign companies from seeking a listing on stock exchanges in the United States.
 
Seeking to Be 'a Bridge'
 In an interview, Ms. Sun, 35, said she would seek ties with the Asian agencies that regulate securities and regional stock exchanges as a way to help companies listed on the American Exchange find partners offshore. As an example, she said, a trip sponsored by the exchange and the Chinese Government in September helped introduce executives of several American companies to their counterparts in China. The trip has led to talks over possible joint ventures. "We'd like to become a bridge for that," she said.
Ms. Sun, who was born in Taipei, Taiwan, has been a senior enforcement attorney for the exchange since 1988.
Asian companies, particularly those that sell consumer goods, are becoming more enthusiastic about having their stocks listed on foreign exchanges, Ms. Sun said. "They want to be global entities and reach our consumer market," she added. A stock exchange listing helps the companies build brand awareness, she said.
 
 
Mid-sized Companies
 Foreign companies are subject to the same listing eligibility rules as United States companies. Companies that are listed on the Amex, the smallest of the nation's three major exchanges based on trading volume, are generally midsized companies.
The ability to trade the shares of foreign companies during regular business hours would be of some benefit to retail and institutional investors, said Christian Wignall, vice president of G. T. Global Mutual Funds, which manages a Japan and Pacific fund.
But because advanced telecommunications have made trading stocks in foreign markets easier for brokers, the effort by the American Exchange appears more like "a rear guard action to keep trading on their floors," Mr. Wignall said. "Markets are losing their geography."
