HEADLINE: Mediterranean Fruit Flies Return to California

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Mediterranean fruit fly has returned to Southern California, threatening many crops and rekindling a debate over how best to eradicate the stubborn pest.
The new outbreak has largely been unnoticed because officials have not yet resorted to aerial spraying, the most obtrusive and controversial eradication method. 
 But some officials fear that the infestation could become the region's worst yet, and it has scientists wondering whether the pest is here to stay after nearly 20 years of off-and-on eradication efforts.
Agriculture officials declared the Medfly eradicated in Southern California after the last big outbreak, in 1989 and 1990. But the new infestation began only a short time later with the discovery of a single Medfly in a trap in the Koreatown section of Los Angeles in October 1991.
More fruit flies have already been trapped in the latest infestation than in the 1989-90 outbreak, and a quarantine in three counties has been extended over 1,010 square miles, close to the 1,300 square miles quarantined in the last outbreak. A total of 395 fruit flies have been found in the current infestation, compared with 279 in the 1989-90 outbreak.
The recent discovery of one Medfly near San Diego suggests that the infestation may be spreading south along the coast, some officials said.
The first fruit flies in Southern California were found in 1975. A serious infestation could strike at the heart of the California economy if it spreads to the fertile Central Valley, the most productive agricultural region in the world. The flies trapped so far have been limited to urban areas, primarily around Los Angeles, but many Central Valley farmers fear that the infestation will spread if intensive eradication efforts are not undertaken soon.
The state ships about a quarter of its $18.1 billion annual agricultural production abroad, but other nations would stop importing California produce altogether or demand inspections and treatments if a widespread infestation develops. Such inspections and treatment of exported produce could cost $900 million to $1 billion annually, according to some estimates.
The latest outbreak has drawn pressure from some nations, especially Japan, to take a more aggressive approach, officials said. As a result, the Department of Agriculture this year convened an international panel of five scientists to study the problem, and state agriculture officials are now debating whether to adopt the panel's proposal for a large-scale eradication program.
Such an approach would contrast with the piecemeal method now used. But large-scale eradication could also raise red flags among the nations that are demanding it, because it would send a clear signal that California's crops are infested. Until now, officials have been able to convince importers that California's produce is safe.
 
Choices Are Limited
 But agricultural officials and scientists say they may have no choice about expanding the eradication, given the persistent infestation. Medflies have been found each year since 1987, after a five-year hiatus following the huge 1980-82 infestation that struck in the San Francisco Bay area and appeared in Los Angeles as well.
In a report submitted to agriculture officials in October, the international scientists recommended treating entire regions with ground spraying of the chemical Malathion as well as releasing millions of sterilized male fruit flies in hopes of breeding the pest out of existence. That technique is already being used on a smaller scale in the zones where eradication is under way, officials said.
The Medfly, one of the world's most destructive agricultural pests, is known to infest more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts. The female flies pierce the host's skin and lay eggs just beneath the surface, leaving the hatched maggots to eat the host and turn it into a rotten pulp. The flies reach adulthood in 30 days and have a life span of about 90 days.
The insect is endemic in some Mediterranean countries as well as Hawaii.

HEADLINE: After Tourists' Deaths, Florida Works to Recover

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The homicide statistics seemed to spell disaster for the $31 billion tourist industry in Florida: since the beginning of last winter's tourist season, nine visitors, all of them foreigners, have been killed near some of the state's most popular resorts.
Yet as visitors begin to stream into the state this week, Government and private tourism officials say that Florida is unlikely to suffer the economic disaster that had been foreseen by some as recently as two months ago. 
 Even the end of the American Airlines strike is a positive sign, since the carrier has a hub in Miami and also flies to cities like Orlando, Fort Lauderdale and Tampa.
"We appear to have passed through the eye of the hurricane where the crime issue is concerned," said Dean Sullivan, a spokesman for the Florida Department of Tourism. Tourists' visits may drop no more than 5 percent, officials say, and may even reach last year's level.
 
Familiar, So Less Attentive
 The main reason is that 93 percent of Florida tourists are repeat visitors familiar with the surroundings and, the reasoning goes, less likely to be deterred by fear of crime. And Florida remains the nation's top travel destination, polls say.
Also, bargain air fares to Florida, a proven stimulus to travel, are proliferating. And the state tourist commission is planning to spend huge amounts of money on advertising to stoke this winter season.
Jim West, owner of Uniglobe West Horizons Travel of Worthington, Ohio, is a Florida booster. "Most people still choose Florida over everywhere else," he contended. "They may be wary of Florida if they've never been there before. But most have been to Florida previously without encountering any security problems, so they feel safe returning."
Moreover, the state has moved vigorously to reassure tourists -- by posting security guards at roadside rest stops, installing toll-free visitors' help lines, printing multilingual brochures about safety and adding 100 cars donated by auto-rental companies for police patrols.
Still, the foreign tourists, who make up 15 percent of the trade, are a wild card. Florida officials are worried about a drop-off in visits, especially from Europe, but even here there may be some basis for optimism.
"We expect a reduction in visitors from Germany and Britain," said Miyco Villafana, a spokesman for the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau. "But we're optimistic that the Italian market will grow, and Latin America remains strong."
International visitors have taken up the slack in recent years as the number of American visitors to Miami has flagged. Some of that has to do with the recession, which appears to be ending, if at an uneven pace around the country.
In fact, from the beaches of Pensacola, Fort Lauderdale and Daytona to the theme parks near Orlando, industry officials say their biggest concern remains the economies of the Northeast and Midwest, regions that contribute roughly 48 percent of Florida's 40.5 million visitors.
 
Private View Is Less Chipper
 The state's Commerce Secretary, Greg Farmer, said Florida tourism would probably remain at a relatively sluggish level, although one state official said privately that he would be happy if tourism fell no more than 5 percent -- which would be two million visitors.
Recent tourism signals are difficult to decipher. August figures, the most recent available, show that the number of visitors plummeted 12 percent from the comparable month in 1992.
Yet, despite the killings, each of the previous seven months of 1993 showed tourist increases. And the last two killings of the nine, which accelerated a torrent of bad international publicity, occurred in September. In tourism terms, their effect will not be known until the month's figures are released in about two weeks.
Florida is the top state destination in autumn, far ahead of California, the runner-up in that period, a survey of 1,500 American adults by the Washington-based Travel Industry Association said. The survey was completed on Sept. 19, five days after the killing of the ninth foreigner, Gary Colley, a Briton, at a rest stop along an interstate highway near Tallahassee.
In another survey, also completed on Sept. 19, Carlson Travel agencies across the United States found that bookings for Florida were as strong as last year. And the Uniglobe Travel network reported last week that Florida remained the most popular destination with Americans in the upper Midwest and Northeast.
But while surveys can tell how many people have booked trips to Florida or made hotel reservations, they cannot say how many others would have booked, had the perception of danger, or the economy, been happier.
"Because of the recession, our numbers have been mostly flat the last couple of years," said William C. Peeper, executive director of the Orlando-Orange County Convention and Visitors Bureau, whose area attracts more than 13 million people annually. "We haven't seen any signs of a drop-off for this winter, but we probably won't be able to tell for a couple of months."
And in Fort Lauderdale, where foreigners account for about a quarter of the 5.1 million visitors, officials say there have been few cancellations, but a softness in bookings for later in the season. European travelers tend to make their plans three months or more in advance.
 
Problems Later in Season
 Likewise, European visits were up 9 percent through September in the St. Petersburg-Clearwater area, where tourism is the leading industry. "But there's concern that long-range bookings are not as strong as they were expected to be," said Lee Daniel of the area convention and visitors bureau.
To bolster foreign tourism, five public and private organizations in St. Petersburg and Tampa will begin a $500,000 British advertising campaign in January. Representatives from other Florida cities, and from the state tourist bureau, have gone to Europe, assuring tour operators and officials that fewer than one-tenth of 1 percent of tourists to the state in 1992 were violent-crime victims.
Nonetheless, some nations have warned their citizens about Florida travel. After two Canadians were shot to death in the summer, the Canadian Embassy's travel information report on Sept. 17 declared, "Foreign tourists in Florida have been increasingly victimized and appear to have been singled out at, or while proceeding to, popular tourist destinations."
And after a British postal worker was killed in Orlando in October 1992, the Foreign Office in London warned those visiting the United States to be wary of muggers and to carry a few dollars in cash to be able to give up to the muggers in the case of attack.
Florida recently resumed a $6.7 million advertising campaign in the United States and Canada, having suspended it after the ninth killing. With the slogan "One Florida, Many Faces," showing visitors disporting themselves at the beach, on the water and at theme parks, the ads are intended to stress the state's diversity while banishing attention to crime. Moreover, the industry has agreed to provide $3 million more for the campaign, provided the Legislature comes up with $2 million.
 
Situation in Miami
 Miami is something of a special case. Domestic travel there has been declining for several years, but foreign tourism has steadily grown and now makes up 20 percent of the total. As a result, Miami tourism had been up 4 percent through the first eight months of 1993, according to Mr. Villafana of the convention bureau. But the city is likely to end the year flat.
Some reduction in foreign visits is already being felt by tour operators and hotels in the Miami area, but things could be worse. "Luckily for Miami, enough time has passed for many people to forget about the murders, or to feel less intimidated," said Patrick D'sa, a tourism specialist with PKF Consulting in Miami.
Another thing in Miami's favor, he asserted, is that "Latin American visitors are more used to that kind of crime at home, so it doesn't keep them away the way it does some tourists."
And as many Latin Americans come to Florida to shop rather than to sun-bathe, which they can do where they live, and as they often arrive on group charters, he said, "their visits are more dependent on their economy at home than on the crime problem in Miami."

HEADLINE: Ex-Albany Workers Fined in Ethics Violations

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Former state employees have paid $8,400 in fines and settlements over the last five years after the state Ethics Commission found violations of New York's "revolving door" law.
Former state officials are prohibited from instantly profiting from their former government ties. Still, such violations are among the most common ethical transgressions discovered by the commission, according to documents made available to The Associated Press under the state's Freedom of Information Law. 
 Twelve of the 41 cases where the commission found reason to believe ethics laws had been broken involved the revolving door prohibition.
 
2-Year Interval
 The cases include a former New York City Transit Authority examiner accused of appearing before his agency as a lawyer two weeks after quitting his public post, and two former state environmental workers who formed their own consulting company and then did business with their former employer.
The law forbids former state officials from appearing before their old agencies in a business capacity for two years after leaving state service. The former state workers may never handle matters they were directly involved with while on the state payroll.
Five of the 12 "revolving door" cases are still pending. Three resulted in fines being levied, with the highest being $2,500. Four former officials agreed with the commission's lawyers on monetary settlements ranging from $150 to $1,500. The commission can seek fines of up to $10,000.
The $2,500 fine was levied on Dominick DeSimone, a former state Education Department employee. After leaving state service, Mr. DeSimone admitted to working for an architectural firm on the plans for the same Troy elementary school for which he had an oversight role while working for the state.
 
Fines of $250 to $1,000
 Mr. DeSimone said he had answered questions about the project while working for the architects but called it "a very minor kind of indiscretion."
"I thought I was bending over backwards in the first place to follow the rules, but I had to bend back further," he said.
He said he grew weary of fighting the state.
"It cost me so much for a lawyer," he said. "After awhile I just gave up."
The commission imposed a $1,000 fine on Gregory Abram, a former employee of the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, for appearing as the lawyer for a client in a rent regulation case before the agency.
Joseph Taggert, a former employee of the state Division of Equalization and Assessment, was fined $250 for appearing on behalf of an association at a meeting with division officials to discuss state regulations, the commission said.
Among the pending "revolving door" cases, with details cited in Ethics Commission reports:
 
Newsletters and Videos
 The Ethics Commission has not taken any unusual steps to curb violations of the "revolving door" law, said Walter Ayres, a spokesman for the panel. Commission workers make occasional visits to agencies and distribute newsletters and videotapes on ethics rules.
All state employees are told to read New York's public officer's law and the commission often offers confidential advice to state workers looking to change their careers, he said.

HEADLINE: Uncaging the Alter Ego, Briefly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

 BODY:
THE premise was simple. I would rent some kind of super-whiz-bang sports car and take my 55-year-old alter ego out for a spin and see what happened.
Automotively speaking, I have always been a short back and sides sort of human. I have, to be sure, had occasional yearnings for fins, aerodynamic curves, speed and power, but whenever faced with choosing a new car I always went with fuel economy, safety features, modest price and something you could drive to a funeral. 
 Now I was ready to change all that, if only for a weekend. I called Roarin' Roadster Rentals, an outfit in Clifton, N.J., to discuss what it could do for me. Bill, the man on the phone, said there were 12 models for rent, from a Ferrari 308GTSi, whatever that is, renting for a basic $999 for a three-day weekend, to a 1966 T-Bird convertible at $349 for the weekend.
I was tempted by the Ferrari but in the end dismissed the thought as probably too rich for my blood and unduly provocative for the accounting department. In my mind's eye I tried to imagine the Mercedeses, the Porsches, BMW's and Jaguars in the Roarin' Roadster inventory.
"Do you have something in red?" I asked with what I hoped sounded like savoir-faire.
"We have a Corvette convertible," Bill said. "It's metallic red, 1991, really a gorgeous car."
Gorgeous sounded right. The basic cost was $499 for the three days, with 300 free miles and 50 cents for every additional mile. Rather pleased with the prospect and feeling like Emerson Fittipaldi, whoever he is, I invited my wife, who is almost as old as my alter ego, to look at peaking leaves in the sleek, low-riding metallic red road hugger, perhaps with the top down. "Why not," she said.
Then I called our 30-year-old son to ask what tapes would be appropriate for a red Corvette.
"Kenny G, definitely Kenny G," my son said.
"But I don't like Kenny G," I replied.
"Neither do I, but you didn't ask me what was good, you asked me what went with a red Corvette," my son explained. This was my first intimation that perhaps I was signing on to someone else's Walter Mitty adventure. I ignored the musical advice and packed tapes of Ella, Sarah, Miles, Chet, B. B., Ludwig and Wolfgang.
For an extra $25 the people at Roarin' Roadster agreed to deliver the car to me in Manhattan and it arrived as promised, sleek and powerful, drawing admiring attention from several layabouts on my block.
 
The Real Point
 "Woo-wee, woo-wee," said one of these as the man from the rental company circled the Corvette with a video camera, preparing evidence that could be used against me in case I returned the car with blemishes. Somewhat intimidated, I was wondering what a scratch, or heaven forbid, a dent, might cost me when, in his own way, the chief layabout commended the car as a vehicle that was irresistible to women.
I looked up. He was leering and I realized I had not misheard. Smiling and friendly, as one predator to another, he exclaimed, "Mister, with that car, if you don't score, you'll have to hang your head in shame."
This is not what I had in mind for my alter ego. Not at all. I had thought I was going off to indulge fantasies of Le Mans, wherever that is, and emulate Juan Manuel Fangio, whoever he was, while driving through the countryside with my longstanding wife. But for the world out there, the car was sending off a set of other signals. Here, for instance, was a total stranger who, with evident admiration, was taking me for a dirty old man. The car, which I viewed as a zippy conveyance, he saw as a lure, a high-test, as in testosterone, bimbo magnet, perhaps even a prop for what he assumed to be my flagging charms.
For a second I thought of setting him straight. Instead, I ignored him and went on learning about the car's features. To my dismay, it had automatic transmission. Without a clutch, how could I pretend to be Jackie Stewart, whoever he is?
 
Short Honeymoon
 But there were some compensations. I practiced taking the top down and putting it up again. Also the steering wheel could be tilted into three positions. When you turned on the lights they flipped up and popped out from the fender. When you turned on the radio you could watch the antenna shoot up in the rear view mirror. And then there were the glove-leather seats. You got into them as you would into a bath, and with the aid of controls on the automatic stick shift console, you could manipulate the seats into any number of configurations. In fact, driving the seats seemed more challenging than driving the car.
Having mastered the gizmos, we set off for Saratoga Springs, N.Y., with the top down, the windows up and Chet Baker playing "Let's Get Lost." It was very nice to look up at the colorful trees reaching across toward one another. The sky was blue and for about an hour and a half everything was very fine. The car reached the speed limit very quickly, and the trick was to rein it in. I kept wishing for more curves.
I also kept wondering what the people driving in the other lanes were thinking of me. Did they realize that the alter ego at the wheel of the Corvette had the hand-eye coordination and courage of Stirling Moss, whoever he is? Did they appreciate the meshing of man and machine? Or did they, like the layabout still on my mind, also presume me to be just another lecher going under the speed limit?
 
Then Rain
 Then it started to rain and we put up the top. It rained for the next two days. At the toll booths, where I spurned the exact-change lanes to better gauge the responses, there were none, which led me to conclude that the toll takers were either jaded or trained in hiding their admiration and respect.
At a restaurant in Kingston, a waiter remarked, "What a great set of wheels; bet it makes you feel frisky." He did not, however, give me a nudge and a wink, for which I was grateful.
At Saratoga Springs, an old friend took one look and said, "Makes you wish you were a kid again, doesn't it?"
And, oh yes, on the way home the driver of a pickup truck smiled and gave me the O.K. sign.
And that was all the feedback there was until I brought the metallic red beauty back to my block, where, as arranged, the folks from Roarin' Roadsters were waiting to pick it up. They checked for scratches, dents or chips and I was gratified they did not find any. I was even more gratified that in the rain no one was on the street. The layabout philosopher would not be asking me whether I had to hang my head in shame.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1961 words

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Sampling Art In Sound Bites

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
FOR many people who listen to Acoustiguides, going to an art museum is like plunging into the ocean without knowing how to swim. The Acoustiguides are their cruise ships and Philippe de Montebello, the voice that launched a thousand exhibitions, is their captain.
I had never listened to an Acoustiguide until this week, when I spent a few hours at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guggenheim Museum and the Museum of Modern Art letting Mr. de Montebello, the Met's director, and an assorted crew of fellow directors, curators, vocal stand-ins, artists and artists' relatives navigate me through several shows. I don't know how much I heard that couldn't be gleaned from the wall labels and accompanying brochures and a little extra effort, but I do have more of an inkling of what it feels like to sail on a Carnival cruise. 
 That's not altogether fair. The tapes are more serious than you might think, or at least they try to be. Acoustiguides have been around since the mid-1950's, believe it or not, and by now the people who produce them have a reasonable idea of what curators want and listeners need, which are not always the same thing.
Acoustiguide is actually the name of the original and biggest of the companies that makes the tapes. Based in Manhattan, it produces hundreds of them worldwide each year, in many languages (visitors to the Forbidden City can hear Peter Ustinov narrate Acoustiguide tours in French, English and German). Acoustiguide did all three of the tapes you can hear at the moment in New York City -- one for the Miro show at the Modern, another for the Roy Lichtenstein retrospective at the Guggenheim and the third for the new 19th-century European painting and sculpture galleries at the Met. Each tape is surprisingly different from the other two in form, not to say content, although all of them last about 45 minutes, the length of a standard cassette tape and, says Acoustiguide's chairman, Amos Melamede, an average listener's attention span.
Tapes take between a couple of weeks and several months to produce, Mr. Melamede explained. The process varies, but for temporary exhibitions it is basically this: The curator putting the show together sits down with representatives from Acoustiguide, or if possible walks through the galleries with them as the works are being installed, describing the layout and talking about what will be on view.
The curator's comments are then edited by Acoustiguide into a form suited to the medium of audio and returned to the curator for approval. The company sometimes suggests music and stand-ins to read the scripts. Mr. Melamede took pains to point out that museums have constant and final say over the shape and content of the tapes. Once the tape is produced, Acoustiguide provides the salespeople to distribute it in the galleries (rental fee is about $4), and the museums take a cut of the earnings.
There was a time when renting an Acoustiguide was like requesting an English menu in a French restaurant, an admission of ignorance to be avoided by the educated classes, but now Acoustiguides are so commonplace that when I asked a few listeners in the Miro show whether they were embarrassed to be seen wearing headphones, I could see they pegged me immediately as a snob.
What did they say they expected from the tapes? Biographical and historical background, to be sure, also guidance about how to look at art that seemed indecipherable; and more than one person wanted the correct pronunciation of names and titles (you don't always get it, by the way).
In this age of CNN and fax machines, it was perhaps not surprising, but depressing nonetheless, that the museumgoers also said they depended on the tapes to provide information immediately and economically. It's a waste of time to read labels and then look at the art when someone can read to you while you look, one woman said. Tapes also pace you through a show, she added, echoing what others expressed. After roughly three-quarters of an hour, and whatever stops you make on your own, you know you will be finished, even if the exhibition is as big as the two-floor Miro retrospective.
Railing against Acoustiguides at this stage is like lamenting the demise of 78's, but you can't help wondering whether listeners know what they're getting, or more to the point, what they're missing. The sensation I had listening to Mr. de Montebello's mellifluous voice at the Met (and whoever that was masquerading as Miro at the Modern) seemed most analagous to -- snorkeling.
Odd perhaps, but I imagined the headphones as my snorkel, the tape as my goggles, while I floated through the shows, somehow never feeling that I was actually in them. When crowds don't make it impractical, I like to walk through an exhibition to get a sense of its scale and an idea of where objects are that I will want to look at more closely. Then I pace myself from the beginning. With the Acoustiguides, I imitated a minnow, darting from one corner to another with the rest of the school of listeners. I even caught myself silently mouthing words, like a fish breathing in water, as I tried to copy Mr. de Montebello's ripe renditions of "Chateaubriand" and "Delacroix" and "palette" ("pal-ETTE").
At the risk of overworking this acquatic metaphor almost as much as Mr. de Montebello works over "van Gogh" ("vhan GUGG"), I imagine Acoustiguides should be like water wings, which listeners eventually wean themselves from as they become more comfortable in museums. But I have the impression they are increasingly perceived as life rafts, to which visitors feel they must cling to survive. With the addition of music and guest stars, no wonder the raft becomes the Love Boat, and the art a visual backdrop, a perk of the voyage, like sunset over the ship's bow.
With a new phase of Acoustiguide technology on the horizon that Mr. Melamede says will allow listeners to call up information about whatever object they choose, there is the prospect of channel surfing, which is at least a form of greater independence.
Until then, here is a brief guide to the current Acoustiguides:
 
Miro
 This is the slickest, most elaborate of the three Acoustiguides, which makes it the most enjoyable or the most manipulative, depending on your perspective. With the largest ambitions in terms of historical information and formal description, it includes evocative comments about the collage paintings of 1933, the small paintings on copper and panel from 1935 and the murals from the 60's.
But it's still frustratingly scattershot, telegraphed and random. I imagine it must be difficult for someone who knows nothing about 20th-century art to decipher from a couple of sentences why Miro suddenly rejected painting and then, just as suddenly, returned to it. And I'm sure people will look at his painting of the number 48 and wonder about the steamy description of the numerals' "swelling curves and contracting lines."
This Acoustiguide features a diverse cast of narrators, including Miro's grandson, who makes some of the more cogent remarks. The curator, Carolyn Lanchner, on the other hand, interjects comments too dense to digest while jockeying for position in front of a picture. New Age music, of all things, sets the mood in various rooms, rather than letting you feel what strikes you when you look at the art.
As on the other Acoustiguides, but less so, the narrators dole out puffery in behalf of the artist and museum. Also, like the others, this Acoustiguide goes out of its way to cajole, prod and entreat listeners to switch off the tape and look around. But people seem to take little initiative, perhaps because this tape is so consuming by itself. I stopped it only a few times, and the Acoustiguide customers who entered the show roughly when I did all finished around the same time, too.
 
19th-Century Galleries
 If the Miro Acoustiguide is a feature film, this one at the Met is a home movie, despite the theatrical savoir-faire of Mr. de Montebello. Little music, no voiceovers, just the facts, ma'am. Mr. de Montebello is half of a cast that also includes the curator, Gary Tinterow, and the two of them do a pretty good Alphonse and Gaston, thanking each other for letting the other one speak, as if listeners will actually believe they were in the galleries together when the tape was recorded.
Their task is the hardest, to cover a vast range of historical material and also provide information about the galleries ("Manet himself would have been very pleased to see his pictures in this particular setting," Mr. de Montebello fantasizes).
The goal of all the tapes seems to be to cover as much as possible and not dawdle over pictures too long, lest listeners get restless. And in this case that means mentioning about three dozen works, which is too many in 45 minutes. There's a genuine effort to condense serious thought into bite-sized nuggets on this tape. But more about less would certainly have been better.
 
Lichtenstein
 Although Mr. de Montebello seems to know Manet personally, there's nothing like having the artist speak for himself. Roy Lichtenstein's descriptions of his own works are what make this Acoustiguide at the Guggenheim the most provocative of the three.
Before you get to Mr. Lichtenstein, you hear an introduction by the Guggenheim's director, Thomas Krens, who sounds suspiciously as if he may be referring to himself when he talks about how both Frank Lloyd Wright's design for the Guggenheim and Mr. Lichtenstein "departed radically from contemporary expectations."
"Both were the center of great controversy and both met with scathing criticism," he says, adding, "But today both have become cultural icons."
You also listen to Diane Waldman, the curator, who, having known Mr. Lichtenstein for three decades, is a knowledgeable guide to his career, but who, suffice it to say, is no Philippe de Montebello of the airwaves.
It's fascinating to hear Mr. Lichtenstein himself, though, describe how he developed a technique for the series of paintings depicting mirrors, first photographing magnifying mirrors that wouldn't reflect objects in focus. From the photographs he derived the canvases, which he calls "pure abstract paintings."
It is also intriguing to hear him say that he sees a link between his own art and Leger's; and to hear him compare his variations on works by Picasso with Picasso's on Velazquez. Only when he says that his work is about "how we see things, what's of value and what's real and what isn't, and nothing is, of course" does Mr. Lichtenstein sound like the Delphic oracle. Otherwise, he's refreshingly down to earth.
Even with less material to discuss than each of the other two tapes must cover, this Acoustiguide has the inevitable once-over-lightly quality. But Mr. Lichtenstein makes it worth the price of headphones.
 
Where and When

Information: (212) 535-7710.

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays and Fridays, noon to 8:30 P.M.; closed Wednesdays. Admission: $7.50; $4.50 for students and the elderly. Tape price: $4. Tour length: 45 minutes. Information: (212) 708-9480.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Cardinals and Their Coach Losing the Numbers Game

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25

 BODY:
Before taking a head-coaching job with the Phoenix Cardinals, be sure to have plenty of food in the refrigerator and some unemployment insurance. The Cardinals have provided a coaches graveyard over the years. In fact, some coaches jokingly call the team's owner, Bill Bidwell, "the nutty professor" because of his horn-rim glasses and what they say are some of the zany things he puts his coaches through.
Joe Bugel knows all about that. At the beginning of the year, Bidwell made the proclamation that Bugel had to win nine games this year. Hint, hint: Though there was no "or else" in the statement, clearly Bidwell wasn't going to give Bugel some nice silverware if he didn't reach the magic number. More like a pink slip. 
 Phoenix is 3-7, a busted-up team that continues to play hard. The Cardinals can do the necessary addition: Ten games played equals six games left, meaning they must win the rest of their games to reach the nine-victory mark and thus save Bugel's job. Common sense dictates that is not going to happen.
 
No Sympathy From Giants
 Standing in the way of the Cardinals are the Giants. While Giants Coach Dan Reeves can understand what Bugel is going through -- Reeves didn't know what the future would hold for him during his last season in Denver -- there will be no sympathy for Bugel on Sunday when the teams meet at the Meadowlands. The Giants are in a battle of their own, trying to match the Dallas Cowboys step for step.
Complicating matters even more is the unbelievably bad luck the Cardinals have had at Giants Stadium. This is the biggest and most important statistic of the game: The Cardinals have lost nine straight games in New York, their last victory coming in 1983 when they were the St. Louis Cardinals and Neil Lomax was throwing to Roy Green. That almost seems like another era.
These are the odds Bugel faces. They are not good ones.
"I'm doing real well," Bugel said this week, when asked how is he dealing with the now infamous nine-game ultimatum. "That doesn't really bother me or our football team. We have a six-game schedule right now, and we're going to give it our dead-level best. Like I said, everything has been full speed. We have a great attitude. We have a good player-coach relationship right here, so the football team has made it very interesting for both me and my staff."
Indeed, the Cardinals have been playing hard, tough football despite the losses. The week after Dallas pummeled the Giants, Phoenix went into Texas Stadium and played them tight, losing by only 20-15. The intensity and heart have never been questions.
"If you look at their last game," said Reeves, "they had a chance at the end of the game to beat Dallas in Dallas, and we had just played them and got beat bad at Dallas. So we can't underestimate this team and we've got to be ready to play."
 
High-Priced Injuries
 The biggest problems for the Cardinals have been twofold. First, they have fallen short of the great expectations provided by the off season of signing of some high-profile free agents and the drafting of some talented rookies like running back Garrison Hearst. Second, the team's psyche suffered tremendously when many of these players got hurt.
They signed four high-priced free agents -- quarterback Steve Beuerlein, receiver Gary Clark and safeties John Booty and Chuck Cecil -- and all of them have missed time because of injuries. Cecil, who is one of the team's emotional leaders but has the reputation of Darth Vader, has also had to deal with being fined by the league for alleged cheap shots and the bad publicity that comes with those fines.
"I think any time anybody has been fined like that or reprimanded like that, you think twice when somebody comes in your zone," said Bugel.
The other big injuries have been to the young blood, like Hearst and a fellow first-rounder, Earnest Dye, an offensive tackle who was so good he had been starting until he had arthroscopic knee surgery at the end of September. Then there's a second-round draft pick, offensive lineman Ben Coleman (sprained medial collateral ligament) and sixth-round linebacker Brett Wallerstedt (torn cartilage). Also lost is defensive lineman Eric Swann, who had arthroscopic surgery on his right knee earlier this month.
"I think the big reason we have lost a lot of close games is this -- and I'll be real honest with you: We don't have six or seven superstars on our football team," said Bugel. "We don't have those kinds of guys that say, 'Hey, jump on my back. I'm going to lead you to the playoffs or the Super Bowl.' "
Right now, the Cardinals aren't thinking Super Bowl. They would settle for just a few victories. Six, to be exact.
 
EXTRA POINTS
 The Giants worked out on Thanksgiving morning, then had the rest of the day off. . . . RICKY PROEHL is the Cardinals' leading receiver with 509 yards on 42 catches. He is originally from Belle Mead, N.J., and his parents, Giants season ticket-holders, haven't missed a home game since the team moved to Giants Stadium in 1975.

HEADLINE: Jailed by Hanoi, Shut Out by Washington

 BODY:
More than 20 years after the last American troops left Vietnam, a sullen shadow war still rages. Psyches on both sides remain haunted by extravagant suspicions, diplomats barely communicate, and unfortunate people trapped in the middle can pay a heavy price.
One such person is Do Ngoc Long, imprisoned and persecuted by Hanoi for his associations with anti-war Americans -- and now rebuffed by Washington in his quest for political asylum in the U.S. It would be particularly appropriate if President Clinton intervened directly in the asylum case and spared Mr. Long further torments. 
 During the war years, Mr. Long worked with the "Shoeshine Boys" project, organized by American conscientious objectors to help homeless children in Saigon and Danang. To Hanoi hard-liners, it was inconceivable that Washington would have tolerated Americans participating in such a project unless they were really secret U.S. agents.
Despite economic reforms, that kind of hard-line political mentality still persists in Vietnamese police agencies. In 1990, Mr. Long was arrested on suspicion of "activities detrimental to the national security." The allegation was based on his supposed cooperation with another anti-war American trying to end the U.S. embargo against Vietnam.
After three years' imprisonment and a campaign of denunciations in the official media, Mr. Long was released last April. Both the Bush and Clinton Administrations had told Hanoi that they were concerned about Mr. Long, and the approval of his application for entry to the U.S. as a refugee seemed a logical next step.
Yet in August, the Immigration and Naturalization Service turned him down, suggesting that he go through the years-long process of applying for an immigrant visa. According to narrow procedural guidelines, Mr. Long's arrest was too recent to qualify as clearly political. Yet the propaganda campaign against him suggests that he remains highly vulnerable so long as he stays in Vietnam.
Fortunately, however, the Immigration Service is ultimately accountable to a President familiar with the powerful emotions of the Vietnam War and the independence of Americans who opposed it. Mr. Clinton can help rescue Mr. Long from the cruel shadow war.

LENGTH: 489 words

HEADLINE: Prayer Won't Balance the Budget

 BODY:
Senator Robert Byrd calls the proposed balanced-budget amendment "a precatory expression of pious hope" -- a prayer that something nice will come of a fantasy. The Senator from West Virginia may be concerned that the amendment would curb his authority over spending as chairman of the Appropriations Committee. But, as the meticulous guardian of proper procedure, he is more certainly alarmed by the threat to the Constitution: In the specious name of balancing the books, this amendment would unbalance government.
Sponsored by Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, with 49 co-sponsors, this pernicious amendment would remove the Federal budget from majority rule. It would do so by declaring that Congress must adopt a balanced budget each year, starting in 1999, unless America is at war, or unless three-fifths of the members of both houses approve a deficit. 
 In practice, this means a two-fifths minority -- 40 percent -- could force its will on the majority. In the current Congress, the minority Republicans would be in the driver's seat. That might look good to Republicans now, but they should realize the shoe could be on the other foot someday.
Not only would the amendment undermine a fundamental concept of democracy, it would clutter the Constitution with micro-managerial detail. It seems safe to assume that if it were adopted, the Administration and Congress would conspire on spending and revenue estimates to make the budget look balanced -- as they do already to some degree. Or they would cut deals to get 60 percent approval of an unbalanced budget.
And who then would declare a "violation"? That would be up to Federal judges with life tenure, and ultimately the Supreme Court, which is no place to sort out fiscal policy. No, this is the duty of elected politicians, who can be booted out if voters are dissatisfied.
The amendment itself represents perverse fiscal policy. As President Clinton has pointed out, the deficit increases automatically when the economy dips; to avoid deficits during recessions "we [would] have to raise taxes and cut expenditures whenever the economy is weak."
Mr. Clinton declared unqualified opposition early this month, when it appeared the Senate would vote before Thanksgiving and it looked as though the amendment might pass. In 1986 a similar amendment barely failed to muster the two-thirds majority required for Constitutional amendments. Since that time the popular taste for easy-sounding remedies -- like term limits -- has obviously increased.
The Senate leadership has now postponed the vote until February, for reasons unexplained -- perhaps only to avoid the pre-adjournment crush, or perhaps to gain time to line up more opposition. It is commonly assumed that if the Senate votes "yes" the House will, too. Final adoption would still require approval by 38 states, but the time to stop this fraud is now. Responsible senators will vote "no."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: There's No Shortage Of Math Doctorates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A new report from the Department of Education, "National Excellence: A Case for Developing America's Talent," refers to a United States "shortage of graduate students in mathematics and science." 
 As a recent graduate of a doctoral program in mathematics, let me assure you that there is no shortage. Nor will there be a shortage in the near future.
A new survey of recent doctorates in mathematics, published in the November issue of the Notices of the American Mathematical Society, reports the following information: United States universities gave out 1,197 doctorates in mathematics during the 1992-93 academic year, 526 of which went to United States citizens.
This is a 14 percent increase from last year, and it is an increase of more than 50 percent from the academic year 1986-87, when these numbers were 739 and 362.
The critical statistic, however, has to do with jobs. Among those new doctorates whose employment status was known in September, 12.4 percent were unemployed!
Mathematics is not the only scientific discipline that is faced with this problem. Young physicists, for example, are so upset that to try and do something about it they worked to get two of their own elected to the board of the American Physical Society.
Using the Internet hookup, groups such as the Young Mathematicians' Network are forming to find ways to dispel this shortage myth. The truth is that there is no shortage of scientists, or graduate students, for that matter. Rather, there is a shortage of jobs!
 
EDWARD F. ABOUFADEL
New Haven, Nov. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: Bowing to U.N., Iraq Will Permit Arms Monitors

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Bowing to the pressure of shortages, hunger and inflation arising from a three-year trade embargo, Iraq said today that it had finally agreed to let the United Nations start monitoring its industries on a long-term basis to insure it does not seek again to produce weapons of mass destruction.
The agreement, described by United Nations officials as a triumph for the Security Council in its long test of strength with President Saddam Hussein, would bring Iraq into compliance with one of the few remaining major cease-fire conditions set by the victorious Persian Gulf war allies after driving Iraqi forces from Kuwait in 1991.
 
Iraq Wants Ban Lifted
 Baghdad also called today for the immediate lifting of a ban on Iraqi oil sales that has deprived it of crucial revenue. But the Security Council has said it will not agree to this until it is satisfied that President Hussein has given a full accounting of his nuclear, chemical, biological and missile weapon programs and shows that he is cooperating with the industrial monitoring. 
 Even with full Iraqi compliance, diplomats said, the embargo would thus remain in force for several months.
In Washington, Clinton Administration officials took a cautious view of the Iraqi move, emphasizing that Iraq has still not provided all the information the United States wants about its weapons of mass destruction.
A State Department spokeswoman, Christine Shelly, called talk of lifting sanctions "clearly premature." Iraq has broken many promises in the past, she said, and must now "demonstrate on the ground over a sustained period of time it full cooperation with the monitoring and verification regime."
Iraq must also fill in "longstanding gaps and inconsistencies" in the accounts it has given of its weapon programs," she added.
Detailed talks on setting up new monitoring procedures will continue here into next week. An Iraqi delegation led by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz is meeting here with the special commission established by the Security Council to oversee the dismantling of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
Over the last two and a half years, Iraq has repeatedly tried to hide nuclear equipment, denied arms inspectors access to industrial and military sites and refused to blow up military installations, before finally agreeing to comply.
Iraq informed the Security Council of its decision in a letter delivered today to the Council President. "I should like to inform you of the decision of the Government of Iraq to accept the obligations stated in Resolution 715 (1991)," wrote Foreign Minister Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, "and to comply with the provisions of the plans for monitoring and verification in accordance with said resolution."
Rolf Ekeus, the Swedish diplomat who leads the special commission on weapons destruction, said he interpreted this to mean that Iraq had accepted the detailed monitoring plans the Security Council has approved. "This means a major obstacle has been removed," he said.
 
Inventory of Sites
 Resolution 715, adopted in October 1991, required Iraq to provide a full inventory of plants and other sites involving potential weapons of mass destruction, as well as lists of machinery, chemicals and other materials that might be used in making such arms.
Mr. Ekeus described Baghdad's pledge as "a triumph for the Council"demonstrating that the sanctions and embargoes against Iraq have worked, "although it takes some time." He said the Security Council had "made it clear to the leadership in Iraq that there is no way out."
But Mr. Ekeus said that Iraq would have to provide him with more information about its programs to develop arms of mass destruction and its long-range missile program before he could verify to the Security Council that the country had abandoned all plans to acquire such weapons.
 
Call to End Oil Ban
 The Iraqi letter called on the Security Council to begin carrying out "its obligations towards Iraq as stated in Resolution 687," which set out the terms for ending the gulf war. It called for "immediate and full implementation of Paragraph 22 without any obstructions, limitations or additional conditions."
Paragraph 22 of Resolution 687 states that the ban on foreign purchases of Iraqi oil "shall have no further force or effect" once the Security Council is satisfied that Baghdad has fully complied with its obligation to give up its weapons of mass destruction and agreed to the long-term monitoring of its arms industry.
Before any reversal of the ban of oil sales, the Security Council is expected to adopt another resolution requiring that a third of such payments go into a special United Nations fund to compensate victims of the Kuwait invasion of Kuwait.
Iraq also alluded in the letter to a longstanding request that the United Nations inspectors use Iraqi helicopters in traveling about the country instead of aircraft loaned by the German Air Force.
 
Embargo Followed Invasion
 The United Nations approved the oil embargo on Aug. 6, 1990 -- days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait -- as part of a broader package of economic sanctions that also barred Iraq from exporting or importing other goods.
Ambassador Ekeus said it would take his inspectors some months at the very least to prepare a monitoring "protocol" for every industry he wants to inspect and to set "baseline" rules for future inspections. He said his inspectors would want to watch any site that could be used to develop nuclear or chemical weapons, including pharmaceutical laboratories and breweries.
Before the special commission can report that it has even accounted for all potential weapons of mass destruction, Mr. Ekeus wants more information about Iraq's suppliers -- particularly providers of sensitive technology that Western companies are not supposed to export without permission.
Last week a team of international inspectors took earth, water and vegetable samples for analysis from a site in the southern Iraqi marshes where Shiite dissidents have accused the Iraqi Army of carrying out chemical weapons attacks in late September.
The C.I.A. has said it suspects Iraq may still be hiding about 100 banned Scud missiles, although the inspectors have not been able to find them.
 
Import Permission
 Even if the ban on Iraqi oil sales is lifted, Baghdad will still need to get the Security Council's clearance to import goods with the oil revenue it receives.
Under Resolution 687, the ban on sales to Iraq must also remain in force until the Security Council decides Baghdad is in full compliance with all relevant resolutions.
The Council must also be satisfied with "the policies and practices of the Government of Iraq," which means, among other things, that Baghdad must recognize its newly demarcated frontier with Kuwait and cease its attacks on the Shiites in the south and the Kurds in the north.

The Economy
Shoppers turned out in large numbers for the opening day of the Christmas retail season. But in Atlanta, at least, the big draw wasn't the merchandise so much as the prospect of discounts and early-bird specials. Some showed hesitancy to buy until they were satisfied with a gift's price and utility, and many came with coupons and plans to shop for the best prices. [Page 35.] 
 The Southeast's economy is outpacing the rest of the country as the nation climbs out of recession, reflecting the changing balance of economic power. The region is adding jobs and people substantially faster than the nation as a whole and cementing its status as the nation's favored location for new manufacturing plants. [1.]
The aging freight tracks threading through New York City and Long Island may be key to the region's economic future, planners say, because the area's highways are clogged with trucks. [1.]

The struggle between A.T.& T., MCI and Sprint for long-distance customers is intensifying as technology expands the number of calls that phone networks can carry and competition from cable companies and local carriers grows. [35.]

Markets
The stock market felt the effects of a sharp drop in oil prices. Shares in big oil producers dragged down the Dow industrial average, which slipped 3.63, while transportation issues rose. [35.]
Mexican stocks surged in a positive reaction to the Government's proposed new foreign investment law. [36.]
Treasury bond prices posted sharp gains, buoyed by the positive effect of falling oil prices on expectations of inflation. [39.]
The dollar posted modest gains and gold was mostly lower overseas. [46.] Lumber futures rose to eight-month highs. [46.]
 
International
An auditor's study commissioned by Volkswagen exonerated the company of industrial espionage accusations in its trade secrets dispute with G.M. VW also said it expected to lose about $1.1 billion in 1993 and sees no improvement next year. [35.]
Japanese share prices plunged amid news that banks' bad loans had risen and business lending was sluggish. The Government also said retail sales had fallen 3.6 percent in October. [35.]
Iraq bowed to pressures of shortages, hunger and inflation from a three-year trade embargo and agreed to let the United Nations monitor its weapons production. [1.]

Low-cost term life insurance can be the answer to the perplexing questions of how much and what type of coverage to buy. [33.]

HEADLINE: Mexican Bull Rides Higher

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Mexican stocks surged again today as investors reacted positively to the Government's proposed foreign investment law.
The Mexican stock exchange's index of 37 issues rose 30.06 points, or 1.35 percent, to a record close of 2,261.20. The gain came atop Thursday's surge of 67.07 points. 
 The Mexican Government disclosed details of the proposed law on Thursday, which would open many sectors of the economy to foreign investment. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has sent the legislation to Congress, where approval is all but certain, given his party's dominance there.
Traders here said that the proposal was prolonging a kind of euphoria in the stock market, already bolstered by the United States approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Among the stocks showing large gains today was the media giant Televisa, as well as two construction companies, Empresas Ica Sociedad Controladora and Tribasa.
More details emerged today on the proposed legislation. Under it, Mexico will allow foreigners to invest in oil-drilling companies and in companies that build oil and gas pipelines.
The bill restricts foreigners to minority stakes in such companies under ordinary circumstances, but allows stakes higher than 49 percent with approval by regulators.
The measure continues to bar foreign and private investors from owning the country's oil and gas reserves. These will remain in Mexican state control.
A spokeswoman for Pemex, the state oil monopoly, said the law would not affect the company's operations.
The measure also provided for less privatization of oil and natural gas than some Government officials and press accounts had suggested.
Officials were quoted as saying that the Government was considering allowing foreign and private companies to build and operate natural-gas pipelines for their own use and even to import their own supplies of natural gas, instead of depending on Pemex.

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: The Southeast;
In Race to Outrun Recession, Southeast Sets Dazzling Pace

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, N.C.

 BODY:
The Southeast is outpacing the rest of the country as the nation climbs out of recession, reflecting a long, slow process of growth in the South and the changing balance of economic power in America.
Whether in increasingly prominent areas of growth like Atlanta, Nashville or Charlotte or more obscure ones like the Greensboro/ Winston-Salem/High Point area here, the Southeast is adding jobs and people substantially faster than the nation and cementing its status as the nation's favored location for new manufacturing plants. 
 "Unemployment rates are around 4 percent throughout North Carolina," said Mark Vitner, an economist with First Union Bank in Charlotte. "Atlanta has added more jobs than any other city in the country in the last year. When you look at state-to-state migration, you see that people are moving to the South, because that's where all the jobs are."
 
Rich-and-Poor Gap
 But the growth comes in a region in which the gap between rich and poor is the largest in the nation and still widening. And it is no longer clear whether the advantages the South has in the national economy will mean as much in the emerging international one. As a result, some of the economic fears in much of the nation remain pervasive in the South as well.
Still, the positive trends for the South are widespread and diverse. This spring, economic activity in the Southeast grew at roughly twice the national rate, 4 percent versus 1.9 percent. Florida led the nation in population growth from 1990 to 1992, adding almost 500,000 residents. Every Southern state exceeded the nation's population growth rate.
For the first two quarters of 1992, job growth in the South was more than double that of the nation, with a regional job gain of 2.2 percent, as against 1 percent nationally. Long-suffering Mississippi, still the nation's poorest state, led the nation in the percentage of jobs created over the past year.
North Carolina led the nation from 1990 to 1992 in new manufacturing plants and major expansions, with 725. Of the top 12 states in manufacturing growth, nine were in the South. Last year 22 new manufacturing plants came to this area, known as the Piedmont Triad, the second largest increase in the nation, after Charlotte. In October, North Carolina had the lowest unemployment rate of the nation's major industrial states, at 4.8 percent. California had the highest at 9.8 percent.
Atlanta added 72,100 jobs over the past year, more than any other metropolitan area. Charlotte was second. Sales tax revenue showed healthy increases in most Southeast states.
 
Problem of Poverty
 To a distressing degree, the progress coexists with entrenched and sometimes worsening poverty.
David Birch, a Boston-based expert on entrepreneurial activity, recently completed a report that concluded that four of the nation's top five centers of entrepreneurial activity -- Charlotte, Atlanta, Nashville and the Raleigh-Durham area -- were in the South. The fifth was Indianapolis. But he was quick to add that this did not reflect a broad regional prosperity in the South.
"It's not like all the South is suddenly like Charlotte," he said. "As the growth in the United States slows down, you're going to have a few bright green islands in a huge mudflat. And a lot of the South is going to be mudflat."
But in a nation where the economic reversals of the past few years have taken a psychological as well as a financial toll on many regions, what most distinguishes the South may be the degree of optimism throughout the region.
There are fears for the future in the South, particularly in areas dependent on low-wage industries like apparel manufacturing. But more common is a sense that the South's current success reflects a long-term economic tide sweeping its way.
"The notion of the American dream, the sense that your children will do as well or better than you, is alive and well in the South," said Wayne Gantt an economist in Atlanta. "It's very bruised in California. It's taken a hit in New England. In the South, people still think their kids can do better than they're doing."
 
The Boom
The South Rises Again
 Greensboro, long synonymous with textile manufacturing, is not one of the glamour locations in the South, like Raleigh-Durham to the east or Charlotte to the south.
But the Greensboro/Winston-Salem/High Point area, with 1.2 million people spread out over 11 counties, is a good reflection of the region's current success.
Unemployment stands at 4 percent, and the 2.2 percent job growth of 12,500 jobs over the past year is well ahead of the national average. While the nation saw manufacturing jobs fall by 2.3 percent over the past year, they rose by 1 percent here. North Carolina now has a higher percentage of its jobs in manufacturing, 26.4 percent, than anywhere else in the nation.
And the manufacturing is increasingly sophisticated. Long rooted in textiles and tobacco, the area's manufacturing has expanded into pharmaceuticals, automotive parts and electronics in recent years as it has become the manufacturing center complementing the banking hub at Charlotte and the research, education and service axis in Raleigh-Durham.
Across the region, the South is succeeding by doing a lot of things well. The most vulnerable sector is the kind of low-skill manufacturing that was once the backbone of the South's economy. The most recent quarterly forecast by Georgia State University says the weakest segment of the South's economy is nondurable manufacturing like apparel production.
But Tennessee is doing well because of the expansion of the auto industry around Nashville. Mississippi is benefiting largely from gambling and the opening of 10 riverboat casinos. Charlotte's economy, based on banking, services and manufacturing is doing so well the 3.7 percent unemployment rate is raising fear of worker shortages. The manufacturing jobs range from low-wage chicken plants to high-wage auto plants, with automobiles, industrial and electronic machinery, lumber, and food processing doing particularly well.
 
I-85's Route to Prosperity
 "The South has a small plus in manufacturing jobs, but the nation is a fairly large minus, so to have any plus at all is a great performance," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta.
Much of the growth is in expected places. The Interstate-85 corridor in North Carolina alone added 75,000 new jobs in the past year. A recent report by Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm, said the 300-mile-long Interstate-85 corridor from Raleigh-Durham to Atlanta offers the nation's best potential for business locations in the 1990's.
But even some of the economic laggards of the Deep South are doing well. Tupelo, Miss., whose previous claim to fame was as Elvis Presley's birthplace, has quietly become one of the furniture manufacturing capitals of the world and a place that is adding about 1,000 jobs a year, many of them in sophisticated manufacturing.
"We've already done $120 million worth of plant investment this year, and before the calendar year is over, we could easily do $200 million," said Harry A. Martin, president of Tupelo's Community Development Foundation. "We have plants here from Australia, from the Netherlands, from Brazil, from Switzerland. We barely knew about the recent recession that everybody talked about so much."
 
The Reasons
Five Secrets Of Success
 In part the South has been succeeding because of its traditional attributes of cheaper labor, land and living costs, a lack of unions and its more relaxed, warm-weather way of life. Also helping is an aging population more likely to move South and a maturing regional banking and finance system in which Charlotte is now the nation's third largest banking center.
In addition, with the exception of Virginia, which is lagging behind the rest of the region, and Charleston, S.C., most of the South has not been hit as hard by military cutbacks as California and some other states.
But at least five factors are particularly significant at a time states and regions are increasingly competing with one another for jobs and industry.
First is the importance of the international economy.
Long before the contemporary vogue for all things international, Southern promoters, particularly in the Carolinas, were beating the bushes for European investment. By the early 1970's, half the foreign industrial development in the nation was coming in the South. Spartanburg, S.C., alone had attracted 24 foreign companies. It now has 83 from 13 countries, including the B.M.W. manufacturing plant being constructed near Greer that will provide 2,000 jobs.
And from the Japanese in Tennessee to the Dutch in Atlanta, the South is increasingly seeing sales, investment and new regional headquarters from overseas companies. It is an advantage for the region that seems certain to continue, spurred in part by the regional marketing bonanza of the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.
Second is the momentum provided by decades of outpacing the nation in industrial and manufacturing growth. The high-profile locations of Mercedes in Alabama, B.M.W. in South Carolina, Nissan and Saturn in Tennessee, and Toyota in Kentucky in recent years, plus the myriad of suppliers and satellite industries they attract, are only the most conspicuous part of what many see as a new industrial axis drawing other companies in its wake.
"Imagine an oval that begins in your mind at Indianapolis," said Carlton Schwab, a senior consultant with PHH Fantus Consulting, in Chicago, one of the nation's leading site-selection consultants.
"You go left or west through Illinois or maybe to Kansas City, down to Texarkana and then across the top of the south back through Birmingham, Tuscaloosa, over down as far as Macon and then over through the Carolinas. That is where most of the new manufacturing investment in the United States is taking place. Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, Tennessee, parts of Alabama are in that oval and are taking advantage of it."
The third factor in the South's success is a long history of and near mania for industrial recruiting and economic development.
There is growing debate, both in and outside the South, over whether the inducements and tax breaks used to lure companies have got out of hand. Some experts, like James C. Cobb of University of Tennessee, author of "The Selling of the South" (University of Illinois Press), a history of Southern industrialization, say the South has given up many of the advantages of industrialization, like adequate tax revenues to provide adequate social services, by being overly generous to industry. But at a time of ever fiercer competition for jobs, the South's history of modest regulation and concrete inducements for industry is forcing other states to play a game the South has pioneered.
 
California No Longer Smug
 "For years a state like California would snub their nose at the South and say we don't have to go chasing around the world for capital like the frequent flier Governors of the South do," said Douglas Woodward, an economist at the University of South Carolina. "It was a smug attitude, and it takes a good recession to wring it out."
Fourth, surprisingly, is education.
Many parts of the South retain their status at the bottom of the nation's educational heap. But the education gap that long scarred the South has been narrowed, if hardly obliterated. For example, Fortune magazine recently named the Raleigh-Durham area, home of Duke University, North Carolina State, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Research Triangle Park, this year's best place for business.
The South still has some of the worst public schools in the country, and the parlous state of education is one of the factors holding back the Deep South laggards like Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana. But states like North Carolina and South Carolina have been innovators in using technical schools and community colleges for job training and vocational education, which is one of the prime attractions for industries in places like Greensboro.
The fifth factor is the South's quality of life, an intangible consideration that is increasingly important as advances in technology and communications make it possible to do most businesses almost anywhere.
With warmer weather, newer roads, bridges and highways, cheaper housing and at least a perception of less crime, cities like Charlotte, Nashville and Atlanta are offering an easier style of urban life than the nation's older cities. That is particularly significant as many residents of older areas from Los Angeles to New York are looking for alternatives.
To some experts the bottom line has less to do with what the South is doing right than an economic balancing act played out over time in which economic inequalities tend to even out.
"I think the main thing the South has going for it is the lower cost of living, and there's just not a whole lot other areas can do about that," said Mr. Woodward of South Carolina. "I think it's just sort of the South's turn."
But throughout the region, there is the sense that just as the Sun Belt boom of the 1970's marked the re-emergence of the region, the 1990's are marking its maturation.
 
The Gloomy Side
Deep Poverty Casts a Shadow
 Still, if this is the South's time, it is often a conflicted, edgy one.
For almost every rosy statistic there is another that is a reminder of how tenuous and incomplete the South's progress has been. Vast stretches of the South from eastern North Carolina to the South Carolina Low Country and from the Alabama Black Belt to the Mississippi Delta remain mired in some of the nation's worst poverty.
"The South, like the rest of the nation, is developing a two-track economy, two-track work force and two-track life style," said Bob Hall, of the Institute for Southern Studies, a research organization in Durham. "There are more B.M.W.'s in the South, and there are more mobile homes, and these days there's a sense of anxiety among ordinary working people that's almost palpable."
To an alarming extent, poverty has not only persisted but increased as the South's prospects have improved.
During the 1980's, as cities like Atlanta and Charlotte boomed and the region outperformed the nation, the number of Southerners living in poverty rose by 8.9 percent, and the percentage of residents living in poverty increased in Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia.
A 1992 study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a nonprofit advocacy and research group, found that of the 10 states with the widest gaps between those at the top of the income ladder and those at the bottom, eight were in the South. Even more ominously, of those states where the gap widened the most in 1980's, five were in the South.
 
Some Troubled Industries
 And if some places like Tupelo and Greensboro can boast of new high-productivity manufacturing jobs, many of the South's manufacturing jobs remain in the imperiled apparel industry or in low-wage, high-stress chicken and catfish processing, like the Imperial Food Products chicken processing plant in Hamlet, N.C., where a fire two years ago killed 25 people and injured 56 others.
One of the South's great coups of the 1990's has been the decision of B.M.W. to locate a $350 million manufacturing plant near Greer, S.C., that will provide 1,200 jobs by 1996 and 2,000 by 2000.
So far, 55,000 people have applied for jobs, a demand so intense the plant will only take applications by mail.
"What used to be the Bible Belt is now the industrial belt, but you go 40 miles from an interstate highway, and it's the Old South," said a B.M.W. spokesman, Bobby Hitt. "It's still poor. It's still backwater."
To many experts, the 55,000 job seekers are more significant than the 2,000 jobs.
"Leading the economy in 1993 is not the same as doing it in 1963 would have been," said Professor Cobb, the author and historian. "It's not just that the South has risen, it's that the rest of the economy has sunk."
 
The Murky Future
Trade Pact Raises Difficult Questions
 If the debate about the North American Free Trade Agreement was searing nationally, it had particular resonance in the South because it got to the heart of just what kind of a place the South is today.
To its supporters, the agreement is a natural for a region that has newer, more productive manufacturing, more entrepreneurial hustle, closer geographic ties to Mexico and more of a history of foreign trade and exporting than the rest of the nation. A study of the trade agreement by the Carter Center of Emory University says that six Southeastern states have seen their trade with Mexico grow by 273 percent from 1987 to 1992, the fastest growth rate in the nation.
To its detractors, the accord represents the South's getting bit by its own dog. They say that a region that has used low costs to lure industry will now see the same industries go farther south, to Mexico. More than 30 percent of the jobs in all the Southern states except Florida and Virginia are blue-collar, as against 25.6 percent nationwide.
To be sure, there is some evidence to support both sides of the debate. But Southern representatives supported the trade agreement in the House by a bigger margin than those from any other region. The accord may or may not provide the benefits its backers say it will. But the support reflects the degree to which Southerners increasingly believe the first view of the South is more telling than the second.
"Success generally breeds success, and this is really helping the South," Mr. Schwab said. "They're sending a signal out that 'Hey, we're not a backwater. We're one of the leading economic engines, not only in the United States, but of the world.' "

HEADLINE: Clinton Plans Change in the Law Banning Military Aid to Pakistan

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is proposing the repeal of a law that has barred American military aid to Pakistan because of that country's efforts to develop a nuclear bomb. But State Department officials insisted today that they did not intend to lift sanctions against Pakistan.
The Administration proposal, in a draft of a new foreign aid bill recently sent to Congress, would repeal the so-called Pressler Amendment, which bans military aid to Pakistan unless the President can certify that Pakistan neither possesses nuclear weapons nor is trying to develop them. 
 In place of the amendment, named after Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, the Administration would substitute generic language in which no specific country is named.
 
Inspections Are Sought
 The provision would ban American assistance to any "nonnuclear weapon states" that have equipment capable of enriching or reprocessing fissionable materials for nuclear weapons, unless the country submits to inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency to insure that the reprocessing is for civilian purposes.
Pakistan would still not qualify for American aid under the proposed change.
"Pakistan remains under Pressler Amendment sanctions in accordance with U.S. law," the State Department said today in a statement. "Even if a new foreign assistance act without specific language on Pakistan were passed, we would continue to apply Pressler standards to Pakistan."
But some in Congress note that the proposed bill allows the President to waive economic sanctions against a country that may be building a nuclear bomb if he determines it is in the national interest to do so. Those critics say the Administration's proposal thus weakens the Pressler Amendment, which contains no waiver provision.
 
'Wonderful Smokescreen'
 "It's a wonderful smokescreen," said an aide to Mr. Pressler. "The State Department has always wanted to get rid of the Pressler Amendment because it has no waiver."
The Pressler Amendment, enacted in 1985, states that as long as Pakistan has a nuclear bomb or the main components of a bomb, "no technology shall be sold or transferred to Pakistan."
For five years, the Reagan and Bush Administrations certified that Islamabad did not possess the cability to detonate a nuclear bomb, a finding widely considered to be a good will effort toward a country that was helping guerrillas fight Soviet forces in Afghanistan.
In 1990, after Soviet soldiers had withdrawn from Afghanistan, the Bush Administration stopped protecting Pakistan from the amendment's sanctions and the aid was cut off.
 
Rapid Ability Estimated
 Central Intelligence Agency analysts have estimated that Pakistan has the ability to assemble a nuclear bomb relatively quickly.
Clinton Administration officials say the proposal to repeal the Pressler Amendment arises from a desire to eliminate references to specific countries in the foreign aid bill to give the Administration more flexibility in conducting foreign policy. This year, Congress did eliminate most of the wording known as "earmarks," references to specific countries in the bill. "Pressler got caught up in a general cleansing of foreign assistance legislation," one State Department official said in reference to the amendment. "In fact, Pressler was the one item that we thought the hardest about, because we understood how important it was to certain members of Congress, and the importance of the issue of proliferation."
Some State Department officials note that the proposal is contained in what is termed a "discussion draft" of the foreign aid bill.
The bill is a kind of trial balloon in which the Administration is floating a number of ideas to gauge Congressional reaction. One official said that if the proposal to repeal the Pressler Amendment touched off a storm of criticism in Congress, the amendment probably would be retained.
