HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
"Finally," President Clinton said at a convention of black ministers two weeks ago, "we may be ready to do something about it."
Mr. Clinton was speaking from the pulpit in Memphis where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his last sermon. The "it" that the President hoped the nation might finally confront was the blight of crime, drugs, joblessness and family disintegration that has cast such a shadow on Dr. King's dream. A political column in The Washington Post by E. J. Dionne termed President Clinton's speech "the most important of his 10-month-old Presidency." 
 Why? Because in dealing with the problems haunting black America, Mr. Clinton was linking the typically liberal emphasis on government actions to foster employment and economic security with the typically conservative emphasis on buttressing family stability, moral values and personal responsibility.
This theme of a moral and cultural revolution has cropped up more and more in White House pronouncements ever since Hillary Rodham Clinton's speech last April about the "politics of meaning."
There are models for this kind of moral and cultural revolution. Two centuries ago, England was hit with a wave of evangelical piety -- the Methodism of Mrs. Clinton's forebears -- combined with Romantic sentimentality, no-nonsense doctrines of self-help and new economic opportunities. A land of libertine aristocrats and displaced country folk marinating themselves in various gin lanes was transformed into a land of middle-class and working-class Victorian respectability.
Whatever the losses, the result was almost certainly a kinder, gentler environment for women and children.
Those who believe that a cultural stiffening of personal standards is still possible point to recent small-scale examples. The culture now stigmatizes, and sometimes even heavily penalizes, behavior that once was taken for granted: anti-Semitism, overt racism, cigarette smoking, public celebration of drug use and the routine designation of stereotypical roles or traits to women. Success is less than total, but the changes are real.
Have things reached the point when society will mobilize, as President Clinton hopes, for a similar cultural revolution in regard to the interlocking triangle of family breakdown, crime-ridden neighborhoods and joblessness?
Are passage of the Brady gun-control bill, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign against inner-city violence and Janet Reno's jabs at televised mayhem straws in the wind? Or are they well-meant but feeble gestures, substitutes for the decisive and possibly costly measures that society is unwilling to take?
Adding urgency to these questions are the data first presented by the author and researcher Charles Murray in The Wall Street Journal.
The nation, he noted, is approaching the point where one of every three children will be born to an unmarried mother. In 1991, 22 percent of the white births were to single women, most of them with low incomes and less than a high school education. The illegitimacy birthrate among white women is nearing the 25 percent that Mr. Murray believes is a kind of tipping point.
Twenty-five percent was the black illegitimacy rate that moved Daniel Patrick Moynihan in 1965 to write his much-debated Government memorandum warning about the state of the black family. Since then, that rate has gone to 68 percent -- and more than 80 percent in many urban neighborhoods -- with parallel increases in crime and dropping out of the work force, developments that Mr. Murray views as linked to fatherless children.
"The single most important social problem of our time," Mr. Murray said, is the emergence of a "critical mass" of fatherless children. It is the crucial factor, he argued, in poverty, crime, drugs, illiteracy -- the whole snarl of social pathologies.
A lot of people agree with Mr. Murray about that, but don't agree with his proposed solution: abolish all economic support for single mothers, all welfare, all food stamps and all housing subsidies (he somewhat begrudgingly exempts medical care).
By throwing poor young mothers and their babies on the benevolence of parents, relatives, boyfriends, neighbors, churches and charities, Mr. Murray expects to detonate one of those cultural and moral revolutions.
The threat of this economic burden would jolt families and communities to reinstate all the forces --like promoting chastity, chaperoning, contraception, abortion, ready adoption, shotgun marriages and social stigma, generally -- that operate against conceiving, bearing or keeping fatherless children.
Leave aside the reasons that this proposal might not work. Even if it did, in the meantime fatherless children and their unmarried mothers would bear the brunt of the change. In effect, they are hostages who would be threatened with disaster in order to restore social discipline.
This is a draconian solution. If strong measures are required, why not ones that might impinge on the more comfortable segments of society, rather than on the most vulnerable?
For example, should the marketing edge obtained by blatant sexual appeals, verbal shock tactics or displays of violence be held as socially despicable as racist demagoguery? Should newspapers and television voluntarily forgo advertising such products and personalities?
Down that route, of course, lies financial disadvantage and what might be even more frightening for the culturally influential, the specter of Victorian respectability.
To what extent are pacesetters in the entertainment industry ready to give up the excitement of breaking taboos or to take seriously the possibility that an environment saturated with images of sex and violence might be linked to the self-destructive behavior of 15-year-olds?
"Finally, we may be ready to do something about it," President Clinton told the black ministers. The President and the ministers may be ready. It is not clear that many of the nation's other cultural leaders are equally determined.

HEADLINE: Armed for Shopping, But Often Just Looking

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Merchants had no trouble whipping shoppers into a frenzy today, luring some from hours away to be first in line when stores opened. By 9:20 A.M., four cars outside the Lenox Square Shopping Center here had a nearly calamitous convergence where just one was pulling out.
But here, as in much of the United States, the big draw on the traditional opening day of the Christmas shopping season wasn't the merchandise so much as the prospect of big discounts and early-bird specials. 
 If consumers are showing some renewed willingness to spend, those crowding the stores today didn't whip out their wallets until they were satisfied with a gift's price and utility.
 
 
The Deal's the Thing
 And many came prepared, armed with coupons, lists and the patience to shop around for a better deal.
Charlotte Doyle and Patricia Boone rose before 5 A.M. to drive down from Cartersville in north Georgia, pick up a friend in the Atlanta suburbs and gather in the darkness by the doors of the Rich's department store at Lenox Square before it opened at 7 A.M.
Clutching a sheaf of discount coupons good only until 10 A.M., they appeared more intent on buying what they needed than adding to their Christmas expenses.
Their friend Bobbie White, in need of a coat, settled on a marked-down leather model. Pushing a coupon across the counter that saved her an additional 10 percent, she asked, "Because I'm the first customer, do I get another 20 percent off?"
The woman behind the cash register smirked. "If that happened, I would be the first customer," she said.
Mrs. White was just warming up. "Twenty-four coupons, ladies," she announced, turning to her friends. "Twenty-three to go."
 
 
Look Now, Pay Later
 Despite heavy traffic today, more and more of the actual buying comes later. Last year, the Friday after Thanksgiving did not even rank among the 10 busiest days in sales, which were all closer to Christmas, said Isaac Lagnado, an owner of the Tactical Retail Solutions consulting firm. "It's a game of chicken that the consumer plays with the retailer," he said. "More often than not, the retailer blinks first."
Laura Leick was doing some Christmas looking at Tiffany & Company at a mall just across the intersection from Lenox Square. "I'm just kind of getting ideas about what's out here," she said as she took in a glistening panorama of silver, crystal and jewels.
But when it comes time to do her Christmas shopping, Mrs. Leick, a middle manager for Delta Air Lines, knows where she will end up. "For him, Home Depot," she said, nodding toward her husband, who was browsing a couple of counters away. "Power tools."
Downpours in Atlanta today and cold weather across much of the rest of the country limited the turnout somewhat. In Atlanta, malls were more crowded than stand-alone stores or shops at strip shopping centers. Snow and ice in Dallas, St. Louis and Minneapolis kept some shoppers away early in the day, retailers said.
 But after 12 percent sales gains last year on a burst of post-election optimism, retailing experts are so far apart in their Christmas predictions that they are listening to every whisper of consumer sentiment.
In Atlanta, they could hear shoppers intent on spending at least as much as last year, but without the income gains to spend much more. Just as corporations are scrutinizing every expense, so are their employees.
 
 
A Favorite Trial Market
 "I don't think we're going to go overboard," said Mrs. Leick, heading out of Tiffany to the Museum Shop, where presents were more likely to cost $20 than $200 or $2,000. Delta was trying to cut costs and restore its profits, she said, adding, "We just got a pay cut of 5 percent."
The Atlanta region, with 2.8 million people, represents the nation's shopping habits so well that it is a favorite trial market for new products. Outside the downtown, malls often sit at the center of communities lacking town squares or business districts.
Nationally, retailers have enjoyed a recent spurt of spending, but economists say much of it represents delayed purchases of furniture, cars, refrigerators and other large items unlikely to be found under a Christmas tree.
"I'm buying less for everybody," said Nancy Akin, looking over the housewares at Rich's. "Every time I buy less, it will be a gift from them to me for fixing up our house."
Ms. Akin and her mother, Nancy, have just finished painting and they need drapes and lighting fixtures. "When everything starts falling down, it's time to do something," her mother said.
Some customers at Tiffany were not quite so conservative. The store manager said the number of shoppers gathering outside the doors long before the normal 10 A.M. opening persuaded him to welcome them in at 9:30. Two promptly bought pearl-and-diamond brooches for $5,900 each.
 
 
High Hopes for Discounters
 A Kmart less than 10 minutes away, however, was ready to open at 7 A.M. Some retailing experts expect discounters to register the season's largest gains.
Demetrius Jackson, who is about to enter college, and his brother Corey, a high school student, were willing to spend their savings from part-time grocery store jobs on a desk for their mother, but not without plenty of research. "This is the first place," said Corey, pulling open the drawers on a do-it-yourself kit at Kmart for $135, marked down from $179.95. "We've got to check around."
Next stop, Service Merchandise. "And Rich's," Demetrius said. "And Macy's," Corey added.
A Home Depot a couple of strip centers away attracted some shoppers who had been checking prices by phone. William and Barbara Wylly found a $23.83 solid brass kickplate for the front door of the house their daughter had just bought, though they couldn't find matching carriage lamps for the doorposts.
"Do we need doorknobs, too?" Mrs. Wylly asked as they passed a display.
"No, dear," her husband said, steering toward the cash register.
Home Depot, which calls Atlanta its home, has come to personify warehouse chic, all cinder block and ceiling-high steel racks. Now it is exploiting its role as a Christmas destination.
Antoinette Armstrong, wearing an orange carpenter's apron, spent much of the day lavishing a new counter with gold garlands, poinsettias, red ribbons and Christmas lights. "Gift Certificates," a banner proclaimed.
"We did such a good business in gift certificates last year," Ms. Armstrong said, "that now I get to decorate."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

TRYING TO GET THE TRACKS BACK
Many policy planners say the area's highways have become so congested with trucks that the revival of railroad freight tracks may well be vital to further economic growth. The first halting steps in that direction are already under way. The Long Island Rail Road expects to move 17 percent more freight this year than in 1991. Another company that hopes to profit through the increase in rail freight is the New York Cross Harbor Terminal Corporation, which operates barges that carry freight trains from Jersey City to Brooklyn. Page 1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
MIDTOWN COURT, SEVEN WEEKS LATER
In its seventh week of business, the Midtown Community Court is gamely struggling with how to mete out punishment, community payback and social services under one roof. Earnestness and optimism still abound, but reality keeps butting in: since the court opened its doors, many defendants have shown up two or three times, already rearrested for the same crime. Page 1. 

TKTS BOOTH CLOSING IN BROOKLYN
The TKTS booth at Cadman Plaza in downtown Brooklyn, operated by the Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn, will slam its shutters for the last time, ending an eight-year run of offering discount theater tickets at the site, and loyal theatergoers were fuming. Page 22.
 
INQUIRY IN TUNNEL ACCIDENT BEGINS
Like explorers on a fantastic journey into the center of the earth, a team of investigators descended into an enormously deep steel-and-concrete shaft at a construction site in Queens to examine tangled wreckage and the winch that fell in, killing one worker. The investigators reported no progress in the search for the cause of the accident, which happened Wednesday at Grand Avenue and Page Place in Maspeth, at a site for the construction of New York City's Third Water Tunnel. Page 23.
 
 REGION
 
WHITMAN FACING SCHOOLS ISSUE
When Christine Todd Whitman takes office next January, she will face an issue that has plagued New Jersey governors for a quarter century and that helped bring down Jim Florio. The issue is equality of education in the public schools: how the schools can serve the poor children of the cities as well as they serve the more affluent children of the suburbs. Typically, the dispute is couched in money: how much school districts spend per pupil and how much they can collect in property taxes. Page 24.
 
BILL TO REIN IN CUSTODIANS IS SIGNED
Gov. Cuomo announced that he had signed a bill giving greater control over New York City school custodians to principals and the Board of Education. The new law enables the Board of Education to set performance standards for the cleanliness and maintenance of the schools and allows principals to evaluate custodians by those standards. Page 25.
 
DEBATE OVER NASSAU BUDGET
Less than a month after Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, newly re-elected, announced in Mineola that he was proposing a "tax freeze" budget that would eliminate a deficit of at least $39 million, opponents say the plan is full of false promises and raises taxes. Page 25.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Four Weeks, 7,000 Trees And Three Guys' Future

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
"I GUESS I am about as petit bourgeois as you can get," said Scott Lechner as he sat in the Pizza Club and explained his entrepreneurial adventures in the Christmas tree business.
Mr. Lechner, who is 36 years old, is one of three partners in the Pizza Club, a happy-looking, sit-down and not-so-very-fast food establishment on Avenue U in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn that was built with Christmas tree profits. 
 "I've sold things all my life -- food, clothing, jewelry, toys, and once I drove around the country selling chemical Mace," said Mr. Lechner, who looks and talks like the Leo Gorcey character in the Bowery Boys films.
Twelve years ago when he was selling fruit from a box on Broadway and 72d Street he was approached by Greg Walsh, a college student on holiday in search of a summer job. Mr. Lechner took Mr. Walsh, three years his junior, under his wing.
One thing led to another and the two became friends and partners in a number of petit bourgeois operations. "I've always been curious to see how far a peddler could go," said Mr. Lechner as he, Mr. Walsh, and Billy Calvoni, a third partner, stood poised to expand their Christmas tree operation to seven different locations in three boroughs. "I mean, is it possible today to start out with nothing and build something like Macy's?"
On such questions Mr. Lechner tends to be upbeat. He has great confidence and ample nerve. On a good day he can sell you your shoes. He keeps accentuating the positive and sees great possibilities looming out there on the entrepreneurial frontier. It was he who first saw the market for hand-painted pumpkins that the partners sold on the street at Halloween. It is he who talks up the chances of someday franchising the Pizza Club on a citywide and maybe even nationwide basis. And it is Mr. Lechner who boldly envisions selling every last one of the 7,000 trees he and his partners have ordered from as far away as the Pacific northwest.
"The economy is improving," he said. "We've got a terrific new location on First Avenue and 68th street in Manhattan. We have a great, ecologically aware and highly trained sales force. We've ordered the best trees. What could be bad?"
Mr. Walsh countered with another view. "The weather could stay warm," he said. "We could get stuck with a lot of trees. We could lose our shirts." Mr. Calvoni, the remaining partner, kept working the oven and the counter and held his views and hopes to himself.
"The first time we got into Christmas trees was 12 years ago," said Mr. Lechner. "We each put up $500. We went upstate and cut down trees. We did everything wrong, even renting a lot in a Jewish neighborhood. We lost everything. But we learned and the next year we did better."
He said in that next year the trio met and were befriended by Charlie Whitey Sr., a man Mr. Lechner described as a "great old tree man." Out of pity or kindness, he said, Mr. Whitey taught them how to trim trees and how to order the Douglas firs from Oregon, the Scotch pines from Michigan, the balsams from Nova Scotia. From him they also learned to weave wreaths and make the blankets of pine boughs that some customers place on graves in the Christmas season.
From year to year they expanded, setting up lots in supermarket parking lots in Brooklyn and Queens. "We hired college kids and moonlighting cops and firemen to work at our stands," said Mr. Lechner. "Some years we made out all right."
"And some years we did lousy," said Mr. Walsh.
Mr. Lechner brushed aside such commentary. "Two years ago we were able to open the Pizza Club. It's built on the site of one of our first Christmas tree stands. Then last year, we sold most of our trees even though we had that freak northeaster. This year is going to be even better."
This it the year that People's Produce, the Christmas-tree, painted-pumpkin and seasonal-merchandising subsidiary of the Pizza Club of Avenue U, is moving beyond Brooklyn and Queens. Their offer of $2,500 having prevailed in Park Department bidding, the partners are about to begin setting up their trees at a vest pocket park on First Avenue. With characteristic enthusiasm Mr. Lechner cited many reasons why these trees will do well in the relatively high rent and discerning neighborhood.
"First of all, there's our guarantee," he said. "If for any reason customers find they do not like how a particular tree looks, they can bring it back and we'll replace it. Then there's our ecological policy. We only buy from tree farms that replace all trees they cut. We also promise that if we have trees at the end of the season we will transport them to Robert Moses state park where they can be used to anchor new dunes on the beach. We deliver. We trim. Our staff is trained to answer all questions."
How far can a peddler go? How does pizza magnate and head of a Christmas tree conglomerate sound?

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Slight Gains; Gold Prices Ease Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar posted modest gains yesterday in quiet trading after Thanksgiving.
"There really is not enough to sink your teeth into today,"' said Bob Ortiz, vice president for corporate foreign exchange at Continental Bank in Chicago. 
 Gold prices were mostly lower in overseas markets. Precious metals markets in the United States were closed for the holiday weekend.
Currency trading was slow, with many participants off for a long holiday weekend. Futures trading closed at 1 P.M., Eastern standard time, and some large banks began to close their trading operations for the day about 2 P.M., two hours ahead of the usual close of the market.
The dollar slipped but then recovered after the president of Germany's Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, signaled that the central bank was not immediately prepared to make steep cuts in German interest rates.
Mr. Tietmeyer said interest rates were not a "miracle cure" for Germany's economy, which has deep-seated economic and political problems. "A policy of cheap money can't do anything against this; indeed, it would increase the intensity of the problems," he said in Frankfurt.
Germany's reluctance to cut interest rates from their high levels has hurt the value of dollar-denominated investments with lower returns.
 
A Rise Against the Mark
 In European trading, the dollar closed at 1.7115 German marks, up from 1.7080 on Thursday. In New York, the dollar closed at 1.7130 German marks, up from 1.7035 German marks on Wednesday. The American currency markets were closed on Thursday for the Thanksgiving holiday.
Oil prices tumbled in overseas trading, a sign of low inflation, but the trend did not help the dollar, traders said. "I really believe the market isn't reacting to much due to the holiday," Mr. Ortiz said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 108.52 yen, up slightly from Thursday's close. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.90 yen, up from 108.17 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4782, from $1.4885 late Thursday. At the closing in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.4775, down from $1.4880 late Wednesday.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $377 an ounce, down from $377.45 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Falling Oil Prices Give Bonds a Lift

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Buoyed by falling oil prices, Treasury bond prices rose sharply yesterday in light trading.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond rose 25/32 point while its yield fell to 6.24 percent. The market closed at 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, after being closed on Thursday for Thanksgiving. On Wednesday, the bond's yield closed at 6.30 percent. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. 
 The bond market opened higher on a drop in crude oil prices in European trading. Oil prices sank after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided on Wednesday not to lower its production ceiling to bolster falling prices.
 
 
Gains Began in Europe
 The lower prices are good for the bond market because they lessen the prospect of inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities like bonds.
Much of the gain for the 30-year bond occurred in European trading and continued into dealings in the United States, said John Canavan, a market analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
Trading was light, and appeared to follow the changes in oil futures prices on the International Petroleum Exchange in London, where the January delivery contract for North Sea Brent Blend lost 8 cents to settle at $14.48 a barrel. The price had dropped 58 cents on Thursday.
"It was such a big drop," Mr. Canavan said. "Traders do watch oil and gold."
The New York Mercantile Exchange, where American crude oil futures are traded, was closed Thursday and yesterday. On Wednesday, the price of light sweet crude oil for January delivery closed at $16.38 a barrel, down 25 cents.
In the Treasury market, prices of short-term issues rose 3/32 point to 5/32 point, while intermediate-term issues posted bigger gains. The price of the 10-year Treasury note was up half a point while its yield fell to 5.74 percent, from 5.80 percent on Wednesday.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.78, to 1,307.77.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills fell 1 basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 3.09 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills fell 2 basis points, to 3.23 percent. And the discount rate on the one-year bill fell 3 basis points, to 3.41 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 101 5/8, up 3/32 from Wednesday. The average yield to maturity was 5.65 percent, down from 5.66 percent.

HEADLINE: Taking Steps to Revive Region's Rail Freight

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The train clanked forward at a top speed of 10 miles an hour, but even so it rocked on the antique, uneven tracks like a ship at sea. The grass and weeds sprouting between the ties might captivate a botanist, but John Cossman, the engineer, complained that when they get high enough, they make the wheels on his twin 130-ton engines spin as if they were rolling "through soup."
This 10-mile section of the Long Island Rail Road's freight line, from Fresh Pond, Queens, to Bushwick, Brooklyn, is a piece of the aging freight tracks that still thread through large sections of New York City and Long Island, mostly forgotten but hardly unimportant. 
 Many policy planners say the area's highways have become so congested with trucks that the revival of these freight tracks may well be vital to further economic growth.
The first halting steps in that direction are already under way.
Despite the appearance of the Long Island Rail Road tracks, the agency expects to move 17 percent more freight this year than in 1991. Another company that hopes to profit through the increase in rail freight is the New York Cross Harbor Terminal Corporation, a 10-year-old business that operates barges that carry freight trains from Jersey City to Brooklyn.
The obstacles to improving the region's freight systems are numerous, from a lack of money for overhauling old tracks to a tunnel that is too small to handle the latest in freight travel, the double-stacked container.
"What we have now isn't going to let us compete with a modern L.A.," said Richard T. Roberts, chief of transportation planning and policy at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
About 20 tons of freight move each year for each person in the region, according to the Regional Plan Association. More than 90 percent moves by truck and 2.8 percent moves by rail. The rest comes by air and water. On average in the rest of America, 26 percent of freight moves on the rails, and less than half moves in trucks.
This disparity, combined with highway congestion, has an impact on shippers.
William H. Van Tuyl 3d, executive vice president for Nassau Suffolk Lumber and Supply Corporation, which uses trucks and, increasingly, rail, said: "All I hear about is that truckers just don't want to come to Long Island. They do it because there's a big market, but they are absolutely furious every time they have to come."
 
Taking Freight More Seriously
 Improving the movement of freight, he and other experts say, is crucial if the regional economy is to grow.
"A good transportation system has to move freight as well as people," said Jeffrey M. Zupan, a senior fellow at the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research organization. Freight does not have such an obvious constituency, he said, because "a box of cargo doesn't complain that it's late," the way a rail passenger or a driver does. But policy makers are looking at freight more seriously, he said.
In fact, the capital improvement program for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is stalled in Albany by a dispute over freight. Norman Levy, Republican of Merrick, L.I., and chairman of the State Senate Transportation Committee, has held up the authority's capital program for five months, and is asking for up to $25 million a year from that program for freight improvements on Long Island.
 
Falling Behind
 The region's dependence on highways to move its goods stems from a variety of factors, including a failure to keep up with rail technology and shifting economic patterns in the region.
The Long Island Rail Road, for example, used to haul 100-car trains of potatoes out of the farm country of Suffolk County, but cargoes like that are no longer around to help sustain the system. Warehouses used to be abundant east of the Hudson, but many have moved where land and energy are cheaper, to northern and central New Jersey.
The region's intricate highway system used to mean that a truck could carry a load from northern New Jersey to Nassau County twice a day. Now, said Gerhardt Muller, a goods movement expert at the Port Authority, if a truck is loaded in New Jersey with cargo for Long Island and sets out in the morning, "you lose your driver for the whole day" because of congestion.
Cargo coming from the west to New York City cannot cross the Hudson by rail because the tunnel under the river was built for boxcars, not the trailers or double-stacked containers of modern trains. Not only that, it is too crowded with passenger trains.
 
A 185-Mile Detour
 The nearest rail bridge over the Hudson, a 1.5-mile span between Highland and Poughkeepsie built in 1888, has been unusable since a fire in 1974, requiring trains from the south to detour through Selkirk, N.Y., near Albany, a 185-mile round trip.
The alternative is New York Cross Harbor, the remnant of about a dozen different car-float operations that once ferried rail cars across the Hudson.
The city and state, seeking to improve car-float service, spent $25 million to rebuild a rail yard on the Brooklyn waterfront at 65th Street, intending to lease it to New York Cross Harbor. The yard was completed two years ago, but negotiations have dragged on. Participants differ on the details, but New York Cross Harbor has extensive tax and lease disputes with the city and others.
"It's not the model of good planning," said Christopher O. Ward of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which owns the yard. The Long Island Rail Road would also like to run the rail yard, and others have come forward with what Mr. Ward described as "fanciful ideas," delaying a resolution.
 
A Downward Spiral
 Because the Long Island Rail Road has recently cut costs in its freight division, it expects to make a small profit in that area this year, reversing a loss of $1.3 million in 1990, even though it expects to carry roughly the same amount of freight this year as in 1990. In the last 20 years the Long Island Rail Road and others have kept trimming service in their freight operations to cut losses, but that does not work forever.
"It's a vicious cycle, because your traffic declines, so you cut services and traffic declines more; it spirals down," said Parvesh Swani, whom the railroad named vice president for freight in July 1992, trying to turn operations around.
Another problem around the region is the competition for space with passenger trains. In the days when the Pennsylvania, the New York Central and the New York, New Haven and Hartford railroads ran the show, that problem required close coordination between a railroad's freight department and its passenger department, but both had a strong incentive to work things out: a need to make a profit. Today it is often Conrail versus Metro-North or Amtrak, which do not have shared interests.
But scheduling can be crucial for freight. Mr. Muller of the Port Authority said that if a company like United Parcel Service could be induced to try the rails, "They're going to want that train at a particular time. They're not going to want to hear that it was delayed by a passenger train for 20 minutes."
 
Food Trains
 The most difficult freight to schedule is food. Sometime early next year, regional officials hope to move the first shipment of fruits and vegetables from the West Coast or Florida by train to the Hunts Point market in the South Bronx. Nearly everything sold there now arrives by truck, much of it from rail yards in New Jersey. According to the Regional Plan Association, Hunts Point requires nearly 80 truck trips per day, and each rail car could replace about three of them.
The food trains are to float across the harbor on the New York Cross Harbor and be picked up by the Long Island Rail Road in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and handed over to Conrail at Fresh Pond in Queens. They are then to be hauled over the Hell Gate Bridge to the Bronx. Considering that trains often wait hours or even days at each handoff, coordinating the transfers is a major challenge.
"You can literally lose value if things are delayed," said Peter D. Cohen, Conrail's manager for economic development in New York.
Local officials see the food shipments as a major step forward. But Wayne A. Michel, director of commercial development at Conrail's headquarters in Philadelphia, called them experimental.
"All the carriers are participating on extremely low margins to see if there is a market," he said.
 
Transporting Trash
 Railways are also hoping to benefit from new developments in garbage disposal. Garbage used to be buried or incinerated locally, but now several companies in Bushwick and elsewhere package recyclable materials for shipment, and commercial garbage is trucked to distant landfills.
The New York City Department of Sanitation would like to export some household garbage. Some city and state officials have talked about the possibility of a new rail tunnel, perhaps from Brooklyn to Staten Island, with garbage exports a guaranteed cargo to help pay for it. The Port Authority would like to study the feasibility of a tunnel running from New Jersey into Manhattan and then to the Sunnyside yard in Queens, to be used for double-stacked freight trains and passenger trains.
More changes are coming. By 1995, New York State hopes to finish a 1.8-mile, $160 million line along the Harlem River to the Oak Point yard in the Bronx that will allow trains to carry truck trailers, although not double-stacked cars. These could then be unloaded and hooked to tractors to be trucked short distances to their destinations. With additional improvements, the trains could continue to Long Island. New York is also trying to revitalize the Harlem River Rail Yard, in the Port Morris section of the Bronx, which has been abandoned for decades.
Mr. Swani of the Long Island Rail Road said that if freight ever became significantly profitable, it would not only relieve congestion, but also might reduce the state's need to subsidize the passenger line, which is the railroad's main business.
Meanwhile, the railroad's trains clank along. The four-wheel-drive Broncos that patrol the tracks carry chains to tow abandoned cars, but there is no push to clean up.
"We've cleaned it up, but in a few weeks it looks the same again," said John F. Keegan, superintendent of freight operations.

HEADLINE: Cities and Suburbs Battle Over Distribution of Aid

SERIES: Remaking Schools: New Jersey's Challenge -- Second of two articles

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
When Christine Todd Whitman takes office next January, she will face an issue that has plagued New Jersey governors for a quarter century and that helped bring down Jim Florio, her predecessor.
The issue is equality of education in the public schools: how the schools can serve the poor children of the cities as well as they serve the more affluent children of the suburbs. Typically, the dispute is couched in money: how much school districts spend per pupil and how much they can collect in property taxes. 
 As an issue, inequality -- between worse off and well off, cities and suburbs -- arrived at the governor's door in 1970, during William Cahill's administration, and it has persisted. When Mr. Florio became Governor, it was the engine that drove his big tax increase, which so soured voters that he became the first incumbent to lose a gubernatorial election.
During her campaign, Mrs. Whitman reiterated a frequent political view: "A lack of money isn't the cause of our education problem. A lack of leadership is." She pledged to squeeze out more for needy districts from the existing budget. She advocated trying a voucher system in troubled Jersey City, using public money to pay for a private education.
But many experts on education fear that by forcing the public schools to compete for pupils, a voucher system would undercut the public schools, not inspire them. They also fear that Mrs. Whitman's pledge to cut state taxes by 30 percent can only come at the expense of state support for local schools, though she has promised it will not. Not only does she inherit a daunting budget gap, but a state court has also ruled that New Jersey now undersupports its schools by $450 million.
 
The Crux: 'Special Needs'
 The core of the issue is 30 poor urban districts like Jersey City and Newark deemed "special needs districts." Test scores lag pathetically, dropout rates are alarming and some students go to class in furnace rooms. More than a quarter of the state's children are enrolled in these 30 districts, yet they spend on average of $1,680 per pupil less than the wealthiest systems.
Hundreds of millions of new dollars have flowed to the state's schools to solve the problem. Without that money, they would be much worse off. Nevertheless, the inner-city districts make do with far less than their wealthier counterparts, while their students face other students with guns in their knapsacks and often live in one-parent homes.
Across the country, states are seeking ways to equalize education for all students, but New Jersey was among the first. It is the most densely populated and most urbanized state, and, more than almost any other, it has tolerated dire inequities in its schools.
In some cases, the disparities were so great and the performance of urban schools so poor that the state stepped in to take over the schools. That happened, with limited success, in Jersey City and Paterson.
The reform movement in New Jersey was spawned in 1970, with the glittering hope of sound public schooling for students in every stratum. Echoes of the past pervade the debate. Yet another court ruling in August found the state's efforts wanting. Yet another State Supreme Court ruling looms. Yet another blue-ribbon commission is laboring to offer its recommendations by year end.
"We are moving in baby steps," said Margaret Goertz, a school finance expert at the Consortium for Policy Research in Education at Rutgers University. "We've put a lot of new dollars into schools, but they haven't gone very far in closing the disparity of rich and poor."
 
Promising Statistics
 Certain facts about New Jersey's schools seem beacons of promise. New Jersey spends more per pupil than any other state, $9,192 for each of 1.13 million students. Its 83,058 full-time teachers receive the fourth-highest salaries in the country. The schooling in most districts has long been saluted by educators as equal to any in the country.
Yet the public schools are the fourth most segregated in the nation, and while almost every other state has been consolidating districts to reap efficiencies and diversify their school-age population, New Jersey continues to add districts, making integration even harder. Some districts are only a mile square, and 22 have fewer than 100 students. Twenty-five have no schools at all; they send their children to neighboring districts.
The state pays less than 40 percent of the cost of public education; the national average is 50 percent. Districts depend largely on property taxes to satisfy the rest. That has proven too shallow a well for urban centers, which tend to have many children who need additional help.
"There are still elementary schools in the state without a library," Mary Lee Fitzgerald, the state education commissioner, said recently. "There are schools in Newark that don't have scissors to cut with."
Taxpayers already feel overburdened, and yet urban schools say they can't succeed without more state money. Wherever one lives, education comes down to politics, class and race and, of course, putting one's own children first. That has been so ever since the genesis of New Jersey's reform movement a quarter of a century ago.
 
Beginnings of Reform
A Lawsuit Results In an Income Tax
 Harold Ruvoldt Jr. needed something to write about. This was 1966, when he was a Jersey City law clerk a year out of law school. Rummaging through the state constitution, he noticed an 1875 amendment that the state guarantee a "thorough and efficient" public education. His familiarity with Jersey City told him that the state was hardly fulfilling that obligation. He fastened on the issue. "I just wanted to write an article," he said.
When he circulated his paper for review, one recipient was keenly interested: the corporation counsel of Jersey City. The city's Mayor, Thomas J. Whelan, was in political trouble over soaring property taxes. He and the counsel saw the constitutional issue as a way to stop financing the schools from property taxes and get the state to pay.
Mr. Ruvoldt was hired to file suit, which he did in 1970, in a case called Robinson v. Cahill. William T. Cahill was Governor. Mayor Whelan's staff supplied Kenneth Robinson, a spindly 7-year-old, as the plaintiff.
Eventually, a landmark decision by the State Supreme Court in April 1973 declared New Jersey's method of paying for education unconstitutional. The Public Education Act of 1975, commonly known as Chapter 212, was passed as a solution. To pay for it, the Legislature enacted New Jersey's first income tax in 1976.
 
Gap Narrowed, Then Widened
 Many education experts doubted that Chapter 212 allowed enough money to equalize districts. For a few years the spending gap between districts narrowed. Then it widened again, prompting a second suit, Abbott v. Burke, filed by the Education Law Center, a public interest law firm, on behalf of children in four urban districts.
With each passing year, economic vicissitudes and social woes made life bleaker for urban children. It used to be tolerable to drop out of high school or forgo college. The cities were flush with factory jobs and other prospects. Now skimpy education means a life on the streets.
In the new case, the State Supreme Court declared Chapter 212 unconstitutional in June 1990. Governor Florio and the Democratic-controlled Legislature produced the Quality Education Act, known as the Q.E.A. It increased state aid by $1.15 billion, but was stymied by opposition from taxpayers and education groups over higher taxes and spending limits.
Along came Q.E.A. II. It removed $350 million from school money and instead applied the money to lowering property taxes, leaving just $800 million for education. To the dismay of many districts, it imposed spending caps on them. What is more, the wealthier districts would lose state support for routine education programs over four years.
Like most sequels, Q.E.A. II was a disappointment. Poor districts complained that the money was still meager, wealthier districts that their pockets were being picked.
In June 1991, Marilyn Morheuser of the Education Law Center returned to court, charging that Q.E.A. II failed to satisfy the previous decision. In a ruling last August, the Superior Court agreed. It found that an additional $450 million was needed by 1995-96, but left the final say to the State Supreme Court.
Ms. Morheuser said that enough of a coalition for more state aid now exists that a solution is at hand. Others feel she is too optimistic.
 
The 'Robin Hood' Act
A Study Finds Little Change
 Q.E.A. II is described (and derided) as a "Robin Hood" measure, taking from the rich to give to the poor. Yet a recent study concludes that it has been a poor impersonation of Robin Hood.
The analysis of the first year of the act by the Center for Educational Policy Analysis at Rutgers found that only $287 million of the $800 million of new state aid went to poor urban districts, while 60 percent went elsewhere, including to wealthy enclaves.
The study examined the impact of Q.E.A. II on 11 unidentified districts, from low to high wealth. While the gap between the districts had closed somewhat, sizable disparities persisted. In fact, the two moderate-wealth districts realized higher percentage increases in state aid than did the five poor urban districts.
"The better-off districts are not suffering at the hands of the poor," said William Firestone, the director of the Center for Educational Policy Analysis. "To the extent that the better-off districts were constrained, it was more a case of the local taxpayers not wanting to contribute more."
The money helped the urban areas, but little was actually spent on instruction. The urban districts, the study found, were able to make only modest changes in school programs, generally using the money for salaries and existing programs.
 
Unhappiness in Ridgewood
 Ridgewood, in northern New Jersey, is known as a town that draws families because the schools are good. But talk to people about the education debate and you hear the patter of unhappiness.
Fred Stokley, school superintendent for Ridgewood, complained that since Q.E.A. II his district has had to make many reductions -- 15 fewer teachers, 8 fewer coaches, fewer field trips -- yet he acknowledged that Ridgewood has not spent up to its limit. It could restore those things if its taxpayers agreed. Mr. Stokley is convinced that Ridgewood people would resist paying more taxes to educate urban children. "They don't want to even pay more money for their own kids," he said.
Matawan-Aberdeen, a middle-class district in south central New Jersey, has lost state aid, made cutbacks and raised taxes, though it, too, has not spent up to its limit. "We're reaching a point where we're going to have a taxpayer revolt," said Ken Hall, the superintendent. "People are saying, 'How much money can you spend in a school district?' " He contends that the money going into urban districts is coming entirely from middle-class districts like his own, while wealthy districts are politically untouchable.
In Westfield, Mark Smith, the superintendent of that wealthy district, complains that Westfield has made unwanted reductions because it is spending almost to its limit. "We want to create equality without districts doing well with their students having to level down," he said.
New Jersey has been unable to overcome the belief of many parents that their children's school is all that counts.
"I live in Millburn," said Paul Tractenberg, a professor of law at Rutgers who has long studied education reform, "and I see it close up with my neighbors. They think the property taxes they pay belong to their schools. The attitude is, 'We deserve it, our children deserve it.' "
 
Looking Ahead
Lines Are Drawn, Suspicion Is High
 Times have changed, and many people feel less generous than they did when the American economy was growing apace.
"At the time of Robinson-Cahill, the climate was more accepting of helping the cities," said Kenneth Carlson, associate professor at the Rutgers graduate school of education. "It was the 60's and the time of the war on poverty."
Since then, the economy has faltered, and many antipoverty efforts have failed. "A lot of people say that the cities have been given enough of a chance," Mr. Carlson said.
The problem keeps burying itself deeper into the fabric of the state. Earlier this year, a new commission was established by the State Legislature to devise a fresh financing formula. Its deadline was Nov. 15, but it is behind schedule and now trying for the end of December.
Albert Burstein, a lawyer, heads the commission. He was a member of the last commission, of which little came. He made his opinion clear in an interview that the taxpayers must come up with a lot more money. In theory, equality could be achieved without higher taxes, by siphoning money from suburban districts. But that, he fears, would result in a dilution of all the public schools similar to what happened in California. "We surely want to avoid that," he said.
Does that mean higher taxes?
"I think that's the bullet we are going to have to bite," he said.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Asked To Cut Tariffs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The United States is seeking cuts in tariffs levied by Taiwan on 2,800 products as part of that country's petition to join a world trade agreement, United States trade officials said today.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the request covered American products that were most competitive in Taiwan's market. If accepted, he said, it would help to improve American exports to Taiwan. 
 Through the first eight months of this year, the United States was running a $5.86 billion trade deficit with Taiwan.
Taiwan has petitioned to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization that governs world trade.
Because it is seeking to join the world trade body as a developed economy, it will be required to lower its tariffs, or border taxes, to the levels that generally prevail in other industrial countries.
As part of that process, countries already in GATT are allowed to make requests, such as that filed by the United States, about particular tariffs they would like to see lowered before approving the country's entry into GATT.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Using Wills as Safeguards
 
Q. Is it necessary for a widow or widower with two grown children, equally loved, to make out a will, thus avoiding probate? Won't the state just divide all proceeds between the two?
HELEN STENBERG, Merrick, L.I. 

A. Although your assets will pass to your children on your death under the laws of almost all states, there are still many reasons to write a will. For example, one child might die before you do, and with a will, you can specify what you want to happen in that situation.
You can also use a will to safeguard property for the benefit of your children by creating a trust or taking other steps. Without a will, this possibility is eliminated.
"In addition, if you do not have a will, your sons will be required to post a bond for the protection of any potential creditors you may have at your death," said Jonathan G. Blattmachr, a partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. "Your estate will have to pay for that bond, which probably will exceed the cost of paying a lawyer to draft a will for you."
 
Getting Payments Overseas
 
Q. It is my plan to move to Denmark when I retire. Will I be able to receive my Social Security check and I.R.A. distributions if I move?
SCHICKI HANSEN, Manhattan
 
A. Yes. Americans living in a foreign country are entitled to the same Social Security payments that they would get if living in the United States. Distributions from individual retirement accounts can also be sent to your new address abroad.
It is important to note that retirees who live in foreign countries are generally subject to the same tax obligations as other United States citizens. These foreign residents must also pay income taxes levied by the country where they live on money received there.
"However, many countries have treaties with the U.S. which exempt nongovernmental pension payments from being subject to income tax in that country," said Lewis J. Altfest, a New York financial planner. "Some treaty countries exempt Social Security payments as well."
In your case, Denmark's treaty with the United States exempts both Social Security and private pension payments from local taxes.
 
Money Market Risks
 
Are there any risks in investing in a money market fund?
PATRICIA HAGOOD, Manhattan
 
A. No investment is entirely free of risk. Money market funds, which are designed to maintain a price of $1 a share, carry little default risk, however. They restrict their portfolios to fixed-income investments like certificates of deposit, commercial paper and bankers' acceptances.
John Markese, the president of the American Association of Individual Investors, said they carried another risk: If interest rates climb, prices will decline.
"Longer-maturity investments are more sensitive to interest-rate changes than shorter-term investments," he said. "The lowest-risk money market funds have the shortest average maturity and the highest quality ratings on their investments."

HEADLINE: CAVEAT EMPTOR;
Exotic Securities Cause Losses at Some Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
AS interest rates have fallen to remarkably low levels in the last few years, bond mutual funds have searched for ways to pump up their yields. Some managers saw a ray of light in derivative securities, though skeptics warned that these complex financial products posed a danger if rates rose.
Those fears were at least partly borne out in September, when three publicly traded bond funds of Hyperion Inc. stumbled. The funds, which had significant amounts of exotic securities derived from mortgages, lost 15 to 20 percent of their value from mid-September through mid-October. 
 Two lawsuits filed by shareholders followed -- the first in October. Then last week, a pension fund that owned shares in the Hyperion fund filed a suit, contending these securities deviated from the conservative strategy described in the prospectus.
"The company believes the claims are without merit and stands behind the disclosure in the prospectus," said Mike Rosella, counsel to Hyperion Capital Management.
 Though Hyperion's funds have taken the spotlight, derivatives are widespread in the fund industry. The value of a derivative is based on another product, like a commodity contract or a pool of mortgages. Most investors do not know their funds own derivatives or what they are.
"Individual investors in mutual funds are probably not fully aware that their mutual fund managers are investing in hybrid securities that bear considerable market risk," Leo C. O'Neill, president of the ratings group at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, wrote in a recent report.
S.& P. puts the size of the derivatives market in the United States at $10 billion to $20 billion. Mutual funds are the most active players.
The Hyperion funds were tripped up by collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s. The securities are created by slicing mortgage-backed securities into many parts. The most common are I.O.'s, which represent the interest on the home loans, and P.O.'s, which represent the principal.
The primary risk in these securities, whose underlying home loans are backed by Government mortgage agencies, is that homeowners will refinance when rates fall. If homeowners prepay their mortgages, anyone holding the securities must reinvest the proceeds at prevailing rates, which will be lower than when the securities were purchased.
This prepayment risk is magnified in an interest-only security. When the income stream disappears, the value of the security disappears.
Along with the Hyperion funds, the interest-only derivatives have pulled down the returns this year of adjustable-rate mortgage funds at Franklin, Putnam and T. Rowe Price, among others.
The unpredictable nature of the securities is only part of the problem. Shareholders are often left to guess what their funds hold. Many reports use the phrase C.M.O. without disclosing the type of security or its use.
Eileen Sanders, an analyst with Morningstar, suggests investors check the list of holdings in fund annual reports and call the fund company for more information. Also, be suspicious of unusually high yields, a clue that something unusual may be stashed in the portfolio.
To be sure, a few mutual fund managers have used derivatives successfully. Worth Bruntjen mixes principal-only securities and other types of derivatives in his Managers Intermediate Mortgage Fund. Balancing one type of risk against another, he has produced stellar returns -- an average 13.2 percent annually for the five years ended in October -- while keeping interest rate risk low.
Even so, that strategy has not been fully tested, Ms. Sanders cautioned. Rates have risen in relatively small increments in recent weeks; what would happen if rates rose sharply?

HEADLINE: Joint Production Takes 'The Joy Luck Club' To China's Stages

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 26

 BODY:
A stage version of "The Joy Luck Club" prepared for audiences in China and Hong Kong has solved a great problem of Amy Tan's best-selling novel of mothers and daughters: how to keep track of all those Chinese names when the author rips through time from one family's set of memories to another's.
In this co-production of the Shanghai People's Art Theater and the Long Wharf Theater of New Haven, adapted by Susan Kim, the costume designer, Susan Tsu, gives the audience an ingenious solution that could have been conceived at Kmart. 
 She has color-coded the families.
Thanks to Ms. Tsu's costuming and the clarity with which Ms. Kim and the director, Arvin Brown, have segmented the march through time, there is no need to remember that Jing-Mei, or June, Woo (color her bright yellow) is the daughter of Suyuan (ditto), who is the one who abandoned the twins as she fled a Japanese invasion. Or that Waverly Jong (candy-apple red) is the chess champion and Rose Tsu Jordan (cobalt blue) is the one who wasn't paying attention when her little brother slipped into the coiled dragon's arms beneath the waves that day at the beach. Or that her mother, An-Mei Tsu, is the one whose own mother overdosed on opium and shame after being trapped in concubinage to the fat merchant from Tianjin.
Ms. Tsu not only used matching colors to keep mothers and daughters joined throughout the play, but also contrasted the costuming to accentuate the generational and cultural dislocations within each pair. So just as Lindo Jong's bright red and very traditional slit-up-the-side dress fixed her in time, so do the bright red mini-skirt, matching lipstick and oversized plastic eyeglass frames on her daughter, Waverly.
With hairstyles and scarves, chewing gum, berets, hosiery and shoes, the costuming of "The Joy Luck Club" wonderfully magnified the contrasts that Ms. Tan had described in her novel as feelings, emotions and attitudes.
The set designer, Ming Cho Lee, used a dozen simple white door frames to set off the memory cells through which the story moves quickly in time and geography, showing the imagination that went into the daunting task of translating Ms. Tan's novel onto the stage. (The film version treats the stories sequentially, making it easier to tell who's who.)
 
Modernizing the Arts
 The stage production, which opened in Shanghai in August and moved to Beijing last Saturday, will also travel to Tianjin before turning southward again to Guangzhou and Shenzhen and finally to Hong Kong, where it will be part of the Hong Kong Arts Festival in February.
This joint venture between the Long Wharf and the Shanghai Theater was fostered by the Yale-China Association and is being underwritten by Northern Telecom, the telecommunications giant, which is competing for the rapidly expanding China market.
It also represents an effort to bring modern stage management and marketing skills to Chinese theater, where the Communist Party and the financially pressed central Government, while trying to maintain control over content, are applying more and more pressure for economic independence in the arts.
In the spring and summer of 1992, Shanghai Theater directors, actors and artists spent three months studying production management and front-office economics in nine American cities, including New Haven.
While reviews of the play in the Chinese press were uniformly positive, some writers seemed rather confused about the nature of the generational disconnections the author explores. Others raised questions about whether the quest of a second-generation American Chinese to understand the culture their mothers involuntarily abandoned registers with a Chinese audience whose members, by choice or restriction, stayed behind.
The Xinmin Daily News in Shanghai said in its Aug. 28 account of the performance there, "Some viewers say the play only reflects a narrow sense of seeking one's roots and lacks a more complete story of the continuing contradictions" in Chinese life, "which makes it hard for some Chinese viewers to appreciate the play as designed."
Ms. Kim's adaptation has been skillfully translated into Mandarin, and this work was undoubtedly made easier by the fact that Ms. Tan's story is full of the instantly recognizable metaphors and images derived from the Chinese language. Indeed, the name Joy Luck Club represents the kind of combination of image words that is common in Chinese. A mundane word in English like train becomes in Chinese the all-purpose character for car jammed together with the character for fire because the first trains in China were steam-driven locomotives.
 
One American Actor
 Although the opening of "The Joy Luck Club" here took place on a night when Beijing's streets were glazed with ice from last week's snow showers, the 800-seat theater was nearly full.
It is difficult to tell how much the ever-polite Chinese enjoyed the staging of this work by Ms. Tan, whose vantage point is distinctly American. They did seem receptive to the performances, however.
The mothers and daughters were played by eight Chinese actresses. The only American onstage, James Andreassi, played all the boyfriends and husbands of the Chinese daughters, from redneck fiance to yuppie whiner to boorish predator. Even when he delivered his bits of English dialogue, the mostly Chinese audience at the Children's Theater in Beijing followed his renditions, and applauded them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene from the stage version of "The Joy Luck Club." The co-production by the Shanghai People's Art Theater and the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven opened in Beijing last week. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Black Children, White Parents

 BODY:
Is it better for black children to be adopted by families of another race than not to be adopted at all? Debate over this question has raged for two decades, since black social workers took a strong stand against such adoptions.
Clearly, matching adoptive parents with children of the same race is a good idea. And more aggressive recruitment of black families to adopt black children is needed. But in the long run, a permanent home is better than foster care, and even as a last resort it's better to raise a black child with a white family than with no family at all. 
 Nationwide, about 100,000 children are candidates for adoption. An estimated 40 percent are black, and many of the available white children are school age or have special needs.
Many white families seeking to adopt want healthy infants. And since the demand is greater than the supply, many of these families consider adopting an infant of another race.
The most controversial of these trans-racial adoptions involve white families and black children. In 1972 the National Association of Black Social Workers came out against such adoptions, calling them cultural "genocide." The association remains convinced that black children who grow up with white adoptive families are less likely to feel positive about themselves and their cultural origins than those adopted by black families.
But a recently published study by Rita Simon, a professor of law and public affairs at American University, and Howard Altstein, a professor of social work at the University of Maryland, takes the opposite position. Their study followed 204 white families who adopted minority children over a period of 20 years. The researchers concluded that minority children who grow up in white families don't become confused about their racial identities.
It's unclear how many black children are being denied permanent homes because willing white families are having difficulty adopting them. But the debate about trans-racial adoptions is likely to intensify. Beyond those children who are headed for adoption, there were also more than 300,000 children in foster care in 1990. Forty percent of them were black children, exceeding the number of white children for the first time. As long as that trend continues, the need to place black children permanently with families of different racial backgrounds will be an issue.
Texas has already passed a law that prohibits the use of race as a factor in adoptions. And Howard Metzenbaum, the Democratic Senator from Ohio, has introduced a bill that would allow agencies receiving Federal funds to consider race, color or national origin in the placement of a child if it is in the child's best interest. But the agencies would not be allowed to discriminate in any other way against a family solely on the basis of race. The bill is supported by Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, who is black.
Still, before there's a rush to place black children with white families, a lot more should be done to recruit black adoptive families, particularly for black infants. A 1991 survey by the North American Council on Adoptable Children, which started with a bias toward trans-racial adoptions, identified several institutional barriers that discouraged minorities from adopting. They include economic guidelines that tend to screen out blacks, inflexible standards that favor more affluent two-parent families instead of alternatives like single-parent households, steep adoption fees and lack of minority staff and managers who might be more welcoming to black families.
Every child deserves a loving home. To the extent that black children are not adopted because of a failure to recruit black families or resistance to trans-racial placements, those barriers ought to be eliminated. It makes sense to give preference to adoptive parents of the same race. But parents of other races should not be disqualified.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Coming: Soccer, The Religion

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
ONE of my jobs around here 30 years ago was taking London bureau chauffeurs to baseball games and recording their inane queries ("Has it begun yet? Why does that chap just stand there?") without making invidious comparisons to cricket. It gave me a pragmatic, philistine world view; if you don't wrinkle your nose at my potatoes, I won't spit in your rice. But it didn't fully prepare me for the coming Big Soccer incursion.
Will I be a terrible person if I don't get swept away by the World Cup? 
 It will not be enough to regard the World Cup as an interesting cultural diversion visiting the United States, like an exhibition of modern French painting or a Balinese dance troupe. No, you may not hafta understand Nafta, but the World Cup is supposedly one of those defining events. Be there or be square. Are you on the bus?
Here we go again. The sporting equivalents of uppity vegetarians, wine-tasters, cineastes, dog snobs, will be telling us that soccer is a world language we simply must learn, as concerned citizens of the planet, as cognoscenti, as decent blokes and as international business dealers -- what if a colleague from another country asks us what "nutmeg" means and we don't know it is a neat kick between an opponent's legs? Deal breaker!
Let's reflect on this before the T-shirts and the Cup cups arrive. Do we have to care because most of the rest of the world cares? Is there space in our crowded spectator-sports schedule for more games? Is there room in our hearts for more heroes?
What's in this World Cup for us?
For starters, let's separate the grass roots from the licensed spectacle. Soccer is a wonderful game, in many social, medical, economic and environmental ways superior to the games that now grip our lives. Youngsters have found in soccer an accessible, joyous, inexpensive team sport safer than football, more forgiving than baseball, less dependent on size than basketball. For girls, particularly, soccer has been an athletic liberation. More and more adult men and women are playing at ages when only softball had been available.
What does this have to do with the World Cup? One of the mandates of World Cup '94, one of the reasons it was awarded to this undeveloped soccer country, was to leave a legacy for the sport's next generation, to build a foundation of youth programs. There is no sense yet that substantial money and energy have been spent on this mandate by the licensed promoters.
There is time yet. The teams have not yet taken up their American posts. One expects they will become inspirations in their communities, offering clinics, school visits and inexpensive exhibition games.
First, however, we need to get past the opening extravaganza, and hope it is not the handle on this cup. On Dec. 19, Caesars Palace of Las Vegas, the sports gambling capital of the United States, will present the drawing for team pairings. A 90-minute television show, to be hosted by Dick Clark (could I make this up?) will be broadcast worldwide.
With Global Bandstand behind us, it will be six months to the first-round games at nine American locations. The championship will be held a month after that, on July 17, in Pasadena.
That should give us time to learn to love or hate Diego Maradona, World Cup '94's designated testosteroney. By June, L. T. will be long gone to his new video game business, Dennis Rodman's season will be over and Wild Thing will still be regional, so there should be plenty of ink and air to promote another cartoon adolescent. Maradona is a kicker of fortune, now playing for Argentina. He is called "glamorous" because he has good hair and is fun to watch. Now, if Maradona dates Madonna. . . .?
Another mandate of World Cup '94 is the formation of an American-based professional soccer league. It's considered critical to high school and college programs to have a pro outlet. Again, there has been little publicized progress; it seems unlikely that a pro league will be functioning in the near future.
Meanwhile, basketball, which is mini-soccer for the vertically gifted, is becoming the global game, one of America's most successful exports. Just when we're being told to get in step with the rest of the world, the rest of the world is responding to the N.B.A.'s marketing genius of brand names, cultural imperialism and touring pros. Maybe if the N.B.A. took over the selling of soccer to America. . . .?
World Cup '94 is a circus that could be fun but is not yet proven a worthy enterprise. The hungry will not be drinking from the cup. Don't listen to the nutmeg terrorists. Unless you're the type who eats Ben & Jerry's Rainforest Crunch to save the world.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diego Maradona (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Isn't It Time to Stop The India-Bashing?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is irresponsible to give readers the impression that some sort of state-supported ethnic cleansing is going on in India in "After Bombay's Violence, Fear and Finger-Pointing" (news article, Nov. 19). 
 India is the victim of Muslim fundamentalist terrorist groups, who are financed by the Arabs and trained by the Pakistani army. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Bombay stock exchange was blown up, killing some 300 people, by these terrorists, who used identical explosives to the ones used in the World Trade Center.
Your correspondent seems to find this almost justifiable because it is widely believed (by whom?) to be a retaliatory act caused by violence against the Muslims.
As an American of Indian origin, having spent half my life in each country, I can say in good conscience that India possibly treats its minority population no worse than this country does. A case in point: Israel has officially declared India as the only country where Jews were not persecuted during their very long sojourn. India carefully preserves many ancient synagogues, and many Jews choose to continue living there.
India is as much a "Hindu" country as the United States is a "Christian" country. Indians have twice elected a Muslim president. Many powerful and sensitive positions at the top are held by Muslims, Sikhs, Christians and other non-Hindus. Indeed, so many scarce jobs are reserved by the Government under the strict minority quota system, that the majority Hindus feel discriminated against. If you wish to portray religious intolerance, you would do better to pick any Muslim country at random.
Obviously, there are radical Hindu groups, who represent neither the majority Hindus nor official policy. What you never mention is that India is the largest democracy on this planet. Even the extremist groups (Hindu, Muslim or Sikh) enjoy freedom of speech under the law. It is ludicrous to suggest that violence against Muslims is initiated or encouraged by the authorities, despite one of your anonymous sources.
It is in the political and economic interest of the United States to support and cultivate democratic India as an ally, rather than to continue the old India-bashing.
 
AMIT SARKAR
Scarsdale, N.Y., Nov. 20, 1993

HEADLINE: Don't Hitch Faster Train Service to Fantasies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's call for a high-speed rail link using magnetic levitation between New York City and Albany illustrates the appeal of high-tech, high-budget projects to politicians, particularly if they involve large Federal research grants to local constituents (news article, Nov. 10). 
 But magnetic levitation or maglev has almost no chance of becoming reality. Aside from its enormous initial costs and its equally large operating costs, mostly for energy, it has problems of environmental impact. The proposed route, along the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, would take it outside almost all major New York State population centers, including New York City.
On the other hand, more modest proposals for upgrading Amtrak's service are languishing. Increasing the maximum speed of Amtrak's trains from the 79 miles an hour over most of New York State's tracks to 110 miles an hour, which is possible with the equipment we have, would achieve almost all the time savings of the more esoteric proposals at a small fraction of the cost.
It could probably be achieved at a cost of the order of $300 million. That would leave New York State with $6.4 billion to take care of other more pressing needs, like schools, prisons, and other infrastructure projects.
At a top speed of 110 miles an hour, New York City to Albany would be possible in less than two hours and New York City to Buffalo in about six hours. (This still represents average speeds of only 71 miles an hour.) More important, it would allow Amtrak to serve local markets in upstate New York, such as Albany to Syracuse or Syracuse to Buffalo, which are now almost entirely dependent on the private automobile.
Alas, such proposals do not have the allure of big budget projects. More than likely, unglamorous proposals are among the first to be cut in the name of balancing the budget, as was the Amtrak operating subsidy, which forced Amtrak to reduce service on several crucial routes just a week ago.
Improving our national rail passenger system should be a top priority for the United States, just as it has been for Germany, Japan, Switzerland, Britain and almost every other industrialized country. Somehow, we still haven't caught on. Instead, we are being diverted by grandiose visions like maglev, which will never happen and should not happen, given the state of our economy and the need to optimize the use of our limited resources.
 
JOHN L. ROSE
East Chatham, N.Y., Nov. 16, 1993
The writer is a consuting engineer.
