HEADLINE: Despair Grows In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By Felicia R. Lee; Felicia R. Lee is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE VILLE
Cops and Kids in Urban America.
By Greg Donaldson.
Illustrated. 401 pp. New York:
Ticknor & Fields. $22.95. 
GARY LEMITE is a New York City housing police officer, a married father of two who is struggling to gain the trappings of middle-class success while negotiating a troubled marriage. Sharron Corley is a teen-age unwed father who shoplifts clothes for his baby and girlfriend and totes a gun. What the two have in common is that they are black men who work the streets of the Brownsville-East New York section of Brooklyn, a deadly neighborhood called "the Ville," where it seems easier to surrender than to succeed.
"The Ville: Cops and Kids in Urban America" is an ambitious, densely packed, atmospheric book that purports to get behind the stereotypes about black adolescents like Mr. Corley and police officers like Mr. Lemite. The neighborhood the book describes, with its usual depressing statistics on homicide, drug use and welfare, is no surprise. But Greg Donaldson, an instructor of reading at New York City Technical College who spent more than a year with Mr. Corley and Mr. Lemite, brings to life the smells, the feelings, the language of Brownsville-East New York and the people who form its world.
His quest has produced an account of how hard it is for people like Mr. Corley simply to do what the rest of the country expects: obtain a diploma, stay out of trouble, get a job or go to college. Mr. Corley lives in a household headed by a hard-drinking mother; he knows few people with a job and earns respect by being bad. Last year a student at his school, Thomas Jefferson High School, fatally shot two other students in the hallway.
The Ville's unrelenting misery and danger -- the police call the bottles and other debris that residents in housing projects throw at them "Brownsville ticker tape" -- breed cynicism and hostility among many police officers, Mr. Donaldson says. Mr. Lemite, who grew up in a white neighborhood and has a white wife, has always been attracted to the adventure of police work and seems really to believe in the Horatio Alger myth, despite the evidence around him.
We see Mr. Lemite begin to question some of his assumptions. There is a chilling scene of mistaken identity in which he is held at gunpoint by two white officers as he stakes out a housing project. And by the end of "The Ville," we also see Mr. Corley spending more time at home and contemplating college.
For all the immediacy that he is able to bring to his book, Mr. Donaldson simply tries to do too much. There are too many stories and too many characters. His method of alternating between the stories of Mr. Corley and Mr. Lemite, and injecting his own analysis -- no matter how cogent -- detracts from the impact a simpler structure could have achieved.
Mr. Donaldson might have been able to offer a greater measure of introspection if, say, he had chosen to profile only Mr. Corley, and had focused more on his beliefs about family, education, crime and work. There are a few tantalizing psychological glimpses, as when Mr. Corley shakes his head at a man who pumps gas for a living and allows that he would never stoop so low.
Mr. Donaldson astutely observes that the children of Brownsville are, above all, consumers driven by a lust for clothes, jewelry and status. Why have they abandoned the hope of anything else, in contrast to the Caribbean students who, Mr. Donaldson notes, seem to hold more traditional values?
Sociologists surely have some answers, but how fascinating it would have been to hear Mr. Corley and his counterparts just thinking aloud. Still, Mr. Donaldson, who has taught school throughout Brooklyn, must be commended for what is, despite its flaws, an engrossing first book.
 
 
 
REBELS WITHOUT A CHANCE
 The teen-agers here are undereducated in most things, but they are connoisseurs of pop culture, ready receptacles for the jingles and scattershot imagery of television. Their speech is drenched in the verbal flotsam of television shows. . . . They know the stars of the soaps and sitcoms as well as they know their neighbors. Brand names tyrannize the classrooms; prestige cars are worshiped. . . . With a neighborhood unemployment rate so high the methods of measuring it are no longer valid, these youths are slated by society to be nothing more than consumers, and somehow they know it.
But they are also a driving force behind pop culture throughout the world, and one of the only charismatic protest cultures left in the United States. . . . Young white kids watch with rapt attention everything they do and say. If they wear their baseball hats backward, their trousers low and loose, kids in the suburbs are quick to swivel their brims to the rear. . . . In a year, lines outside trendy clubs in Paris and Tokyo are filled with would-be homeboys in backward caps and droopy pants.
The irony is that the young white kids are not rebelling against anything, and neither are the boys in the Ville. The young black men in Brownsville indict society by their total belief in it. They trust what they have been told about image, status, competition, hierarchy and the primacy of self-gratification. Their faith is lethal, mostly to themselves.
 From "The Ville."

LENGTH: 1115 words

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio

 BODY:
Editing a weekly newspaper in rural Maine should be a breeze. You put in a few days covering the big news events -- layoffs at the lumber mill, pileups on the highway, opening of ice-fishing season, hockey game at the high school -- then you knock off and go skiing. Right?
Not the way Gerry Boyle tells it in DEADLINE (North Country Press, $17.95), a bone-cracking first novel set in a gritty mill town where the snow starts falling around Labor Day and the hearts of the citizenry stay frozen all year round. That's how it seems to Jack McMorrow, a jaded newsman who has fled New York City to edit The Androscoggin Review. McMorrow runs into granite indifference from the town cops when his staff photographer is found floating in an icy canal, but he attracts plenty of rough attention when he does a little muckraking on the local paper mill. 
 "I didn't trust anybody," McMorrow has to admit, "and in this town, way up here in the woods, it really was a terrifying feeling." Mr. Boyle's emotionally guarded style strongly conveys that stark terror of isolation. There's a steel backbone in his lean plot, and the clipped prose and flinty characterizations are to this rugged literary landscape what the black woods and craggy cliffs are to the contours of Maine -- a daunting kind of beauty.
Christmas is quickly creeping up on Maggody, Ark. (population 755), in O LITTLE TOWN OF MAGGODY (Dutton, $19). But the recession got there first, and folks are singing the blues in the Ozark Mountain hamlet where Joan Hess sets her droll mysteries. What they're actually singing is Matt Montana's lachrymose country hit "You're a Detour on the Highway to Heaven," a song that puts Arly Hanks, the Chief of Police, in mind of hog-slaughtering season.
Arly gets a chance to exercise her "smart mouth and snippety way" when the Nashville star declares himself to be a long-lost son of Maggody and announces that he's coming home for Christmas. Smelling tourist blood, the mayor's fearsomely ambitious wife masterminds a promotional blitz in which the whole town turns itself inside out to capitalize on the golden boy's return. "I hear they're painting Matt's face on the sides of all the cows" is one of Arly's kinder comments on the Matt madness. But she wipes off the smirk when Matt's dear, dotty auntie is kidnapped from the nursing home, and when a Nashville promoter turns up dead in the window of the Official Matt Montana Souvenir Shoppe.
There's a sturdy plot and keen satirical point to all this giddy nonsense. But in the spirit of the season, the author is as generous with her affection as she is with her wit. So, sing out, Maggody -- somebody loves you.
Matt Minogue, the world-weary Dublin Garda inspector in John Brady's brooding police procedurals, drags himself home to County Clare in ALL SOULS (St. Martin's, $20.95), hoping for a bit of a rest. But before he can sip his drop of Jameson and savor the peat fire at his old pub, Minogue steps hip-deep into a bog of local troubles. The rural gentry are in cahoots with a German industrialist whose plans for tourist development are driving farmers like Minogue's brother off their land. The I.R.A. is making hay of the sorry situation by recruiting discontented youths like Minogue's nephew. And an ugly political scandal is fueled by the death of an obsessional, delusional man who may have been falsely convicted of murder many years ago. "Very tricky people down this part of the country," Minogue's partner dryly observes.
The author, who lives in Dublin, pitches the muted tone of his story to the bleak, barren atmosphere of a countryside on the edge of winter. The pace of his story is slow, the plotting is subtle, and passions, even murderous ones, run cold. The warmth is all in the language -- "the light inflections of whimsy, the sonorous and beguiling range of tones and emphases, of words lingered on, others dropped like petals on water, at once inviting and intimate" -- that burns through the cold and lights up the dark.
"Not great, but good" is how John Marshall Tanner sums up his life for a civil rights lawyer from Charleston, S.C., when the two old friends meet at their 25th college reunion in SOUTHERN CROSS (Morrow, $20). Pressed for details, Stephen Greenleaf's honor-bound private eye confesses that his life in San Francisco is "too lonely, too selfish, too ordinary to be great." Any reader who can relate to that middle-aged plaint will sympathize when the conscience-driven hero stops his political waffling and commits himself to the dangerous job of protecting his friend from the murderous threats of a white-racist hate group.
On his initial exposure to Charleston, Tanner is too easily distracted from his duties by the charm and history of the city -- "I had never been in a place that celebrated its past so passionately," he marvels -- and by the seductive graces of its native daughters. But once he gets the guidebook lectures off his chest and starts tracking down the rabid hatemongers and skinhead punks who are persecuting the lawyer and his black clients, Tanner turns over some good dirt on race relations past and present. Although he's more of a gasbag here than usual, with his preachy messages about "America's greatest shame," Tanner is still one of the most relentlessly professional investigators in the game.
Dorothy Simpson's 12th procedural mystery, NO LAUGHING MATTER (Scribners, $20), is well named, because even in her hero's salad days Inspector Luke Thanet never went in much for hooting and hollering. "Amongst policemen an apparently inappropriate levity was often a safety mechanism against the sordid reality of much of their work," he ponderously acknowledges. It just doesn't do the trick for Thanet, whose compassionate heart still does flip-flops at the sight of a corpse. "There was something so poignant about the newly dead," he reflects, after wading through buckets of blood to view the tattered remnants of a vintner who went through the laboratory window of his prosperous family-owned vineyard in the Kentish countryside.
But if Thanet has always been a glum one, the Scotland Yard detective is also a shrewd and observant judge of human nature, as well as a perfectionist in the clever art of the police interview. Not a grape is left unplucked, nor a motive unsqueezed, in his research into the murdered man's business dealings (a bit complicated) and personal character (thoroughly despicable). "We grumble about it," Thanet says about all the verbal bobbing and weaving, "but just think how boring it would be if everybody told us everything we wanted to know straight off." A stuffy man, that Thanet, but never a bore.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1993;
Taking It Out in Trade

 BODY:
Money isn't everything. There's compost, ice cream and beer, available free to employees at, respectively, Rodale Press (publishers of "Organic Gardening"), Ben & Jerry's and the Miller Brewing Company.
For many Americans, getting a job would be enough. But the lucky few get jobs plus perks (perquisites). In hidden corners of the economy there is still a gravy, or perhaps an ice-cream, train. 
 At L. L. Bean, employees get free use of snowshoes, tents and other equipment. They also are able to take "outdoor experience days."
CNN gave watches at Christmas, although there is a rumor that many of them broke.
The perks at J. P. Morgan in New York suggest why investment bankers have not been out stumping for President Clinton's health plan. Employees not only have health insurance, they have access to in-house doctors, including an orthopedist and a gynecologist, and a staff social worker for short-term counseling.
Employees at Rikers Island get free tuberculosis tests, although that hardly seems appealing.
Nike provides an extremely appealing range of subsidized services (no free shoes), but it may have a hidden agenda. On its Oregon "campus," says a spokeswoman, Nike has a health club, tennis courts, a delicatessen, a hair salon, a dry cleaner and a day-care center, "so you never have to leave."

LENGTH: 3867 words

HEADLINE: Hubble Jeopardy

BYLINE: By Dennis Overbye; Dennis Overbye is the author of "Lonely Hearts of the Cosmos: The Story of the Scientific Quest for the Secret of the Universe." He is at work on a book about Albert Einstein.

 BODY:
Sun beats through the skylights and mingles with the scent of chlorine, creating a tropical oppression atop the Neutral Buoyancy Simulator, a four-story human aquarium at the Marshall Space Flight Center, in Huntsville, Ala. Lying at the bottom of the tank like a sunken pirate ship is the cargo bay of a space shuttle, chockablock with high-tech fittings, boxes, handholds, airlock and a 30-foot white robot arm draped with cables. Nearby, standing upright on the pool bottom, is a sizable section of the Hubble Space Telescope -- not the real one, of course, which has drifted in famous myopia 370 miles above the earth these last three years, but a full-scale model. Kathy Thornton and Tom Akers, dressed in bulbous spacesuits, float through the landscape like marine Robocops, trailing hoses, bubbles and a bevy of frogman assistants.
Prowling the edge of the pool is 58-year-old Story Musgrave: surgeon, parachutist, gardener, ex-marine, literary critic, holder of six university degrees, father of five children, veteran astronaut and bald as a monk. On Wednesday, Musgrave will make his fifth trip into space, accompanied by Akers, Thornton and four other astronauts, aboard a space shuttle Endeavour crammed with tools and instruments. Their mission: repair the orbiting Hubble telescope, which suffers not only blurry vision but also several potentially fatal mechanical ailments. Practice, Musgrave hopes, will make perfect. By early October, he and his crew have spent nearly 400 hours in tanks like the one in Huntsville, rehearsing every conceivable excruciating moment of Hubble's rebirth. 
 When it was launched from the space shuttle in April 1990, after 44 years of planning and development, the Hubble Space Telescope was hailed by the spinmasters of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as "the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo." And it might have been. Floating above the earth's unruly atmosphere, the telescope would see what no eyeball had seen before. Its lenses and finely polished mirrors would concentrate the light from distant stars into dots a hundred times finer and more intense than earthbound telescopes, enabling astronomers to peer with unprecedented clarity into the hearts of quasars, seek evidence of black holes, follow the swirling storms of Jupiter and discern galaxies emerging from their milky cribs 10 billion light years away.
Instead, shortly after launching, astronomers discovered that Hubble's 2.4-meter primary mirror (about 94 inches in diameter) had been exquisitely polished to the wrong shape. The telescope became a $1.5 billion laughingstock, and it is now Musgrave's job as payload commander to quell the laughter. It won't be easy. The coming flight, a $690 million undertaking, will include at least five and as many as eight action-filled space walks lasting six hours each. "If they bring the repair mission off, it will be the equivalent of a modern-day miracle," says John Bahcall, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., who has been involved in the space telescope for years. "I'll be there cheering and praying."
When Musgrave and his crew clamber up the side of the space telescope later this week, however, more than the secrets of the universe will be at stake. Their jobs, for example. NASA long ago bet the future of the space program on the notion that humans can routinely and economically work in space. But a decade into the space shuttle era, space work seems more costly and dangerous than ever. The agency's credibility now dangles precariously, unlikely to survive any more setbacks like the 1986 explosion of Challenger, the disappearance this summer of the Mars Observer -- and recent NASA inspector general reports that the agency's contractors overcharge and many of its employees sleep on the job.
A recent Senate committee report spells it out in so many words: "Should this mission fail to live up to the promise that Hubble's capabilities will be fully restored as a result of this undertaking, NASA's entire flight program will suffer a substantive and financial setback that will take many years from which to recover." The agency administrator, Daniel Goldin, dismisses that assessment. "If our space program depends on just this one mission," he grumbles, "we shouldn't have a space program." Like it or not, though, the message could not be clearer: One small misstep by the Hubble repairmen could mean one giant leap backward for space agencykind.
HUBBLE IS A RELIC OF A time when NASA thought humans could do anything and everything in space. "The astronauts originally wanted it to be a manned telescope," says Lyman Spitzer, the Princeton astronomer who cooked up the idea back in 1946. In the early 1970's, advocates of the space telescope played on NASA's enthusiasm for manned flight by designing it to be serviced by astronauts from the then-coming space shuttle. Musgrave, who at the time was NASA's resident expert on space walks, offered critical advice. As a result Hubble, completed in 1989, came equipped with 225 linear feet of handrails and 31 pins for attaching portable foot restraints. "Hubble is very E.V.A. friendly," Musgrave says proudly, using astronaut-speak for extra-vehicular activity.
User-friendliness came at a price. The telescope was constrained to a low orbit, roughly 370 miles up, that the shuttle could reach. At that altitude, however, the earth blocks half the sky, limiting observations of any particular celestial object to less than half of each 96-minute orbit. And making the telescope compatible with astronaut repairmen proved expensive. "Imagine," says one astronomer, "what your television would look like if all its components had to be accessible from the outside to someone wearing boxing gloves."
Mismanagement, turf wars, inadequate financing while NASA strained to pay for the shuttle and simple incompetence led to the black day in the summer of 1990 when astronomers discovered Hubble's flaw. The outer edges of the primary mirror were seven hundred-thousandths of an inch too low, an amateurish optical mistake. Computer processors at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore quickly managed to correct for the aberration and reconstruct images of relatively bright objects. But Hubble's cosmic potential was still unfulfilled, a major shortcoming for an instrument that costs more than $100 million a year to operate. "They've got to repair it," says Marc Davis, an astronomer at the University of California at Berkeley. "Or they should close down the institute."
The fix had already begun. Even before Hubble's launching, NASA had built a backup replacement for the main camera, known as WFPC (pronounced wiff-pick, for wide field and planetary camera), and had scheduled installation for the first astronaut house call in 1993. When he heard about the aberration, John Trauger, principal scientist on the WFPC-2 team at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, realized that they could correct for the effects of Hubble's warp by outfitting the new camera with small mirrors containing precisely the opposite warp.
But Hubble's problems kept mounting. Ground controllers discovered that the telescope shakes violently for about 10 minutes twice each orbit when it passes between day and night; the poles supporting the blanketlike solar arrays expand and contract unevenly during the temperature change, causing the arrays to flutter. If they rip, the observatory will lose power and die. To make matters worse, soon after launching the gyroscopes that control the telescope's spatial orientation began to fail. Hubble had been launched with six gyroscopes. By last summer only three were still working -- the minumum needed. Fortunately, help was on the way.
THE CREW OF SPACE Shuttle Endeavour is probably the most experienced ever to fly into space. Its seven members have among them 16 space flights and, perhaps more important, 31 hours of space walks. The commander, Dick Covey, and the pilot, Ken Bowersox, have flown the shuttle before. Musgrave made the first-ever space walk from the shuttle, in 1983. During the repair he will work with Jeffrey Hoffman, who was an X-ray astronomer at M.I.T. before joining the astronaut corps in 1978, and who is making his fourth flight. The other space-walking pair consists of Akers, a twinkly-eyed former high-school principal and Air Force pilot, and Thornton, a slight, brown-haired nuclear physicist, both of whom have been to space twice. The shuttle's robot arm, crucial to the mission, will be operated by Claude Nicollier, a Swiss astronaut who represents the European Space Agency.
A day in the tank, however, is no advertisement for the glamorous astronaut life. The morning starts at 7 with a briefing, and NASA does not provide coffee; the astronauts straggle in, bleary-eyed, carrying bag lunches. Thornton wears a T-shirt declaring "Maggots in Space 1984" -- not a reference to a shuttle biology experiment, but the motto of her graduating astronaut class.
The briefers report that the new practice robot arm is having troubles and may have to be replaced with an older, less reliable one. Moreover, they caution that the chlorine in the pool is corroding the paint, creating a fine powder that accumulates on the bottom and is easily stirred up.
The plan for the day calls for Akers and Thornton to practice their second space walk, or E.V.A., in which they are scheduled to replace Hubble's solar arrays. "We've never done this whole E.V.A. before, only bits and pieces," Thornton says in a drawl that belies her Alabama origins. "Connecting the tasks is where all the choreography comes in."
Akers and Thornton spend most of the morning getting dressed and undressed while technicians fuss with the robot arm. When Thornton finally shows up poolside, looking like a Klingon in a white bodysuit veined with cooling tubes, Akers kids her about her figure. Thornton then lies on her back on a black mat and begins squirming, as a technician slides her into her iron-waisted trousers. Standing, her pants down around her knees, she then ducks into the torso unit hanging on a nearby stanchion, and is cinched up. Dressing is easier in zero gravity, Thornton grunts in her 300-pound suit. Now, her belt weighted with tools and her helmet fastened down, Thornton waves goodbye and settles slowly into the pool.
After much debate, divers swarm into the pool to disconnect the new robot arm and reinstall the old one, which has been lying on the bottom. With the good arm now unavailable, Musgrave scraps the original practice exercise; instead, Thornton and Akers will practice replacing the gyro systems, scheduled for the first day of space walks. Thornton rides on the platform at the end of the robot arm, barking continual radio instructions to Nicollier in a mock shuttle cabin a few feet away. Akers, attaching tethers as he goes, clambers like Spider-Man around the shuttle bay and the telescope.
Musgrave sits in a control room downstairs, watching the monitor. Things aren't going well in the cloudy tank. At one point Thornton accidentally jettisons half her tools; Akers is busy coaxing a rusty bolt to life. It's all good practice, Musgrave points out: a loose or broken bolt floating through the telescope would do as much damage as a hand grenade.
Akers suddenly breaks radio silence.
"See what happened, Story?" he asks.
"No, I can only see your backpack"
"That's good."
An astronaut since 1967, Musgrave is the straw that stirs this drink. He joined the astronaut corps hoping to get to the moon. When NASA cut back on the number of planned Apollo flights -- having won the space race -- Musgrave was left without a ticket. He would wait 16 years before getting to space, a memory that still rankles.
In the meantime he managed to fly more than 17,000 hours, earn an airline pilot license and make more than 460 parachute jumps. His medical and physiological expertise (Musgrave worked as a surgeon throughout his career, even as he compiled university degrees from coast to coast) was put to work helping NASA to develop spacesuits and space-walk techniques for the space shuttle. That in turn him made a natural choice to help develop the space telescope. Unsurprisingly, Musgrave was the first astronaut chosen, in April 1992, for the repair flight, an honor that he views as entirely fitting.
"When I was a kid, I liked to lie on my back and watch the stars at night," he says. "I've thought of that instrument as contributing to my personal ideas about my place in the universe, about what it is to be human."
In the last 20 months, the repair mission has taken over Musgrave's life. Last summer it nearly cost him his fingers. Early plans for the flight called for the shuttle to fly in such a way that the cargo bay would be kept in darkness, to prevent sunlight from damaging the telescope's delicate optics. Training in a vacuum tank in Houston that simulated those conditions, Musgrave got frostbite on four digits. He had been handling tools whose temperature had descended to minus 130 degrees Fahrenheit.
"The plan was changed," he says grimly.
Since then, Musgrave has developed a nearly zenlike passion for, literally, nuts and bolts. One screw in particular occupies his thoughts and dreams. Known as the "A" latch, it's not just any screw; this one is a rod seven feet long. It holds the $100 million WFPC camera, about the shape and mass of a grand piano, in place on Hubble. There's a light to tell when the latch is about to settle in, and there are springs to keep it from jamming too far. It will be the job of Musgrave and Hoffman to unscrew that latch, slide out the old camera and slide in the new, improved version. When they screw that latch back down, snapping WFPC-2 into register, the space telescope for the first time will be blessed with the crystal vision its founders intended.
For the dime-sized corrective mirrors to work their magic, however, WFPC-2 must be precisely aligned with the optical axis of the telescope. All this makes WFPC-2 extremely delicate, no part more so than a small mirror that pokes out from the front to divert light into the camera. Just before the astronauts slide WFPC-2 into place, Musgrave will remove the cover from the mirror -- very carefully. If the mirror alignment is disturbed by as much as one-quarter of a degree, the images will be worse than before. "In that case," Hoffman says, "you can just open your spacesuit vents, disconnect your tether, and push off."
Musgrave has prepared for the moment like Baryshnikov. He knows where every appendage of his space-suited body will be when it comes time to remove the cover from the mirror, that fragile portal of dreams. So when an engineer from the Goddard Space Flight Center, fearful of cross-threading the all-important bolt, suggests during an evening debriefing that the astronauts lower the setting on their power torque wrench, Musgrave does not react lightly. Leaping from his chair, he scolds the engineer for fiddling at the last minute with well-learned work habits. To reset the torque wrench, Musgrave points out, an astronaut would have to swivel to face the work station on the robot arm, turning his back on WFPC-2. "The program is at risk," he declares flatly.
The engineer takes Musgrave's outburst in stride. "It's a good sign," he says later. "It means the crew is ready to fly. They're pumped."
THE FOLLOWING morning finds Thornton and Akers back in the tank, rehearsing the installation of an ingenious gadget known as Costar, for Corrective Optics Space Telescope Axial Replacement, the second of the two devices that will restore Hubble's eyesight. Costar was invented by a team of systems engineers at the Space Telescope Science Institute who were trying to figure out a way to correct the light entering the four other scientific instruments on Hubble. Nobody could devise a solution until Jim Crocker, a member of the team, had a revelation in a Munich shower.
"The shower head was on a bar," he explains. "It ran up and down and folded up." It occurred to Crocker that if the astronauts removed one of Hubble's instruments there would be room to insert a narrow tower up through the crowded focal plane, which could then unfold like a Swiss Army knife, lodging pairs of small corrective mirrors in front of the apertures of the other instruments. Back home in Baltimore, Crocker made a model of the aft end of the telescope and of his invention using plastic foam and his son's set of Ramagons, the modern equivalent of Tinker Toys. "The box said they had been used by NASA to design the space station," Crocker says.
The delicacy and cleverness of Costar's innards are obscured by the brute operation of installing them. Four of Hubble's instruments, each in a box the size of a telephone booth, are aligned with the axis of the telescope and are enclosed by doors that ring its base; they slide in and out on rails. (WFPC-2 slides into the side of the telescope, above them.) Light from the telescope falls on a saucer-sized area at the center where the phone booths come together. To insert Costar the astronauts must engage in an intricate dance of weightless phone booths. First they must pull out one instrument and park it in a temporary carrier on the side of the cargo bay. Then they must open the container in which Costar has been stored during the flight, lift it out and slide it into the vacated space, screwing down the assorted latches that connect it firmly and accurately to the telescope. Finally the sacrificed instrument -- the high speed photometer, which rapidly and accurately measures the brightness of celestial objects -- will be put in Costar's container and returned to earth.
Today, with the good robot arm in place and working, the rehearsal goes smoothly. Thornton rides up to the telescope, its bay doors tethered wide, and grabs the handles of the high speed photometer. Nicollier pulls her back and the instrument slides free. An hour later, right on the time line, Costar is in place. The astronauts move on to their next task, adding more memory to the spacecraft's computer.
By last spring there were 12 items on Musgrave's to-do list. Seven of the tasks, including the replacement of the solar arrays, gyros, WFPC and Costar, are considered so crucial to the survival and scientific capacity of the telescope that, according to the mission director, Randy Brinkley, NASA would consider a second repair flight to finish them. The agency originally hoped to complete the work in three space walks -- the standard shuttle capacity -- but Musgrave pushed for more. "They finally gave me five," he says. "I just wanted the resources. Everything we're doing must be done."
THERE ARE BILLIONS OF REASONS to root for Musgrave and his companions -- one for every galaxy and star of which the reborn telescope will have an unfettered view. The clear view will enable astronomers to tackle some large-scale questions. How fast is the universe expanding? Will the galaxies all fall back together in some future millenium, starry cymbals in a giant clash? By detecting and timing the variations of individual stars known as Cepheid variables in faraway galaxies, Jeremy Mould, a Caltech astronomer, and his colleagues hope to fix precise distances to those starry clouds. Closer to home, other astronomers hope to train the Hubble on Jupiter next July. Some 20 chunks of a comet, several as big as a mile across, are predicted to crash into the planet's back side in the biggest cataclysm in recorded history, producing fireballs the size of Texas.
Restoring the Hubble telescope, however, may not completely mend NASA's frayed relationship with scientists. With an astronomy and astrophysics budget of more than $700 million, NASA is the biggest sponsor of stargazing in the world. Yet its gifts often come with strings that drive up costs and have little to do with science. During the 1980's, for instance, the agency required satellites to be launched by the problematic and often delayed shuttle. Many scientists now argue that NASA should be split into two agencies: one to do science, the other to run the shuttle trucking business.
The space agency itself likes to view the Hubble repair as evidence of a new NASA -- or of the good old NASA returned. But optimistic rhetoric cannot disguise the fact that NASA has foundered for a mission ever since it beat the Russians to the moon. With the cold war over, the public appetite for ambitious scientific projects has diminished. And NASA offers no new dream to lift us, or itself. The proposed international space station and Mission to Planet Earth may be responsible public works projects, but they are hardly stirring. To save the world -- or at least regain its own technological edge -- NASA needs an inspiration, and the universe is waiting.
THIS, THEN, IS THE PLAN so far: To match the telescope's orbit, the shuttle Endeavour must blast off at about 4:30 A.M. Eastern Time Wednesday. For the next two days, Endeavour will chase the telescope, finally grab it with the robot arm and dock it in the cargo bay on the third day. That could be the diciest day of the flight. Last year, after two tries to nab the Intelsat satellite with the robot arm, three astronauts had to grab it by hand.
The repair work begins the next day. "We'll probably be out of the airlock early for the first couple of space walks," Thornton says. "And then we'll be dragging." To maintain the crew's sleep schedule established by the launch time, all the space walks will take place at night United States time. Musgrave and Hoffman will exit the air lock for the first space walk at about the time New Yorkers are tuning into "Saturday Night Live." The two will alternate nights with Thornton and Akers.
"The philosophy for working in space," a tanned and rangy Hoffman explains during a lull in the Huntsville proceedings, "is the same as for working on your car. One: Don't hurt yourself. Two: Don't break anything that's not already broken." In space, of course, as under your car, a million things can go wrong. "Just replacing WFPC is the kind of thing they would devote a whole mission to, and we've got five of those days," Hoffman says. "Only with a certain amount of luck will we be able to do everything."
No one seems more determined to exploit luck than Musgrave. "We're prepared to do the whole thing without the robot arm," he volunteers. Sitting in the control room while Thornton and Akers swim on the monitor above him, Musgrave lists the contingencies and backup procedures that had been included in the rehearsals: cranking out the new solar arrays by hand if they fail to extend automatically, jettisoning the old ones if they fail to roll up properly, carrying along spare bolts and WFPC latches.
"We'll get it done, but not without surprises," Musgrave says. "You can change our flight plan while we're out there and we'll get it done. That's a requirement I put down at the start." He leans forward, his head back-lit by flickering video screens. "It's gonna be drama," he says with a smile. "Just stand by."

By replacing the camera with a modified backup version, WFPC-2, right, astronauts hope to correct the telescope's vision. WFPC-2 captures the light beam with a series of mirrors. After striking the doughnut-shaped relay primary mirror, the light bounces to the relay secondary mirror, which has been exquisitely shaped to compensate for Hubble's original flaw. Now properly focused, the light beam then passes through the hole in the relay primary mirror to electronic sensors, which send the image back to Earth in digital form. A phone-booth sized device called Costar will correct the light entering Hubble's four other scientific instruments (outlined in green above) -- but only by sacrificing one of them. SECTION: Section 6; Page 52; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3180 words

HEADLINE: The Dalai Lama

BYLINE: By Claudia Dreifus; Claudia Dreifus is an interviewer for Playboy, TV Guide and other major magazines.

 BODY:
The last place one expects to find His Holiness Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama of Tibet, the exiled secular and religious leader of the Tibetan people, the winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize, the world's leading exponent of nonviolent political change, is at a glitzy Tucson, Ariz., golfing resort called the Sheraton El Conquistador. Yet there he was on a recent autumn morning, dressed in his traditional maroon robes, surrounded by Buddhist monks and non-Buddhist bodyguards, astonishing tourists as he rushed past the snack bar.
The Dalai Lama had come to this unlikely corner of the world to give a series of interpretive readings from "A Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life" by Shantideva, an eighth-century Buddhist saint. For five full days, 1,500 attendees risked bad backs and cramped hands to sit for hours taking notes on the nature of patience. For them, participants in the expanding Buddhist movement in the Western world, this was a rare opportunity to study with the head of the faith -- the equivalent of taking Bible classes from the Pope. Moreover, many of the aspirants were more secular types, veterans of the 1960's who'd come to regard the Dalai Lama as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the Mahatma Gandhi of this political moment. It is a forum the Dalai Lama clearly enjoys, a needed break from routine as head of the Tibetan government-in-exile in India. "I am a simple Buddhist monk -- no more, no less," he often says of himself. At the teachings, he gets to be that. 
 Yet his life has been anything but simple. Born in 1935 to a peasant family in northeast Tibet, he was, at the age of 2, identified after the death of the 13th Dalai Lama as the 14th reincarnation of the Buddha of Compassion. That recognition brought a new name; Lhamo Thondup now became Jetsun Jamphel Ngawang Lobsang Yeshe Tenzin Gyatso (Holy Lord, Gentle Glory, Eloquent, Compassionate, Learned Defender of the Faith, Ocean of Wisdom). Taken to Lhasa to be educated, he grew up in a 1,000-room palace, surrounded by doting monks who tutored him in subjects like philosophy, medicine and metaphysics and gave him a childhood of pure magic.
The magic ended in 1950 when the 15-year-old Dalai Lama was called upon to assume full powers as head of state. This, at the very moment the People's Liberation Army of China was invading Tibet. For the next nine years, the young ruler attempted to negotiate with Mao Zedong and Chou En-lai, who were intent on absorbing Tibet into China. Then, in 1959, after China brutally "quelled" a Tibetan civilian uprising against Chinese rule, the Dalai Lama fled to India; some 100,000 Tibetans have since followed him across the Himalayas.
In India, he was permitted to set up a government-in-exile in a small village, Dharamsala, a long day's drive from New Delhi. "His Holiness reconstructed a viable Tibetan community in India, preserving the culture of Tibet," says his close friend Robert Thurman, professor of Indo-Tibetan studies at Columbia University. "He held the Tibetan people together in exile and gave them hope during the very severe, even genocidal oppression in their homeland. He's also the first leader of Tibet to become a world leader, even without a political base -- just on his moral force."
In Tucson, a day after his teachings were completed, the Dalai Lama met in his suite with the interviewer. As would be expected from someone who has been worshiped as a demigod since age 2, he greets strangers with a mask of pleasant formality, which soon melts as he becomes engaged in ideas and conversation. An hour and a half becomes three; formality turns to laughter. One senses he's a little bored by the adulation that is his daily fare. The most striking thing about the Dalai Lama is his capacity for joy -- how widely he smiles, how amused he is by his own contradictions, his own human foibles. The journalist William Shirer once said of his interviews with Gandhi in the 1930's, "You felt you were the only person in the room, that he had all the time in the world for you." This is true of Tenzin Gyatso also.
Q: Your Holiness, you seem such a happy person. Have there been moments in your life when your faith in human goodness was tested?
The Dalai Lama: No.
Q:You've never felt in danger of becoming cynical?
A: No. Of course, when I say that human nature is gentleness, it is not 100 percent so. Every human being has that nature, but there are many people acting against their nature, being false. Certainly there have been sad moments for me. The Chinese suppressions in Lhasa in 1987, 1988, now that was sad. A great many people were killed. I am sometimes sad when I hear the personal stories of Tibetan refugees who have been tortured or beaten. Some irritation, some anger comes. But it never lasts long. I always try to think at a deeper level, to find ways to console.
Q: I understand that you were very angry during the 1990 gulf war, as angry as you've ever been.
A: Angry? No. But one thing, when people started blaming Saddam Hussein, then my heart went out to him.
Q: To Saddam Hussein?
A: Yes. Because this blaming everything on him -- it's unfair. He may be a bad man, but without his army, he cannot act as aggressively as he does. And his army, without weapons, cannot do anything. And these weapons were not produced in Iraq itself. Who supplied them? Western nations! So one day something happened and they blamed everything on him -- without acknowledging their own contributions. That's wrong. The gulf crisis also clearly demonstrated the serious implications of the arms trade. War -- without an army, killing as few people as possible -- is acceptable. But the suffering of large numbers of people due to a military mission, that is sad.
Q: Did you say that killing sometimes is acceptable?
A: Comparatively. In human society, some people do get killed, for a variety of reasons. However, when you have an established army, and countries with those armies go to war, the casualties are immense. It's not one or two casualties, it's thousands. And with nuclear weapons, it's millions, really millions. For that reason, the arms trade is really irresponsible. Irresponsible! Global demilitarization is essential.
Q: In Tibet, from the late 1950's until the early 1970's, one of your brothers was involved in leading a guerrilla movement against the Chinese. In fact, the guerrillas were supported by the C.I.A. How did you feel about that?
A: I'm always against violence. But the Tibetan guerrillas were very dedicated people. They were willing to sacrifice their own lives for the Tibetan nation. And they found a way to receive help from the C.I.A. Now, the C.I.A.'s motivation for helping was entirely political. They did not help out of genuine sympathy, not out of support for a just cause. That was not very healthy.
Today, the help and support we receive from the United States is truly out of sympathy and human compassion. In spite of their desire for good relations with China, the Congress of the United States at least supports Tibetan human rights. So this is something really precious, genuine.
Q: To change the subject, you have spoken, as few religious leaders have, of the dangers of global overpopulation.
A: Well, the population problem is a serious reality. In India, some people were reluctant to accept birth control because of religious traditions. So I thought, from the Buddhist viewpoint, there is a possibility of flexibility on this problem. I thought it might be good to speak out and eventually create more open space for leaders in other religious traditions to discuss the issue.
Q: How do you feel, then, about Pope John Paul II's continued opposition to birth control?
A: That's his religious principle. He is acting from a certain principle -- especially when he speaks about the need to respect the rights of fetuses. Actually, I feel very touched that the Pope has taken a stand on that.
Q: Can you also understand the needs of a woman who might not be able to raise a child?
A: When I was in Lithuania a few years ago, I visited a nursery and I was told, "All these children are unwanted." So I think it is better that that situation be stopped right from the beginning -- birth control. Of course, abortion, from a Buddhist viewpoint, is an act of killing and is negative, generally speaking. But it depends on the circumstances. If the unborn child will be retarded or if the birth will create serious problems for the parent, these are cases where there can be an exception. I think abortion should be approved or disapproved according to each circumstance.
Q: I understand you've experienced a major change in thinking about the role of women in the world.
A: It's not so much a change. I've gained an awareness of the sensitivity of women's issues; even in the 1960's and 1970's, I didn't have much knowledge of this problem. The basic Buddhist stand on the question of equality between the genders is age-old. At the highest tantric levels, at the highest esoteric level, you must respect women: every woman. In Tibetan society, there has been some careless discrimination. Yet there have been exceptional women, high lamas, who are respected throughout Tibet.
Q: In a recent issue of the Buddhist magazine Tricycle, the actor Spalding Gray asked you about your dreams, and you said you sometimes dreamt of women fighting.
A: Women fighting? No, no. . . . What I meant was that, in my dreams, sometimes women approach me and I immediately realize, "I'm bhikshu, I'm monk." So you see, this is sort of sexual. . . .
Q: In your dreams, you realize this and you "fight" the feeling?
A: Yes. Similarly, I have dreams where someone is beating me and I want to respond. Then, immediately I remember, "I am monk and I should not kill."
Q: Do you ever experience rages? Even Jesus had rages.
A: Don't compare me with Jesus. He is a great master, a great master. . . . But as to your question, when I was younger, I did get angry. In the past 30 years, no. One thing, the hatred, the ill-feeling, that's almost gone.
Q: So what are your weaknesses and faults?
A: Laziness.
Q: It is said that you get up at 4 in the morning. How can you be lazy?
A: It's not that kind of laziness. For instance, sometimes, when I visit some Western countries, I develop an enthusiasm to improve my English. But when I actually make the effort to study, after a few days, my enthusiasm is finished. [Laughs.] That is laziness. Other weaknesses are, I think, anger and attachments. I'm attached to my watch and my prayer beads. Then, of course, sometimes beautiful women. . . . But then, many monks have the same experience. Some of it is curiosity: If you use this, what is the feeling? [Points to his groin.]
Then, of course, there is the feeling that something sexual must be something very happy, a marvelous experience. When this develops, I always see the negative side. There's an expression from Nagurajuna, one of the Indian masters: "If you itch, it's nice to scratch it. But it's better to have no itch at all." Similarly with the sexual desire. If it is possible to be without that feeling, there is much peace. [Smiles.] And without sex, there's no worry about abortion, condoms, things like that.
Q: Sir, your laugh is world famous -- what makes you laugh?
A: There is something in my family . . . a tendency to laugh a lot. One brother, Gyalo Thondup, doesn't laugh too much. Another, Lobsang Samten, was very fond of cracking dirty jokes. A third, Taktser Rinpoche, he also laughed a lot. And Tibetans generally are very good-natured. In my childhood, I had a religious assistant who always told me, "If you can really laugh with full abandonment, it's very good for your health."
Q: What do you do for leisure, to relax?
A: I like to let my thoughts come to me each morning before I get up. I meditate for a few hours and that is like recharging. After that, my daily conduct is usually driven by the motivation to help, to create a positive atmosphere for others. I garden . . . gardening is one of my hobbies. Also, reading encyclopedias with pictures. [Laughs.] I am a man of peace, but I am fond of looking at picture books of the Second World War. I own some, which I believe are produced by Time-Life. I've just ordered a new set. Thirty books.
Q: Really? Why does the Reincarnation of Compassion have such a fascination with one of the most terrible events in human history?
A: Perhaps because the stories are so negative and gruesome, they strengthen my belief in nonviolence. [Smiles.] However, I find many of the machines of violence very attractive. Tanks, airplanes, warships, especially aircraft carriers. And the German U-boats, submarines. . . .
Q: I once read that as a little boy in Lhasa, you liked war toys.
A: Yes, very much. I also had an air rifle in Lhasa. And I have one in India. I often feed small birds, but when they come together, hawks spot them and catch them -- a very bad thing. So in order to protect these small birds, I keep the air rifle.
Q: So it is a Buddhist rifle?
A: [Laughs] A compassionate rifle!
Q: Let me ask you a difficult question in that regard. You are indispensable to your movement. Are you ever afraid you might suffer the same fate as Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: The thought sometimes crosses my mind. As far as being "indispensable," people can carry on without me.
Q: Asian scholars say that the Tibetan nation wouldn't have survived after 1959 if you had not been such a skilled political leader. That being the case, aren't you concerned that the Chinese might try to finish off the Tibetan independence movement by killing you?
A: Some Chinese have frankly said to Tibetans: "You only have one person. If we take care of that, the problem is solved."
Q: Have you prepared yourself for the possibility?
A: Not really, although in general, as a Buddhist, my daily meditation involves preparation for death. Death by natural causes, I'm fully prepared for. If sudden death comes, that is tragic -- from the viewpoint of practitioners.
Q: In September, the Palestinians accepted a compromise for regional autonomy. If the Chinese offered such a deal, would you accept?
A: Actually, for the past 14 years, my basic position has been very similar. There is one difference: in the Palestinian case, virtually every government viewed the Territories as occupied and showed concern. In the Tibetan case only the U.S. Congress and some legal experts consider Tibet an occupied land with the right of self-determination.
Q: What was your feeling when you watched the recent signing of the Middle East peace agreement?
A: It's a great achievement. This issue is just one year older than the Tibetan issue. Our problem started in 1949, theirs in 1948. In those years, a lot of hatred developed. Imagine: Palestinians were taught to hate from childhood. That was seen as good for the national interest. In fact, it was rather negative; a lot of violence took place. Now, both sides came to an agreement in the spirit of reconciliation, in the spirit of nonviolence. This is wonderful.
Q: Are there any signs that the Chinese might accept a compromise?
A: [Quickly] No.
Q: You once wrote that the Chinese want to rule the world. Do you still think so?
A: I didn't mean it that way. The remark was related more to the Marxist world intention, rather than Chinese national historical expansionism.
Q: Do you think that still is the case?
A: It's changed, I think. That kind of spirit . . . perhaps in the 1960's, with the Cultural Revolution, it was there. On the Soviet side, Khrushchev realized around 1956 that that kind of goal was not realistic. By the end of the Cultural Revolution, in the 1970's, the Chinese realized that it was out of the question. Now I think the issue is Chinese nationalist historic chauvinism. To them, all other people are barbarians.
Q: Including you?
A: Oh, certainly! Of course! They are a proud nation. With Marxism gone, the strategy is to reach the economic levels of Western countries. They consider themselves a champion of the third world, particularly after the Soviet Union collapsed. They see Russia as having become a part of the West. So what you have is the most populous nation, the worst kind of totalitarian system, the rule of terror -- with nuclear weapons and with an ideology that force is the ultimate source of power. Their economy was poor, but now it is improving -- without changing those other things. Time magazine has called them "the super-power of the next century."
Q: Does that scare you?
A: We already lost our country. But I'm concerned about the world! The world community has the moral responsibility to see democracy in China. Now, how to bring it about? The Chinese intellectuals and the students, they are already a strong political force, and very essential. The world community must give every encouragement to that force. We should not indulge any act which discourages them.
Q: Did you think at the time of the Tiananmen Square uprising that the democracy movement would succeed?
A: Yes. Actually, the events of the 4th of June shocked me. I did not expect them to fire on their own people.
Q: But if the Chinese Communists have been as ruthless against Tibetans as you charge, why not against pro-democracy demonstrators?
A: Because it was their own people! How could they shoot them? During the Cultural Revolution, this was understandable. Tiananmen Square proved that a regime that would have no hesitation to shoot their own people, such a regime. . . . There should be no doubt about their attitude towards other nationalities.
Q: Given that not-so-optimistic assessment, what possible scenarios for China and Tibet do you see?
A: Basically, the Chinese Communist regime, it's only a matter of time: it will change. Worldwide today, there is a growth of freedom and democracy. And the democratic movement, inside and outside China, is still very active. Once the Chinese are willing to listen to others' problems, the Tibetans will not be against the Chinese nation. My approach is in the spirit of reconciliation. Certainly we can have an agreement.
In the meantime, the international community must support Tibet and put pressure on China. Without that, our own approach, according to the last 14 years of experience, has no hope of response.
Q: In closing, I read somewhere that you are predicting that the 21st century, unlike the 20th, is to be a century of peace and justice. Why?
A: Because I believe that in the 20th century, humanity has learned from many, many experiences. Some positive, and many negative. What misery, what destruction! The greatest number of human beings were killed in the two world wars of this century. But human nature is such that when we face a tremendous critical situation, the human mind can wake up and find some other alternative. That is a human capacity.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 28, 1993

SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1181 words

HEADLINE: PUBLUC STAGES;
Burn, Baby, Burn!

BYLINE: By Frank Rich

 BODY:
I was 7 when I tried to burn down the forest bordering my suburban neighborhood. My friends and I had no good excuse with which to placate the army of parents who descended after only a few sticks and shrubs went up in flames.
It never would have occurred to us to say that Howdy Doody, that notorious reprobate among television puppets of the time, made us do it. Only in retrospect could I argue that we were 60's rebels in embryo, venting antiauthoritarian impulses against that fascist, Smokey the Bear. 
 Even though I've long since outgrown the childhood urge to play with matches, I still find fires mesmerizing -- as long as they're someone else's and seen from a safe distance. I am hardly alone. When large patches of Southern California coastline went up in flames for Halloween, television reporters rushed to the scene, eager to satisfy the huge market for pyromaniacal pornography. Alhough the networks called their reports news, this was merely a convenience so no one would feel too guilty about their voyeurism. The news was presented as entertainment, and it was.
Inevitably so, perhaps. From the day that Americans first witnessed a murder live on television 30 years ago last week -- Jack Ruby's of Lee Harvey Oswald -- the appetite for televised images of real-life carnage has grown. Video technology has long since caught up with the appetite. If CNN is not bringing us continuous coverage of a war or natural disaster, then Court TV is offering a play-by-play of the behind-closed-doors mayhem practiced by the Menendez brothers. All the world's a Zapruder film that can be endlessly re-examined frame by frame on a VCR.
Typically, the California fire story was dressed up with artful logos befitting a feature film. Both "Tales From the Ashes," as one ABC "Nightline" installment was titled, and CNN's continuous coverage, which settled for the simple but elegant "California Fires," used a "Gone With the Wind" image, minus Scarlett and Rhett: silhouettes of firefighters set against red-orange flames. CNN topped ABC in cinematic frills by adding ominous theme music reminiscent of its similarly packaged coverage of the Persian Gulf war.
More gripping still, the leap of the fire from Laguna Beach to the sexy show-biz enclave of Malibu lent the drama a cast of fading names who might actually star in a fictional disaster movie. Ali MacGraw, Mark Hamill, Charles Bronson and Rod Steiger all lived in homes in the threatened neighborhood, prompting some of them to put in cameo appearances on camera. The only archetypal disaster-movie character missing was the Feisty Little Old Lady. If only Miss Helen Hayes were alive and well in Malibu, defying police lines to dash into a smoking beach house to save a rag doll for some latter-day Linda Blair.
THE MALIBU SETTING ALSO stoked the competitive fires at NBC's "Today" show, which sent its co-anchor, Bryant Gumbel, to California. The ensuing theatrics should win "Today" a dramatic Emmy, especially given the considerable handicap that had to be overcome: by the time Gumbel arrived on Thursday, Nov. 4, the fire was rapidly being contained and fresh pyrotechnics were at a premium.
Undeterred, "Today" packed the whole epic into that one morning's show, giving it a shrewdly paced beginning, middle and end as adeptly as any screenwriter might. As "Today" opened at 7 A.M. (4 A.M. in California), Gumbel spoke from a perch on Malibu's darkened Pacific Coast Highway, which he described with a touch of martyrdom as "hopefully a safe haven for our special edition of 'Today.' " Heaven knows we had reasons to fear for our brave correspondent. "The battle is far from over," Gumbel intoned. Malibu was "a deadly inferno" and "the tape we've been seeing from back in New York doesn't do it justice."
Soon Gumbel was coaxing tales of horror from a couple who had lost everything in the blaze. While the interviewees were stubbornly chipper -- they could hardly wait to collect the insurance money and move to Australia -- Gumbel kept to the tragic script. "Maybe in time he'll forget this," the anchor said mournfully of the couple's toddler as the segment ended. Never mind that the playful child seemed more annoyed by the television camera than the fire.
After an intermission, "Today" efficiently advanced the story from its tragic opening to its more hopeful second act: the show's news reader, who had announced that the fire was 40 percent contained at 7:30, abruptly raised the figure to 60 percent at 8:00.
At that point, "Today" briefly fanned the dying embers by rerunning California flames as a poetically stylized logo and by bestowing major prominence to the news report of a very photogenic, if less than catastrophic, dormitory fire in the obscure hamlet of Cleveland, Tenn. Back in California, heroic firefighters, suddenly with time on their hands, trooped on to tell their war stories. An economics reporter described the disaster's "silver lining" (lots of work for contractors) and announced, after inspecting one household's fire-gutted Steinway, that "the music will return." And, in a sentimental piece de resistance for the final fadeout, Gumbel revealed that his earlier interview with the homeless couple had stirred "the emotions and hearts of some of our viewers" so much that they had phoned in offers of aid.
Thus had the fire been turned into an entertainment with a full dramatic arc -- from deadly inferno to paradise reborn -- in a lean two hours. Could Darryl Zanuck have done it any better?
"We'll see you from Malibu tomorrow morning as well," said Katie Couric in New York to her co-anchor as "Today" faded out. But when "Today" reappeared the next morning, Couric announced that "Bryant's off today." Clearly the contained fire, no longer a major entertainment, ceased to require a star's presence. No matter that an equally newsworthy but less telegenic story -- the search for arsonists -- had risen from the ashes.
PERHAPS THERE WILL BE AN instant docudrama about the California fires -- "Beach Blanket Inferno"? -- with Victoria Principal as Ali MacGraw and William Shatner as Charles Bronson. That would be in the tradition of recent quickie network movies like "Triumph Over Disaster: The Hurricane Andrew Story" and "Without Warning: Terror in the Tower." It is not only trash television that blurs the line between news and entertainment anymore. Almost everybody does it, squeezing every last drop of blood out of every last disaster, war and crime.
Such infotainment is as ubiquitous and, finally, as numbing as the parade of wares on QVC. If Janet Reno is really curious about how television desensitizes young and old alike to the dangers of playing with matches and guns, she might start by looking at television's protracted, prurient coverage of events like the firestorm at Waco (which she co-produced). At least "Beavis and Butt-Head," a cartoon, does not pretend to be reality. Next to the pyrophilic news spectaculars surrounding it, its jokey efforts to stimulate a viewer's imagination almost start to look like art.

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Wizardry on the Keyboard

BYLINE: By MILO MILES; Milo Miles is a commentator on world music for National Public Radio.

 BODY:
MUSICAL LEGENDS are thick on the ground in New Orleans, and the inflation of reputations by fans is always a danger. The pianist James Booker, who was plagued by alcohol and drug addiction and neurosis and died in 1983 at the age of 43, seemed like a victim of this: until now, he always sounded a shade more stellar in anecdote than on records.
But those who saw him in concert claimed that he took more chances on the keyboard than other New Orleans wizards. Now the full Booker prowess can finally be heard on two complementary collections, "Resurrection of the Bayou Maharajah" (Rounder 2118; CD and cassette), which features vocals, and the all-instrumental "Spiders on the Keys" (Rounder 2119; CD and cassette). 
 The selections were culled from 60 hours of music performed by Booker, using only an upright piano, in his element at the Maple Leaf Bar in New Orleans. Here he felt comfortable enough, on occasion, to divert patrons with nothing more than an evening of jive talk and false starts on the keys. The standout numbers on these releases toss off barbs of wit and anguish that strike with casual precision.
When Booker sat down to play seriously, his performances touched on the styles of a wide group of jazz, rhythm-and-blues and classical musicians. The abrupt block chords and barrelhouse stomps produced by his left hand reinvigorate the rock syncopation of "Eleanor Rigby" on the "Spiders" album even as Booker's right hand strengthens the song's string-quartet echoes.
Throughout, Booker shows flair for revisiting the 60's. Creeping along, "A Taste of Honey" becomes a contemplation of vast ruins, followed by a defiantly jaunty rendition of "He's Got the Whole World in His Hands." The impeccable stride piano instrumental of "Papa Was a Rascal" is as characteristic of Booker as the sprawling vocal version of the same song on "Resurrection." In this treatment, he spins a wild tale of miscegenation and international paranoia. He builds passages between melodic phrases with scampering keyboard runs that complement his zany lyric flights.
Booker's voice is anemic at times, and while he can command an ardent falsetto, he knows it is no match for his left hand, which takes over near the end of "Resurrection."
The piano showpiece that results is a breakneck medley that goes back and forth between "Wine-Spo-Dee-O-Dee" and "It Should Have Been Me." Booker tops that feat with a ragtime "Pop's Dilemma" that saunters through three tempo changes before sliding into "Good Night Irene," done with a deft bayou bounce. Doubters need no more proof than these collections that James Booker was made for a city where music grows in bouquets.

HEADLINE: Where Man Meets Beast, A Conflict

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is head of the Rio de Janeiro bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
BARE feet crunching on the coral sand of Espanola Island, a tour group recently savored the Galapagos experience -- walking within inches of wild sea lions snoozing peacefully in the equatorial sun. For one sunny moment on that morning in September on Gardner Beach, man and beast seemed to be reconciled. Then, a young sea lion emerged dripping from the Pacific Ocean surf. Around his neck was a white plastic bag.
"A little world within itself" was how Charles Darwin described the rare laboratory of biological evolution that is the Galapagos, an archipelago of 19 islands 600 miles west of South America. 
 But ever since a Spanish bishop strayed into these waters in 1535, the Galapagos have suffered successive onslaughts at the hand of man. First English pirates and then American whalers butchered hundreds of thousands of giant tortoises. Later, California sealers abused the trusting nature of Galapagos seals and nearly exterminated the species. In the last century Ecuadorean fishermen and prison convicts started introducing wild herds of goats and pigs to guarantee fresh meat in these desolate outcroppings of volcanic rock.
Today, with 97 percent of the archipelago off limits for colonization, man's modern intrusion is tourism.
Starting with an occasional Lindblad cruise in the late 1960's, Galapagos tourism has increased nearly tenfold since 1970. From 4,579 visitors in that year, the number rose to 17,840 in 1985 and then reached its current level of 41,000 in 1991. Fueling the boom, the number of tour boats soared from 10 in 1980 to 90 today. On land, the number of Galapagos hotels has doubled since 1980 and now numbers 35. The resident population has quadrupled since the early 1960's, to about 14,000 people.
To block further tourism growth, Ecuador's Government moved in July to close the archipelago indefinitely to large visiting boats, those that carry more than 90 passengers. Environmentalists fear that ships arriving from outside will bring flora and fauna alien to the islands.
And last year the Government stopped issuing permits for new tour boats anchored in the islands. Today 90 boats cruise the islands, offering 1,400 berths.
"Supposedly, the issuance of new permits is frozen," said Pedro Proano, marketing vice president for Metropolitan Touring, which operates three boats in the archipelago. "But new boats keep arriving."
In the light of human history on the islands, however, some say that today's intrusion by tourists is benign.
"All told, the adverse impacts of tourism are probably minuscule compared to the ecological imbalances that are the lasting legacy of past human incursions," Douglas Southgate and Morris Whitaker contend in "Economic Progress and the Environment," a book to be published early next year by Oxford University Press.
A different point of view is expressed by Chantal Blanton, an American ecologist who directs the Charles Darwin Research Station at Puerto Ayora, the archipelago's busiest port. Tour boats "empty their sewage tanks wherever they please," said Ms. Blanton, whose research station borders the Galapagos National Park. "More and more, our beach is littered with plastic oil containers and one-liter Coke bottles."
The research station has conducted autopsies on sea turtles only to discover that they died from swallowing plastic, a material that blocks their digestive tracts. Sea lions have cut their sensitive muzzles playing with tin cans that have fallen to the ocean floor.
Ever vigilant against transferring endemic species from island to island in the 20,000-square-mile marine area, ecologists fear that the bright lights of tourist boats attract insects off islands at night, only to deposit them the next morning at other islands. "The big tour boats are lit up at night like floating cities," complained Ms. Blanton.
Scientists also say they are largely in the dark about the impact of hundreds of tourists walking annually along park paths that pass through the nesting areas of such birds as the blue-footed booby, the flightless cormorant and the waved albatross.
In 1975 Orlando Romero, a tour guide, marked trails on North Seymour Island around frigate bird nesting sites. "Today very few frigate birds nest there, possibly because they are permanently bothered by visitors," Mr. Romero wrote recently for La Garua, an island bulletin. To disperse the tourist impact, park officials have gradually increased the number of permitted visiting sites in the Galapagos to 48.
Faced with these and other threats, Galapagos environmentalists are constantly battling to mesh tourism with the islands' fragile ecosystem.
In the largest project seen here in years, the Spanish Government is starting a three-year, $5 million program to improve environmental awareness among visitors and residents. Starting next year, construction will begin on three visitor reception centers -- one for each island with an airstrip.
"The idea is that every tourist will go directly from the airplane to the center," said Antonio Morales Mengual, coordinator of Spanish aid in Ecuador. The center will teach visitors how to enjoy the archipelago's wilderness without harming it.
In addition, the Spanish money will pay for improvements in the training of park guides and for environmental education of residents. Many residents have only a dim awareness of the archipelago's volcanic origins and rare diversity of flora and fauna.
"Most people only know the town, and maybe the farms, if they have one," said Jorge Sotomayor, an environmental educator in Puerto Baquerizo, the islands' administrative capital. "My wife was born here and grew up here. But she had never been out of town until she married me."
The Spanish aid comes at a time when Ecuador's Government shows signs of reversing a decline in conservation support.
Currently, the national park service is running at half of programmed staff levels. Over the last decade the Government's share of the Darwin Foundation's budget has dropped precipitously, from 60 percent to 5 percent. Short of money, the foundation cut its staff in March by one third, to 40.
"Tourism has not paid its way," charged Douglas Southgate, an American environmental economist who advises Ecuador's Government on the issue. "The Ecuadoreans have been selling a resource at a pittance."
According to Mr. Southgate's calculations, each of the two largest cruise ships operating in the Galapagos nets about $4 million every year. Almost half of that is profit, he says. Mr. Proano, the tour operator, dismissed these profit estimates as "completely out of touch with reality." He said that Metropolitan Touring's profit margin is around 3 percent.
But for a license to operate in the Galapagos, a big boat has been paying no more than $1,000 a year. To raise more revenue, the Government increased the annual boat tax this year from $10 a berth to $200. For the largest boats this would mean an increase in its tax from $1,000 to $20,000.
WITH Ecuadoreans now accounting for half of the 40,000 annual visitors to the islands, authorities realized this year that national tourists were grossly undertaxed.
Foreigners and Ecuadoreans are separated into two lines at Galapagos airports; foreigners pay $80 a person for admission. Until early this year, Ecuadoreans paid 40 cents. Today they pay $6.
Only 5 percent of the 400,000 foreigners who visited Ecuador last year visited the archipelago, underscoring the Galapagos' image as an elite tourist destination. Park officials vow to keep it that way.
"We don't want to develop mass tourism in the Galapagos," Jorge Barba Gonzalez, executive director of the Ecuadorean Institute of Forests, Natural Areas and Wildlife, said in an interview in Quito, the capital. "We can't put hotels everywhere. We don't want to compete with the Caribbean."
To keep tourism at its current level, the Government can refuse permission for airlines to fly to the Galapagos, refuse permission for additional tour boats to operate in the Galapagos and refuse permission for the construction of major hotels. In 1990 officials revoked permission for the building of a 200-room luxury hotel in Puerto Baquerizo.
Environmentalists foresee an unending battle between forces of preservation and development on an archipelago once known to sailors as "The Enchanted Islands."
"There are powerful pressures to bring the big cruise ships back in," said Roberto Troya Villacorta, director of Fundacion Natura, a leading environmental group. "It seems that we will never stop being firemen for the Galapagos."
 
 
 
DOS AND DON'TS
 Because each island in the Galapagos has a unique ecology -- often with endemic species of plants, birds, animals and insects -- visitors should take special care when touring the archipelago. Rules go beyond standard national park "don'ts" -- Don't Litter, Don't Camp and Don't Smoke.
To prevent transporting seeds, spores and insects from one island to another, don't carry food to uninhabited islands. And check clothing and shoe soles for biological hitchhikers.
To avoid disrupting the natural social structure of the animals, don't feed, touch or handle the wildlife you encounter.
Many trails weave through nesting colonies of sea birds, such as boobies, cormorants, gulls and frigate birds. Don't drive birds from their nests. If startled, a bird may fly from a nest, leaving an egg or chick exposed to the sun. A newly hatched booby chick will die within 30 minutes if exposed to the equatorial sun.
When visiting towns on the islands, don't buy souvenirs made from Galapagos plants or animals, with the exception of wood. To supply the souvenir trade, local divers have devastated black coral formations around the archipelago.
Only certified guides are allowed to lead visitors into the Galapagos National Park, which covers 97 percent of the archipelago's land mass. In the park, there are only 48 approved visiting sites. But captains of small boats chartered locally for short trips sometimes try to evade these rules. Insist on a guide who has been trained and certified by the park service. Not only will this encourage respect for conservationist practices, but a park-trained guide will inevitably be more informative than a local freelancer.
 
Books to Read
 The following provide a good introduction to the ecology and history of the islands:
"Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands," by Rob Rachowiecki (Lonely Planet Publications).
"Galapagos Guide," by Alan White and Bruce Epler (Imprenta Mariscal, Quito,
Ecuador).
