SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2590 words

HEADLINE: Guardians at the Gate Unbowed by Time

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
DOORMEN don't kiss, and they certainly don't tell on tenants. That is a principle of the job advocated by some of New York City's most experienced dooormen, who were interviewed at the post during this pre-Christmas season as they took packages, hailed cabs, dispensed information, directed repairmen, questioned deliverymen, remarked on the weather, and held doors.
"I know the habits of all the tenants in the building," said Rudy Martoni, as well he might after 22 years at the entrance to 174 East 74th Street, at Third Avenue. He would disclose none of them. 
 But there are other requirements for success, say the amiable individuals who have spent their careers at or near the doors of residential buildings. They chat happily on the subject once assured that management won't mind. Doormen (and presumably the sprinkling of doorwomen as well) are dutiful.
"Treat everybody the same," advises Eddie Steakin, 62, who has been doing so for 38 years at 1088 Park Avenue, at 88th Street.
"You have to like people -- that's Number One right off the bat," says Ronald Berk, 54. He has been on the job for 12 years at 110-20 71st Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens.
"I'm trusted," says Pat Guerin, a fixture at the door of 120 East 81st Street for 23 years, citing not only a prerequisite of success in the job but also one of the sources of his satisfaction. "I know all the people. I'm like family here."
If doormen had been asked years ago to discourse on the requisites of the job, they would no doubt have made the same points. With the exception that security systems have grown more elaborate and doormen have grown more conscious of their crime-prevention responsibilities, the job requirements don't seem to have changed much.
That is a lucky thing for management. Building maintenance is a strongly unionpoints. With the exception that security systems have grown more elaborate and doormen have grown more conscious of their crime-prevention responsibilities, the job requirements don't seem to have changed much.
That is a lucky thing for management. Building maintenance is a strongly unionized field that is not about to be replaced by a competitive technology. (Not entirely, placed many elevator operators.)
It is also a field undergoing ethnic transition. Older doormen, say several of the managing agents who employ them, tend to be of Irish descent. They came into the business 20 or 30 years ago as younger friends and acquaintances of the Irish men who were then prominent in the construction trades and in building management.
NOW many younger doormen tend to be Hispanic, though other groups are also represented, including whites. They don't need advanced education for the starting jobs -- porters and hallmen, probably, with fill-in stints on the door -- and they work their way up. Some day they may become handymen, or concierges or building superintendents. Other doormen look on the job as transitional, a way to earn money while they seek work in other fields.
"It's a good job for young people, but I don't think they like to do it," said Jose Ruiz, 51, one of the doormen at 66-36 Yellowstone Boulevard, in Forest Hills, Queens, who has been at the job since 1975. "This is like a prison for them."
But not for him. He says he's never bored and he appreciates the security and benefits the job provides.
He is also content, like many colleagues, to live by the book -- or rather, the books, because there are two. One is a pocket-sized paperbound blue volume called the Resident Managers and Superintendents Agreement, for superintendents and resident managers in larger buildings. The other is a little yellow volume, the Apartment Building Agreement, covering all other workers, plus the superintendents of smaller buildings.
The agreements are negotiated every three years by Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union and building owners, represented by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations. A separate local, 32E, represents workers in the Bronx and negotiates with a different management group there. The issues in the current negotiations are wages and benefits, as they invariably are. Work rules tend to change little.
IN the building-services contract, seniority does not bring higher pay. A man working as a doorman for 30 years has the same base pay as a man newly hired for the job. Typically, only ambition -- to become a superintendent, for example, or a concierge -- leads to differentiation in base pay between older and younger men performing the same tasks.
Tipping adds an indefinite amount to income, and individual buildings can reward merit in various ways and do -- with bonuses, higher base wages or time off.
Under the 1991 contract, doormen earn $518.17 a week. That comes to $27,981 a year (including employer payments for sick days, 10 of them under the contract). It matters not how many days or few the worker has been on the door, or what his specific duties are. They usually vary with the size of the building. In smaller buildings the doorman may operate as a concierge.
True, the contract guarantees 52 weeks of work. There can be no temporary layoffs, and part-time workers are rare. The contract is also generous on hospital and sick-day benefits. It provides for employer payments to a pension fund, an annuity fund, a training fund and a legal fund for legal services exclusive of landlord-tenant cases. Employers say that the real cost of a doorman to them is about $42,000 to $45,000 a year.
Actually, "doorman" is not a classification under the Apartment Buiilding Agreement. There are only two classifications: handymen and "other." Handymen ("handypersons" in the contract) earn $50 more a week than the "others."
The doorman is an other. Other others are porters, hallmen, concierges and elevator operators. But the contract studiously avoids job descriptions, which would deprive management of flexibility in utilizing personnel.
So far the "man" suffix has not been endangered by the arrival of many women at the job, but there are a few. One of them is Hilda Mendoza, who handles the duty four shifts a week at 257 Central Park West, at 86th Street. On the fifth day she is a porter.
Her first 30 days on the job, five years ago, were the hardest, because that is the probation period. "I could have gotten fired," she said. But she wasn't, and now she has been accepted by employees and tenants, and above all, by children.
"It's great when the kids come down in the morning and say, 'Good morning, Hilda,' ' ' she said. "That's my kick. And the benefits are great."
Using the language of a negotiator for employers (which he is), James F. Berg, executive vice president of the Realty Advisory Board, observed that it takes 4.2 people to man a door 24 hours a day seven days a week. That's because there have to be three shifts a day, or 21 shifts a week. Four workers can cover 20 shifts in a week, working eight hours a day for five days. That level of manning costs the building $175,000 a year in wages and benefits.
Often there is a fulltime porter as well as a fulltime doorman. Some buildings may economize by combining the two tasks during night shifts or on weekends.
Management usually finds ways to reward long-time employees, says Mr. Berg, possibly with extra time off or bonuses. But practices vary widely. "One building might give a week's pay; another might give 10 weeks' pay," he said. "And another might say they're getting enough from tenants so we don't need to give them anything."
What doormen and other employees get from tenants as a Christmas gift also varies. Many tenants want no part of a uniform buildingwide policy, jealously guarding their prerogative to reward as they please. Doormen themselves are reticent. However, if a doorman were to get an average of $20 an apartment in a 200-unit building, he would take in $4,000 in Christmas tips, over 10 percent of his base pay.
But some co-ops and condominiums set up a buildingwide fund and a distribution system. Contributions are voluntary. One 300-unit co-op in Greenwich Village, with a staff of 25, suggests that each shareholder pay in $65 an apartment plus 20 cents a share to a single fund. That works out to about $145 for a two-bedroom apartment.
The co-op distributes the money by seniority. A doorman with 26 years of experience would get $2,400. The newest employee gets $296.
AT a 200-unit co-op on the Upper East Side the assessment is based on apartment type -- $105 for a studio; $165 for a one-bedroom, and $215 for a two-bedroom. Distribution to the staff of 14 is based on seniority. The highest bonus is $2,000; the lowest is $1,350.
A 500-unit East Side condominium tries to collect a flat $100 an apartment, or $50,000, to distribute among 28 employees, including four doormen. But since it is a fairly new building and the longest seniority is seven years, individual employees don't do as well as they do in older co-ops.
All three of these buildings are managed by Kreisel Company, which operates 175 co-ops and condominiums with 37,000 apartments, and has 2,500 employees. James O'Connor, Kreisel's director of management, estimated that about 85 percent of tenant-owners contribute to the buildingwide fund, but many of these also make individual contributions to employees who have given them special service during the year.
"Most buildings just send around a list of employees with their tenure," he said.
When that happens, money probably flows to the doorman of long standing more freely than to most other employees, with the exception of the superintendent and the concierge. Certainly Pierre Verlaet, the concierge at the new condominium at 160 West 66th Street, which is known also as 3 Lincoln Center, believes the opportunities are splendid for a doorman to ingratiate himself with tenants, and that converts to more generous gifts.
"A good doorman makes the best of a few seconds through the ego," he says. "It only takes that long to say a flattering thing, like 'You look gorgeous!' You create a relationship over 365 days."
The rewards shrivel in comparison with those a skillful hotel doorman can expect, however. With the right shift the hotel doorman can pull in as much as $100 a day, says Mr. Verlaet.
In any event, it is not tips or even the pay that keep Eddie Steakin on the job at 1088 Park Avenue. At 62, he works from 7 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday through Friday. Every morning he delivers the mail directly to the door of half the 90 tenants; the hallman handles the other half. It takes him two hours.
A dignified man in a handsome blue uniform, he is expert at one of his major early-morning tasks, hailing taxis speeding south on Park Avenue for residents headed for work. After that he delivers the mail directly to the doors of half the 90 tenants. The hallman handles the other half. The sorting and delivering job takes two hours.
"When I came here in the 50's Frank Harris was the doorman," Mr. Steakin said. "I walked off the street looking for a job and the super needed somebody for a couple of weeks. I wound up staying. Frank told me, 'Just keep smilin' whether you like 'em or you don't." '
Mr. Steakin is still smiling.
Nor is it tips that have kept Robert Hughes on the go for 22 years at 157 East 72d Street. He began as a porter and then worked the service elevator for 14 years. He has been "in the front" for seven years. The 140-unit condominium has a staff of 12, including the superintendent.
A graduate of Alexander Hamilton High School in Brooklyn, Mr. Hughes came down with pneumonia while he was working in the freezer room of the Fulton Fish Market years ago. A change in career was called for, and a friend working in the East 72d Street building got him a job there.
"I thought I was coming here for six months," he said. "I was going to get something else." Instead, he stayed.
"You get to be very friendly with people," Mr. Hughes said. "I know some people here all their lives, since they were 2-year-olds in diapers. I know everybody by name."
Too much standing is not a problem for him in the job. "We've got a stool," he noted.
Memories of job insecurity have helped many men of middle age to stay on the job. Almost to a man, doormen in their late 50's and 60's tell tales of job losses by themelves or young men they knew in the period when the economic boom that followed World War II was subsiding.
But the longer they stay, somehow, the more they seem to rely on the job for personal satisfaction.
"If you take this job away from me, you take away my whole life," said Dominick Franklin, a gracious 65-year-old from Deer Park, L.I., who mans the door at the elliptically shaped silver-glass rental building owned by the Solow Organization at 265 East 66th Street, at Third Avenue. "I love it."
He has been there only since 1979, when the building opened, but he was at 936 Fifth Avenue for 15 years before that. He is on his feet from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. five days a week, except for a half hour for lunch, and is an indefatigable dispenser of pleasantries to arriving or departing tenants. The building has 300 tenants, and in his pocket Mr. Franklin carries a list of their names.
Longterm tenants might tip $50 or $75 at Christmas time, Mr. Franklin says, but over-all tipping has declined in the last seven or eight years. "There used to be bigger tips because there was less transience," he said. Mr. Franklin and his wife have four grown children, including a daughter who is a lawyer and a son who is a physician. Both won scholarships to college.
Because of the size of the building and its staff, and the degree of activity at the door, Mr. Franklin's tasks are more limited than Rudy Martoni's at 174 East 74th Street. In that 120-unit co-op he doubles as concierge. He also keep an eye on a television screen that displays the action at the service entrance on Third Avenue. He screens out the suspicious while allowing in the authorized, a task that sounds simple and often is, but riles tenants quickly when there is an error.
"There are so many misunderstandings I blank them out," said Mr. Martoni. "It's ridiculous -- so petty."
THE experienced doorman takes no chances on security nowadays, so petty misunderstandings, when legitimate visitors are delayed, are to be expected. Burton Wallack, president of Wallack Management Company on East 64th Street, which manages 63 buildings in Manhattan, told of a trick that intruders were trying on Manhattan doormen last summer. Two or three well-dress men would surround the doorman to distract his attention while one tried to slip inside.
"We sent memos around," Mr. Wallack said. His doormen weren't fooled.
Mr. Wallack estimated that 25 to 30 percent of Manhattan doormen over the age of 50 are of Irish descent. "But right now it's a regular United Nations," he said.
Wallack itself took on 50 people last summer as porters or doormen. Many were of Hispanic or Yugoslav extraction. "Filipinos are beginning to come into the field," he said.
Occasionally, long-experienced doormen who are doubling on the concierge task in smaller buildings express dissatisfaction that the contract is so structured that they make no more money than a starting doorman. But most who have held on for years emphasize security and job satisfaction as their reasons for carrying on.
"I could retire anytime," said Mr. Steakin, at 1088 Park Avenue, who lives at 93d Street and York Avenue and walks to and from work every day. "But what would I do?"

HEADLINE: After a Decade of Decline, Homeownership Is Rising

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
REVERSING a decade-long decline, homeownership rates, a key indicator of the nation's economic health, have been rising modestly over the last year, according to the National Association of Home Builders.
Housing analysts attribute the increase to the decline of mortgage rates, which have fallen to 25-year lows, and to home prices, which are not rising as much as they did in the 80's in most parts of the country. They note, though, that homeownership rates, especially among people under 35, remain lower than in the early 1980's, evidence of unaffordable prices, stagnating wages, job insecurity and changing demographic trends. 
 The homeownership data track the percentage of housing units across the country whose occupants include the owner. Statistics are collected by the Census Bureau every 10 years and updated every three months through sample surveys of about 47,000 households nationally. The bureau's statistics are then bought by various organizations, including the NationalAssociation of Home Builders, which analyzes the data in semi-annual reports.
Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research for the National Association of Home Builders in Washington, said the recent trend upwards for homeownership was a sign that the econony remained weak but was improving.
"Economic growth is still at a sub-par level," he said.
Though they are not as publicized as much as short-term data like housing starts and sales, homeownership rates, many housing analysts believe, are important measures of the nation's overall economic health.
"If homeownership rates are declining it means we have a problem with affordability," Mr. Ahluwalia said. "If the percentage of people who live in their own homes is on the rise that obviously means our standard of living is going up."
As of June 30, the national homeownership rate was 64.4 percent, up from 63.9 percent a year earlier but down from 64.9 percent at the end of the second quarter in 1982 and 65.5 in the second quarter of 1980. There were 97.2 million households in the nation as of June 30th compared with 83.7 million at the end of 1982.
"If 1980 homeownership rates had maintained themselves, there would have been two million more homeowners by 1990," said William C. Apgar, the executive director of the Joint Center of Housing Studies of Harvard University.
Homeownership rates are rising the least among younger adults, those under 35. For that group the rate was 37.8 percent as of June 30, up from 37.6 percent in 1992 but down from 41.2 percent in 1982.
SOME housing anaysts believe the rates depict a growing division in homeownership between young and old.
"The gap in homeownership rates between young and old has widened, and there is nothing to suggest that it is going to diminish," said Peter A. Morrison, a demographer who has studied housing issues at the Rand Corporation, a research institute in Santa Monica, Calif.
Regionally, the Northeast was the only section where the homeownership rate rose in the 80's and early 90's; it grew to 62.5 percent in 1992 from 61.1 in 1982, but was still lower than in the South and the Midwest.
Mr. Ahluwalia said the rate had increased in the Northeast because nonhomeowners tend to be newcomers to an area and the Northeast has seen little inmigration in the last decade.
"The younger population, the ones most likely to be renters, are moving to other areas of the country, like the South and the West," he said. "So those areas are seeing a decrease in their homeownership rates."
Several factors influence homeownership rates.
"It's affordability," said David W. Berson, vice president and chief economist Fannie Mae -- the Federal National Mortgage Association -- a quasi-governmental agency that buys mortgages on the secondary market. "Buying a home hasn't been this affordable since the early 60's."
Mr. Berson also cited programs aimed at first-time buyers in their 20's and early 30's, low-income renters and minorities. The percentage of mortgages taken out by first-time home-buyers is currently at its highest level since 1979, he said.
"There have been increasing efforts to reach households that have been under-represented in the homeownership market," he said.
"WHAT we have been seeing in the last few years are the fruits of those efforts."
The rise in homeownership rates, which had been climbing steadily until the decline from 1980 to 1990, is projected to continue throughout the 90's, possibly to record levels by the year 2000. Economists cite not only increased affordability but also the aging of the baby boomers. Homeownership rates are highest among those 50 and older.
Some also believe that there is a pent-up demand among those in their 30's and 40's who have been priced or frightened out of the market and that this demand will be unleashed by an improving economy and lower interest rates.
"The percentage will continue to go up -- but slowly," Mr. Ahluwalia said. "We expect it to go up by the end of the decade to 67 or 68 percent and some people say maybe even 70 percent."
Demographers have attributed the decline in homeownership in the 80's and early 90's partly to the fact that Americans under 35 are more mobile and increasingly leaving home later, marrying later and forming smaller, less child-oriented households, all of which makes home-buying less imperative.
Economists, meanwhile, cite the run-up of home prices, sparked first by a period of high inflation in the 1970's and then, in the 1980's, by a surge in demand from an unprecedented number of Americans, the baby boomers.
The rise in home prices has made it hard for many younger Americans to afford a home. Saving enough for a down payment and closing costs is particularly difficult.
The fall in interest rates has helped make a home more affordable, as have the smaller rates of appreciation -- or in some places, the depreciation -- in home prices. Wages, however, have not caught up with the increases in housing prices of the 70's and 80's.
FURTHER, many lenders have increased downpayment requirements to 20 percent and tightened qualifying standards for mortgages. They no longer make no- or low-down-payment loans or no-income-verification loans and they are more conservative about how much money they will lend for a home.
Even for those younger people who have the funds and the financing and have found homes they can afford, the legacy of falling prices in the late 80's and early 90's, combined with the wave of corporate layoffs, has made increased wariness about buying.
Some fear that they will lose their jobs and not be able to afford their mortgage payments, or that they will have to relocate and won't be able to sell their homes or rent them for enough to cover their carrying costs.
Some also are unwilling to buy houses or live in neighborhoods that do not meet their expectations. Others believe that putting their down payments and the difference between a mortgage payment and rent into mutual funds or in tax-deferred I.R.A.'s and 401k plans is a better investment than a house whose value is appreciating slowly, if at all.
Indeed, some housing analysts believe that the popularity of these programs, along with the larger estates that many younger generations now stand to inherit, will make home equity a less important component of a retirement portfolio.
"It won't be the big retirement thing that it has been," said William A. Downs, a housing statistician with the Census Bureau.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in/Pelham;
Planned, Small and Close to the Big City

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
IN the late 80's, the Town of Pelham, in Westchester County, developed a reputation as a smart suburb for young professionals from Manhattan who were looking for a little more elbow room. National magazines began mentioning it, and an article in Esquire described it as ideal for "fleeing Manhattanites who want to stay near the center of the universe but don't want to fall off the face of the earth."
Nicholas Lemann, a national correspondent for Atlantic Monthly, who moved with his wife, Dominique, to Pelham from Manhattan seven years ago, fit that profile perfectly. 
 "We had been told these horror stories about life in the suburbs," Mr. Lemann said. "We thought it would be something like walking into the second act of a play."
Now he is a Pelham booster. "Maybe we missed something, but we love it here," he said. "It's a real community with a small-town feeling where everyone knows everyone else."
Actually, the term "Pelham" is often used to apply to both villages in the town -- Pelham and Pelham Manor -- which meld into little neighborhoods, all within walking distance of the downtown in the village of Pelham. It has several small shops, a movie theater and restaurants.
"Pelham is an excellent example of a planned community," said Susan Swanson, historian for the town and for Westchester County. "It was designed to resemble a small town where people could live comfortably and raise their families."
When Beatrice and Thomas Sos told their neighbors in California they were moving to New York "everyone said we weren't going to like it, that New Yorkers were unfriendly," Mrs. Sos said. "But we were surprised."
When the Soses settled in Pelham in June, neighbors stopped by with a cake and flowers. "That's never happened to us anywhere we lived before," Mrs. Sos said.
She and her husband, who is director of food and beverages at the new Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan, were also attracted by the short commute to midtown. "My husband drives in every day, and it takes 30 to 45 minutes door to door," she said.
One of the first things people notice in Pelham is the maturity of the architecture. Most houses were built in the 20's, when Tudors, colonials and Mediterranean style housing dominated. The houses "were meant to evoke an earlier time," Ms. Swanson said.
One current listing is $369,000 for a 10-room 1920's English stone house with a walled garden. At the higher end is a 14-room 1912 Mediterranean with a pool and a separate cottage, listed at $1.1 million.
It is also possible to get a house for under $200,000, said Marilyn M. Stiefvater, owner of Prudential Stiefvater Real Estate. "But those houses are usually fixer-uppers or not in a great location, such as a four-bedroom that recently sold for $155,000 because it was next to a gas station." Most houses in Pelham sell in the mid-$400,000's, she said.
There is also a wide variety of co-op apartments, many in converted Tudor apartment buildings downtown. They range in price from as low as $39,000 for a studio to $155,000 for a three-bedroom with a formal dining room, said Barbara McCann, a sales manager for Stiefvater Real Estate.
Since the surge of building in the 20's, Pelham has had little available land for development. During the Depression several large mansions had to be demolished because nobody could afford to keep them, Ms. Swanson said, and after World War II those lots were subdivided for ranch-style homes.
History has left several landmarks, however, including the 1843 Christ Church, whose window over the altar was the first figured stained glass made in the country. And the Romantic-style Priory, built in 1838 and formerly a girls' school, is on the National Register of Historic Places.
Pelham, the oldest town in Westchester County, dates to 1654, when Thomas Pell, an English aristocrat, bought 9,160 acres from the Siwanoy Indians. He established a manor that stretched from the Bronx through Pelham all the way to Mamaroneck on Long Island Sound. In 1689, his son, Sir John Pell, sold 6,000 acres to the French Huguenots. This later became the City of New Rochelle.
At the turn of the century, New York City annexed 1,800 acres, essentially claiming what remained of Pelham's shoreline. Now the town's waterfront is less than a mile long, most of it occupied by the six-acre Manor Park, owned by the Village of Pelham Manor, and the 15-acre summer headquarters of the New York Athletic Club.
The Town of Pelham comprises two villages, Pelham and Pelham Manor, each with its own government and fire and police department.
"One day the two villages will merge," said Joseph E. Durnin, Mayor of Pelham. "It's only a matter of time because the economics of it will force that to happen."
After little development for most of the 80's, construction is about to start on two projects, one for people with moderate to middle incomes, the other for upper-income buyers.
Pelham Commons, a 130-unit apartment house that will rise in the Village of Pelham, will give priority first to village employees, village residents over the age of 55, then, in order, village residents, town residents and county residents. Prices will range from $119,987 to $220,603, with no down payment required.
The project is jointly sponsored by the Village of Pelham and the National Development Council, a nonprofit corporation that develops affordable housing nationwide. The agency is providing mortgages to the buyers and $23 million in development money through the sale of bonds.
Prospective buyers must have annual household income between $61,500 and $104,790, depending on family size.
The other development, Pelham Esplanade, 10-unit town-house project, is for "empty nesters," said Harlan W. Thayer, president of Pelham Esplanade of Armonk, the developer. "It's for people who want to stay in Pelham Manor but don't want to be responsible for a larger, older home," he said.
There will be a total of five buildings, each with two town houses. Units will range from 3,050 to 3,295 square feet and be priced in the $500,000's, Mr. Harlan said. Construction is expected to begin in the spring and be completed by fall.
In recent years, space has been at such a premium in Pelham that the only library was in a cramped 1,500-square-foot space in an elementary school. That will change when the 1927 Christian Science Reading Room is converted into a 6,000-square-foot community library with 25,000 volumes, said Victor Henningsen, co-chairman of the Friends of the Town of Pelham Public Library. The group has raised $1.2 million but will need $1.8 million, Mr. Henningsen said.
"It will not only be a first-rate community library," he said, "but a central meeting place for the town."
For parents in Pelham, the unifying element is often the schools.
"Sometimes I think the town is divided into little individual communities around the four elementary schools," said Dudley Hare Jr., superintendent of schools. In addition to the four k-5 schools, there is a building housing a middle school and high school.
CLASSES in k-5 schools have 17 or 18 students, Mr. Hare said, and the schools are sited so that almost all students can walk to school.
"It fosters a sense of neighborhood and community and close personal relationships," he said.
There is a district-wide technology program in which students from kindergarten through grade 12 can use computers and CD-ROM equipment to "incorporate into their academic work," Mr. Hare said. "We have the National Earthquake Center on line," he added, "so our science students can monitor earthquake activity around the world."
This year, Pelham Memorial High School was named one of the best schools in the nation by the Federal Department of Education. It offers advanced placement courses in calculus and biology and three foreign languages, French, Spanish and Latin. In, physical activity is also encouraged.
"About 70 percent of our students participate in at least one varsity or scholastic sport," Mr. Hare said.
The town has one Roman Catholic parochial school, the k-8 Our Lady of Perpetual Help.
Since there are few public parks, town residents use school facilities for recreation. The town runs a basketball program for adults at the high school and four tennis courts at Grover Field are open to the public. There are also two tennis courts at the town's Sixth Street Park. In addition, Pelham has the Pelham Country Club and the New York Athletic Club.
While some convenience and supermarket shopping is available downtown, most residents travel 15 to 20 minutes to shopping centers in either White Plains or Scarsdale for more extensive shopping.
Popular restaurants include Funiculi Funicula, for Italian cuisine, and Viva Zapata for Mexican food.
"I was a bit spoiled when I lived in Manhattan," said Beatrice Sos. "I could just stop by anywhere and get an espresso or anything I wanted. Here, your basic needs are covered but it's nice to know you have Manhattan so close by when you want more."

HEADLINE: Seton Hall Shoots For Higher Goals

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE

 BODY:
THINK of Seton Hall University and most people think of five students dribbling a basketball down a hardwood floor.
But after a 10-year effort to upgrade the university's buildings and athletic teams, Seton Hall officials say they are ready to go head-to-head with their competition on a more cerebral level. 
 "We've gone through a building renaissance of sorts," said the Reverend Thomas R. Peterson, president and chancellor of Seton Hall. "What we're going through now is a kind of academic renaissance, in which not only the building continues but there is great stress placed on the academic life of the university."
Recently, times have been good for Seton Hall, one of the larger Roman Catholic universities in the country and the only one in New Jersey. Enrollment is increasing in the face of withering demographics, the campus sparkles with new buildings, money is pouring in and optimism about the future abounds.
"Seton Hall is on a roll," said Craig Leach, vice chancellor for university affairs, who is directing a $100 million capital campaign, the largest in the university's history. "The list of universities we compare ourselves to becomes better and better with each passing year. We think we can compete with the great Catholic universities in the region like Fairfield and Villanova."
While not everyone is convinced that Seton Hall will ever match Villanova or Georgetown, there is widespread agreement that, given its focus on providing a pre-professional education and location near the most impoverished city in the country, Seton Hall has established itself as a particularly solid institution at a time when many colleges of its kind are struggling.
The 137-year-old university, operated under the auspices of the Archdiocese of Newark, was until recently largely a commuter school with little visibility outside the state. That was before the basketball team threw Seton Hall into the spotlight in 1989 by making it to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four, losing to the University of Michigan by one point in overtime.
While not denying the importance of that near-win in boosting the school's morale and reputation, university officials say it is the quality of education Seton Hall delivers that will ultimately determine the school's fate.
A key part of Seton Hall's effort to upgrade its academics is a plan to introduce a core curriculum throughout the university, exposing students enrolled in specialized programs like nursing, education and business to more of the liberal arts.
"It's an attempt to bring about a balance in a person who is graduating," said Father Peterson, who led a similar effort as president of Providence College. "If someone graduates from the School of Business and knows nothing about history or literature, music and art, then that person really would not be what we hope our students would be at the time of their commencement."
 
Defining Specific Goals
 The university is also in the process of defining specific educational goals and assessment procedures for each of its 83 programs. A history major, for example, might have to demonstrate an understanding of changes in perspective within historical literature and how history is written as well as a command of historical fact.
"People on the outside assume that most colleges have something like this, but that's not necessarily true," said Bernhard Scholz, provost of the university. "We want to say exactly what kind of goals we are aiming for."
The move to upgrade academic programs began in earnest in the mid-1980's, when the university overhauled its business school. A center for teaching was founded in 1987 to improve the teaching skills of the university's faculty, and a freshmen studies program was introduced the same year that has gone on to receive national recognition.
The 1980's also saw the start of a building boom that continues today. A $15 million sports center was completed in 1987, a new $25 million law school building opened last year in Newark, a $20 million library opens this spring, and construction begins on another academic building this summer.
And, most important for a school trying to broaden its reputation, several dormitories have been added, doubling the number of residential students the university can accommodate. Today, nearly half of Seton Hall's 4,400 full-time undergraduates live on campus.
 
Struggles in the 70's
 The glistening new structures make Seton Hall's economic struggles of the late 1970's seem like a long time ago, when to reduce a $7 million deficit, the university tried lowering admisssions standards and opening its doors. The debt was finally erased through better management and a series of tuition increases, and the school has had a balanced budget for more than a decade.
Financially, the university has outperformed even its own ambitious plans. A five-year $100 million capital campaign, the largest collegiate campaign under way in New Jersey, will conclude in 1994, a year ahead of schedule.
The success of the basketball team has, of course, added to the overall picture of financial health. Attendance at the team's Meadowlands games has risen from an average 3,500 people a game during the 1985-86 season to 15,000 last year, making the Pirates the second leading team in both average and total attendance in the Big East Conference, trailing only Syracuse.
The principal advantage of Seton Hall's 1989 near-win, as far as administrators are concerned, was that it has allowed the university to maintain its applicant pool at a time when the number of high school graduates has been plummeting and high tuitions at private institutions have been driving many students to public colleges.
At $11,380 a year for tuition, Seton Hall falls in the mid-range of cost for an independent New Jersey college, but it is still substantially more expensive than the average $2,310 tuition at New Jersey's eight four-year public colleges or $3,433 for Rutgers.
 
10,358 Enrollment
 With a total enrollment this fall of 10,358 students, its highest level since 1981, Seton Hall is soon expected to surpass Fairleigh Dickinson University as the state's largest independent institution.
An increasing number of undergraduates are being drawn from the top third of their high school class, though test scores on the Scholastic Assessment Test have not fared quite so well. After rising nearly 70 points between 1983 and 1989, scores for incoming freshmen have been inching downward for the last four years. School officials refuse to release mean scores, saying only that most students fall within a range of range of 840 to 1,100 for a combined math and verbal score.
Patricia Burgh, dean for enrollment services, admissions and financial aid, said the university was aiming for average S.A.T. scores of at least 1,000, but that it would not back away from a commitment to diversity to achieve that goal. In the last decade, minority enrollment at the school has doubled, constituting more than one-quarter of this year's freshmen class.
"It's not a racist statement, but the fact is that test scores have been lower for minorities," she said. "So while we aspire to reach that 1,000 average, we also would not do that to the detriment of admitting qualified students that may not be testing well."
If there has been a slight decline in the standardized test scores of students, faculty don't see it as a dilution of quality, particularly in light of earlier gains.
 
Improvements in Decade
 "As a general rule, the students over the past decade have improved, as have the faculty," said Robert Shapiro, chairman of the faculty senate and an associate professor of accounting and taxation. "Students who 10 years ago didn't know Seton Hall existed are now here from other parts of the country."
Relations between the faculty and administration have improved a great deal since the faculty unsuccessfully tried to organize a union in 1981. Some of the good will stems from a newly instituted faculty senate, but rising salaries may have had even more of an impact. With an average teacher salary of $55,536, Seton Hall has jumped from seventh place in 1985 to first in faculty compensation in a comparison with eight other Catholic institutions in the area, including Fairfield and Villanova.
Despite the generally upbeat mood on campus, Seton Hall has not escaped the tension that has arisen on many Catholic universities when students espouse positions that are at odds with official church teachings. In 1991 there were protests when university officials barred Leonard Jeffries, the controversial City College of New York professor, from speaking. Then last year administrators refused to sanction a gay student organization.
 
Issues Still Remain
 While much of Seton Hall's predominantly middle-class, conservative student body seemed happy to let the issue die, it touched a nerve in others.
"At this university and at all Catholic universities, the administration and students have to grapple with the issues of are we Catholic first or a university first," said Maria Perotin, editor of the school newspaper, The Setonian. "It's very safe to say Father Peterson is 200 percent Catholic first. It's also safe to say the way he has handled the issues has alienated a number of students."
Father Peterson doesn't accept such a dichotomy.
"I see no contradiction in those two things," he said. "As a university one must assemble a strong faculty and academic freedom, but we certainly would expect that people who come here would not do something that is contrary to the commitment of the church."

HEADLINE: ART;
Bringing Out the Works of So-Called 'Outsiders'

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
SINCE a halfway adequate review of "Dream Singers, Storytellers: An African-American Presence" would be as long as the show's 238-page catalogue, this can be no more than a notification. To begin with the nuts and bolts: the spectacle celebrating the "sister-state" agreement between New Jersey and the Fukui prefecture in Japan is now on view here, at the State Museum, where it was organized by the assistant curator, Alison Weld. Its debut, however, took place last year in Japan -- hence the bilingual catalogue.
As explained in the foreward, the project seeks to reconcile differences between the two countries, on the assumption that art is a universal language. Be that as it may, viewers in a homogeneous culture like Japan's may have had trouble grasping the nuances of an African tradition modified by three centuries of subjugation and one of relative freedom. 
 Without slavery, would there have been a Bill Traylor, suddenly producing at an advanced age images reminiscent of cave drawings? Would the sculptor, Mel Edwards, have been inspired to devote 30 years to welding his series, "Lynch Fragments," while also making monumental sculpture in the David Smith tradition? Finally, can a show be called representative that is heavy with folk artists (more than half the 33 participants are self-taught, including four quilt makers) but that excludes Richard Hunt, Martin Puryear (admittedly at his own request), Betye Saar and many other major figures?
The first two questions are unanswerable, the third one, too -- but only after a glance at the catalogue. In an essay that discusses every artist, Ms. Weld contends that distinctions made between folk art and the mainstream kind are "artificial." She also states that the differences are "merely a question of particular life situations and discernible motivations," thus demolishing the barrier between amateur and professional.
Whether or not one accepts Ms. Weld's proposition, three anthropomorphized tree stumps by Bessie Harvey and three more by a kindred spirit, Ralph Griffin, are enough already. The same goes for the eight junk assemblages of Hawkins Bolden, who is blind, and the 14 little bundles of metal and plastic objects compulsively trussed up by the Philadelphia Wireman, who is presumed to have been black because his work was discovered in a black neighborhood.
While Traylor has no more devoted a fan, this observer sympathizes with black professionals who wince slightly at the overly enthusiastic mention of his name and those of other black "outsiders." Could it be that, in the art public's uninhibited embrace of his "unspoiled" talent, they suspect a fondness for noble savages and their natural sense of rhythm?
To make matters more complicated, James Smalls takes issue in his essay with those who would know "precisely" what makes the art African-American. He feels that the question smacks of the "division between us and them" that has caused so much trouble in the world.
Notwithstanding the title identifying the art as African-American, Mr. Smalls, an assistant professor at Rutgers University, insists that it is not about us and them but rather about "cultural continuities and understanding." Admirable as such sentiments are, they make "outsiders" of the professionals who have achieved fame in the real world but who are mixed in with the self-taught under headings seemingly designed to promote political equality. Thus, recent assemblages by Mr. Edwards, which are, by the way, larger and less clenched than their predecessors, fall into the "Poetics of Accumulation" category, along with the Wireman's assemblages and those by Lonnie Holley, another autodidact.
The logic of this grouping can be understood if not necessarily applauded. But what to make of William T. Williams's inclusion in the party? His patchworks of alligatored paint on canvas could symbolize the accumulation of years, especially in slum dwelling decor. But in appearance, they seem closer to the quilts, which fall under the heading, "The Constructed Image."
This pattern of incongruity continues with "The Poetics of Economy." On the one hand, the category includes William Edmondson's chunky stone figures and, on the other hand, the sleek, pigmented forms carved in wood by Tyrone Mitchell and the paintings by Norman Lewis of which the sparest and loveliest are two irregular Cubistic grids smudged in orange and brown on white paper.
Ms. Weld appears to have joined the school of thought that would discourage all notions of aristocracy in art, would in fact divert the viewer from esthetic values altogether. Considering her record both as a curator at the museum and as the former director of Rutgers' Robeson Gallery in Newark, this is a crying shame. In any case, most of the professionals in the show resist her efforts, willy-nilly. They include Benny Andrews, Willy Cole, John L. Moore, Joe Overstreet, who is currently showing some massive new abstractions at Kankeleba House, in Manhattan, Jacob Lawrence and Faith Ringgold.
Nevertheless and despite its implied contentiousness, "Dream Singers" is a visually handsome and spiritually heroic statement that is guaranteed to ignite discussion long after it closes next year, on March 20. The museum is at 205 West State Street; hours are 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M., Tuesday through Saturday; noon to 5 Sundays.

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Jay Romano

 BODY:
IN one of my earliest memories I'm standing with my mother at the window of an apartment in Hoboken looking west and up the palisades at Union City.
My mother points toward the crest of the steep rise and says that soon we will be moving from our Hoboken apartment to a house of our own on the hill.
"Why?" I ask. 
 "Because if the Hudson River ever overflows," she answers, "we'll be up there and won't get wet."
The real reason we were moving, of course, wasn't fear that river was about to breach its banks; it was because our young family was moving up in the world. Forty years ago, upward mobility for a second-generation immigrant family from Hoboken was a move "up the viaduct" to Union City. The next step, if my father worked enough overtime, would be a move from "the city," which included nearly all of Hudson County, to "the suburbs," which meant just about anywhere west of Union City.
Thousands of families made similar journeys, eventually settling in houses with yards and driveways and detached garages, often in Bergen County.
Some stayed behind, though, and toughed-out life in the city. And over the intervening 40 years, those who remained have watched their property values -- and their pride in their towns -- rise and fall and rise again as Hoboken, Jersey City, Union City, West New York, Weehawken, Guttenberg and North Bergen continued to serve as they had served for more than a century: as stepping-stones for succeeding waves of immigrants a little too timid to tackle New York City and a little too poor to even think of life in the suburbs.
Over the last decade or so, however, "the Gold Coast," as it is now called, has undergone a significant change. Instead of being a way station on the road to the American Dream, the area has now become a destination in itself.
"It's a wonderful place," said Theresa Burns, 33 years old, of her adopted hometown, Hoboken. "If you don't mind being surrounded by people all the time."
Mrs. Burns and her husband have two young children. Five years ago, the couple moved from Jersey City to Hoboken to start their family.
"I'd like my kids to be raised here," Mrs. Burns said, holding one child semistationary on her hip while watching the other play on on the swings in Church Square Park.
Forty years ago, a family moving out of Jersey City would typically move to Lyndhurst or North Arlington or Rutherford.
So why Hoboken?
"It's hard to put a finger on it," Mrs. Burns said. "I guess it has a small-town feel with all the advantages of the big city."
In the past, people settled in the densely populated cities and towns of northern Hudson County because rents were low and houses were relatively inexpensive. Now, the opposite is true. A town house or a condominium in Hoboken, Weehawken, North Bergen and parts of Jersey City can command prices that 10 years ago would have inspired investor nirvana. And rents are comparable to some parts of New York City.
For people who live in the most densely populated county of the most densely populated state in the country, amenities like garages and trees take on great significance.
"I spent about $35,000 fixing up the house," said Mercedes Babot, 37, referring to renovations she made to her two-family house in Union City. The first item on the agenda, she said, was excavating several tons of dirt from the front yard and busting through the foundation wall to make a driveway and garage.
"Parking is a horror here," she said.
Ms. Babot, who came to this country from Cuba as a child and who is now manager of electronic graphics for Capital Cities/ABC in New York, originally had other plans.
"Like every other upstanding citizen, I had intended to buy a house somewhere else," she said. "I looked and looked and looked and then I said to myself, 'If Union City was good enough for me to grow up in, then what's wrong with staying here?"'
Indeed, the towns in the northern half of Hudson County -- along with parts of Jersey City -- offer an attractive alternative for those who want a cosmopolitan way of life but disdain the prospect of taxi horns blaring and police sirens screaming at 3 o'clock in the morning.
All of the towns have a lively mix of ethnic groups. The Italian, German and Irish immigrants of the late 1900's have been supplanted by Cubans, Puerto Ricans, Indians and Asians. Just a 15 minute commute to midtown Manhattan, the area is also a lure for thousands of young professionals who want to be within striking distance of New York City but not so close that their jobs follow them home.
Greengrocers, coffee shops, ethnic restaurants, newsstands and health-food stores line the main streets and cater to wants and needs that range from the mundane to the eclectic. The proprietors of many neighborhood shops often know their customers by their first names.
And though there are more than 150,000 residents living in Hoboken, Union City, Weehawken and North Bergen alone, the words one hears most when residents are asked to describe their neighborhoods are "small town" and "community."
"We looked in Queens and we looked in Brooklyn, and then we realized that no one would come to visit us there," said Laura Quisenberry, 32, who was driving through the streets of Weehawken with her husband, Brian Felton, 34, looking for houses for sale.
Mr. Felton, who is from Ramsey, said that Bergen County was "too suburban" for his tastes. Ms. Quisenberry, the artistic director of the Waterfront Ensemble, a professional theater group in Hoboken, said that she couldn't possibly live in a place "where everybody's the same."
"People of diverse ethnic backgrounds seem to add to the community," she said.
There is something about Hoboken and the other Gold Coast towns that make them special. Lifelong residents shrug their shoulders, shake their heads and smile when asked why they stay. Often, their answer is: "Where else would I go?"
Dr. Nino Falcone, a professor at Jersey City State College and the municipal judge in North Bergen, often calls North Bergen "the center of the universe" when addressing those who appear in his court.
"We're 15 minutes away from the greatest metropolitan area in the world," Dr. Falcone said. "Yet North Bergen has that small-town charm."
Dr. Falcone, who was born and raised in the town, said that despite the changes he has seen, there is nowhere else he would rather live.
"I've been around the world twice," he said. "I've been to the White House four times. But every time I get back to North Bergen, and walk along Boulevard East, and look at that marvelous New York skyline, then I know I'm home."

LENGTH: 272 words

HEADLINE: Libraries Are Used More in Recession

 BODY:
It's too bad that the committee that was set up by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to investigate fees for use of the public library chose to solve the problem by seeking private funds ["Libraries Urged to Lobby for Funds," Oct. 24]. Public library operations should be supported by public funds. That's what will keep a library public!
Each public library in Westchester is having monetary problems and to suggest that private industry (which is having its own problems) will freely give money to the public libraries with no strings attached seems rather naive. I was offended by the elitist statements attributed to Dr. Sal J. Prezioso, who suggests merging the public libraries. 
 Who will choose where the libraries will be located and who will provide free transportation to those sites so that the concept of a free library within the means of all citizens is available?
Unfortunately, we are living at a time when the spiraling costs of day-to-day living make politicians feel that money has to be spent on items not necessarily concerned with expanding education and the quality of life.
Somehow, we have to make our electees aware of the fact that public libraries are used more when the economy is down and are more important than keeping a baseball team in New York or building or increasing spending on roads or buildings.
The public library serves as a source of education and growth for all citizens at all ages of their lives.
 
MIRIAM K. MARGOSHES
Tarrytown
 
The writer is a member of the Warner Library Board in Tarrytown and a former member of the Westchester Library System Board.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2001 words

HEADLINE: To Asia With Hope: Opportunity Lures A U.S. Executive

 BODY:
At a time when Asia is enjoying an economic revolution, executives from Sun Microsystems Inc., the $4.3 billion-in-sales maker of computer systems, visited eight countries there during two hectic weeks earlier this month. They were led by the chairman and chief executive of Sun, Scott McNealy, 39. Mr. McNealy, who received a degree in economics from Harvard and an M.B.A. from Stanford, co-founded Sun in 1982. Mr. McNealy's impressions, recorded in a diary he kept during the trip and later agreed to release for publication, offer a sense of the opportunity that so many American businesses see in Asia -- and of how much American businessmen still have to learn about Asian economies and cultures.
Here are excerpts from the diary:
 
Jakarta, Indonesia, Oct. 30
 The next two weeks will take us through Jakarta, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Bangkok, Hong Kong, Beijing, Shanghai, Taipei and Seoul. We see a mutual opportunity here: to learn from their efforts as well as to share our technology, which will open markets for our company and their countries.
The developed world is tied to outdated technology and keeps investing in it because they must make it pay off. For example, while many companies in the United States understand why network computing -- distributing the workload among many computers rather than relying on just one central one -- makes the process quicker and less vulnerable to logjams and breakdowns, the fact is, they've got this heavy investment in old proprietary systems. Countries out here, however, can start fresh.
 
En Route to Singapore, Nov. 1
 We decided to wear a "uniform" on this tour to give it a sense of continuity and teamwork. For the Jakarta visit, we donned colorful Indonesian batik shirts. But otherwise we're all wearing white polo shirts with Sun's logo on the sleeves and khaki slacks. Somebody told us at breakfast that we look like a soccer team. I had wanted to go in blue jeans and T-shirts, my standard work clothes at Sun (that's what I wear to board meetings). But the sales staff said these cultures would find that offensive. They wanted me to wear a suit. So we compromised.
A group of us this morning paid a visit to a Dr. Bacharuddin Jusuf Habibie, an important Indonesian Government minister who oversees something like 12 industries. We met in his office, which is more like a museum for model planes, hundreds of them. I eased into my pitch: how Sun can help Indonesia modernize its infrastructure. We provide enabling technology.
Dr. Habibie, in his mid-50's, is an energetic Renaissance man who knows and understands technology from aerospace to computers, including Sun's. His engineers use them. But he doesn't believe a network of computers can be made secure. I made note of the fact that the United States intelligence community is a big Sun customer and well known for meeting strict security requirements. Dr. Habibie didn't care. Why should he? He believes the way to security is to load his files on his Macintosh Quadra at home and have his driver hand-deliver the floppy. Most of us in the room were trying to envision any business in the United States being profitable using couriers to deliver floppies.
It looked like an impasse. Then a member of my team suggested that rather than discuss our differences on network security, we show Dr. Habibie and his engineers what our technology can do. We suggested a seminar with demonstrations from key scientists and engineers at Sun. Dr. Habibie loved the idea.
 
Singapore, Nov. 2
 This is a remarkable island-city-nation that the United States could learn a thing or two from. In a meeting this morning with the National Computer Board, we were briefed on Singapore's plan to build an information highway. They are light years ahead of the United States on this endeavor, and remarkably more organized. Of course, it's easier to do in an island nation of 2.5 million, as opposed to 250 million. But this may be the first real "test bed" of that technology. The model they're using is very close to our philosophy of distributed computing with an architecture that is not proprietary but instead open to all who might want to innovate.
This is an English-speaking country, but some analogies just don't translate. I like to describe the "master-slave" mainframe computing model as a "hairball" -- a massively complex web. An American colleague suggested "bowl of noodles."
We got started on politics at lunch. I've never been one to hold back what's on my mind, and these people seem to find it amusing. The brash American, somebody said. The Asians are more reserved. We put our cards on the table, but we don't always know what they're thinking. This puts us at a disadvantage in dealings.
After less than 24 hours in Singapore, I'm more of a capitalist than ever. Low taxes, no capital-gains tax, no unemployment, mandatory savings instead of Social Security. What's right with this picture?
 
Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Nov. 2
 A very positive meeting this morning with the Malaysian Institute of Microelectronic Systems. This Government-sponsored research and development group was started in 1985 to help drive Malaysia to a position as a worldwide player in the microelectronics industry. The most hopeful aspect of the meeting is that they understand and endorse open-computing systems.
 
Bangkok, Thailand, Nov. 2
 The ride in from the airport was amazing. They're working feverishly to build new freeways but they're not keeping up. Traffic jams are the worst I've ever seen. I don't think I've ever seen so much construction in one place. Kuala Lumpur is a close second. These countries intend to be serious players in the world economy. If anything holds them back, it will be this traffic.
 
Bangkok, Nov. 4
 Lunch with customers today was very tough. Definite language problem. Even with an interpreter. The jokes just don't translate.
 
Hong Kong, Nov. 7
 I try to get a little work done on the plane. But I always have a difficult time reading and writing on the road. At home, the minute I get on the elevator something switches in my brain and I'm mentally at work. Out here, the switch doesn't seem to click. I am better connected than in the past, however. Now, I'm at least able to log on to my computer at work with a portable (an H.-P. Omnibook). I check the 150 to 200 electronic mail messages I get each day, so I'm able to keep up with the office chatter and memoranda. Of course, my managers hate it because it means they can never get away from me now.
People ask me what's the most "mission critical" application at Sun. I usually answer e-mail. For a global company, e-mail is the one sure method of communication. We have 12,500 employees doing a million e-mails a day. We have a saying at Sun that the network is the computer. I'm advising Government officials out here that the next computers they buy should be ones that communicate with other computers, not just process information. Also, get on the Internet.
 
Beijing, China, Nov. 7
 Everything is dull brown and gray, like going from Oz back to Kansas. But the economic growth rate here is 12.8 percent, and there is no sign of abatement. Yet based on my extended meetings with officials here, it's hard to gauge where China is going. They seem to be advocating free enterprise, yet talk about controlling growth and a return to Communist values.
 
Beijing, Nov. 8
 Just finished a walk before breakfast. About 100 yards from the hotel is a river that serves as an open sewer, a garbage dump and a place to bathe. Capitalism is often criticized for seeking profits at the expense of the environment. Here's all the proof anyone would need that a centralized, socialist government is not the answer.
I'm excited because the Chinese appreciate the value of our computing model. But I'm concerned because some companies are still trying to push yesterday's technology and these countries are, too often, taking that advice. The Bank of China met with us today and told us they understand the value of open-systems network computing. But the Federal Reserve Bank in the United States is advising the bank to buy mainframes. I tried to explain that the Fed is espousing the technology it knows and understands, purely for traditional reasons. When one mainframe goes down, it's a big problem. With 500 servers, when one goes down, it's one-500th of a problem. This is the sort of advice we can transfer to these areas. In exchange, they can help us by converting our software applications into their own tongue, growing the market for Sun and partners.
 
Shanghai, China, Nov. 9
 Opened the curtains to my hotel room to check the view. And there was a huge banner across the street, "Hewlett-Packard No. 1 in Unix." Ugh. Guess we've got some work to do getting the message out around this town. Shanghai and Beijing are the consummate study in contrasts between Communism and capitalism, all in one country. Beijing, a centrally planned, centrally run economy, can feel lifeless, dormant. Shanghai is alive with energy. There are shops springing up on every corner. Skyscrapers are going up. The mayor explained today about the city's plan for developing a whole separate city called Pudong, which will be a free-enterprise zone.
 
Taipei, Taiwan, Nov. 10
 Gen. Kuo Yun, the vice chairman and president of the Institute for Information Industry, joked that R.O.C. stands for Republic of Computers, not Republic of China. Little wonder, since 80 percent of PC's worldwide are made here. Still, those are PC's cranking out proprietary operating systems.
General Kuo's principal job is to oversee a strategy for the computerization of government and private industries. I'm trying to imagine the United States being that farsighted. The United States, meanwhile, is caught up in the possibility of bringing movies on demand into the home rather than developing a fiber-optic-based information highway to help businesses be more competitive. With priorities like that, it's not difficult to see who is going to get ahead in the information-based economy of the future.
The general introduced me in English for a speech I gave (with an interpreter). I learned that this was the first time he had spoken English in public, which is very unusual, and should be considered an honor to me. It's little things like this that you need to pick up on when doing business here. Fortunately for us, we rely heavily on partners for business in many of these countries, and they understand the customs and culture.
 
Seoul, South Korea, Nov. 11
 The last leg on the trip. One question that comes up often is when Sun will open a manufacturing plant in South Korea. I try to explain that our business model does not include looking for new sites for low-cost labor. For some reason, it seems to carry more weight in the press to open a plant and employ low-wage workers than it does to forge partnerships with local companies that involve transferring knowledge to them.
 
En Route to San Francisco, Nov. 12
 Prepared for serious jet lag: 348 hours on the road, 45 in flight, about 12 in immigration and baggage-claim lines, 18 in cars, 140 in presentations, press interviews and meetings. That left 84 hours for sleep, 30 or so for checking into hotels, packing and unpacking and catching up on e-mail and phone calls. I think that left us a grand total of 18 or 19 hours of free time. Forty-five speeches given, 500 or so business cards collected, 1,600 business and government leaders and partners who heard our message and delivered their messages to us.
Was it worth the expense, the time, the effort? I think so. American companies usually approach emerging markets as a chance to sell a lot or to pay low wages for menial labor. Yet the intellectual capital available in Asia is tremendous. American companies that realize this and figure out how to become partners with these countries will be successful in the 90's and beyond.
