HEADLINE: From Sibling Rivalry to Civil War

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
FREDERIC V. SALERNO, vice chairman of the Nynex Corporation, has spent the last 18 months gearing up for the fight of his career. Shuttling between his office in White Plains and his investment bankers at Morgan Stanley, he has been poring over maps, studying demographics and using computer models to size up the competition in Nynex's New York and New England markets.
His conclusions have been sobering. 
 "If we do nothing, we can expect an erosion in our residential telephone market share of 40 percent over the next decade," he said. That translates to a loss of $1.6 billion in annual revenue. Alternatively, if Nynex spends billions a year on fiber optics and video technology, it will lose "only" 10 percent of the telephone market but may make back the difference in cable television.
Who could possibly grab more than $1 billion in annual sales from one of the seven regional Bell companies? Answer: another Bell company, or several of them, in league with cable television operators.
In Manhattan and Queens, U S West of Englewood, Colo., has hooked up with Time Warner to upgrade cable TV lines for telephones and a host of futuristic services. To the east, on Long Island, U S West and Southwestern Bell of San Antonio are vying to buy the Cablevision Systems Corporation, which serves about two million customers in Nynex's market. Finally, Bell Atlantic of Philadelphia is buying Tele-Communications Inc., the country's biggest cable company, which has systems sprinkled across New York and Massachusetts.
Ten years after the breakup of the old Bell System, the seven "Baby Bells" are rapidly dividing into hunters and prey. Led by Bell Atlantic and U S West, the hunters are using their alliances with cable television systems to raid their siblings' territories. While most publicity about the recent mergers has focused on the offering of futuristic services, it is the huge $100 billion market for basic phone service that is most ripe for plundering.
As a result, industry analysts say, many local telephone companies are in for a competitive shock that could rival what the American Telephone and Telegraph Company endured in the long-distance market a decade ago. Indeed, Mr. Salerno's worst-case scenario for Nynex closely matches A.T.& T.'s loss of market share -- from nearly 100 percent in the late 1970's to just over 60 percent today.
 
Goliath vs. Goliath
 For the Baby Bells, "the world is evolving into one divided between the haves and the have-nots," said Daniel P. Reingold, a communications analyst at Merrill Lynch. "It is now crystal clear that the haves are going to be attacking the have-nots, and that investors will have to value these two types of companies very differently."
The transformation of a sibling rivalry into outright warfare pitting Goliath against Goliath has profound implications not just for the Baby Bells, but for consumers as well.
Within five years, consumers in big cities may have a choice between two companies offering local telephone service, and the competition may lead to better prices and enhanced features. But it is also possible that residents in relatively unprofitable inner city markets or rural areas could see their service get worse, as telephone companies devote money and people to shoring up their most profitable lines of business with corporations and affluent residential customers.
The risks for the Baby Bells are enormous. Those that are uncertain of their strategy or that don't line up big cable partners -- notably Nynex, Ameritech Inc. of Chicago and the Pacific Telesis Group in San Francisco -- risk becoming second-tier players with a shrinking revenue base or even disappearing as independent companies. But such aggressive players as Bell Atlantic and U S West are taking chances too, by spending billions on cable companies and on constructing new kinds of networks that may not click with consumers.
"Until we've got some certainty or some reasonable feel for demand, we're not going to go overboard deploying technology," said Robert T. Burns, head of strategic planning at the BellSouth Corporation in Atlanta. BellSouth has been concentrating less on cable deals and more on wireless services, as well as on modernizing its network for traditional phone service to business customers.
For now, at least, Wall Street is rewarding the aggressive companies with higher stock prices. Bell Atlantic stock is up 15.4 percent this year, closing Friday at $59.125. U S West has jumped 20.9 percent, to $46.375. In contrast, Nynex climbed just 2.2 percent, to $42.875.
And those telephone company executives who have been waiting to make a big move in cable may find it is getting to be too late.
Because the cable industry is dominated by a handful of big companies, just a few strategically significant players remain up for grabs. These include Cablevision Systems; Boston-based Continental Cablevision, with 2.9 million subscribers; and Cox Cable, owned by Cox Enterprises of Atlanta, with 1.5 million subscribers.
 
Other Permutations
 Some analysts caution that there is still time and room for other types of alliances and other kinds of strategies, which could change the equation of power. It is possible, for example, that a Baby Bell could choose to become a long-distance carrier or merge with a second Baby Bell, turning what are now prey into a new type of hunter.
Michael Elling, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, theorizes that two of the Baby Bells could merge with a smaller cable company and end up with a system that covers more than half the homes in America. "Everyone is saying that Bell Atlantic and T.C.I. are the final solution," he said. "I'm arguing that they're not the final solution, and someone else could up the ante."
The five Baby Bells that are not, as yet, front-line hunters are using a variety of approaches to deal -- or not deal -- with their new environment:
* Cherry-pick the deals. Be more cautious about the multimedia future, but diversify through selected acquisitions outside the core territory in cable or in the cellular telephone business. Manage them as separate assets in a portfolio rather than as parts of a single grand vision.
This strategy is best exemplified by Southwestern Bell, which has become the third-largest cellular company in the country by buying systems in Boston, Chicago, Washington and elsewhere.
* Hunker down. Spend whatever it takes to fortify the home territory against the expected invasion.
The most extreme practitioner of this strategy is Pacific Telesis, which missed out on a big-league cable partner and has announced its own $16 billion plan to build a video network for its biggest cities by the year 2000. Pactel has gone one step further by planning to spin off its cellular operations, leading some to describe it as "the naked telephone company."
* Don't worry, be happy. This strategy works only for companies with predominantly rural territories, where competition will be slow to materialize. Concentrate more on buying cellular properties and foreign acquisitions for high growth, and concentrate initial fiber-optic deployment in the few big cities where competition will come quickly. Best exemplified by BellSouth.
* Blinded by the lights. No clear movement in any direction, best exemplified by Nynex and Ameritech. These two are unwilling to pay the high prices for big cable systems, and they have made no major decisions on building a fiber-optic network that reaches most customers.
In Washington, the White House and Congress are encouraging the free-for-all among the Bell siblings.
Last week, a bipartisan group in the House introduced bills that would end a Federal prohibition barring the Baby Bells from providing television programming over their networks. Separately, Rep. John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who chairs the Energy and Commerce Committee, introduced a bill that would eventually allow the Bells to enter the long-distance business and to manufacture equipment.
Meanwhile, the Clinton Administration is drafting a broad overhaul of communications law, and officials have made it clear the plan will support competition between cable and telephone services.
The only thing Washington is certain to block is a telephone company buying an existing cable system in its own region, on the widespread belief that such mergers would create unacceptable monopolies.
 
Ahead of the Pack
 Even without Washington, Bell Atlantic and U S West are leading the way. Outside their regions, they are teaming up with Tele-Communications and Time Warner to upgrade cable systems for a full array of voice communications and new services, such as movies on demand and interactive television. Inside their regions, they are upgrading their own telephone networks to achieve the same thing, this time competing with local cable companies.
But the most immediate target -- and it is a huge one -- is the $100 billion market for bread-and-butter telephone services.
The technology to offer telephone service over cable TV networks is now straightforward. And the economics can be irresistible, because many local telephone rates are overpriced and can be easily undercut.
The current wave of deal-making between cable and telephone companies is, in large part, a reflection of those new realities.
Cable systems can carry enormous amounts of information, but they were built as one-way pipelines into the home. Telephone networks have sophisticated switching systems that can link people almost instantly, but the copper telephone wires that go into most homes have just minuscule capacity.
 
A Common Vision
 As digital and fiber-optic technologies have advanced, the telephone and cable industries have been racing toward a common vision of two-way interactive networks that offer voice, video and data communications. That race was already beginning to transform what had been two separate monopolies into head-to-head competitors. By buying cable systems outside their territories, such companies as Bell Atlantic and U S West are expected to sharply accelerate the rate at which cable systems enter the telephone market.
Many local telephone companies have a lot to lose. Not only is their business five times bigger than that of cable television, but the most profitable chunk of the telephone business is also the easiest to snatch away.
That chunk is the $24 billion a year that long-distance carriers currently pay local phone companies in "access charges" to connect to local customers. What makes these charges easy to plunder is that they are highly inflated, in part because they allow state regulators to subsidize low prices for basic phone service.
Nynex executives, for example, estimate the actual cost of providing access is about a half-cent a minute, but the going price is seven times higher. That spells big danger for traditional telephone companies, because it means rival networks have lots of room to undercut them.
None of this cutthroat competition among the Baby Bells was predicted back on Jan. 1, 1984, when A.T.& T. offically spun off the Baby Bells into separately owned local telephone companies. At the time, local telephone service was assumed to be a quasi-public "natural monopoly" that needed to be closely regulated. In effect, Federal policy quarantined the seven Bells in their protected niches by barring them from long-distance service and other lines of business.
The Bells still have a virtual monopoly over much of the local market, but most experts say there is nothing natural about it any more.
Consider the reach Bell Atlantic will have if its $26 billion takeover of Tele-Communications is approved by the Government, a likely occurrence. That would put Bell Atlantic in a league of its own, controlling more than 400 cable systems in every state outside its region except Alaska. Between its telephone and cable properties, its networks could reach 42 percent of all homes in the country. It would also own stakes in much of the most popular programming on cable, including CNN.
U S West, which has invested $2.5 billion for a one-quarter stake in Time Warner's cable properties, will be not far behind. Time Warner is the nation's second-largest cable operator, with 7.1 million customers. Most of its systems are also clustered around big urban centers, including New York, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C. Time Warner also owns valuable programming, including Home Box Office.
Bell Atlantic and U S West now seem secure in their hunter roles. But their five siblings vary in the degree of their vulnerability -- and even in their own sense of danger.
Indeed, Southwestern Bell has been rumored to be forming a joint venture with Cox Cable, a deal that would place it squarely within the ranks of the hunters.
 
No White Flags
 In contrast, Nynex appears to be among the most threatened of all, and among the most uncertain. Its territory is ardently sought by outside competitors. It remains saddled by some of the highest costs in the industry. And it has yet to define its video strategy.
Even so, Mr. Salerno, the vice chairman, is hardly about to wave a white flag. Nynex had looked at many potential domestic cable deals, he said, but it shied away from their high prices in favor of placing its bets on cable investments abroad.
"Bell Atlantic paid 11.75 times running cash flow" for Tele-Communications, Mr. Salerno said. "They could be right, I'm not criticizing them.
"But that's not our vision. Outside our region, every investment, whether domestic or international, has to be balanced carefully.
"We're not a sitting duck," he added. "Our first strategy is to make sure you are the best in your region. What you want to do is fight them, fight them to the death in your own territory."
Next week: A closer look at Nynex.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Baby Bells: What They Are Doing, Where They Are Going"
 
AMERITECH
 
Recent Deals: None.
Attack Capability: None yet.
Defense Strategy for Home Turf: Cutting costs, spending heavily on fiber optics to support core telephone business. Wants to enter video business, but hasn't decided yet on time frame or strategy.
Outlook: Very vulnerable. Its big urban territories already under competitive attack, and no cable partners with which to fire back.
 
BELL ATLANTIC
 
Recent Deals: Buying Tele-Communications Inc. in $26 billion stock deal. Also spent $1 billion for 46 percent of Iusacell Group, Mexico's second-largest cellular company.
Attack Capability: Excluding cable systems within its own region, which will not be acquired, it will have more than 400 cable systems in every state except Alaska and extensive ownership of popular cable programming. Spending roughly $5 billion over five years to upgrade systems for two-way voice and data services.
Defense Strategy for Home Turf: Has been spending more than $2.2 billion annually on new technology; hopes to deliver video services through 20 top markets within five years.
Outlook: Unmatched ability to raid other Bell territories. But dense and affluent markets in its region will come under attack as well.
 
BELL SOUTH
 
Recent Deals: Acquiring minority stake for $1.5 billion in QVC home-shopping network, which is seeking to buy Paramount Communications. Bought 22.5 percent of Prime Management, a cable company with 500,000 customers in Las Vegas, Houston and Chicago. Owns cellular properties in Latin America.
Attack capability: Very limited. QVC and Paramount would provide programming.
Defense Strategy for Home Turf: No video strategy yet, but heavy spending on fiber optics in key cities to shore up telephone market for business customers. Outlook: Steady but unspectacular growth in region. Limited competition, due to heavy rural concentrations. Not much growth from invading other regions.
 
NYNEX
 
Recent Deals: Investing $1.2 billion for non-controlling stake in Viacom Inc., the cable company.
Attack Capability: Limited. Viacom owns cable systems with 1 million subscribers and popular programming, not enough to make a dent in other territories.
Defense Strategy for Home Turf: Not yet announced. Expected to speed up spending on fiber optics and digital switching, but seeks state regulatory changes first.
Outlook: Extremely vulnerable. Heavy competition looming; no major cable partner; high costs within region. But cable TV investments in Britain and Asia could bring hope.
 
PACIFIC TELESIS
 
Recent Deals: None in cable. Spinning off its cellular properties as a separate company.
Attack Capability: None.
Defense Strategy for Home Turf: Fortress strategy. Spending extra $400 million annually to provide video services and defend key urban markets like Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego.
Outlook: Uncertain. Big California cities to be under heavy competitive attack. Company still lacks a programming partner within region, and no ability to grab market share in other Bell territories.
 
SOUTHWESTERN BELL
 
Recent deals: Buying cable systems outside Washington for $650 million. Has bought numerous cellular systems outside its home base and a 10 percent stake in a Mexican phone company. Now third-largest cellular carrier in country.
Attack Capability: Limited, but believed on prowl for deals with Cox Enterprises and Cablevision Systems, the fourth- and fifth-largest cable TV operators, respectively.
Defense Strategy for Home Turf: Conservative, betting that large rural areas are insulated from imminent competition. Relatively slow fiber-optic installation, mainly directed at needs of big business.
Outlook: Promising. Cellular purchases doing well, allowing company to rely less on traditional core telephone business. Competition on its home ground will be less acute, because so much territory is sparsely populated.
 
US WEST
 
Recent Deals: Invested $2.5 billion for 25.5 percent stake in Time Warner cable systems -- the largest collection of cable systems after T.C.I. The two companies will invest $5 billion over five years to upgrade systems reaching 85 percent of customers.
Attack Capability: Formidable. Cable systems primarily clustered around urban markets, including 15 of top 50 metropolitan areas.
 Defense Strategy for Home Turf: Recently announced a 25-year plan to extend fiber-optic network throughout its region, adding $500 million a year to its capital budget to wire 500,000 customers annually. Moving to shore up Denver and other big cities first against expected competition from Bell Atlantic/T.C.I. and others.
Outlook: Strong ability to raid other Bell territories. Heavy rural concentrations make much of region unattractive to new competitors, though cities like Denver and Seattle are vulnerable. (pg. 6)

LENGTH: 1458 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: November 21-26

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Hear That Gobbling? It's the Nation's Paycheck Being Devoured
It all comes down to jobs. To those without them, nothing on this page is worth a used turkey. But let's take it a step further: What kind of jobs? The corporate behemoths keep making mind-numbing cutbacks -- last week Warner-Lambert, Philip Morris and NCR took their turns in draining away thousands of jobs. And the trends behind their moves couldn't be clearer: Warner-Lambert, cutting 2,800 jobs, faces narrower drug profits in the great health care shakeout; Philip Morris, cutting 14,000, is facing up to a less-smoky society, and NCR, cutting 7,500, is adjusting to a shifting computer world. But all the while, the Government says payrolls are rising. Where? Some good jobs, to be sure, are emerging at small, entrepreneurial companies, but many new jobs are at the bottom of the heap. It was hard to give thanks on Thursday if you made the minimum wage on Wednesday. 

Back to Flying as Usual (for Now)
For the sake of argument, let's look on the bright side of the airline strike. All sides could be called winners: flight attendants (now the world knows how little they make, how disjointed their lives are), American Airlines (the costly strike ended fairly quickly), travelers (they were in time for dinner) and President Clinton (he emerged as a peacemaker). Then again, Robert L. Crandall, American's chairman, was disappointed, saying he can't afford the compromise sure to emerge from arbitration. And while the White House says Mr. Clinton "facilitated" talks, those who were facilitated say it was more like strong-arming. And for travelers, truly bad news: with airlines going through big changes, this disruption was far from the last.
 
Game of Chicken in Los Angeles
A bizarre disruption looms in Los Angeles. The city's airport tripled landing fees, and airlines refused to pay, so Los Angeles said it would ban their planes, starting Saturday. The airlines say the fees (about $900 for a 747) are unfair, even though they are far lower than at, say, La Guardia, Kennedy and O'Hare. Last week the airlines asked the Administration to step in, but no intervention is expected. What happens if no one blinks? Then it gets interesting, for though an airport can't stop a plane from landing, it can effectively block passengers from getting off.
 
A Warm and Cuddly Stock
As childhood memories rush to the surface everywhere, don't investors have a right to regress, too? Recalling, in a flash, how comforting teddy bears were at age 6, last week they grabbed for that fuzzy warmth at 36 or 56, buying shares in the Vermont Teddy Bear Company's initial offering as if it might keep Daddy from turning off the light. Shares in the company, which sells bears through cuddly radio ads, were offered at $10, but jumped to $19 before ending the week at $16.25.
 
Paramount Is Public, After All
It comes down to this: At a public company, whose interests must be considered first? The answer, a Delaware court said last week, is . . . the public's. By agreeing to merge with Viacom, the court ruled, Paramount put itself up for sale, so Paramount's directors had no business putting all sorts of roadblocks in the way of a higher bidder just because it didn't fit their well-laid plans. The ruling was a surprisingly strong victory for QVC, whose bid is higher than Viacom's; the judges said the board had failed in its duties by not considering that bid. It's not over yet, of course, what with appeals and possibly yet higher bids. No self-respecting takeover battle could end after less than three months.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Strength, With Fingers Crossed
There was a troubling exception last week to the cascade of positive numbers. Yes, October durable-goods orders jumped 2 percent, to a record -- building a solid base for continued strength after another nondurable holiday season. And, yes, car sales rose 20 percent. But the University of Michigan consumer confidence index slipped a bit, a sign that no matter how strong the general economy, a particular person could still be on edge, worrying about tax increases, health care upheaval or, mainly, whose paycheck this job-devouring economy will snatch next.
 
At VW, Fewer Hours, More Jobs
What's to be done as advanced technology and corporate streamlining whittle away at the work force. By rugged pioneer rules, in hard times you work harder. But in Europe, the idea is spreading that if those with jobs work a bit less, there'll be more jobs to go around. This is uncharted economic territory, though, and because workers would never stand for seeing their pay cut as much as their hours, many have doubts. But last week Volkswagen gave it a try, putting workers on a four-day week -- a 20 percent cut in hours, a 10 percent cut in pay. Workers agreed because the alternative was a grim lottery: Of 100,000 jobs, the auto maker vowed to cut 30,000. VW had to do something: it has lost nearly $1 billion so far this year.
 
House Seats: Not for Sale
Once voters install you in the House of Representatives, it's hard to get thrown out. It's easier for an incumbent to raise money, and since the races draw relatively little attention, a gate-crasher has scant hope. A big hurdle to reform has always been that House members, naturally, don't want to rock the boat. But public pressure got so great that last week the House voted an $800,000 campaign spending limit. The overall limit is voluntary -- but exceeding it could be made a campaign issue, and meeting it would qualify you for $200,000 in vouchers to buy ads. "For the first time," said Carolyn B. Maloney, Manhattan Democrat, "we will have elections and not auctions to the highest bidder.
 
A (Simpler) Eye on the Bankers
Banking was a simpler affair until, in recent decades, the tentacles of savings and loans and holding companies got all tangled up. Government regulators tried to keep up by creating new agencies -- to the point, the Administration says, that the overlapping agencies were in their own hopeless tangle. Last week, giving its "Reinvent Government" war cry, the White House proposed creating a single agency -- a Federal Banking Commission -- to oversee the whole thing. The Federal Reserve wasn't happy about the idea: though it would retain much of its clout, it would lose its regulatory powers -- which it called "vital for the effective conduct of monetary policy." And the consumer? No direct impact is expected, though the Administration insists the simplification will lower the costs of credit.
 
Clean Kids, Dirty Dancing
Fact: A lot of adults want to watch dirty television programs. Fact: If such shows are on, kids are bound to see them. What's society to do? The F.C.C. tried for a balance, banning the broadcast of indecent shows between 6 A.M. and midnight. But last week a Federal appeals court said no, you can't brush away the First Amendment so easily, and ruled the ban unconstitutional. It was simpler before the days of cable, but since cable customers choose their channels, cable is deemed beyond Federal oversight. Trouble is, it's often the kids who choose to turn the set on, spending a frightening number of hours before the tube daily. Parents, of course, could always rush in where the Feds can't seem to tread.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Patience, Santa: There's Time
Thanksgiving. Just whisper the word and it gives retailers giddy little shivers. It's the day they can finally get out the lights and the plastic Santas, unleashing the Christmas hard sell in all its blaring glory. (Russell Baker once suggested renaming it "Thunderherd Day," a kickoff for the shopping spree.) But venture to a Dutch town called Assen this week and you'll never know the annual frenzy has descended. This year Assen said Enough!, and banned any sign of Christmas until Dec. 6. That's when Sinterklaas, patron saint of children and sailors, traditionally visits, and the Dutch are tired of having him smothered by his plump, white-bearded cousin. Said one Dutch woman of the American Christmas: "It's just some big pile of loot."
 
No Airline Merger in Europe
It's gotten out of hand. So many airlines own pieces of other airlines, or have deals of some sort, that they can't forge new ties without tripping over old ones. Earlier this year four European airlines had the quite reasonable idea that if they joined forces, they'd create a global powerhouse. But then the four -- Swissair, S.A.S., KLM and Austrian Airlines -- discovered that most of them had links with United States carriers. And try as they might, they could not agree on a crucial element: a single American partner. So last week they called the whole thing off.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Accounting for the Uncountable

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
ECONOMIC indicators may help investors gauge the health of the economy but the typical indicator doesn't have a lot of soul. It doesn't tell us, for example, why, if layoffs line the road to recovery, the recovery still looks like Oz off in the distance. Or why George Bush got skewered on the economy thing last election, when the economy thing was in an upturn. Or why, if unemployment has fallen, 1.9 million jobs have been created in the last two-and-a-half years and the economy is starting to look like a rosy-fingered dawn, consumer confidence is hunkered down lower than an economist's navel.
The fault, according to Greg Tarpinian, is not in our moods but our numbers. Or in at least one number, unemployment, the principal measure of the state of the labor market. Mr. Tarpinian, executive director of the Labor Research Association in New York, contends that the unemployment figures released monthly by the Government don't tell the full story of the current wistful relationship between Americans and employment. So he invented a new indicator, the Job Opportunity Barometer, or -- just to cue your memory -- the JOB. 
 Is he allowed to do that? Indicators, it turns out, are not etched in tabular form by a divine statistician but devised by people who put on their Birkenstocks one shoe at a time, just like everyone else. Mr. Tarpinian, whose place of employment is often described as a "labor advocacy organization," has recently spent some time pondering the disparity between the rising employment figures and the decline in the consumer confidence index, a disparity he attributes to workers' worries about the future.
The index, Mr. Tarpinian said, "was an attempt to come up with something that doesn't just deal with numbers, but with the kinds of jobs and the expectations of income from those jobs. I'm trying to capture those things that may help shape people's perceptions of the economy."
People clearly understand, as Mr. Tarpinian writes in the October issue of one of the association's newsletters, that "the job market is not what it used to be. While jobs are being created, they are primarily low wage, part-time or temporary jobs with no future."
The barometer is a composite of six figures Mr. Tarpinian believes are critical to employment opportunity:
* Average real weekly earnings, or how much full-time employees earn. When the barometer declines, workers will feel the impact in reduced purchasing power. "Earning power is key to people's outlook on the future," Mr. Tarpinian said.
* Temporary employment.
* Involuntary part-time employment.
Both of these components of the barometer reflect the instability of the current job market, as workers accept short-term or part-time assignments -- often without "fringe benefits" like health insurance -- to maintain their standard of living.
* Unemployment rate.
* Unemployment duration, an indication of how much trouble unemployed workers have finding new jobs.
* Help-wanted advertising, the job seekers' principal replacement for the cereal box and the style section of the newspaper at the breakfast table and thus a good indication of their perception of the labor market.
THE JOB's baseline is 1982. When the barometer is less than 100, the employment outlook is worse than in the 1982 recession, a period of serious economic dislocation, especially for blue-collar workers. The most recent JOB figure, a preliminary number for September, was 97.8, down from 98.31, meaning confidence is below 1982-recession levels. The most recent recession reached deeper into the ranks of white-collar workers, undermining confidence into the vast middle-class, the nation's economic bedrock.
In the long term, Mr. Tarpinian said, the barometer is trending down, a reflection both of a decline in income and of a serious erosion of confidence in the economy. Bubbling just below the surface of the JOB is a tacit acknowledgment of the Tinkerbell factor: Beliefs (and hand clapping, of course), not facts, can be the drive train of economic behavior, especially in a consumer economy.
The gap between what people believe about the numbers and the numbers themselves sometimes has profound political consequences, as the incredulous patrician, George Bush, discovered a year ago. If the JOB is any indication, the gap hasn't narrowed.
 
 
 
ARE HAPPY DAYS HERE AGAIN YET?
 TO commemorate Thanksgiving, the holiday Franklin Delano Roosevelt moved to encourage consumer spending, here is more happy news, courtesy of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington:
* From 1989 to 1993, men's median hourly wage fell 4.9 percent, including a 2.7 percent decline in the recovery. From 1979 to 1989, the median wage for men dropped 11.1 percent, or 16 percent overall since 1979. Women experienced a gain of nearly 6 percent in the same period. All figures are in 1992 dollars.
* Of the 1.9 million jobs created in the recovery, only 46 percent were nontemporary private-sector jobs. More than a quarter of the job growth was generated through temporary-help agencies.
* A quarter of the jobs gained in the recovery were part-time, and three-fourths were filled by people who would rather have been working full-time. Voluntary part-time work has grown at half the normal rate.

HEADLINE: Profile: Victor A. Kaufman;
No Armani Jacket. No Glitz. Just a Savvy Film Executive.

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
VICTOR A. KAUFMAN is hardly the typical movie mogul.
While most film executives live in glitzy, art-drenched mansions in Bel Air or Beverly Hills, Mr. Kaufman lives sedately on Long Island. Buttoned down and bespectacled, Mr. Kaufman would seem utterly improbable in the jeans, Gap shirts and Armani sports jackets favored by many of his Hollywood buddies. When Mr. Kaufman, the former president and chief executive of Columbia Pictures, earned more than $30 million from the sale of the studio to Sony in 1989, his life barely changed. He did not unravel, undergo plastic surgery, enter new-age therapies, divorce his wife or do the usual Hollywood mid-life crisis thing. 
 What did he do? He learned to program computers and taught a course on entertainment-industry finances at his alma mater, New York University Law School.
And in the end, he said, he saw "a good opportunity to come back into the movie business, when everyone else was receding." Mr. Kaufman, 50, is now the chairman of Savoy Pictures, a 20-month-old, publicly traded company that has emerged as the town's newest and potentially most aggressive independent distributor and producer.
Savoy stands out for a number of reasons. For one thing, the Kaufman way of financing is fairly unusual by Hollywood standards: He lets select filmmakers own a piece of their films. "The point is," he said, "we would finance the movies but let filmmakers own their films -- let them make what they wanted to make."
What also sets Mr. Kaufman apart from most independents is his ability, with his longtime partner, 48-year-old Lewis J. Korman, to raise huge sums on Wall Street. In addition, Savoy has forged an alliance with Home Box Office, valued at $350 million to $500 million.
Mr. Kaufman's creative judgment in choosing films has been criticized. He is quick to admit: "I'm most fascinated by the numbers and the economics of the movie business. Yes, the creative people interest me. They're quite exciting and enjoyable. But I'm not a creative person. That's not my strength."
Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Korman plan an ambitious and well-financed slate of films, including two this year, 10 to 12 next year and more than 20 in 1995. Such numbers put Savoy, which is based in Los Angeles and New York, right up there with most leading studios.
The performers like Robert De Niro, Anthony Hopkins, Debra Winger, Tom Berenger and Kathleen Turner, as well as the hot directors like Andrew Davis ("The Fugitive"), Mike Nichols and Gary Marshall are set to make films for the company. Tom Clancy, the author of "The Hunt for Red October" and "Patriot Games," which have been a franchise for Paramount, recently sold the rights to a new book, "Without Remorse," to Savoy.
The company's aggressiveness comes at an especially difficult time for independent movie makers. Vestron, DeLaurentiis Entertainment and New World Pictures have died, and Carolco and Orion are struggling. As a result, Savoy is being watched here with intense interest, largely because of the ambitions of the Kaufman-Korman team, coupled with their successful track record over the years in the Byzantine and often high-stakes poker game of film financing.
Too many independents, Mr. Kaufman says, flounder or disappear because they are undercapitalized. While movie makers fantasize about the one bonanza that will enrich them, Mr. Kaufman says such notions are wildly unrealistic.
"In the movie business you have to have enough capital to withstand bad performance," he said. "In the short run, it's very unpredictable. When you're undercapitalized, your overhead is too high and you have too much leverage through high interest charges. Failure is inevitable."
Mr. Kaufman's aim is simple: to finance and market films partly by selling various rights, reducing the financial risk. And Savoy has also sweetened the pot considerably for its select directors. Recently, the company signed a three-picture deal with Mr. Davis, one of the hottest directors in town.
Mr. Davis said he was flattered that probably the only other directors who had such creative freedom were Steven Spielberg and Clint Eastwood. But even though these two directors have lucrative studio deals, Mr. Davis has been guaranteed a share of the foreign rights to his films and a salary of perhaps $4 million to $5 million a picture, the going rate for a top director. Such a deal on "The Fugitive," which has grossed about $150 million overseas, would have earned Mr. Davis roughly $20 million.
Mr. Kaufman said of his timing: "Everyone in Hollywood was nervous. Everyone was talking about the collapse of the box office. The idea was to finance the movies and be a marketing and distribution company, without a huge infrastructure."
Mr. Korman put it another way. "The key is not to believe any one film, or two or three, will be so successful you take risks that turn out to be unwarranted," he said.
Savoy was started in 1992 with $100 million in seed money, and this year the Kaufman-Korman team took it public with a $60 million initial stock offering. It has raised $500 million. The initial investors included Allen & Company, the New York investment firm that for years has been closely aligned with Mr. Kaufman; GKH Investments, a partnership that includes the Pritzker family of Chicago, whose holdings include the Hyatt Hotels; Mitsui, the Japanese trading house; Daniel Lufkin, a founding partner of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette; Mel Klein, an investor aligned with the Pritzkers and Mr. Lufkin; Frank Price, a former chairman of Columbia Pictures, and the producers Jake Eberts and Andy Vajna. Together, Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Korman invested $8 million of their own money.
THE four-year deal with HBO, Savoy's most significant strategic move, has the potential to provide perhaps as many as 50 Savoy films to HBO after theatrical release for home video, pay TV and pay-per-view markets. Essentially, the deal means Savoy can borrow against HBO commitments to raise production money.
Michael Fuchs, the chairman of HBO and a friend of Mr. Kaufman's, said candidly: "We're looking to get an efficient source of big movies. Soon Victor and Lou will be in the studio league, and we've gotten in on the ground floor. Certainly Victor and Lou have figured it out financially. The missing thing here is movie performance. The movies have got to make a bit of a difference."
Savoy's first film, "A Bronx Tale," a drama that marked the directorial debut of Robert De Niro, was well received by the critics but proved a box office disappointment. Its next film, "Shadowlands," an elegiac and wrenching love story, starring Anthony Hopkins and Debra Winger, is set to open in New York and Los Angeles on Dec. 25. Films after that include a traditional studio-like mix: a John Waters comedy, "Serial Mom," starring Kathleen Turner; an action film, "Penal Colony," starring Ray Liotta; an erotic love story, "Exit to Eden," directed by Gary Marshall, as well as films directed by Mr. Nichols and Mr. Davis.
Because of Mr. Kaufman's reputation as a businessman, some of the most formidable players in Hollywood are convinced that Savoy, unlike other upstarts, will endure. Moreover, Mr. Kaufman seems especially prescient about the film business in light of the current stampede to take over entertainment companies like Paramount.
MICHAEL OVITZ, the chairman of Creative Artists Agency, said: "Victor has a very, very facile mind and he has the ability to create financial architecture with a sensitivity toward creative people." And Ray Stark, the producer, said simply: "He's the smartest corporate financial executive in the business."
Privately, though, some executives and producers say that while Mr. Kaufman's qualifications as a businessman are stellar, his creative judgments are flawed. His years, starting in 1982, as the president and founding chief executive of Tri-Star Pictures resulted in a few hits but mostly tepid films, with forgettable titles like "Odd Jobs," "Let's Get Harry" and "The Squeeze."
No matter how bad the movies, though, Mr. Kaufman, Mr. Korman and their investors have profited handsomely. Tri-Star merged with Columbia in 1987, and two years later Sony bought the studio for $5 billion. (Tri-Star went public in May 1985 at $8 a share. Three years later, when the company was sold to Sony, the stock had reached $27.)
Savoy stock has done well, too. From an initial price of $14.50, it has risen as high as $22, but has since slipped to $19. Although several Wall Street analysts say it is too soon to make predictions about Savoy, some producers privately view Mr. Kaufman with a strange combination of grudging admiration and disdain.
"These guys know how to make money; they're horse traders who should be in the securities business," one top producer said. "But I wish they loved movies the way they love to work a deal." The aim of the Kaufman-Korman team, critics say, is not so much to build and nurture a studio as to develop a movie library and quickly sell the company for a hefty profit.
Mr. Kaufman says simply: "We love movies as much as anyone. Our love, though, is in the support of filmmakers and not our own creative involvement."
To his Hollywood associates, Mr. Kaufman's businesslike style works for him. In an industry where people spill out their most personal thoughts to relative strangers, Mr. Kaufman is intensely private. It is not an overstatement to say that he hates talking about his personal life, partly, it seems, because of his wealth.
Born in Bayside, Queens, the son of a furrier, Mr. Kaufman graduated from Queens College in 1965, where he majored in economics, and then attended New York University Law School. (One classmate, still a friend, is Peter Guber, the chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment.)
Mr. Kaufman taught criminal law at the University of California at Los Angeles in 1967-68, then joined the New York law firm Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, where he specialized in corporate and securities law. He joined Columbia in 1974 as deputy general counsel, and two years later became the studio's general counsel. He held various senior jobs at Columbia, where he met and worked closely with Mr. Korman. The two then founded Tri-Star, where Mr. Kaufman was the chairman from 1983 until December 1987, when he became the president of its successor company, Columbia Pictures Entertainment. He resigned two years later when Sony acquired Columbia.
He has been married to Loretta Kaufman for 29 years, and the couple have two grown children. He declined to say where he lived on Long Island, and what he drove to work ("You know what New York is like"). Asked where he bought his conservative, obviously expensive suits, Mr. Kaufman paused for a long time as if the question were painfully personal. Grudgingly, after some prodding, he finally made the not-so-startling revelation: Barneys.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Victor A. Kaufman, left, chairman of Savoy, and Lewis J. Korman, the president, at their Manhattan office. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 518 words

HEADLINE: The Myth of Free Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Drop Textile Tariffs, for GATT's Sake" (Viewpoints, Nov. 7),James Bovard perpetuates the damaging myths that free traders have trumpeted for decades. None of this rhetoric ever seems to consider the damage that the loss of manufacturing jobs is inflicting on the United States, while it uses gross distortions to support the position that free trade is always right and any hint of protectionism is always wrong. 
 Mr. Bovard contends that apparel producers are more heavily protected than any other American industry and that tariffs and quotas amount to an added tax of $500 on every American family and cost consumers as much as $40 billion at the retail level.
If textiles and apparel are so protected, why are 64 percent of such products sold in this country imported? Why have more than 500,000 jobs been lost in this industry since 1979? The 1992 textile and apparel trade deficit was $29.2 billion, which accounted for 35 percent of the total United States trade gap of $84.5 billion, and it is not improving. After record imports in June and July, August was the highest month on record for textile and apparel imports.
In every year since 1985 the average cost of imported clothing has either exceeded or equaled the average cost of American-made clothing, as documented by the Marketing Research Corporation of America. Furthermore, a research report for the Economic Policy Institute states that William Cline (cited by Mr. Bovard as the source for his figures) overstated the cost of protection in apparel fourfold by failing to take into account high and increasing retail market concentration. According to the policy institute's model, apparel retailers and importers, not consumers, would benefit most by the lifting of import restraints.
Mr. Bovard says the United States textile and apparel industry is not competitive, yet research shows that it takes 14 standard labor minutes to manufacture a shirt, compared with 19 minutes in Taiwan, 20 minutes in Hong Kong, 21 minutes in South Korea and 25 minutes in Bangladesh.
Low labor costs are the only competitive advantage that many of our trading partners can legitimately claim, and that is not a compelling reason when you consider the huge economic losses we suffer when we lose manufacturing jobs to low-wage foreign competition. Larger numbers of lower-paying service sector jobs do not balance the loss of more than three million manufacturing jobs in the United States since 1979.
We have seen what happened to the footwear industry when it was exposed to an onslaught of imports. Are we going to expose the 1.8 million workers in the United States fiber, textile, apparel and home-fashions industries to the same fate? We simply cannot afford to continue to let our valuable manufacturing jobs drain away, whether in textiles and apparel or any other industry. Any trade agreements that encourage and permit that to happen must be revamped or blocked.
 
JERRY IASON
New York, Nov. 12
 
The writer is the chairman of N. Erlanger, Blumgart & Company, a wholesale textiles concern in New York.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Gauging Weatherstripping's Economy and Durability

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
SHOPPING for weatherstripping can be confusing. First, it is important to realize that the presence or absence of weatherstripping will probably not greatly affect energy bills unless one lives in a small house having many large windows and doors.
But weatherstripping does stop drafts. A homeowner may be able to lower the thermostat, and windows may develop less inside fog or frost. Also, because weatherstripping is subject to wear and tear, most types eventually deteriorate. 
 Choosing a long-lasting type does not always guarantee superior sealing. Instead, make selections based on a combination of performance, durability, ease of replacement and price.
Adhesive-backed tape of solid or sponge rubber or thick closed-cell foam is a good overall choice. It seals well, is priced toward the low end of the scale, is easy to install and usually lasts five years or more if applied to clean surfaces.
To prepare a surface for adhesive-backed weatherstripping, scrub it thoroughly with a strong mixture of household detergent and water. Rinse the surface, wipe it dry and wipe it again with a cloth dipped in mineral spirits to remove grease or detergent film. Dry the surface again thoroughly before installing the weatherstripping.
The chief drawback of adhesive-backed weatherstripping is that it has to be installed indoors, where it may be visible. The adhesive does not hold up well outdoors. Also, avoid using foam tape to seal sliding surfaces. When subjected to such wear, the foam breaks down quickly. Avoid using inexpensive open-cell foam tape altogether. It crumbles readily and is less resistant to drafts than the other kinds.
Foam weatherstripping attached to thin wood strips is also available for supposedly easy mounting. Although nailing the strips in place against the sides of wood door or casement-window frames is reasonably easy, strips have to be carefully sawed to the correct length, which sometimes involves cutting their bottom ends at an angle to accommodate sloping sills. The strips are then painted or varnished for protection and to match existing woodwork.
Self-sticking tension-seal plastic stripping is also a good choice, especially for sliding surfaces. An advantage is that it fits between surfaces like a door and frame and cannot be readily seen. It seals well, is easy to apply, extremely durable and is about in the middle of the price range.
Some tension-seal stripping has a V-shaped cross-section. When installing it around doors or hinged windows, position the crease away from the stop molding, which is on the outside if the door or window opens in, and vice versa. Another type of tension-seal stripping forms a wide angle instead of a V. Position the side having the adhesive as you would the crease in the V-type.
Bronze tension-seal stripping, also called spring-metal stripping, is the most durable of all varieties and costs about twice as much as its plastic counterpart. Unfortunately, it seals less well than rubber or most foam and can be tedious, if not difficult, to install. Nailing the strips is required, using small tacks generally supplied with the material.
Periodically, the free edges of tension-seal weatherstripping have to be pried from the window or door frames. If not done, the weatherstripping eventually flattens, creating a gap between the surfaces that it is supposed to seal.
Tubular gaskets, either hollow or solid sponge rubber, both with lengthwise flanges, constitute a third weatherstripping variety. Solid tubular stripping repels drafts better than the hollow style and is more expensive, about the same price as spring metal. Both types are as durable or somewhat more so than the best foam or rubber tape. They are installed by stapling or tacking, but are not as difficult to attach as spring metal.
Tubular weatherstripping can be installed outdoors. Generally, it is best to fasten the material against the frame, rather than to the window or door. On double-hung windows, fasten the top and bottom stripping to the sashes. Stripping along the sides should be fastened to the frame.
To install tubular weatherstripping, close the window or door and position the weatherstripping snugly against the surfaces. Starting at one end, drive staples or tacks through the flange at two-inch intervals while stretching the tubing slightly so that it does not pucker.
Staples should be installed parallel to the flange's length, not perpendicular to it. Finish by trimming away any excess tubing.
Felt strips are a fourth variety. Felt has to be installed indoors. Although durable, it seals out drafts only reasonably well. Like tubing, it requires stapling or tacking to secure. On the plus side, felt is the least expensive weatherstripping available, often costing much less than rubber or foam tape.
Sturdy weatherstripping is required beneath doors. Door sweeps that attach near the bottom of doors on the inside are the easiest to install. A vinyl sweep with multiple lower edges for enhanced sealing and a metal backing strip at the top for extra strength is a good choice. The average cost is less than $10.
A sweep with self-adhesive backing is marginally easier to attach than the type that fastens with screws. But the screw type is less likely to come loose.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: Among varieties of weatherstripping available are adhesive-backed rubber or foam strips, metal tension-seal strips, tubular gaskets and felt seals. Attach door sweep to inside of door to seal gap above threshold. Slots in metal backing strip permit adjustment. (Edward Lipinski)

HEADLINE: The Designs Behind the Surprises

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON has just completed maybe the most successful month of his Presidency, with victories ranging from trade to gun control to labor disputes. But just when his Administration seemed to be taking off, the President's deputy chief of staff and legislative affairs director quit from exhaustion and Mr. Clinton blew up at reporters from Rolling Stone Magazine for never getting "one damn bit of credit" from the "knee-jerk liberal press."
Such contradictory scenes have become a fixture of the Clinton Presidency, which is why pundits trying to make weekly judgments are constantly shifting between proclamations that he has finally "turned the corner" and denunciations that his White House is in irreparable "disarray." 
 But both these judgments -- he's up, he's down -- miss something essential about the Clinton Presidency. It is destined to be the White House equivalent of "Mr. Toad's Wild Ride," because that is what his contradictory personality, and these extraordinary times, demand. He may be the most empathetic President in history, easily brought to tears in public, and he is also an unusually hot-tempered President, who can easily reduce aides to tears in private. He is Rhodes Scholar and Razorback, an internationalist with a small-town touch. He is the detail man, the policy pointillist, who nonetheless loves to paint visionary landscapes. And he is the President who can jawbone with his staff in the Roosevelt Room for hours, seeking consensus on every issue, while at the same time so dominating his Cabinet that it often seems as if he is sitting in every chair.
A George Bush can turn a corner. A Bill Clinton will always be careening up, down, around, and loop the loop, because this is not a man, and this is not a moment, given to right angles.
Despite the now weekly Clinton caricature in the press that seizes on one element of his personality or agenda and uses it to define him as a whole, it is becoming clear that Mr. Clinton's complexities may be well suited for these times. In recent weeks, what seem to be contradictory or unrelated strands of his politics are beginning to weave together into an ideology that the President himself has yet to fully articulate but is clearly groping toward. There is something called "Clintonism."
It is an ideology that attempts to bridge such seemingly unconnected events as crime in the streets and the North American Free Trade Agreement. That is, it tries to make sense of a world growing increasingly large, distant and sterile in economic terms, while people desperately seek to counter that sterility and distance by building a sense of community and family closer to home.
"If you listen to what Clinton has been saying," remarked the Harvard University political theorist Michael Sandel, "it is that Nafta is important in a world that is no longer organized within national boundaries. We have to adjust to that world to remain competitive and create high-wage jobs. But there is one thing Nafta cannot provide, and that is a sense of belonging. Nafta has no flag you can salute, no national anthem you can sing, no real sense of community to which people can relate."
That makes it all the more important, if transnational institutions like Nafta are to succeed, that we build local communities with which people can identify, Mr. Sandel added. "Otherwise, we will find ourselves without any form of political community that expresses our shared identity, and knits us together in the families, schools and neighborhoods that democracy requires."
That is why Mr. Clinton, in the middle of the Nafta debate, went to Memphis to give a speech to a black church about the "great crisis of the spirit gripping America today." He said it is a crisis that can be countered only by nurturing the quality of life of communities, by providing jobs that give structure to daily life and by demanding responsibility from people for their neighborhoods -- all this as the nation integrates with economic frameworks that are distant and global.
That Mr. Clinton seemed to make great progress on his agenda in the past few weeks is as much a credit to him as a comment on his times. It is as though the country and Congress, in passing Nafta, in passing the Brady bill requiring a waiting period to buy handguns and in applauding Mr. Clinton's decision to stress trade with Asia and Latin America as much as with Europe, has resolved that the status quo has finally become intolerable. There are too many guns on the streets to continue treating gun control as if it were simply a question of individual rights. A protectionist economy simply cannot compete in a global village. America's traditional Eurocentrism simply makes no sense in a world in which the South China Sea has become the new economic main street.
Not surprisingly, making this emerging Clintonism real has required the building of new, cross-cutting political coalitions by the President, because the old two-party structures forged during the New Deal can no longer answer the challenges of the new world. Thus, Mr. Clinton said crime cannot be dealt with merely by putting more police on the streets, as conservatives have traditionally argued, and it cannot be dealt with solely by focusing on poverty or the rights of the accused, as liberals have insisted. He argued instead that the best antidote to crime was a combination of 100,000 new police officers, gun control and -- most importantly -- jobs, which can provide a structure and routine to the lives of families that have broken down.
One irony of Mr. Clinton's vision stressing Nafta and neighborhood is that it seems to leave an unclear role for the nation, and the President, in between. Mr. Clinton's recent speeches make it clear he is groping to redefine those roles. He is basing this redefinition on the argument that the combination of global economic forces, which make some Americans real winners and others real losers, and violence in the streets, which is sealing people into walled communities, are splitting the country -- income from income, race from race, neighborhood from neighborhood.
One response was his creation of a National Service corps, a new all-volunteer youth army stressing community service. The hope is that it will inspire a sense of national political community at a time when our sense of national identity is increasingly blurred and there is no external enemy to sharpen it. Another response has been to argue for a new notion of "national security" -- not security against change, but security for change. The role of national Government today, he has argued, is to help the nation face the demands of Nafta and neighborhood by providing personal security, job security and health security. Because without them, he says, the rich will never make the necessary sacrifices for the poor, the poor will never embrace communal responsibility and the middle class will never make the huge changes required for the nation to remain competitive.
While Mr. Clinton has laid out all the parts of Clintonism,from National Service to Nafta to health care, he himself has yet to draw them together in a unified ideology and theme for his Presidency. This is partly because he seems to be still pulling them together. The other reason, say friends, is that he is afraid to articulate his full diagnosis -- that the disintegrating forces at work on the society from above and below threaten the fabric of the nation -- out of fear that it will depress the country, like Jimmy Carter's famous "malaise" speech.
But without such a compelling diagnosis, Mr. Clinton is like a doctor who prescribes one drug for backaches, another for knee joints, another for headaches. Each prescription alone promises relief from a particular symptom. Yet without a full diagnosis of where the nation is and why it needs to take such medicines, his prescriptions can also seem confusing and lack authority, and it is not at all clear the public will swallow them.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Seeking After Truth In Times of Scarcity

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WITH the anointing last week of Harold E. Varmus as director of the National Institutes of Health, the organization that is the breath and blood of biomedical research in America, many scientists dared to fantasize that a sunnier and more abundant era might finally be upon them.
Yet some researchers say that even with his radiant scientific credentials, his Nobel prize and his forceful and persistent personality, Dr. Varmus has scant hope of reviving the grand old days of government largess and unbounded freedom that made him and his peers in the upper scientific strata what they are today. 
 Indeed, Dr. Varmus may represent a dying breed of scientist: the university researcher able to command a large and easily renewed Federal grant that supports an army of graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and technicians, all devoted to the unearthing of the body's deepest truths.
"No one has a sure source of funding anymore, no matter who they are or how good they are," said Dr. Jeff Boyd, a researcher at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, an N.I.H. division at Research Triangle Park, N.C. "We're all feeling more threatened in our ability to carry out our research."
Not only is the Government growing generally stingier, but Congress and the public alike are clamoring for greater accountability from basic researchers, stiffening their demands that whatever problems scientists choose to address at taxpayers' expense will clearly result in clinical payoffs or marketable products.
The recent squeeze in biomedical research is having the greatest impact on young scientists. Many are abandoning the uncertainties of university science, taking jobs in pharmaceutical or biotechnology firms.
But even those who remain in academia find themselves adopting a supple and entrepreneurial approach to getting their work done. Young investigators are learning to live with the notion that their careers are not likely to proceed in an unbroken march forward, but that there will be lean years and fat years, years when they have the resources to follow their noses and luxuriate in the joys of experimental research; and years when they cannot afford to buy their flasks or pay an animal keeper to clean out the mouse cages. They are adjusting their projects and expectations accordingly.
 
Doing It Yourself
 "There's a selective pressure now for scientists who can do experiments that start and stop," said Dr. Florence Haseltine, director of the Center for Population Research in Bethesda, who has been involved in many programs designed to help women, minorities and young scientists. "People aren't continuously funded. Those who are good at managing under constrictions are probably the people who are going to do the best."
Young scientists are also making do with smaller labs with fewer full-time technicians -- one of the biggest expenses -- and they are doing more of the hands-on experimental work themselves, rather than assigning it to students and underlings. "Junior researchers are not going to see the senior scientists with megalabs as role models anymore," said Dr. Haseltine.
Paradoxically, much of the current crunch in financing stems from biomedicine's triumphs in delving into the origin of cancer, the birth and death of cells, the cause of AIDS, and the like. These successes have seduced an ever-widening pool of people to join the field, and the population explosion has outstripped the capacity of the N.I.H. budget that supports research. Between a sharp increase in the number of doctorates awarded in the biomedical sciences, and a steady influx of foreign researchers to universities and laboratories in the United States, the total of biologists and medical scientists has almost tripled in the last 20 years. During the same period, the institutes' budget, on which all those scientists rely for research grants, has grown by maybe 50 percent to 75 percent when adjusted for inflation. In the 1970's, at least half of all grants submitted to the N.I.H. won support, while today only 10 to 15 percent do.
 
Honing Their Prose
 Such figures sound discouraging, but it turns out that many worthy projects do end up winning approval -- eventually. Young researchers say they are spending many long and painful hours writing and rewriting grants. That may not be such a bad thing. In mastering the craft of persuasive prose, the researchers concede, their thinking is sharpened and their scientific goals are clarified.
Dr. Kathy Foltz, a 30-year-old assistant professor of biology at the University of California at Santa Barbara, who studies how fertilization occurs by looking at sea urchin eggs, said her first application to the N.I.H. for money was turned down, but she now has hopes that her second recent attempt will succeed. "I get resentful when I have to write grants all the time," she said. "But I also realize that it forces me to focus my attention and to think about my science carefully."
And no matter how arcane and removed from the patients' bedside their projects may be, biologists are feeling pressured to emphasize the practical potential of their work. "You may be in science for the intellectual stimulation of it," said Dr. Boyd, "but when you talk about it, you stress how your work relates to cancer. Accountability is the big issue here." Traditionally, scientists have not liked talking about how or when their work might lead to cures. Many have preferred to take a loftier stance, describing the intellectual pleasures of puzzling-solving, of slowly and deftly uncoiling nature's whorls and spirals.
But that sort of purity has a smaller place in this decade of relentless pragmatism.
"In the current climate, it's okay to think about applied stuff," said Dr. Foltz. When writing grants, she said, "I put in the obligatory paragraphs about how my work may lead to new approaches to human contraception."
She said her parents are dairy farmers in Ohio who pay a lot of taxes, that she grew up with the children of steelworkers and coal miners. "I'm sensitive to the issue that it's taxpayers' dollars that let me do my work," she said. "I agree that I should be held accountable for how I spend their money."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
China Chooses Not to Prod North Korea

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
AS brothers in arms, China and North Korea have a long history of standing shoulder to shoulder against Western "hegemony" in Asia. Perhaps half a million Chinese soldiers died defending the right of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's longtime dictator, to commit one of the century's great military blunders in attacking South Korea on June 25, 1950.
Today, the world is anxiously waiting to see how a much different China, one desperately seeking an era of stability in which to lift its 1.2 billion citizens to prosperity, is going to help North Korea escape its most serious confrontation with the West since Harry Truman was forced to send a general named MacArthur onto the beach at Inchon. 
 There are many signs that China's leaders are torn over which course to take, whether to back the doddering, 81-year-old general in Pyongyang, thereby supporting his quest to become Asia's second nuclear power, or join a United Nations pressure campaign to stop him.
Either way, China could lose, and that is why few analysts here expect China's untested new President and Communist Party boss, Jiang Zemin, a fence-sitter all his career, to take a leading role in Korean diplomacy.
This month in Seattle, Mr. Jiang, in his first performance on the world stage as China's leader, clearly demurred when Pacific leaders looked to him to exert some influence on his North Korean comrades.
Instead, Mr. Jiang told Prime Minister Mirohiro Hosokawa of Japan in private that China has little influence these days over Kim Il Sung and, therefore, could not be counted on to change North Korea's ways.
This must have added to the disappointment of President Clinton, who has little to show for upgrading relations with China at some political risk this fall -- including meeting with Mr. Jiang in Seattle. Afterward, he returned to Washington to strike a shoulder-to-shoulder stand last week with South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, but avoided the more bellicose vocabulary that his Administration has recently directed at North Korea. And Mr. Clinton held out an unexpected carrot.
If North Korea allows inspections of its nuclear installations and resumes its dialogue with the South, the United States would consider standing down from the annual "Team Spirit" war maneuvers it conducts with South Korea -- war maneuvers that North Korea, through its paranoic lens, views as a prelude to invasion.
Asian diplomats say Mr. Clinton's offer, including other incentives like aid and the possibility of normal relations, was not self-inspired. Japan, South Korea and China have all warned that painting the prickly North Korean dictator into a corner is counterproductive. Mr. Clinton last week said he got the message.
Asian leaders also felt that the American oratory was too far out in front of the politics. They say no Asian power, especially those most threatened by the prospect of a nuclear North Korea, is now ready to support United Nations sanctions for the simple reason that they won't yield any result except perhaps a war devastating to the region's vibrant economies.
Japan and South Korea have made it clear they eventually may go along with a United Nations campaign of pressure and sanctions, but neither feels the threat has "ripened," as one Japanese diplomat said. After a briefing from Defense Secretary Les Aspin in Tokyo last month, a Japanese official said, "We still are not persuaded that North Korea has a full nuclear capability or an effective means to carry a nuclear weapon."
Such statements raise the question of whether the Administration and its Asian allies agree on what constitutes a North Korean nuclear capability. If North Korea has extracted enough plutonium from its five-megawatt research reactor to assemble one or several crude, untested nuclear bombs -- but is still far from actually assembling a device -- is this a threat so severe as to warrant an immediate United States-led military assault aimed at leveling North Korea's well-dispersed nuclear complex? Presented with such a scenario, an Asian diplomat will warn of the enormous flow of Korean refugees to the Chinese border in a military conflict, or about how the peninsula's economy could be set back decades, or of heavy casualties.
Now, as diplomacy approaches the brink over North Korea, the key players seem focused on different schedules.
The United States remains riveted on the International Atomic Energy Agency's inability to inspect North Korea's nuclear labs or assure the Security Council that North Korean scientists have not yet tightened the last screw on their first nuclear bomb.
 
The Long View
 At a meeting next month, the atomic-energy agency may well conclude that, having been thwarted since the spring, it can no longer guarantee North Korea is in compliance as a signer of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. That could trigger an unwelcome escalation of the crisis.
China's leaders seem to take greater comfort in focusing on the long term in North Korea -- the prospect that the death of Kim Il Sung will bring an era of change for a country caught in what Secretary of State Warren Christopher calls a "time warp."
Implicit in China's strategy is that it might tolerate the development of a nuclear bomb until it could persuade a successor regime to return to non-nuclear status, as South Africa did under President F. W. de Klerk. A Western diplomat here said that beneath China's noncommital statements on the need to avoid pressure is the hope "that they can somehow manage the collapse of the Kim dynasty and bring about a transition to a Communist regime that is more like China or Vietnam, one that is open and interested in economic development, but which is still Communist and retains stability."
If Mr. Clinton succeeds in his new policy of broader diplomatic engagement with what seems a hopelessly isolated regime, he will have scored a major Asian policy success, as well as a blow for nuclear non-proliferation. But the North Korean problem may also demonstrate a new imperative about the new world order -- that commercial interests and stability outweigh all but the most advanced, the most "ripened," of security risks.

North Korean President Kim Il Sung, center, and his son, Kim Jong Il, right, appeared at the dedication of a monument earlier this year. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Clinton Won't Take Credit For These Jobs

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
LARRY OSWALT doesn't like "Bubba." He has even less use for Hillary Rodham Clinton. And Socks the Cat? Me-ouch! Yet, as far as he is concerned, Bill Clinton hasn't received nearly enough credit for some of the less-than-shining moments of his Presidency. The Memphis resident, after all, made a tidy sum when the President reneged on his middle-class tax cut and another when he retreated over homosexuals in the military. "Nannygate" was a shot in the arm, and the Haircut was a real boon.
Mr. Oswalt sells Bill Clinton doormats -- "wipe feet liberally." He is one of a growing legion of rankled right-wingers producing products that poke fun at the President. Of course, items lampooning Presidents are nothing new, but lately it seems that conservative magazines like the National Review are positively swollen with ads for anti-Clinton paraphernalia -- a confirmation, perhaps, that for those who believe the business of America is business, making a profit is the best revenge. 
 Among the novelties are Clinton condoms and toilet paper, voodoo dolls ("so you can stick it to him"), calendars that count down his term, "Slick Willie" golf balls ("good lie guaranteed") and T-shirts and bumper stickers saying things like "You Elected Him, Now I'm Stuck with the Bill."
"It may be the only growth industry in America," said Tony Savage, the National Review's classified-advertising director. He said most of his advertisers are "mom and pop entrepreneurs" who dip into savings to develop a single product, sell it for a few months and then recede to be replaced by others.
The 15 entrepreneurs interviewed for this article all said they had defining moments that transformed them from critics to critics with a product.
Nikki White of Waterford, Mich., said she and her husband, Chuck, "bugged out" in March when the President was promoting his deficit-reduction plan. "He was biting his lip, with a tear in his eye saying that it was our patriotic duty to pay more taxes," she said. "My husband looked at his pay stub, shook his head and said he must be one of the most patriotic people alive." Their response: a "Pop Goes the Weasel" Clinton doll.
Michael Dalton Johnson, a publisher of computer magazines from Carlsbad, Calif., said he has been "flabbergasted" by the success of his "Slick Times," a quarterly with stinging jokes and venomous fabrications about Mr. and Mrs. Clinton (cover price: $3.95). "We printed 10,000 copies of our first issue in March," he said. "We sold 120,000 copies of our most recent issue."
Although such products can be discounted as sour grapes, Ben Wattenberg, senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, said Mr. Clinton should take heed. "The most difficult thing for a President to recover from is being laughed at: remember Gerald Ford," he said. "I think Clinton is straddling that thin line where people who are now laughing about him will laugh at him. Of course, he is smart enough to turn this around."
Former Vice President Dan Quayle, who knows from nasty political humor, said the President should "just ignore" it. "These ad hominem attacks reflect a viciousness that has crept into American politics," he said. "The best thing he can do is build an economy that offers jobs and a foreign policy that provides security. It's hard to make fun of that."
