HEADLINE: From Drugs and Homelessness Back to Self-Respect: One Man's Round Trip

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
When Christopher Phillips first became homeless, he spent his days riding the No. 2 subway line from end to end and his nights sleeping fitfully in the Clark Street Station in Brooklyn.
At first, he tried to doze sitting up, he said, so people would think he was waiting for a train. But the tactic was as much for his own state of mind. "I didn't think of myself as homeless at first," Mr. Phillips said recently at a Queens Y.M.C.A., where a modest room recently became his home after nearly two years on the streets, when crack cocaine controlled his life. 
 "I just started riding up and down all day because I didn't have anything else to do," said Mr. Phillips, who is 46 years old.
He told himself that he could always return to the Bronx apartment of his ex-girlfriend's grandmother, where he had slept for several months. But in more sober moments, he knew that she wouldn't have him back.
 
A $200-a-Day Habit
 Mr. Phillips had lost his job of 10 years as head of security at a Food Plaza grocery store in Manhattan because of crack addiction. To support his $200-a-day habit, he began to steal, mostly from the backs of trucks as they were unloaded at delicatessens and supermarkets, a racket he had stopped dozens of times as a security guard.
"I would steal anything," he said, lacing his fingers over his face as his voice broke. "Anything I could get my hands on and resell: cases of fruit juice, diapers, infant milk. None of it was food for me; it all just meant money for crack."
From 1991 to early 1992, Mr. Phillips was a textbook example of how a person can become homeless in New York City, where 86,000 individuals passed through public shelters last year as a result of unemployment, illness or drug use. More than 5,600 families were housed in city shelters this year, the highest number ever, officials said.
Mr. Phillips is one of the fortunate few who have managed to beat the odds. With a dogged determination to salvage his life, and with a boost from the Community Service Society of New York, one of seven charities helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, he now has a job, a roof over his head and new hope.
 
Help for Thousands
 Today, the Neediest Cases Fund begins its 82d annual appeal for donations to help people like Mr. Phillips and thousands of others. While economic pressures may be easing in other parts of the country, their effects are still being felt in New York City, increasing the demand for privately run human services as donations to charities fail to keep pace with demand.
"The seven charities dependent on the Neediest Cases Fund are counting more on our campaign this year than in any time since the Depression," said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Foundation, which administers the fund. "The lingering effect of the recession in the Northeast is extending the need for assistance to the ranks of the lower middle class, where more and more families are requiring relief from charities faced with a dramatic drop in contributions."
During last year's campaign, nearly 14,000 donors from around the world helped raise $4,469,034.47, the second-highest total ever. But the figure represented a drop of more than 12 percent from the previous year's contributions.
The idea for the campaign was born during a Christmas Day encounter in 1911 between Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The New York Times, and a destitute man, an orphan from Denmark, who asked him for money to find shelter for the night. Mr. Ochs gave the man money for shelter and clothes. Several days later, he was given a job in the newspaper's circulation department.
The encounter inspired Mr. Ochs to have a reporter write about the city's 100 neediest cases the next year. The publisher saw the campaign as a way to encourage good will throughout the city and to improve understanding of the plight of the destitute. The first appeal, which lasted for nine days, collected $3,630.88 that was distributed to three charities.
 
Direct Aid to Charities
 In the ensuing years, the campaign ceased to focus on just 100 cases, as poverty became too widespread to reduce to so few examples. Dozens of other newspapers in the United States and abroad developed similar campaigns.
This year's drive will run through Feb. 28. As in the past, The Times will pay for all overhead expenses so that the contributions can be given directly to the seven charities.
In Mr. Phillips's case, support from the Neediest Cases Fund helped him to help himself when he finally decided to fight his addiction.
"I felt like I had reached the end of my life," he said. "I felt awful talking to people with dirty tennis shoes and ripped pants, smelling bad. I couldn't look anybody in the eye. Once you're taking drugs, nobody respects you, especially you."
Although he successfully completed a drug treatment program in upstate New York, Mr. Phillips returned to the city with no money, no place to stay and no job. For several weeks he was precariously close to slipping back down the distance he had climbed.
Having never before been unemployed, he knew nothing about the public assistance system. When he went to look for a job -- as a hospital orderly, a bicycle messenger, a porter -- he was always asked where he lived. "I'd have to tell them I lived in a shelter," he said. "I knew I wouldn't get the job. Without the job, no place to live."
With help from the Community Service Society, he was able to get $215 from the city to find housing, without the usual 45-day wait. He was able to get a room in the Y.M.C.A. The Society also helped him get help from an employment service. And when he finally found a job, on his own, with a bottling company on Long Island, the Society bought him the pair of black work boots that allowed him to start with no delay.
 
Regaining Self-Respect
 Mr. Phillips said the most important thing the Society helped him regain was self-respect. "I was thinking no one cared. No one's reaching out to help me, but they did," he said. "Now I have money and I have a place to lay my body and I'm proud of that."
By early next year, he said, he expects to move into an apartment of his own. For now, he is content to take each new step slowly. "I don't want to hang my hat higher than I can reach it just yet," he said, smiling.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I felt like I had reached the end of my life," said Christopher Phillips, at a Y.M.C.A. in Queens where he is aided by the Neediest Cases Fund. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Marvin Feldman, Retired Head Of Fashion Institute, Dead at 66

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Marvin Feldman, who was president of the Fashion Institute of Technology for 21 years during which its enrollment and academic scope increased dramatically, died on Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 66 and had lived in retirement in Newport, R.I.
The cause of death was cancer, said Loretta Lawrence Keane, the school's director of college relations. 
 Mr. Feldman headed the institute from 1971 until his retirement last year and was the longest-serving president of the school, which is in Manhattan's garment district. During his tenure the college's enrollment rose to 12,000 from 5,000, the selection of courses went up greatly and the number of buildings went to eight from two.
The major fields of study now include interior design, museum studies, fashion design, toy design and photography.
Under his direction, the institute, which is affiliated with the State University of New York system, began awarding bachelor's and master's degrees, as well as the associate degree.
 
Advocate of Aid Programs
 F.I.T. also set up the Advanced Apparel Manufacturing Technology Demonstration Facility, which includes a large collection of computer-driven equipment, and, in 1983, a Small Business Center that provides services and support for entrepreneurs.
Two months ago the school renamed its Administration and Technology Center the Marvin Feldman Center.
"Marvin Feldman's vitality and wisdom were the primary reasons behind the success of F.I.T.," said Peter G. Scotese, the chairman of the school's board of trustees.
Over the years Mr. Feldman was a vocal advocate for Federal aid for programs that would help both vocational training and small business.
Early in his career Mr. Feldman was a secondary school educator and administrator in California, and from 1964 to 1969 he was an officer of the Ford Foundation's Division of International Education and Research. He served in a variety of capacities in Washington in the Office of Education and the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Before his retirement, Mr. Feldman had been a longtime resident of Montclair, N.J. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy Feldman of Newport, and two sons, Brian and Michael.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton on Crime

 BODY:
Spotting a White House political offensive is a lot like spotting a tidal wave. All you have to do is look offshore and watch for a big bump. By that standard, it takes no special genius to see that President Clinton and his staff have fastened on crime.
It is an impulse to be saluted, especially since Mr. Clinton does not seem drawn to the simplistic -- and sometimes demagogic -- approach embodied in Nixon-Reagan-Bush rhetoric. Their main theme was that the nation could stamp out crime by chasing and punishing criminals more relentlessly. But several decades of experience have proved beyond reasonable doubt that a purely punitive approach can, at best, hold the line. To decrease crime requires a mixture of law enforcement, social and economic remedies. 
 Even so, we have to start somewhere, and the Presidential pulpit is the logical place. In that regard, Mr. Clinton's speeches in Memphis on Nov. 13 and in Los Angeles on Nov. 21 were interesting exercises. The themes of personal responsibility and family stability he enunciated will serve as important public-relations wrapping for any full-scale political offensive.
By seizing the responsibility theme, Mr. Clinton hopes to protect himself from Republican assault as an old-style Democratic liberal. But by invoking the legacies of Martin Luther King Jr. and Cesar Chavez, he hopes to distance himself from those who deliver racially loaded bootstrap lectures to impoverished inner-city minorities.
It will be a tactical coup if Mr. Clinton can pull it off and a heavy blow to Republican hopes in next year's Congressional elections and in 1996. The danger for the White House is that it may get so caught up in political gaming that it loses touch with Mr. Clinton's impulse to attack the underlying causes of the national murder epidemic: poverty, ignorance, addiction and unrestricted availability of firearms.
The family pathologies that Mr. Clinton diagnosed do not persist when income and education levels go up. That is the lesson from every impoverished population in American history. Conversely, populations sentenced to poverty and ignorance fulfill every prophecy of doom directed at them.
That is what Mr. Clinton was saying in the most important, if less quote-worthy passages of his crime speeches. "We cannot repair the troubled wounds of this country simply by making ourselves safer on the streets," he said in Los Angeles. "We must also give our young people more to say yes to. Not only faith and family, but work. Work is required to organize society."
There is another interim requirement while the long-term remedies of education, economic opportunity and family discipline are applied. The President and Congress must be tough and smart enough to reduce the firepower on American streets by regulating the availability of handguns. The long stalemate over the Brady bill, just ended, shows how far they are from that task.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Proposal Would Return 'Clang! Clang! Clang!' to 42d

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Some say it will provide quieter, cleaner transportation. Others call it the nostalgia trip of a few visionaries.
Decades after making its last trip in New York City, the trolley car is resurfacing -- or at least the idea of it. Mayor Dinkins, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and various civic groups like the Parks Council have expressed support for the return of the trolley along 42d Street. 
 The city has been studying a proposal to restore the trolley on a 2.2 mile route along the southern side of 42d Street from the United Nations to 12th Avenue and south to Port Imperial Ferry at 39th Street, across from the Javits Convention Center. Westbound automobile traffic would move on the north side of 42d Street while eastbound traffic would be routed along 40th Street. Trolleys with up to 250 passengers (compared with 75 for a bus) would draw power from a wire over the track. The $75 million project would be financed and operated by private investors and fares would be comparable to bus fares.
Tomorrow the 42d Street Development Corporation, a private nonprofit group, and the City Department of Transportation, will make a full public presentation of the plans at 7 P.M. at Playwrights Horizons Theater 416 West 42d Street.
The trolley project could be completed by the end of 1996, said Frederic Papert, president of the development corporation. But the process might not be so smooth. Community board leaders and elected officials have expressed serious doubts about it. They see massive traffic tieups at intersections and along 40th Street and increased waiting and loading times.
A joint trolley task force for community boards 4, 5 and 6 is urging the city to go back to the drawing board. "What we want to know is whether the city can afford to disrupt midtown traffic and devote significant resources to give us less than we have now," said Peter Obletz, a director of the task force.
Supporters say trolleys would be quieter, faster, more economical and more energy-efficient than current crosstown bus service.
"We hope it will happen because it would reduce traffic noise and be visually attractive," said Daniel Biederman, executive director of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation.
While people say the trolley revival, first proposed 15 years ago, is being taken more seriously than before, most are unwilling to predict whether it will become a reality. Neither Borough President Ruth W. Messinger nor Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken a position on the service. MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG/DOWNTOWN - UPDATE;
Rabbi Quits Housing Plan

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
A Williamsburg rabbi has pulled out of a project to rehabilitate an apartment building that would have been shared by Hasidic and Hispanic residents, saying he could not trust his Hispanic partners.
The move comes nearly two months after 200 Hispanic squatters took over a new housing project out of fear that the majority of the apartments would go to Hasidim. The event highlighted the anger between the two groups, as they continue to grow at about the same rate and clash over housing. 
 The rabbi, David Niederman, director of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, said he would reconsider if leaders of the group he was working with, the Southside Housing Development Fund Corporation, or Los Sures, would denounce the Oct. 1 protest. But if not, he plans to work with other Hispanic organizations to build housing, he said.
"What went on there was pure anti-Semitism," Rabbi Niederman said last week of the protest. "We have rights to housing just as much as they do. If Los Sures denounces this protest, then I will know that I have a partner. The way things stand now, I don't know if they would alert me if they saw someone running at my back with a knife."
David Pagan, administrator of Los Sures, said that the project was still alive as far as he was concerned. Only one worker from his office participated in the protest and she did not represent his organization, Mr. Pagan said. Therefore, he said he felt no need to denounce the event.
After a year's work, Rabbi Niederman and Mr. Pagan came up with a plan to redevelop a six-story, red-brick building with 21 apartments at 907 Driggs Avenue in the heart of the Hasidic community. Work was scheduled to start in the spring.
On Oct. 1, the squatters, organized by groups including the Southside Fair Housing Committee (not affiliated with Mr. Pagan's organization), took over the 150-unit complex at South 10th and Berry Streets. They left the next day after city officials promised them the right to monitor the selection of tenants. L.H.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK

 BODY:

Appetite for Burritos Is Spreading in Manhattan
 First there were hamburgers, then salad-bar salads, then sushi. Now, burritos. Fast Mexican takeout is cropping up all over. Capitalizing on the city's taste for cheap rice and beans and sloppy guacamole is the California Burrito Company. 
 The company opened its flagship store at 456 Hudson Street, near Morton Street, in the West Village in October 1992, and has since opened four more in Manhattan. In the next two months, it plans to set up a store in the World Financial Center and another in the West Village (right near a competitor, Benny's Burritos on Greenwich Avenue).
"We are going to build these seven stores firmly, and then we're going to open even more," said Victor Semper, a partner in the company.
 
A Theatrical Approach To Finding a Job
 You've tried mass mailings of your resume. You've made 459 cold calls. Perhaps what you need is someone to sing to you.
Dorothy Leeds, who writes books on career issues, will give an unusual job-hunting workshop tomorrow, "How to Overcome Telephone Phobia Without the Help of a Shrink," for people out of work.
Miss Leeds uses her Theater for Learning -- part business-training service, part theater -- to inspire and entertain people who have been frustrated in job searches. Her three-hour seminar includes discussions, training sessions, a mini-melodrama called "The Case of the Unloved Employer" and a few songs.
"I think adults need a sense of drama and creativity in their learning process," Miss Leeds said. "Job-seekers really need to be psyched up. I do a lot of singing to get them out of their negative thinking."
Tomorrow's workshop will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street in Manhattan at 6 P.M.; the fee is $19.
 
Teatime for the Trendy: A Specialty Shop in SoHo
 New York now has a giant tea emporium. On Friday, Miriam Novalle, a hot-beverage lover and entrepreneur, opened T, a 6,000-square-foot showroom for teas, teapots, tea accessories and everything else related to potable infusions. The basement-level store is at Prince and Mercer Streets, down a few steps under the Guggenheim Museum SoHo.
In January, the store plans to begin serving tea twice a day in a salon setting. The space was once a speakeasy but has been empty for years, said Michelle Joslin, an assistant to Ms. Novalle.
 
Health and Beauty From the Same Source
 A Manhattan-based vitamin shop now has a city-specific line of beauty products. The Vitamin Shoppe, with 10 stores, will introduce its h-treatment line of skin care products in time for Christmas.
City shoppers will be able to pick up lemon cleansing gels and herbal clarifiers, and a lipo-vite complex or two. "The h-line provides treatment from the inside out, which is something that New Yorkers really need," said Helen Howard, a co-owner of the chain. "We live in a polluted environment and are under a great deal of stress, both of which weaken the skin structure. The h-line offers vitamins and botanicals to help the skin look beautiful and glowing."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Crowded School Plans to Grow, Vertically

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Trinity School, a private day school on West 92d Street, is suffering a problem common in the city's public schools: overcrowding. But because the school occupies the bottom three floors of a 29-story apartment building, it is trying an unusual solution that has stirred protests: expanding into the tenants' community room and fourth-floor recreation area.
"We are busting at the seams," said Blaine Fogg, president of the school's board of trustees. "We have 930 kids this year in a building designed for 600. Our building is old, and we use every nook and cranny of it." 
 But the plan has infuriated many of the residents in the 200 apartments on the upper 25 floors.
"We are ready to concede that many buildings don't have these facilities, but we don't think that's a reason for them to be taken away from us," said James A. Paul, the vice president of the tenants' association.
Although the tenants have not been able to pay for a lawyer, they have enlisted the support of several elected Manhattan officials. They have asked for help from Community Board 7, which wrote a letter to Trinity School asking for further information.
And the tenants have pursued more active forms of protest. They picketed the school in October and have taped a television show about their concerns, which runs twice a week on public-access cable.
The school sponsored the building, which opened in 1970, between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, under the Mitchell-Lama housing laws, so any change must go through a long approval process. To take over the fourth floor, the school must request a change in the urban renewal plan for the area, which governs space use.
The school's lawyers have already submitted a preliminary plan to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, and intend to file a final plan with the City Planning Commission next month. The plan will then be reviewed by the community board and other agencies.
The tenants say they use the community room for meetings, or rent it out for private parties. Tenants once had access to a terrace, where children played while older people sat on benches. But the school closed the terrace was closed two years ago because of fears that people might fall from it, said Mr. Fogg, who described the space as underused.
But Christine Spencer, president of the tenants' association, who has lived in the building since it opened, said she used to see plenty of people there.
"How can we use it if they lock it up?" Ms. Spencer asked. "They keep it locked so they can continue to say it's underutilized. Then they'll say, 'If the tenants don't use it, why shouldn't the school take it?' "
The expansion would also cost tenants their laundry room. The school would pay for a new laundry room in the basement, Mr. Fogg said, but tenants say that would be less safe and would not have as much ventilation. The school also would allow tenants to meet in a vacant classroom, Mr. Fogg said, but they would probably not be able to use it for parties.
The proposal is only one part of a master plan for expansion that Trinity School has drawn up. But most of the proposals will cost much more than the $100,000 estimated for renovating the floor, and the school does not have the money, Mr. Fogg said. EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Angel of the Airwaves

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
IT IS around 2:30 A.M., and yet another livery-cab driver is calling WNYE-FM. "This is B-24 from Black Pearl," he says, giving his car number and the name of one of Bedford-Stuyvesant's biggest car services. Sirens, coughing exhausts, a dog's barking and other sounds of the night thump and bang in the background.
"Are you watching your back?" asks Al Angeloro. 
 "Always," the driver answers.
In the jangled, jazzy clutter of New York City's wee hours, Mr. Angeloro sometimes seems to be one of the drivers' few friends. Sitting in a dreary basement in downtown Brooklyn, he dishes out the pulsating, electrified music of Africa and the Caribbean to those who crave it. In some crazy sense, he is whistling past the graveyard for drivers fearing instant death; so far this year, 40 have been killed, 2,000 robbed.
These drivers -- like most of the show's audience of computer programmers, car-wash attendants, emergency-room nurses and all the other soldiers in New York's army of the night -- come from far, far away. Most are recent immigrants, often illegal, and work 60 or more hours a week.
In recent months, Mr. Angeloro has been offering the drivers more than a good beat that's easy to dance to. He has been inviting Capt. Richard Savage, the head of the Police Department's task force on taxi crime, to go on the air and give safety tips. Stay off less-traveled streets, the captain advises. Avoid some address where the security is known to be lax.
Mr. Angeloro's special relationship with his listeners means a lot to Captain Savage, particularly since it helps ease fears of the police harbored by people from Haiti and other dictatorships.
"He's certainly someone who cares about his cabdrivers," Captain Savage said. "He calls them his drivers."
The show, "New York International," is broadcast daily from 1 A.M. to 6:30 A.M. Since WNYE (91.5 FM) is owned by the Board of Education, there are no commercials. There is just song after song after song, occasionally punctuated by a comment.
Listeners include insomniacs and sophisticates eager to progress beyond Paul Simon's latest third-world enthusiasm. But the drivers are central. It is they -- and their passengers -- whom Mr. Angeloro greets immediately upon coming on the air.
"If you're listening for the first time in a taxi, welcome to New York," he says. "If you're listening in a taxi and the driver is courteous and the car is clean, our tipping policy is 25 percent."
But words are few. The music begins with "Pygmy music from northeast Cameroon going into Zaire," Although calls come in constantly, he puts few on the air. "People want to dance," he explains. "This is almost like a jukebox."
Off the air, unbeknownst to listeners engrossed in the latest from Kanda Bongo Man, he is talking to a cabbie from Zaire who is at 146th Street and Eighth Avenue. They banter about business for awhile, and Mr. Angeloro promises to play a song by Diblo Dibala, a singer from Zaire.
The show is based on the conviction that nobody listens to the words anymore. From Cuban charanga music to Zairean soukous to Martinique's zouk to Haitian voodoo rock, it is the endless beat of the wildly playful melodies that matters.
This eclecticism is what Mr. Angeloro insists makes the show unusual, although more and more of this music is available on other stations. For instance, he says Spanish stations, many of which he admires, play only Spanish-language salsa, rather than the emerging African salsa.
What is unarguable is that this world beat music is geared to the changing mosaic of New York. "New York is becoming an African-Caribbean city," the disk jockey said. "Brooklyn is the Caribbean."
Mr. Angeloro was born and grew up in Bensonhurst, the son of working-class parents. Radio was his fascination. As a youth, he would huddle under his covers late into the night listening to voices he still adores. There was Long John Nebel, who staged seances on the moon and interviewed Martians. There was Daddy Sears out of Memphis, the disk jockey who discovered Little Richard.
Most important were the black disk jockeys on WNJR out of Newark. He was swept away with the new sounds they launched into the crackling night, and it was Bo Diddley and all the rest of the great black rock-and-rollers who shaped his musical tastes the most.
"Radio is the theater of the mind," he said, remembering the worlds he has visited throughout the medium. His current musical obsession is but another step on this quest.
He made a detour in 1966, going to Brooklyn Law School to avoid the draft. But after a short stint with Legal Aid, he called a local jazz station and landed a job reporting and reading news. Wearing many different hats, he has been on the air without a stop since 1973.
Some stations for which he has worked have closed; some have gone all-sports or country; one turned to an exclusively Christian format. Although Mr. Angeloro developed his third-world format on a three-hour show on WBAI, he came to see that station as "a left-wing cult" because many people at the station supported Cuba's Communist revolution. He sees the revolution as bankrupt, not least because it gets in the way of the country's great music.
"If you've got any kind of brain, that's not how you see the world," he said.
Mr. Angeloro is paid nothing. In nearly three years at WNYE, he has made ends meet by working part time as an administrative law judge for the state Human Rights Commission, putting in a couple of days a week counseling drug addicts, and collecting a bit of unemployment.
The free-form nature of the show continues past sun-up. Nothing is planned. Callers' requests are sometimes played instantaneously, and balance is achieved by keeping a chart of what has been played. Most radio stations, by contrast, are completely programmed in advance, Mr. Angeloro said.
The night veers toward early morning. With street sounds audible in the background, a driver from the Ivory Coast calls to ask for a song by Kofi Olomides, an eerily romantic rocker from Zaire. Somebody else wants Zin, a hot Haitian band. Mr. Angeloro dishes out a treat, a cut from an unreleased concert tape given to him by Baaba Maal, the superstar of Senegal.
The disk jockey sits in his rectangular underground bunker, sips strong coffee, and snatches a page or two of "The Hobbit," which he is rereading with delight. He recalls his favorite listener compliment.
"You no prejudice," an African voice said several months ago. "You play anything."
 
 
 
Dial Tones: Seeking Baaba Maal
 Hearing the sort of African-Caribbean music that some call World Beat is catch-as-catch can, even in New York. Tunes pop up on jazz and rock stations, particularly when a famous artist is in town. Here are four shows that offer more regular doses:
 
WNYE-FM (91.5) "New York International," from 1 A.M. to 6:30 A.M. every morning.
 
WKCR-FM (89.9) The "African Show," from 9:30 PM to 11:30 PM Sunday.
 
WNYC-AM (820) & FM (93.2) "Afropop," National Public Radio, broadcast simultaneously on both stations from midnight Thursdays to 1 A.M. Friday.
 
WNWK-FM (105.9) Less predictable. Presents a variety of ethnic programming at different times.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Going-Out-of-Business Business

BYLINE: BY THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
THE very act of going out of business, or trying not to, has become big business in New York's rough and tumble economy. Lawyers, collection agents, auctioneers, liquidators -- they have always flourished here, but for the last three years they have been working overtime.
Consider David J. Doyaga, a bankruptcy lawyer who works at least 10 hours a day, seven days a week. 
 "I feel like a mortician in wartime," he said.
On any given day, Mr. Doyaga has more than 200 clients -- real-estate investors gone bust, small merchants mired in debt, people who have simply lost their jobs -- being guided through the dreary legal thicket of bankruptcy.
"In the early part of this recession, most of my clients were poor," said Mr. Doyaga, whose 23d-floor office looks out over downtown Brooklyn's court buildings. "Now I'm seeing architects and doctors. Last week, there were two lawyers, and that begins to unnerve me."
Mr. Doyaga is among a small cadre of lawyers and business consultants for whom financial failure has become a growth industry. No one knows how many firms and advisers have been buoyed by the boom in business failures. But a boom it has been, with an eightfold increase between 1989 and last year, and a wide spectrum of businesses, from multinational corporations to corner bodegas, being pulled down.
This year, amid widespread evidence that the slump has bottomed out, the rate is running slightly behind last year's. Dun & Bradstreet, the financial-analysis corporation, said there were 2,659 business failures in New York City in the first nine months of this year, down by 11 percent from the 3,035 in the first nine months of 1992.
Still, "there are all kinds of companies out there that are just hanging on by their fingernails," said Stanley B. Frieze, a Manhattan business consultant.
Mr. Doyaga said the greatest demand for his services comes from real-estate investors and developers; among small business owners, most of his clients are merchants dealing with luxury items like furs and jewelry.
His clientele fits the larger profile: Dun & Bradstreet records show that in 1990, when bankruptcies tripled, the hardest-hit New York businesses were real-estate brokerages and financial-advisory firms, followed by stores, small construction firms and manufacturers.
In a situation typical of his clients, Mr. Doyaga described the problems of one Brooklyn entrepreneur who had invested in laundromats, which failed for reasons that illustrate the depth of New York City's economic decline.
The entrepreneur had expected to profit from serving "drop-off" customers instead of those who took the time to use coin-operated washing machines themselves. But a dwindling number of people can afford to have someone else wash their clothes.
By the time the entrepreneur was ready to consider bankruptcy protection, Mr. Doyaga said, he was already being buffeted by financial and legal problems. Collection agents were calling, his lenders were threatening to seize his laundry equipment, and his landlords had gone to court to evict him.
"This was a case when he should have come to me much sooner," said Mr. Doyaga, whose fee ranges from $1,000 for a simple personal bankruptcy case to more than $25,000 for one involving a small business. Personal bankruptcies are normally filed under Chapter 7 of the Federal bankruptcy code and involve liquidation of personal assets, while small business cases, filed under Chapter 11, are more complicated and require the court to approve plans under which troubled businesses can continue to operate.
For anyone trying to salvage a small business through bankruptcy proceedings, the cost in aggravation and fatigue may be as high as the legal fees. After a Chapter 11 filing, a business owner and his lawyer must attend separate meetings with creditors and a judge every 45 days, sometimes for periods exceeding a year. Required monthly financial reports can be more detailed and complicated than tax forms.
And while struggling through the legal obstacle course, merchants often find that some of their most important suppliers -- the deli's bagel maker, the builder's plumber -- either refuse to continue doing business with them or require cash in advance for their services.
In the hope that bankruptcy can be avoided, many business owners have turned to consultants like Mr. Frieze. A senior vice president of Carl Marks Associates, a financial-services company based on the East Side of Manhattan, Mr. Frieze is often hired by company owners who have been ordered to seek outside help by lenders.
Mr. Frieze is a "turnaround specialist," a financial Mr. Fixit. If straightening out a company's books, closing down unprofitable operations or even dismissing employees will avert insolvency, he promises to find out.
Since the economic slump began, he said, he has advised 60 companies, often spending months working with their books and managers, and sometimes even taking over day-to-day management himself.
"I like to think of myself as a company doctor," said Mr. Frieze, who charges $1,200 to $2,400 a day. His obligation, he said, is to provide a detached, unflattering financial assessment of his clients' companies. "I often have to bring the news people don't want to hear, but I will never mislead."
Both Mr. Frieze and Mr. Doyaga speak of the emotional strain of trying to help business owners for whom little can be done. Feelings run so deep that many of Mr. Doyaga's former clients cross the street rather than greet him on the sidewalk.
"People think they can cling to their businesses, that things will turn up, that somehow they will survive," he said, "but by the time they come to see me their finances are really a mess."
Mr. Frieze agreed. "There are a lot of situations where the patient has already died, and you simply have to say so, to pull the cord."

HEADLINE: Art Lovers, Take Your Seats. Now, Stay There for Hours.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Life is short. Art is long. Actually, these days, very long. And getting longer all the time.
Tony Kushner's "Perestroika," which opened last week on Broadway, runs at operatic length: three and a half hours. And it's only half of a theatrical diptych, seven hours over all. "The Kentucky Cycle," also on Broadway and also in two parts, runs six hours. And this year's revival (Broadway needs at least one each season) is "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," which runs three and a half hours. So much for abstracts and brief chronicles. 
 Opera lovers, in peak physical condition after several seasons of Wagner's "Ring" cycle at the Met -- the gold standard of length, with its four operas adding up to nearly 20 hours of Teutonic struggle -- look forward to December, when Berlioz's rarely performed masterwork "Les Troyens," all five hours of it, opens at the Met.
Want to take in a movie? It used to be a 90-minute proposition. The holiday lineup includes "Carlito's Way," (2 hours 21 minutes), "Mrs. Doubtfire" (2 hours 5 minutes), "A Perfect World" (2 hours 17 minutes) and, coming up next month, "Schindler's List" (just over 3 hours). Art-film devotees can buy a jumbo tub of popcorn and settle in for Robert Altman's misleadingly titled "Short Cuts" (3 hours 9 minutes) or perhaps "Gettysburg," which, at 4 hours, seems nearly as long as the actual battle.
 
A Daunting Winner
 It is somehow symptomatic that the most visible winner at this year's National Book Awards was Gore Vidal's essay collection "United States." It runs more than 1,300 pages and weighs slightly more than a brick. It was so daunting in aspect that neat piles of Mr. Vidal's book, free for the taking at the awards ceremony at the Plaza Hotel, remained undisturbed.
A three-hour movie, a thousand-page book or a six-hour play, like the bumblebee, should not be able to fly. In the television era, particularly its MTV phase, the nation's cultural attention span is supposed to be contracting at warp speed. The conventional wisdom has it that audiences barely have the time or patience to work their way through the narrative on a bubble-gum wrapper.
Yet even as economic forces conspire to turn life's movable feast into a succession of fast-food gulps, Lucullan feasts have been laid out upon the cultural table, and audiences are eating their way, slowly, through all 12 courses.
 
And the Meaning Is . . .
 It is not clear whether this phenomenon is supply-driven or demand-driven. Are writers and producers lodging a protest against the incredible shrinking power of television? Or have they sensed a latent demand for length and complexity in the benumbed mass of zombies who constitute the ideal television audience?
One thing seems fairly certain: some issues of power and status are bubbling beneath the surface. Big art suggests a big artist tackling big themes. It also establishes something like a master-slave relationship with an audience. It was revealing when Mr. Kushner, speaking of "Angels in America," said in an interview, "I like it that people are appalled and amused by the size of this work, that it claims so much space."
The example of film is instructive. Most critics agree that the turning point was "Dances With Wolves," Kevin Costner's 1990 epic. The film proved to Hollywood that longer could be better at the box office. Against all odds, the film made big money. It also lit the fire of envy in every director in town. Suddenly three hours became the new base line from which to negotiate one's status.
With a certain inevitability, Oliver Stone's "J.F.K." came in at 188 minutes -- eight minutes longer than "Dances With Wolves." Then Spike Lee, in a see-'em-and-raise-'em move, decided that "Malcolm X" required precisely 199 minutes to achieve artistically perfect form.
Mr. Costner may have the last laugh. When "Dances" was shown on television two weeks ago, 40 minutes of outtakes were added to create a two-part drama as endless as the Dakota prairie. To top that, Mr. Stone may have to add two more conspiracies to "J.F.K."
 
Intermission? Forget It
 The members of Hollywood's three-hour club look like miniaturists compared with their counterparts in the theater. Last year, Ariane Mnouchkine created a sensation with "Les Atrides," a romp through the House of Atreus that lasted about 10 hours. Presented in four installments, it was the intellectual equivalent of an iron-man competition. Each play was given without intermission, and audience members, once seated, could not leave the theater, perhaps to even out the balance between the suffering on the stage and in the seats.
"Les Atrides," a sellout for its two-week run, brought back fond memories of marathons past at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where in the early 1970's hardened audiences sat through 12 hours of Robert Wilson's "Life and Times of Joseph Stalin." Some audience members, comparing notes afterward, found themselves describing episodes in the plot that others did not recall. The explanation was that after about six hours, they had lapsed into a kind of trance and were recalling private hallucinations.
"Les Atrides" and, before it, Peter Brook's nine-hour "Mahabharata," can be explained away as the excesses of the European avant-garde. But the theater of cruelty seems to be gaining ground on Broadway, perhaps as a kind of penance for "Cats."
 
The Book as Paperweight
 Books have also been putting on serious weight. Novels range from slim to bloated, but it's worth noting that three years ago the publishing industry was abuzz over Harold Brodkey's "Runaway Soul" and Norman Mailer's "Harlot's Ghost," weighing in at 835 pages and 1,328 pages, respectively. And this year, Knopf put a serious stack of chips on a 1,300-page novel by Vikram Seth, "A Suitable Boy."
For the novel, 1,000 pages represents carbo-load. For biography, it is nothing special; anything less suggests a certain lack of seriousness.
Some literary critics have argued that biographies got big when the novel got small. The lean cuisine of minimalism did not satisfy the American appetite for epic narratives. Hungry readers took their business elsewhere. Biography offered the old-fashioned consolations of a gripping narrative, a central character engaged in a mighty struggle with events, the clash of passion, mind and will.
There are other theories. "There is a problem with writers, and it's called the word processor," said David Rosenthal, executive editor at Random House. "All those things that you just might have excised previously because it was too much of a pain to rewrite you can now keep in. That last footnote you wanted to add but didn't because it would mess up the page? Now you can add 4,000 footnotes to the page."
Publishers also find that as book prices climb, size has a beneficial effect on what the industry calls perceived value. When customers shell out $30 for a book, they want to feel some heft under their arm when they walk out the door.
The principle extends to film and theater as well. No one left "La Belle Noiseuse" (four hours) complaining that he didn't get enough film for his $7.50. No one is likely to stagger out of "Les Troyens" at midnight saying, "Please, sir, can I have some more?"
Video packagers, acutely aware that more is more, make a point of releasing cassettes with material not seen during theatrical release. These "director's cut" versions imply primeval struggle between the untrammeled vision of the director, who inevitably thinks big, and the cruel demands of the Hollywood machine, which leaves spools of genius on the cutting-room floor.
 
Computers' Legacy
 The argument that cultural consumers have less time and that television has shortened attention spans, conceals a fallacy. In some respects, television and the new forms of cultural interaction arising on computer bulletin boards represent the ultimate in sustained attention. Viewers follow soap opera plots for years.
On computer bulletin boards, users log on around the clock, sending messages back and forth, submitting works of fiction for comment, belaboring points, building philosophic systems, and in general behaving as though they had all the time in the world. Length is no problem. Cyberspace, as they say, is infinite. Computers, the ultimate time savers, have turned out to be the most efficient time wasters since the invention of whittling.
How long can this go on? As audiences approach the three-hour mark at "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," they might recall that Abe's most memorable piece of work was a 272-word address. And operagoers who are cramping in the final hours of "Les Troyens" may wish to sample Darius Milhaud's "Deliverance of Theseus," with a running time of seven and a half minutes (no intermission).
On the other hand, assuming a $50 ticket, Milhaud delivers a unit price of $6.66 a minute. The rate for "Parsifal" is about 15 cents a minute, a bargain of truly Wagnerian proportions. More culture for much less money. Who could resist?

CORRECTION-DATE: December 1, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
'Rights Offerings' at Wrong Time?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
THE rage among closed-end funds to raise capital has intensified.
Using "rights offerings," in which investors are invited to buy additional shares at discounted prices, 31 funds have raised money through mid-November this year and three more are in the process. That will be more than twice the 16 offerings that came to market last year and more than eight times as many as in 1991. 
 In addition, the types of funds considered suitable for rights offerings have increased. Equity funds were first to adopt this largely British technique about five years ago, and bond funds joined in two years ago, accounting this year for nearly a quarter of the deals so far. Now municipal bond funds are caught up in the craze: the first muni rights offerings were announced earlier this month by John Nuveen & Company for two of its funds.
But the demand for capital from bond fund managers at a time when investing in the bond market has its perils -- with interest rates at their lowest in many years and prices at their highest -- raises a serious question for shareholders: what's in it for them?
In some cases, rights offerings are justified. Raising capital makes sense for small funds, which can use economies of scale to lower expenses. Or managers might use new money to take advantage of an unusual opportunity, as the managers of the First Australia Prime Income Fund did recently in anticipating a drop in Australian interest rates.
These reasons, however, don't apply to most of 1993's eight bond fund offerings, which were made by large funds during inopportune times in the United States bond market. The low interest rates create a dangerous situation for bond buyers. As the economy improves, rates are expected to rise, but as they do, bond prices fall, so today's bond fund share owners are particularly susceptible to capital depreciation.
Indeed, fund managers whose bonds are being called complain that they must reinvest the proceeds at today's low rates. A fund that raised a big chunk of capital through a rights offering today would have little choice but to invest in the same tough market.
"Given the proliferation of bond funds, the last thing you'd expect to see today is rights offerings," said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a closed-end fund analyst and trader in Miami. Noting that management fees are paid as a percentage of assets, he added: "It's just another technique for raising capital from which to draw management fees."
Moreover, recent experience has shown that rights offerings, which usually last about a month, nearly always put downward pressure on funds' share prices resulting from the "dilution" of the fund's net asset value as the number of outstanding shares increases at a lower price for each share.
When the Prospect Street High Income Fund, a leveraged junk fund, began its offering in July, shares traded at a 10 percent premium; that disappeared by August. After recovering and settling at 3 percent in mid-October, the premium plunged to a discount of nearly 9 percent in mid-November as a second rights offering proceeded.
Similarly, when three funds run by Alliance Capital Management -- ACM Government Securities, ACM Government Spectrum and ACM Government Income -- raised $200 million in August, their share prices fell during the offering period from premiums to discounts between 6 and 8 percent during the offerings.
So why try to raise money now?
"We felt that the funds had performed extremely well since inception and saw an opportunity to give shareholders an additional investment, if they were so inclined, without going out and buying a new fund," said Dave Dievler, chairman of the ACM funds.
And despite today's market, the ACM funds were surprisingly able to raise dividends, to roughly 9.5 percent, in October. Mr. Dievler insisted the funds' strategy had not changed, though investors should note that the bigger dividends come courtesy of a 20 percent position in junk bonds -- specifically Brady bonds created from Latin American loans in a program under former Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
But perhaps investors are becoming skeptical -- Alliance raised only 35 to 40 percent of the money it would have if all rights had been exercised.
As for Nuveen, its two offerings, expected to being in early January, apply to the Premium Income Municipal Bond and Municipal Value funds. They were chosen because they are "our two oldest and largest funds, with solid records of performance," said Tom Spalding, who manages Municipal Value.
Both funds have relatively short durations, about five years, partly because they are older funds. Duration measures how bond prices respond to shifts in interest rates, taking into account maturity, call protection and other factors. The shorter the duration, the less sensitive a fund is to rate changes. Proceeds of the Nuveen offerings will be used to buy new, longer-term issues, increasing duration -- and, therefore, risk.
As for yield, "we don't expect the offering will have a major impact on the dividend," Mr. Spalding said, although he acknowledged that we "don't know what the market will be like when the money comes in in 1994."
Share prices of the Nuveen funds have dropped more than 6 percent since the rights offerings were announced.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Los Angeles

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD; ROBERT REINHOLD is chief of the Los Angeles bureau
of The Times.

 BODY:
No major American city in recent times has suffered quite the body blow to its tourism industry that Los Angeles did after last year's devastating riots. Those events changed the world perception of Los Angeles from one of a dreamy land of towering palms, movie stars and sunny escape to one of urban apocalypse, with violent street gangs and drive-by shootings. If both notions were exaggerated, the result was that visitors avoided Southern California, and especially its intimidating core, Los Angeles.
 The latest blow was the wildfires, and then mudslides, that afflicted the region in October and November. Despite the horrific television images, though, few visitors will notice the damage except in parts of Malibu, Laguna Beach and suburbs remote from most tourist attractions. Indeed, a year and a half after the riots, visitors are returning. With the peaceful reaction to verdicts in both the retrial of four white police officers who beat a black man and the trial of two young black men accused of brutalizing a white truck driver, Los Angeles has regained a measure of self-confidence. 
In fact, with the recent reopening of the Central Library, the start of subway service and the Nov. 17 opening of a vastly expanded convention center, Los Angeles is experiencing something of a renaissance.
 The visitor need not fear it any more than any other major American city. You might even consider visiting the riot-scarred South-Central area, for it offers glimpses into the vital African-American and Hispanic cultures that have flowered in Los Angeles. The city today is above all a place of diversity, where one can sample scores of cultures from every continent, all in uneasy coexistence.
 
Events
 A metaphor for the city's rebirth is the reopening of the landmark 1926 Egyptian-style Central Library, gutted by two arson fires in 1986. The library, at 630 West Fifth Street, (213) 228-7000, has been celebrating with many events, including "Shades of L.A.," an exhibition of the city's ethnic diversity, with 5,000 photographs.
 The Los Angeles Philharmonic is marking its 75th anniversary, with a variety of guest conductors in December. Among them is Bobby McFerrin, the jazz vocalist, who will conduct his amusing concerts on Dec. 17 and 18 at 8 P.M. At the Music Center, 135 North Grand Avenue, (213) 850-2000; tickets $6 to $50.
 Appropriately enough, Andrew Lloyd Webber's Broadway-bound new musical, "Sunset Boulevard," is to have its American premiere in Los Angeles on Dec. 9, starring Glenn Close. It's now in previews at the Shubert Theater, 2020 Avenue of the Stars, (800) 447-7400 or (310) 201-1555. Tickets are $20 to $65.
 The Santa Monica Heritage Museum, 2612 Main Street, Santa Monica, (310) 392-8537, is presenting a surfing exhibition until Feb. 27 called "Cowabunga! The Santa Monica Bay Surfing Experience." Admission $2, children under 12 free.
 Los Angeles's enormous Mexican community holds its annual Christmas festival, Las Posadas, with music, food, pinatas and a candlelight procession re-enacting the story of Mary and Joseph seeking shelter. At Olvera Street downtown, Dec. 16 to 24, starting 7 P.M. Free; (213) 628-4349.
 After the Rose Parade, the floats are on display on Sierra Madre Boulevard between Paloma Street and Sierra Madre Villa Avenue in Pasadena from 1:30 to 4 P.M. on Jan. 1 and from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Jan. 2. Admission is $1; (818) 449-7673.
 The Huntington Library, 1151 Oxford Road in San Marino, (818) 405-2141, has opened "The Last Best Hope of Earth: Abraham Lincoln and the Promise of America," a collection of Lincoln documents, photographs and possessions. Open till Aug. 30, Tuesday to Friday, 1 to 4:30 P.M., Saturday and Sunday, 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Free admission, but $5 donation is suggested ($3 for children).
 Excavations of three 1,700-year-old burial chambers in Peru have produced gold, silver and other artifacts of the pre-Incan Moche civilization. "The Royal Tombs of Sipan" exhibit is at the Fowler Museum of Cultural History, the University of California at Los Angeles, north campus, to Jan. 2. Open daily noon to 5 P.M., Monday and Thursday to 8. Admission $5, free Monday evening; children under 5 free; (310) 206-9161.
 
What to See
 As Reyner Banham, the British author, observed of the city two decades ago, "mobility outweighs monumentality." To see this fantastic mix of freeways and buildings, take a helicopter over the basin with Heli U.S.A. Day and night tours start at $119 a passenger; a deluxe tour lands on a downtown skyscraper for dinner in a rooftop restaurant, for $299 with the meal; (310) 553-4354.
 For a less expensive view, climb the Hollywood Hills. One good walk is up Runyon Canyon in Hollywood. Park at the end of North Fuller Avenue and follow the fire road around to the left to the bench at the top for a spectacular view from the Pacific to downtown. Below is the estate of the late Errol Flynn, which burned in a wildfire years ago.
 This year marks the city's re-entry into mass transit. A modern five-station subway, decorated with art such as murals by Joyce Kozloff, a New York artist, crosses downtown. For a pleasant car-free outing, board at the Spanish-mission style Union Station and change at Metro Center for the Blue Line, a surface light rail line to Long Beach 30 miles away. Fare is 25 cents for the subway and $1.10 for the Blue Line each way.
 For all its troubles, South-Central Los Angeles is one of the nation's main centers of African-American culture, art and music. Degnan Avenue near Leimert Park features galleries and restaurants. Valerie Holton of Black L.A. Tours, (213) 750-9267, arranges custom tours that visit such sites as the Dunbar Hotel, where entertainers like Louis Armstrong and Lena Horne stayed when barred from posher Hollywood hotels, major black churches, nightclubs and the California African-American Museum in Exposition Park. Prices range from $20 to $90 a person.
 With its huge influx of Asians, Los Angeles has become a leading center of Buddhism in America. Colorful temples welcome visitors. One is Wat Thai in North Hollywood, where Thai monks in saffron robes pad about in sandals. Enter the painted pagoda-like main building between 8 A.M. and 7 P.M., take off your shoes and listen to chants. At 8225 Coldwater Canyon Avenue; (818) 785-9552.
 For a fuller description of the city's rich ethnic attractions get copies of the new "Cultural Kaleidoscope" guides published by the Visitors Bureau. So far there are Afro-American and Asian and Pacific Islander editions, with a Hispanic edition expected this fall. Send $2 for each guide to the bureau at 633 West Fifth Street, Los Angeles, Calif. 90071.
 For children, a sure-fire hit is La Brea Tar Pits, where the bones of thousands of mammoths, saber-tooth tigers and other prehistoric animals have been excavated. The tar is still bubbling and active excavations can be viewed free. On the same grounds, the George C. Page Museum offers fascinating exhibits of the finds, at 5801 Wilshire Boulevard; (213) 936-2230. Admission is $5, $1 for children 5 to 12, under 5's free. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Wednesday to Sunday.
 For a more comprehensive calendar of cultural, sports and neighborhood events, call the Visitors Bureau events line at (213) 689-8822.
 
Where to Stay
 The new Hotel Inter-Continental offers good access to the Museum of Contemporary Art, the Music Center, Grand Central Market and other downtown attractions. The 439-room hotel at 251 South Olive Street is offering an introductory special of $119 for a double until the end of the year; (213) 617-3300 or (800) 327-0200.
 The new Shutters on the Beach, 1 Pico Boulevard, Santa Monica, mimics Southern California cottages of the 20's, with 186 rooms and 12 suites. Rates start at $220 for a double; (310) 458-0030 or (800) 637-7200.
 A more moderate beach choice is Barnaby's, the 124-room Victorian-style hotel at 3501 Sepulveda Boulevard in Manhattan Beach. Rates range from $98 to $159 for a double; (310) 545-8466 or (800) 552-5285.
 In Pasadena the 350-room Doubletree Hotel at 191 North Los Robles Avenue, is in the Plaza Las Fuentas, six acres of pedestrian walkways, fountains, gardens and shops, close to the walkable Old Town. Doubles are $170 standard, $89 at weekends; (818) 792-2727 or (800) 528-0444.
 Budget: The five-room Salisbury House is a restored 1909 craftsman house turned bed-and-breakfast at 2273 West 20th Street in the historic West Adams district, where tours of old homes are held over Thanksgiving and Christmas. Rates are $75 to $100 for a double with breakfast; (213) 737-7817 or (800) 373-1778.
 The Spanish-style Figueroa Hotel, at 939 South Figueroa Street, is popular among Europeans and Japanese. The 285 rooms range from $78 to $135 for a double; (213) 627-8971 or (800) 421-9092.
 Luxury: The Sunset Marquis Hotel and Villas, 1200 North Alta Loma Road, West Hollywood, is a favorite among the movie and music industry crowd, with 106 suites and 12 villas set among pools, fish ponds and exotic birds. Rates from $215 for the suites to $450 and up for the villas; $499 buys a "star for a day" package, including a private villa for two, a butler, a limousine ride to Rodeo Drive and a poolside cabana; (310) 657-1333 or (800) 858-9758.
 
Where to Eat
 The latest rage in the Asian-influenced California kitchen is Zenzero, in a glamorous Southern California setting with sidewalk patio at 1535 Ocean Avenue, Santa Monica, (310) 451-4455.
 The menu features such items as wok-seared sea scallops with Japanese tomato salsa and Chinese air-dried duck with fruit chutney. Dinner for two with wine and dessert runs about $100.
Possibly the best Mexican restaurant in town is La Serenata de Garibaldi at 1842 East First Street, (213) 265-2887.
 It offers such unusual items as lean pork in green tomatillo sauce, with a more elaborate menu at dinner. Lunch for two about $40, dinner about $65.
 In South-Central, a local favorite is Marla's Jazz Supper Club, owned by the actress Marla Gibbs. American and soul food dishes followed by entertainment, 2323 West Martin Luther King Boulevard; (213) 294-8430. Open Friday and Saturday this year; open nightly starting next year. Dinner $12.95 a person at 7 P.M.; show at 9 an extra $15 a person.
 For authentic Thai cuisine, try the L.A. Food Court, upstairs at 5321 Hollywood Boulevard; (213) 993-9000. Along the vast dining room are about six restaurants offering more than 300 dishes. Lunch or dinner for two can run as little as $20; no alcohol.
 A good choice for families is the Daily Grill, offering such basic fare as meatloaf and chicken pot pie. It is one of the few good restaurants with a real children's menu, including peanut butter and jelly sandwiches at $1.75. Dinner for two adults is about $45. The grill has five locations, the most central at 100 North La Cienega Boulevard; (310) 659-3100.
 The 18-year-old Shibucho restaurant still has a loyal Japanese following for its excellent sushi even though the neighborhood near 3114 West Beverly Boulevard is now mostly Hispanic. It serves strictly sushi in a wood-paneled Tokyo-like dining room. Shibucho is a rarity among Los Angeles restaurants, staying open for dinner until 3 A.M. every day except Sunday and holidays, when it closes at 11; (213) 626-1184.

HEADLINE: Off a Historic Road, Decorators Show Off Historic Houses

BYLINE: By LISA PULITZER

 BODY:
UNTil 1958, Shelter Rock Road was a two-lane roadway in North Hills that provided access to some of the most prestigious "Gold Coast" addresses.
The road was home to William Singer of the Singer Sewing Machine Company; Walter Marshall, the president of Western Union; Irene and Vernon Castle, the dance couple of the 1920's who brought the tango and Castle Walk to America, and to the publisher Ralph Pulitzer. 
The nations first motor parkway, the Vanderbilt Motor Parkway, crossed Shelter Rock Road. And William K. Vanderbilt built a golf course, The Linx, on the road. It was a re-creation of St. Andrews, the famous course in Scotland. Only those personally invited by Mr. Vanderbilt himself could play on the course.
Over the years, a former Miss America, Jinx Falkenberg; a former Yankees owner, Dan Topping; the president of CBS, William S. Paley, and the movie director Lewis Haywood and his wife, the actress Maureen O'Sullivan -- mother of Mia Farrow -- built their lavish homes on the tree-lined roadway.
Many of the mansions have been replaced by split-level homes, their land sold off to build condominium projects or donated to the county. But some remain intact -- like the Whitney estate, built by William Payne Whitney, the former publisher of The New York Herald Tribune.
The industrialist J. Peter Grace also made his home on Shelter Rock Road. His expansive Palladian Estate was built in 1906 for William Singer, and later named Gracefield by the Grace family.
Mr. Grace sold the estate to a developer in the 1980's. The property is now called Gracewood. The neo-classic mansion will be used as a clubhouse for the owners of homes that will be built on the 80-acres of remaining property.
This month, Gracewood, with its crystal chandeliers and gothic arches, and neighboring Jemstone, are open for a Designer's Showcase and Holiday Boutique Show.
Three-tenths of a mile down the road from the Gracewood estate, at Jemstone, a 65-year-old English manor, 20 interior designers are showcasing their talents.
Jemstone is the former estate of Elsie and Joseph Martino of Dutch Boy Paint. Mr. Martino, the son of a Long Island shoemaker, amassed his fortune with his idea to make paint more luminous by adding titanium to it. He eventually became the chairman of the board and president of Dutch Boy Paints. Mr. Martino, died six years ago.
His Tudor-style country estate, circa 1928, now owned by his two children, is situated directly across the street from a historic cave-like rock, once used as shelter by the Indians. The rock was deposited there during the Glacial Period.
Visitors can wanderthrough period salons and bedrooms swathed with lace and silk, and through tiled kitchens and breakfast pantries, to pick up decorating ideas for their own homes.
"The concepts are here," said Arlene Travis, a producer of the showcase. For instance, she said, in the dining room Anne and Karyn Tarasoff combined dinner plates, glassware and candlesticks of various shapes and sizes to give the look of a Victorian-style dinner table. Monogrammed men's handkerchiefs bordered with Belgian lace were substituted for ordinary dinner napkins.
"People can keep these ideas in mind," Mrs. Travis said. "And when they are traveling, or visiting an antique shop, and see one candlestick that has been marked down because it is no longer part of a pair, they will have an idea of how to use it."
Many of the rooms have hand-painted designs on the walls, and artists have painted faux rugs on the floors of the hallways and breakfast room.
Kevin Mayo and Ralph DeLucci created a farmhouse-style kitchen, using a chicken motif down to the last touch, the dishtowels. The men commissioned an artist to paint a French chicken coop on white tiles they used to cover one wall. The mural was fired to make the design permanent.
"I grew up on a farm," Mr. Mayo said. "And I used chairs that did not match around the kitchen table to enhance the farm-style flavor."
"It's a really fun room," said Eleanor Andrews, a visitor from Massapequa. Mrs. Andrews and her friends, Alice Weber of North Carolina, and Rollande Johnston, also of Massapequa, said they came to Jemstone to get ideas for their own homes.
"The showcase is very unusual this year," said Mrs. Johnston, who has visited a number of the Designer Showcases over the years. "They gave us a lot of wonderful ideas we can really use."
The producer of the showcase, Mrs. Travis, and her partner, Carole Aronson, are private fund-raisers, and have been putting on Designer Showcases in mansions around Long Island for 22 years.
Mrs. Travis and Mrs. Aronson of Mansions and Millionaires, the sponsors of the showcase, said they usually chose larger homes for their Decorator Showcases. But this year, at the request of Mr. Martino's daughter, Mrs. Charles Burger, they decided to try a smaller home.
"Part of what a showcase should do for everybody is give them an appreciation of the finer things," said Mrs. Travis. "We don't have an audience of millionaires coming through the showcase. We have an audience that is mixed. Right now, we are in a recession and people are watching their dollars. We decided to try a tiny house and see how it is handled by the designers, and people love it."
The Decorator's Showcase and Holiday Boutique will be open through Dec. 12. Both events will benefit the Friends of Long Island's Heritage. Admission to Jemstone is $15, Gracewood $5 and both houses $18.
The hours for both houses are Monday through Friday, 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. On Thursday evenings the houses will also be open from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M. Saturday and Sunday the hours are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. For more information call 365-7112 or 365-2211.

HEADLINE: Businesses Find New Sources Of Credit

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN the Cannondale Corporation was looking for a $30 million line of credit this year to expand its Redding-based bicycle manufacturing business, it didn't go to a bank. Instead, the company's financial consultant, Michael R. Carter, managing director of Carter & Company in Fairfield, arranged for the loan from Barclay's Business Credit in Glastonbury, a commercial credit arm of the England-based Barclay's Bank.
"Commercial credit companies have been gaining market share here in Connecticut dramatically since 1989," Mr. Carter said, "when the credit crunch really started." 
 Many businesses, large and small, are turning to sources of credit other than banks, because bankers say they no longer have as much money to lend as they did a few years ago, and because the money available from banks is under stricter regulatory controls.
Mr. Carter estimates that 50 to 75 percent of his clients have tried a bank first for credit, "but they get their head handed to them, and then they walk over here."
 
$10 Million in Sales
 The director of research for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, Peter M. Gioia, recently conducted a series of seminars on credit for business people throughout the state, and heard the repeated lament that banks are not writing many loans. "If you're a business with $10 million in annual sales, the banks will talk to you," Mr. Gioia said. "But if you've got $500,000 a year in sales, it's difficult to get the financial support that you need."
Although the state's Department of Banking does not keep statistics, the department, banking associations and finance professionals all agree that as banks attempt to recover from the real estate loan disasters of the late 1980's and early 1990's, non-traditional lenders are steadily gaining market share. In addition, nearly 30 banks have failed or been taken over in the last few years, which means fewer banks are writing loans, further limiting the market.
The president of the Connecticut Bankers Association, Gerald M. Noonan, said it was not solely the banks' fault that they have become more restrictive in lending. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which has been bailing out failed banks by the hundreds, has made it much more difficult for banks to write loans, while commercial credit companies are unregulated.
 
Impact of Regulations
 "When's the F.D.I.C. been in to examine their books? What are they paying for deposit insurance? How many C.R.A. projects are they doing?" Mr. Noonan asked. (The Community Reinvestment Act is a law requiring banks to invest in communities where they receive deposits.)
"With all that regulation, sometimes it's just easier not to write a loan," Mr. Noonan said. "A lot of those close calls are being lost. No one wants to write a loan and have to take over the business a year from now."
Mr. Noonan said that while his association does not keep figures specific to Connecticut, what is happening in the state mirrors a nationwide trend. Over the last 20 years, banks' share of the financial service market has slipped to about 26 percent from more than 40 percent, he said.
Some financial experts believe that unless the trend turns around soon, banks could lose their share of the commercial credit market, as companies get used to doing business with nontraditional lending institutions.
 
'Snarfing Up the Business'
 A professor of finance at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, Lewis Mandell, said there were "firms that are far more service-oriented that are out there snarfing up the business, and they aren't tied up with passbooks and depositors and the other things a bank has to deal with. The commercial credit companies can focus only on their loan customers."
Dr. Mandell said commercial credit companies can do asset-based lending in which the size of the loan depends on the company's accounts receivables. "Somebody has to be looking at the receivables all the time, and making sure the loan is secure," he said. "That's a lot of paper shuffling, and banks just aren't set up to do it."
Banks are becoming very general financial-service businesses, unable to compete with specialized services like commercial credit companies. For instance, Dr. Mandell pointed out, Bank of America is on the verge of selling off its credit card division, a business it pioneered, because it does not have the specialized data processing services needed to manage it.
 
Increasing Frustration
 Dr. Mandell said in the last couple of months, he has seen indications that banks are starting to get back into the commercial credit arena. But it may be too late, because businesses are becoming increasingly frustrated with the tight money situation at most banks, he said. "If you're going to make your customers mad, and your customers survive, it's going to be a long time before they come back to you," Dr. Mandell said. "Why in the world would they want to come back to the bank that said 'No'?"
The vice president and chief financial officer for Cornucopia Natural Foods in Killingly, Steven H. Townsend, said that when he arranged for a $13 million line of credit this year, he ended his long-term relationship with a bank and went with a commercial credit company. "We had an offer of credit from the bank but not at the level we required," he said.
Mr. Townsend said while the bank would give him a loan based on the company's 16-year history, the credit company came in and looked at his accounts receivable, business plan and other factors. "They do their homework ahead of time, get comfortable with the company's risks and management, and then they're ready to do the deal," he said. "You'd never get that with a bank."
 
'You Never Say Never'
 Mr. Townsend said that if he has to arrange financing any time in the near future, he would go directly to a commercial lender, even before he investigates a bank. "You never say never," he said. "But if existing attitudes don't change, I can't see us ever going back to a bank for financing."
The president of a business brokerage firm called Venture Resource Group Inc. in Waterbury, Ronald R. Zemper, said that when it came to selling a business, banks were often not involved at all. "In order to effect a transfer of a business these days, the seller has to end up being the financing source," he said. "There's not a lot of banks writing loans to buy a business these days. The best you can hope for is partial financing, maybe to use as a down payment, if you put up the equipment as collateral."
Mr. Gioia said he had heard numerous anecdotes about how tough it is to coax credit from a bank during his recent seminars, and he agreed that the damage is considerable. "It's going to be something that's a continual challenge to the banks, to repair and re-cultivate these relationships," he said.
Some credit companies have started to give Connecticut more consideration because of the lending void left by troubled banks.
 
State Still in 'Tough Times'
 Barclay's, for instance, "is starting to pay more attention to Connecticut because of what's going on in the marketplace," said the company's senior vice president, William E. Swindells. Businesses that are good credit risks are still having trouble getting money from banks, which gives Barclay's an opportunity, he said. "Credit is probably tighter in Connecticut than in the rest of the northeast," he said. "Connecticut is still going through its tough times."
Mr. Carter, who arranged the loan for Cannondale through Barclay's, said commercial credit companies offer some other advantages for businesses. The Cannondale loan, for instance, took less than 30 days to process. "That would never, ever have happened with a bank," Mr. Carter said. "They're just not set up to move that fast." Commercial credit is often more flexible with terms and conditions, he said, and commercial loan officers will work nights and weekends to work out a deal, something many banks are just starting to do.
Dr. Mandell said some commercial credit companies may have stepped up their lending activity because they sense the worst of the state's economic problems are over. "A degree of what we might call business Darwinism has taken place," he said. "The companies that were weak have already gone under, and the companies that are left are lean and mean and good credit risks."
And some financial experts note that no matter how much business credit companies grab during the banks' troubled period, there will be room for the banks to rebound when they get back to normal.
"There are alternate sources of funds out there, but they're not putting out enough to make up for the more normal sources of funds," said Alvin J. Epstein, the managing director of Fowler, Goedecka, Ellis & O'Connor Co. of Westport, which services a $500 million loan portfolio. "The venture capital companies are out there, but they can't come anywhere near what the banks used to do."
Mr. Epstein said he was sure that banks would come back strong in the commercial credit markets eventually, but in the meantime "I don't know where small companies are going to get the money they need to grow."
