HEADLINE: West Indians In Pursuit of the American Dream

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
WHEN Monica Watson began her long shopping list a week ago for the 60 guests expected for Thanksgiving dinner, she included more than just the traditional turkey and trimmings. The menu for the holiday this year was also to include delicacies like curried mutton and Jamaican spice cake -- favorite dishes from the land of her childhood.
Mrs. Watson, 49, said she was proud to be the hostess to a large and extended family of relatives from her native Jamaica who have settled in the United States. And this year, she said, the holiday dinner would be served in the grand dining room of the home she and her husband, Vernon, 51, recently purchased -- a sprawling 13-room, turn-of-the-century house on North Columbus Avenue here. 
 Mrs. Watson is the treasurer of the 100-member All Islands Association in Mount Vernon, a social and fund-raising organization, and she manages real estate properties in addition to her studies. Her husband is a truck driver who transports automobiles. They are among 7,432 Mount Vernon residents whose roots reach into the West Indies.
 
From the Bronx to Westchester
 In all of Westchester, there are 19,965 West Indians, accounting for 2.5 percent of the county's population, according to the 1990 census.
The Watsons were married in Jamaica. They left the parish of St. Mary (near Ocho Rios) in Jamaica, where each had grown up, 25 years ago and settled first in the Bronx, raising a family and integrating into a new culture. They worked hard to achieve their vision of the American dream, and they have three children, Gregory 24, Vanessa, 22, and Tarsha, 16.
"Like most other West Indians, we are mainstreamers," Mrs. Watson said. "When in Rome, we do as the Romans, because the best way of living happily in a new culture is to integrate."
Although there are mementos from the past throughout the house, and broad-leafed crotons -- tropical plants -- grace the sun porch, Mrs. Watson has decorated her home in a style that reflects more of the family's current eclectic life than its heritage. The furniture is of French design; the rugs are Persian, and the books in the library are from Mrs. Watson's studies at the College of New Rochelle, where she is taking psychology courses toward a bachelor's degree.
 
A Blending of Old and New
 In the kitchen, where the family was organizing the Thanksgiving menu, the refrigerator held the usual supermarket provisions, although there were also jars of Jamaican home-cooked peppers, called Scotch Banning, which Mrs. Watson uses to flavor fish and other dishes.
"It is a blending of the old and the new life," she said of both the new home and the food she would serve for the holidays. "My father, a Baptist minister, taught his children the value and dignity of hard work, and I have put those parts of my past to use in this country."
Although Haitians, Jamaicans and other immigrants from the islands have settled throughout Westchester -- in Yonkers, White Plains, New Rochelle, Greenburgh and Ossining -- by far the largest concentration of people from the West Indies is in Mount Vernon, a city that Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood calls a "successful mosaic" of many cultures.
The Mayor, himself an immigrant from Jamaica, said that most West Indians come to the United States "for the same reason anyone leaves another country for this one -- to better their quality of life, to improve themselves, to change."
Like the Watsons, Beris Henry, a restaurateur and caterer, also immigrated from St. Mary Parish in Jamaica. Since 1979, he has worked throughout Westchester as a chef and has attended restaurant management school. He opened his own business in 1988 -- B & C Restaurant and Caterers -- on busy South Sixth Street here, where he serves Jamaican specialties like curried goat, brown stew chicken and steamed fish to customers, including Mayor Blackwood, from many different cultures.
"We are a private people," said the 39-year-old Mr. Henry, a former amateur cricket player from a country where that sport is the rage. "And we are also very proud and ambitious. We know what we want from life."
 
Currency Devaluation a Factor
 West Indians are generally defined as people of African descent from the English, French and Dutch-speaking Caribbean Islands as well as from Belize in Central America and Guyana in South America.
About 34 percent of all immigrants to the United States who settle in New York State come from the West Indies, said Dr. J. A. George Irish, executive director of the Caribbean Research Center of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn. More than two million people of West Indian descent live in the state, with most of them in Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan and the Bronx.
Since 1965, when immigration laws were eased for people from the Caribbean, many have come to this country to study. Their numbers have grown especially strong in recent years, as West Indian countries have seen a devaluation of their currencies and residents there have had difficulty maintaining their standard of living.
Dr. Irish said that the economic difficulties at home have led to a newer wave of emigration, particularly among working people and farmers, and he estimated that more than 800,000 West Indians now live in or close to New York City.
 
Racial Hostility Cited
 Once in this country, many of the men seek jobs in the construction industry, although such jobs have become scarce since the recession. Female immigrants typically seek employment as domestic workers or as nursing assistants.
As Mrs. Watson described it, "We start off with bottom-of-the-ladder jobs and work our way up."
One of the biggest problems for West Indian immigrants, Dr. Irish said, has been an ongoing climate of racial hostility. "We dare not close our eyes to the fact that color makes a difference, and that is something white European immigrants do not experience," he said.
That was also the case for Mrs. Watson's generation, she said. "It was a shock for us coming to this country from a culture where the differences were not about black or white but about class," she said.
Because of racial issues, Dr. Watson said he believed it was important for West Indians to align themselves with other American blacks. "There is no way Caribbeans can isolate themselves from African-Americans politically or socially because we are fighting the same racism and the same need for a place to survive and prosper," he said.
 
Youth Organization Planned
 Mayor Blackwood, who has lived in the United States for nearly 40 years, said he is seeing a new and disturbing trend among younger West Indians moving to this country: their growing involvement in crime.
"It used to be that a judge never saw a Jamaican come before the court, and that is not so anymore," the Mayor said. "It is like 'Come and join the American land and the American way' means all kinds of things nowadays, like gangs and drugs -- things we never heard of years ago."
Mr. Henry, the restaurateur, said he is planning to start a local Caribbean association for West Indian youths in Mount Vernon.
"I'm not a politically oriented person," he said, "but as a people, we need togetherness. Those of us who are established here need to be role models for the next generation, to help them find their way."

HEADLINE: Art to Snuggle Under

BYLINE: By Patricia T. O'Conner; Patricia T. O'Conner, an editor at the Book Review, is a quilter and a textile collector.

 BODY:

THE AMERICAN QUILT
A History of Cloth and Comfort 1750-1950.
By Roderick Kiracofe
with Mary Elizabeth Johnson.
Illustrated. 290 pp. New York:
Clarkson Potter Publishers. $60. 
 THERE was a time when Americans came into the world swaddled in quilts and left it the same way, wrapped in a favorite old quilt or "comfort" and laid into a rough board coffin, tucked in for all eternity. When Americans moved west, quilts went with them, padding the floors and insulating the sides of covered wagons, lining the walls of sod huts or log cabins. Quilts went to war, and at least one -- mailed home to Limestone County, Ala., to the grieving mother who made it -- became the tattered and stained memorial to a soldier's final hours.
The enduring romance of the quilt, its legitimacy as an art form and its importance in American domestic life have been the subjects of many excellent books in the last 20 years. ("Quilts in America," by Patsy Orlofsky and Myron Orlofsky, and "Amish: The Art of the Quilt," with text by Robert Hughes and commentary by Julie Silber, are two of the best.) And a surge in academic interest has led social historians as well as scholars in art history, textile design and preservation, women's studies, black history and other fields to break new ground in dozens of specialty areas. Research by Cuesta Benberry and by Gladys-Marie Fry into slave quilts and African-American needlework traditions is an example of this lively emerging scholarship.
Now "The American Quilt: A History of Cloth and Comfort 1750-1950," by Roderick Kiracofe with Mary Elizabeth Johnson, offers a profusely illustrated survey that ingeniously weaves the threads of America's social, political, economic and industrial history into the evolution of the quilt-making arts. Several cherished myths, dear to our hearts, are deflated along the way.
"Quilted" clothing (made of a top and a backing fabric, stitched together with padding in between) goes back thousands of years, to the ancient Egyptians. Quilted bed coverings in Europe, the authors say, can be traced to 16th- and 17th-century Portuguese and English traders who brought from East India padded coverlets or "whole cloth" quilts of muslin or chintz. These expensive imports were luxury goods, rare items in the 17th-century English household. But the Industrial Revolution was to a large extent a revolution in the production of textiles, and the pieces of cloth that were stitched by the fireside came to represent sweeping changes in the larger world. By the late 18th century, with the mechanization of the English textile industry and French innovations in dyes, mass-produced, colorfast printed cottons became widely available. England's biggest export market was America, which in turn supplied raw materials for the English mills.
So important was this trade -- vast quantities of indigo and thousands of tons of raw ginned cotton a year going in one direction, millions of yards of printed cotton fabrics in the other -- that it continued right through the War of Independence. It was these finished goods, first from English mills and later from American ones, that went into American quilts, not homespun or even home-woven material.
In fascinating detail, "The American Quilt" explains how the technological advances of the 19th century stimulated artistic innovation. Fierce competition to perfect dyes widened the color palette (the inventor who succeeded in synthesizing indigo in 1880 was later awarded a Nobel Prize); this color explosion, along with the sewing machine, which was in general use by the 1860's, inspired the outpouring of the pieced block designs that are emblematic of American patchwork.
Meanwhile, political and social reform found its way into quilts. Church sewing circles and needlework societies devoted to abolition, temperance and woman suffrage expressed their political sentiments in their stitchery ("May the points of our needles prick the slave owner's conscience" was a popular motto) and sold quilts to raise money for their causes. The women of the South, according to the authors, made and sold quilts to help pay for three Confederate gunboats during the Civil War (the Charleston, the Fredericksburg and the Georgia), while in the North, seamstresses supplied the Union Army with a quarter of a million quilts.
But this book's chief importance is its insistence that the primary impulse behind the American quilt-making tradition was creative, not pragmatic. The image of the impoverished needle woman painstakingly constructing warm bed cov erings out of bits and pieces left over from more important projects, and stumbling across a pleasing visual effect in the process, is a fiction.
Yes, leftover scraps sometimes went into quilts, but scrap quilts were the exception, not the rule. For the most part, women bought fabrics intended just for quilts and planned color and design elements accordingly. Some fabrics, in fact, were manufactured and marketed specifically for use in quilts. And yes, quilts were functional and useful. But woven blankets were inexpensive, they were just as warm and they could be bought ready-made. The authors, both of whom have written previous books about quilts, puncture another myth, the quilt as an economic necessity, by demonstrating that in the early 19th century, quilt ownership increased in direct proportion to rising household wealth. Homemade quilts were not the resort of the poor, but conscious works of art, domestic totems that grew out of creativity, not frugality and need.
This handsome book (designed by Adriane Stark, with photographs by Sharon Risedorph) persuades us that "women's primary reason for making quilts was to satisfy the need to make something beautiful. . . . Quilts were to their makers what canvas and oils were to the Impressionist painters."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detail from "Couples," a late-19th-century quilt attributed to Mary Jane Batson and her granddaughter, Mariah Chapman. (FROM "THE AMERICAN QUILT")

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 298 words

HEADLINE: Why This Country Still Needs to Cut Spending

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"A Dangerous Deficit Bill" (editorial, Nov. 22) alleges that the spending cuts that were advocated in a bill by Representatives Timothy J. Penny, a Missouri Democrat, and John R. Kasich, an Ohio Republican, are dangerous because they would have thwarted the Administration's investment plans. I disagree, though the bill was narrowly defeated by the House, 219 to 213 (news article, Nov. 23). 
 The Administration's plans for investment are admirable and well intended. But the premise behind the Penny-Kasich plan, and of the Kerrey-Brown plan in the Senate, is that the best national investment plan is to cut Federal spending and free capital for private sector investment. The best evidence for this hypothesis is that new Government borrowing consumes $3 out of every $4 in national savings -- savings that would be used to invest in the economy and create jobs if they were not being gobbled up by the Government.
You state that further cuts are unnecessary because Congress made a tough decision last August to cut spending -- for example, you note, increases in nondefense discretionary spending will be held to the rate of inflation over the next five years.
This is a choice specimen of Beltway thinking. Decreeing that spending increase only at the rate of inflation is a far cry from cutting spending, which is what the economy needs. Even with the August reconciliation bill, the deficit is projected at $253 billion in fiscal year 1994 and remains at $200 billion in 1998.
Nevertheless, you are right to point out that Congress took a difficult and important step forward last August. Now it is time to stop this frenzy of self-congratulation and to take another one.
 
BOB KERREY
U.S. Senator from Nebraska
Washington, Nov. 23, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Japanese, in a Painful Recession, Trim Industrial Research Outlays

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 28

 BODY:
After years of rapidly expanding their technology, Japanese companies are beginning to trim spending on research and development, an area that until recently had been considered sacred.
The cutbacks, if they continue, could threaten Japan's long-term competitiveness at a time when manufacturing of less advanced products is migrating to countries with lower wages and when this country's future depends more than ever on innovation. 
 The slowdown, brought about by the nation's severe recession, could also mean that Japan will not, as some American analysts have feared, pull rapidly ahead of the United States in corporate spending on research and development.
From 1981 to 1991, Japanese industry increased its research and development budget about 10 percent a year, or 167 percent for the decade, compared to 119 percent for American companies. By some analyses, Japan has caught up with the United States as a world leader in industrial research and development spending, which accounts for the bulk of new-product development.
But now, companies are holding spending level, or in some cases reducing it. In many cases, they are scaling back low-priority or long-term research to marshal their resources behind projects that offer the more immediate chance of making money.
 
Dampening of Innovative Spirit
 When the new superconductors -- materials that can carry electricity without resistance -- tantalized the scientific world a few years ago, for instance, Sumitomo Electric Industries leaped into the long-distance race to develop high-capacity electric wires, ultrasensitive sensors and other products using the materials. But now Sumitomo, whose fervent pace and blizzard of patent applications had alarmed competitors, is reducing the number of scientists working on superconductors by about 15 percent.
Japan's research and development spending remains substantial, of course, and what has been trimmed so far has largely been fat, not bone. Sumitomo Electric, for instance, has curtailed its search for superconductors. But it is still actively developing wires using already known superconductors, an endeavor in which it is a world leader. Such wires might one day be used to make highly efficient electric power lines or strong electromagnets.
Many Japanese companies, which are known for their emphasis on long-term growth rather than short-term profits, are trying to spare the research and development budget from the ax, or even eke out a small increase, as they slash capital spending, entertainment expenses, overtime pay and even regular employment. This reflects the importance attached here to research, and the recognition that developing new hit products could be the best ticket out of the economic slump.
"If we cut research and development, we are cutting our future," said Minoru Morio, executive deputy president of the Sony Corporation, using words that are echoed by many Japanese executives. Sony's development budget is rising 1 percent this year. Mitsubishi Kasei, Japan's largest chemical company, has held spending level for several years at a time the company has been running in the red.
But some companies, caught in what may wind up being the worst economic downdraft since the years soon after World War II, have been unable to hold out against the near-term pressures of falling profits, or even losses.
"A few years ago, research and development was a holy area -- they could not touch it," said Takeshi Ito, an official of Japan's Agency of Industrial Science and Technology. "But now they have to touch that area."
 
Some Noticeable Reductions
 Fujitsu Ltd., the country's largest computer company, is cutting its research and development budget this year 14 percent, to about $2.5 billion, because it is suffering severe losses. Hitachi and NEC, two other electronics giants, recently announced smaller cuts.
The Ministry of International Trade and Industry, in a survey of 28 big companies, found that total spending would be down 1.9 percent this year, after a decline of 5.6 percent in the 1992 fiscal year. Some private surveys do not show spending dropping that much, and one predicts a slight increase. But if the Trade and Industry Ministry is correct, this recession will be the first one in which research spending has been reduced.
The United States is ahead of Japan in total spending on research and development, when combining outlays from industry, governments and universities. But in relation to the size of the economy, Japan says it leads the world, with spending running 3 percent of its gross national product in 1991, compared with 2.65 percent in the United States. In 1991, the United States spent $145.3 billion, according to the National Science Foundation, while Japan spent 13.77 trillion yen, or $102 billion, using the exchange rates that year.
However, in Japan, where there is little military research and where universities are not the strong and autonomous sources of research that some big American colleges are, industry research accounts for about three-quarters of the total. In the United States, the Government provides about 40 percent of what is spent, with roughly half of that military-related.
 
Comparisons Hard to Make
 In industrial research alone, Japan spent 10.25 trillion yen, or $76 billion, in 1991, roughly similar to spending by American industry of $78.8 billion.
Comparisons, though, are tricky. The National Science Foundation prefers a currency-conversion formula that accounts for the relative purchasing power of different currencies. Under such a formula, Japan's industrial research spending would be only about two-thirds that of the United States.
Whether Japan's slowdown will help the United States remains to be seen. Growth in American industrial research is slow, and some companies are cutting back. The International Business Machines Corporation, suffering from problems similar to Fujitsu's, slashed its spending on research and development by $1 billion, or 17 percent, this year. In superconductors, some American companies have also scaled back substantially.
 
Technology Budget
 While corporate research has stopped expanding, the Japanese Government has increased its budget for science and technology 6.2 percent this year, to 2.27 trillion yen -- about $21 billion. Government spending is weighted more toward basic research and includes some big projects like fusion and other nuclear energy research.
Technology projects backed by the Government, for which Japan is famous, have fallen out of favor to some extent because the companies have grown so big that they no longer need Government funds. But now, some officials predict, companies will become more receptive to financing from Tokyo.
"Computer makers want to now ask the Japanese Government to pay more to establish national projects," said Toshio Yokoi, director of the Japan Electronic Dictionary Research Institute, a national project in computerized language translation.
To avoid cutting back research personnel or projects, Japanese companies are first invoking economies like restricting travel to conferences or delaying purchases of laboratory equipment.
"We are squeezing water from the towel," said Tokuta Inoue, a managing director of the Toyota Motor Corporation. Fujitsu is collaborating more with other companies to cut costs and still get the same results, said Mikio Ohtsuki, senior executive vice president.
 
Pressure for Products
 Many companies are cutting long-term basic research in favor of development of products.
"Every research laboratory feels the pressure to have immediate products," said Morio Onoe, executive vice president and director of research at the Ricoh Company.
Dr. Onoe, a physicist, said the office equipment company was still doing long-term research related to its core imaging business but had trimmed such research in other areas. It has reduced the number of scientists who work on exotic new semiconductors to a handful, from more than 30.
Japan Synthetic Rubber has suspended biotechnology research. "In the economic slump, the efforts appeared too costly and could not be expected to bear fruit in the immediate future," a spokesman said.
In the 1980's, some leading Japanese companies began doing more basic research, believing that they could no longer thrive by merely making products based on advances pioneered in the West. Some of these large Japanese companies also opened laboratories in the United States and Europe. NEC, which took part in both trends, said it would not cut back either fundamental research or its laboratory in Princeton, N.J. Spokesmen for Hitachi, Toshiba and the Victor Company of Japan also said that they were not reducing activities at their American research centers.
Other projects are being eliminated because Japanese concerns, which went on a diversification binge when times were good, now find themselves having to concentrate on fewer businesses.
Sapporo Breweries Ltd. closed its pharmaceutical research center this year when it decided to abandon a move into the cancer drug business.
Sumitomo Electric used to devote only half of its research and development budget to existing businesses, with the other half going to diversification or basic research. Sumitomo, Japan's leading electrical wire and cable producer, expanded into optical fibers, synthetic diamonds, artificial blood vessels and other products.
 
 
'Not Too Successful'
 Now, the Osaka-based Sumitomo, while holding its overall research and development spending at about $275 million, is increasing the share for existing businesses to 60 percent.
"In the 1980's, we stressed new-business creation too much," said Nobuo Yumoto, managing director. "Some of the new projects were not too successful."
The company is curtailing development of automated cell-growing machines. Researchers who have been doing advanced organic chemistry are being moved to advanced wires and insulators.
In superconductors, Sumitomo Electric has cut back from 42 scientists to 35. Instead of searching by itself for materials able to achieve superconductivity at higher temperatures, it will rely on the International Superconductivity Technology Center, a consortium largely financed by the Japanese Government.

HEADLINE: Ex-Political Prisoner Is Apparently Winner in Honduran Elections

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Carlos Roberto Reina, who was arrested four times and spent six months in solitary confinement for political activity in the 1970's, appeared to win election as President of Honduras today, defeating Oswaldo Ramos Soto.
Late this evening, Mr. Ramos conceded defeat. However, official results were not expected until Tuesday. . 
 The two candidates represented the major parties here. Mr. Reina leads a progressive wing of the Liberal Party, whereas Mr. Ramos said he counted most on the conservative, old-line elements of the ruling National Party.
The challenge for the new President is to recover from the economic and political difficulties left in the wake of the 1980's when Honduras went from a third-world backwater to a key player in a cold world struggle between the United States and Central American revolutionary movements. Mr. Reina also faces a tradition of political interference by the armed forces and corruption by public officials.
 
Cut in Military Planned
 Mr. Reina, an urbane attorney who is well thought of by Honduran human-rights groups, said in an interview prior to his victory that he would reduce the size of the armed forces. He also said he would vigorously investigate charging of military involvement in narcotics trafficking, and expressed disapproval of the tradition under which military officers have immunity from prosecution for crimes.
Such positions could put him in a confrontation with the military, still considered a very potent force here.
The losing candidate, Mr. Ramos, told a reporter before the election that should he win, he would not oblige the armed forces to effect reforms to which they were strongly opposed, because if he did so the military would remove him from office.
Mr. Reina said he would make cleaning up the Government a top priority, starting with the justice system, long thought to be corrupt. "We will have a judicial power that is absolutely clean," he said.
 
Era of Civil Wars
 This is the country's first election since the end of the wars in Nicaragua and El Salvador that divided the region and brought Honduras thousands of United States troops, more than $1 billion in American aid, and hundreds of Central Intelligence Agency operatives.
Washington's intention was to turn Honduras into a reliable platform from which the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras, could attack the Sandinista Government. Now, however, American attention has turned elsewhere, and Hondurans are assessing whether they have been beneficiaries or pawns of United States interests.
"The position of the majority of the population is worse now," said Mr. Reina. "There is more poverty, even misery, and less health, less education. The foreign debt has increased now."
While Honduras's neighbors, El Salvador and Nicaragua, have greatly reduced the size of their armies, the incumbent President here, Rafael Leornardo Callejas, has cut the military budget little. The military has turned to business investments that bring its officers economic security and political influence.
Using the military pension fund, the armed forces have bought businesses worth more than $50 million, according to Juan Ferrera, president of the Honduran Private Enterprise Council.
 
Criticism From Washington
 United States officials have begun to criticize the Honduran military. Many Hondurans, including Mr. Reina, say that the reason for this change is that the United States no longer needs the Honduran military to insure a pliant Honduran Government.
Throughout the 1980's, according to Gen. Walter Lopez, who was elected to one of the three vice presidential posts today and is a former chief of the armed forces, "the United States got whatever it wanted." At the same time, American diplomats sternly defended Honduran officials against charges they trampled human rights.
However, in a report last year, the State Department demonstrated a new point of view by declaring, "the people who run the Government, both military and civilian, have very little interest in police or judicial reform."
 
Most Hondurans Poorer
 There are small signs of improvement. This year, a colonel was convicted in the rape and murder of a 17-year-old student. Human rights groups say it is the first time a high-ranking officer was convicted of a crime against a civilian.
But even after some $1.4 billion in American assistance in the 1980's, most of the five million Hondurans may be worse off economically. The annual per capita income fell from $720 in 1985 to $580 in 1991, according to the World Bank.
The reason, say politicians and business leaders, is that much of the money was embezzled or used for programs that they say encouraged support for United States policies but have not brought Hondurans long-term benefits.
"There was a rain of dollars all over Honduras," said Mr. Ferrera, "but I think the military, the politicians and the contras took advantage of it."

NEW YORK CITY
 
GIULIANI JOINS CALL FOR TOUGH GUN LAWS
Insisting on the need for urban reform, Republican leaders of two of the nation's largest cities -- Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City and Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles -- said they support tough gun-control laws. A NEED TO EXPAND BOUNDARIES?
Politicians who are wringing their hands over whether the city will be made less if Staten Island secedes are largely overlooking an alternative: Forget Staten Island. What about Long Island? Metro Matters by Sam Roberts. B3.
 
PERSISTENT CABBIE FOILS THIEF
A gypsy-cab driver who was robbed at gunpoint of his money and cab flagged down two police officers, who chased the car and arrested one of the two attackers, the police said. Unfortunately for the cabby, Lamine Kaba, a 30-year-old immigrant from Guinea, West Africa, the suspect crashed the stolen cab into an elevated train pillar in the Bronx. In totaling the car, the robber stole Mr. Kaba's livelihood. B2.
 
THE MOON IN THE EARTH'S SHADOW
Rain and clouds had vanished in time to yield a dazzling sight of the most widely visible lunar eclipse in 14 years. Nearly 80 of the city's moon-watchers gathered in the chill of Central Park for the occasion. B2.
 
NATURAL CLEANING
Newcomers say they come to Ecomat, a dry cleaner and laundry at 90th Street and Lexington Avenue, simply because it is convenient. It is not those "Perc-free" tags on the hangers that bring them to its door. The tags refer to per chlorethylene, or perc, a petroleum-based chemical long used in dry cleaning but classified as hazardous in the 1989 Clean Air Act. But clothes cleaned at Ecomat are perc-free because of an unlikely collaboration involving the Environmental Protection Agency and the Greenpeace environmental group that has brought a British businessman's idea to Manhattan. B2.
 
FROM AFGHANISTAN TO THE BRONX
From the battlefields of war-ravaged Afghanistan to the underground railroad millions of refugees took into Pakistan before coming to the streets of New York City, tthe life of Fareedullah Nawabi could have been a blueprint for the experience of many Afghans in America. That is, until Mr. Nawabi was arrested on charges that he has sold a virtual arsenal of firearms, along with heroin and cocaine, to undercover police officers at his business, Mama's Fried Chicken, in the East Tremont section of the Bronx. B3.
 
REGION
 
WHITMAN MUST FILL POSTS
Distracted by the political brouhaha caused by her campaign manager's post-election comments, Christine Todd Whitman still faces the formidable task of appointing dozens of people to top state jobs to carry out policies like the 30 percent income tax cut she proposed during the campaign. B5.
Plans proceed for Whitman inauguration. B5.
 
ARRESTS IN DEADLY PRANK CALL
Two New Jersey men accused of making a prank emergency call that ended with the death of a police officer may face manslaughter charges, the Bergen County prosecutor said. B5.
 
HELP FOR HARRIED PARENTS
Like most parents, Jan and Denise Visser find it a struggle to juggle their schedules and those of their children. But the Vissers, who live in Manlius, N.Y., have found help with their car-pooling problems thanks to a company called Kids Taxi. For $6 for a one-way trip, and $10 for a round trip, parents can have their children shuttled from place to place. B5.
 
CONVENTION CENTER PLAN REVIVED
Tourism officials are reviving a proposal to construct a $150 million convention center in downtown Hartford to bolster the economy and stimulate the sagging hotel industry. The plan was blocked by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. a year and a half ago. B5.

HEADLINE: Government Says Federal Tariffs Cost Shoppers $19 Billion Yearly

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Protective trade tariffs on goods as diverse as ball bearings and costume jewelry cost American consumers an extra $19 billion a year, a Government study has found.
The United States International Trade Commission said high tariffs and quotas pushed up average prices in 44 sectors of the economy by 3 percent. 
 Officials at the agency, which rules on American industries' complaints of unfair trading by foreign competitors, said on Friday that the report underscored what the benefits would be if the talks aimed at lowering trade barriers globally were successfully concluded.
The talks, which began in 1986 in Uruguay, face a Dec. 15 deadline, with negotiators far apart on several issues. The discussions, involving 115 nations, are conducted by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world organization that governs trade.
 
The Case for Tariffs
 Economists say global output could receive a boost of $270 billion by lowering tariffs and expanding trade, but protected industries in the United States and elsewhere want to retain their trade barriers to preserve jobs.
According to the commission's report, 44 areas of the American economy receive significant protection from imports. The greatest impact of these measures was on the apparel and textile industries, where trade barriers added $15.85 billion a year to prices that consumers must pay.
The commission estimated that the average price for clothing would drop by 11.4 percent if trade barriers were removed, the largest price cut for any of the economic sectors studied.
After clothing, some of the largest price drops would be in luggage, with a projected decrease of 9.1 percent, and sugar, a projected drop of 8 percent.
The commission's report acknowledged that American jobs would be lost from the removal of trade barriers. The apparel industry alone, it said, would lose 46,724 jobs, or 6 percent of its employment. Counting all areas of textile and apparel, the report put the potential job loss at 71,369.
 
No Adverse Impact, Over All
 But the report concluded that there would be no adverse impact on overall employment in the United States. It said jobs lost in protected industries would be offset by gains in other areas of the economy because of higher consumer spending that would result from lower prices.
After apparel and textiles, the biggest price drop -- $3.09 billion in all -- would come from removing restrictions that prohibit foreign ships from carrying domestic cargo between United States ports, the report said. The change would result in a loss of 11,905 jobs in ocean shipping, but the commission said that would be more than offset by gains in related industries, as dock workers benefited from increased volume of shipping by foreign carriers.
Next, the commission found the biggest price impacts in agriculture, where trade barriers push dairy prices $847 million higher annually; sugar, $657 million; peanuts, $353 million, and meat, $177 million .
Other areas where prices were higher because of tariffs included shoes, watches, ball bearings, pressed and blown glass, costume jewelry, machine tools, frozen produce, ceramic wall and floor tiles and leather goods.

HEADLINE: Unbending Regulations Incite Move to Alter Pollution Laws

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YORKTOWN, Va., Nov. 22

 BODY:
A three-year study of pollution and how best to clean it up at a small Amoco Corporation refinery here is prompting the Clinton Administration to consider a sharply different approach to the way the nation's environmental laws are written.
The study, conducted jointly by Amoco and the Environmental Protection Agency, found that Federal regulations forced the refinery to solve relatively minor pollution threats at major expense while far more important problems were overlooked. 
 Specifically, Amoco was required under a change in the Clean Air Act to spend $31 million to rebuild the refinery's waste water treatment plant to prevent benzene, a toxic chemical, from evaporating into the air. But investigators found that the major source of benzene pollution was coming from a part of the plant not yet addressed by the Clean Air Act: the marine terminal on the York River, where ships unload oil and load gasoline. Controlling benzene pollution there would have cost only about $6 million, the company said.
 
'Really Serious Problems'
 Using the Yorktown study as a model, the Clinton Administration plans to ask Congress for money for analyses of pollution at up to a dozen other plants serving the automobile, paper, chemical, steel and food processing industries, among others. In addition, the E.P.A. has begun examining the nation's laws that regulate air and water pollution and control hazardous wastes to try to eliminate overlapping rules that are often in conflict.
"The Yorktown project pointed up some of the really serious problems with regulation that have developed," said Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of Environmental Protection who was the top environmental official in Florida before joining the Administration.
"When I worked at the state level, I was constantly faced with rigid rules that made doing something 100 times more difficult and expensive than it needed to be. It makes no sense to have a program that raises costs and while doing nothing to reduce environmental threats."
H. Laurance Fuller, the president and chairman of Amoco, which is based in Chicago and has revenues of $28 billion a year, said industrial executives were actively supporting the Administration's work. And though they are nervous about the outcome, staff members of some of the nation's most influential environmental groups, among them the Natural Resources Defense Council, based in New York, said their organizations were also embracing the Administration's proposals.
The Clinton Administration is trying to address problems in the current approach to environmental regulation as Congress is being presented an opportunity to rewrite five of the nation's basic environmental statutes for protecting rivers, purifying drinking water, managing solid wastes, cleaning up toxic wastes and safeguarding endangered species. In some respects, the Administration wants to return to the approach to environmental regulation developed in the 1970's.
Then Congress set broad policy goals that depended on regulations for specifics. But in the 1980's because members believed that the Reagan and Bush Administrations were hostile to environmental protection, Congress itself provided the specifics and took away the discretion earlier given to agencies to write regulations.
Often some Congressional orders were based on old assumptions about where pollution occurred. Here at the Yorktown refinery, for instance, the regulation requiring the cleanup of benzene at its waste-water treatment plants was based on 1959 estimates of pollution at such plants. The Yorktown study showed those estimates to be wildly inaccurate.
When legal analysts reviewed the Yorktown study in June, they found that the environmental policies of the 1980's had swamped companies with new and wasteful regulations that left them almost no room to decide for themselves how to reduce their worst pollution problems.
Amoco executives said in interviews here that they could design equipment to control benzene pollution at the marine terminal, and that it would cost around $6 million. But Amoco will not do anything until the regulations are made final in 1995 or later. The reluctance, the executives said, is because the regulations now are so specific in defining how a company should control pollution that if the equipment did not exactly fit every requirement they might have to dismantle it, making the investment a waste.
"Look, the E.P.A. and Congress have a point about regulating benzene; it's a known carcinogen," said Randall W. Browning, the manager of environmental health and safety at Amoco's Yorktown refinery. "But what is the point of spending $31 million to solve a problem that wasn't a problem while doing nothing about the real problem? What we are looking for is a new approach. Give us a goal to meet rather than all the regulations telling us what controls to put on what sources of pollution. That worked in the 1970's, when the pollution problems were much more visible and simpler. It's not working now."
Ms. Browner said two projects were being planned by environmental officials to untangle the snarl of rules that she and other Administration officials said was both a drag on the economy and a serious threat to the credibility of environmental programs.
Both projects will focus on gathering scientific and legal data to develop a much less rigid scheme for controlling pollution. Ms. Browner said the top environmental advisers to the President had come to believe that a more flexible program would encourage innovation and reduce the cost of environmental controls.
The first project is being proposed by the President's Council on Sustainable Development, a group Mr. Clinton appointed in June to join five Cabinet officers with leaders of environmental and business groups. The council plans to ask Congress early next year for money to pay for studies of other industries like that of the Yorktown refinery. The idea is to identify more clearly the most serious pollution problems at industrial plants and to understand how regulations help and hinder efforts to control them.
 
Looking for Simplicity
 A second effort has begun at the E.P.A., where Ms. Browner and her aides are searching for novel ways to make it simpler and less expensive to comply with environmental rules. Industrial plants are now regulated under at least half a dozen separate laws, each with thousands of regulations.
The agency is developing an experimental program that will enable a few plants in different industries to consolidate all the rules in one operating manual. Ms. Browner said she hoped that one result of the project would be to identify how regulations from one law overlap with another, often with detrimental results.
"What we want to do is design environmental programs that set goals, and then give industry the opportunity to decide for themselves how to meet them," Ms. Browner said. "We can insure that this approach has credibility with the public by making sure they meet those goals with tough fines that we enforce."
The Administration's work on altering environmental policy, which in some respects is as complicated as the White House's effort to reform health care, also carries political risks.
Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore enjoy unalloyed support from national environmental leaders. But several environmental leaders said they were anxious about the Administration's plans because they supported the old approach as bringing cleaner air and water.
Nevertheless, several environmental leaders said they had begun to recognize serious problems in carrying out the laws and were helping the Administration to design the proposed projects.
"We are exploring the possibility of sitting down with industry to see whether we can construct a framework," said Linda Greer, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "The bottom line for us is that whatever new approach is taken, there must be no backsliding."
"What the environmental community is most worried about is that the public gets something out of this and that we are not giving something away. The appealing part of all this talk about new approaches is that we will get less pollution. What industry is saying is: 'We'll do that if you give us flexibility.' The question is this: Is there really something here or not? We think there is."

Diagram: "What Investigators Found at the Yorktown Refinery"
 
THE PROCESS
 
1. Oil is unloaded and gasoline loaded onto ships at a marine loading terminal on the York River.
 
2. Crude oil is refined.
 
3. Waste water containing benzene and other compounds is treated.
 Pollutants include benzene (15 tons) and other volatile organic compounds, which are liquids that quickly evaporate and contribute to smoge.
 Treating the waste water created during refining releases 178 tons of volatile organic compounds, including three tons of benzene, into the air annually.
 
ACTION TAKEN
 
None. Currently, the Federal Government requires no cleanup at marine loading terminals. Because of strict Federal rules on controlling pollutants, Amoco says it is reluctant to build pollution control equipment until it knows precisely what the rule will be. The cost is around $6 million.
 
Installed closed treatment system that now prevents the release of benzene and other harmful compounds. Cost for the system was $31 million.
 
(Source: The Environmental Protection Agency; Amoco) (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: Wave of Cuban Defections at Puerto Rican Games

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES

 BODY:
A father and son on the archery team were among the first to depart. They were followed by two champion weight lifters, Cuba's top female softball pitcher, and even a photographer who had apparently arrived in Puerto Rico, portfolio in hand, with defection in mind.
By yesterday evening, 34 of the 900 or so members of the Cuban delegation attending the 17th Central American and Caribbean Games in Puerto Rico had defected. And though the mounting departures are hardly an exodus, they represent enough of a trickle to fuel speculation that a major walkout may occur before the athletic contests conclude on Tuesday. 
 Despite increased security, at least 11 members of the delegation defected on Saturday, said Rescue Legion, a Cuban exile group that is helping the asylum seekers. The defections brought the total to 34 since the games began on Nov. 19.
 
To Apply for Political Asylum
 The 34 athletes plan to hold a news conference today and to apply formally for political asylum in the United States, representatives of the Rescue Legion said.
People in the Cuban delegation, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the most recent defectors included two weight lifters, Lino Elias Ocana and Emilio Lara Rodriguez, as well as two coaches; a journalist, Manuel Valle, and the pitcher, Odalys Hernandez.
The Cuban Government has not issued a statement on the defections.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has flown an officer to Puerto Rico to process the growing number of requests for political asylum, an agency spokesman said. Under the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966, Cubans entering United States territory can become residents a year later, without having to apply for political asylum.
Human rights experts noted that the number of Cuban defections had been increasing, with Cubans fleeing their homeland by inner-tube, raft and airplane. Still, they attributed the defections in Puerto Rico to a unique convergence of time, place and chance, as well as a growing desire to escape a repressive Government and a deteriorating economy, which has been hurt in part by the 32-year-old United States economic embargo and the loss of subsidies from the former Soviet Union.
"There are not many cultural exchanges that would permit Cuban athletes or performers to seek asylum," said Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, in New York. "In a real sense our laws invite Cuban asylum seekers to come to the U.S."
The fact that Puerto Rico is a United States territory in which Spanish is the official language also made it an easier place for defection, said Frank Calzon, a representative for Freedom House, the human rights organization.
"If a Cuban was attempting to defect in France or Sweden, there's the problem of approaching a police officer and being understood," Mr. Calzon said. "That's not the case in Puerto Rico."
In an effort to hold on to its premier athletes, the Cuban Government had begun allowing them to keep a bigger share of athletic purses. But during the regional championships in Puerto Rico, Cuban officials have had to beef up security to try to stem defections.
Members of the delegation are counted nightly at the National Guard barracks where they are housed in Salinas, 60 miles southwest of San Juan. And in the wake of the first defections, athletes say they must now ask permission 24 hours in advance so security can be arranged before they visit friends or family in Puerto Rico.
Likening the defections to those of athletes from Communist European countries during the cold war, Mr. Calzon said it was not unusual that even the Cuban elite were seeking political asylum.
"I think the balance between fear and repression is beginning to tilt," Mr. Calzon said. "There is also a generational problem for the Castro regime. Cubans in their 20's and 30's don't care about Batista," he said, referring to Fulgencio Batista, a notoriously corrupt dictator who ruled Cuba before Fidel Castro's revolutionary movement won power in 1959.
"They know they have a Government that's ineffective and repressive, and they need to try something else," he said. "The athletes are young. If you're 20, and all Castro says is he doesn't know when things are going to get better, if you're 20 and know a friend who went to prison for writing a poem, you want to leave."
Defection is often a heart-wrenching decision, Mr. Calzon said, with those who do it leaving behind parents, spouses and children who will probably not be allowed to leave Cuba and join them. It will also mean starting a new life, far away from home.
Still, the defections in Puerto Rico may prove to be a lightning rod in the debate over political asylum. Human rights groups are quick to contrast the relative ease with which Cubans attain asylum with the difficulties faced by Haitians, who are generally returned to their island.
"It is a stark reminder of the inequitable treatment of the Haitian boat people," Mr. Helton said. "But I think the key issue is not unfair favoritism of the Cubans but unfair discrimination toward the Haitians."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Odalys Hernandez, a softball pitcher from Cuba, during a game last week in Puerto Rico. After the game, she and other athletes defected to the United States. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Reviews were upbeat for the traditional opening weekend of the holiday shopping season, but merchants refused to celebrate too soon. Shopping during the Thanksgiving weekend is no longer considered a good barometer because consumers now make most of their purchases in the final week of the season. [Page A1.] 
 Machine tool orders fell 8.5 percent in October from September but remained about 25 percent higher than in October 1992. Despite declining in three of the last four months, orders so far this year are still nearly 30 percent ahead of a year earlier. [D3.]
 
International
Japanese companies are beginning to trim spending on research and development, cutbacks that could threaten Japan's long-term competitiveness. [A1.]
The slide in Japanese stocks continued Monday, as investor anxieties over the economy and the Japanese Government's apparent lack of action pushed share prices lower. [D1.]
Protective trade tariffs on everything from ball bearings to costume jewelry cost American consumers an extra $19 billion a year, a Government study has found. [A14.]
 
Companies
Change is sweeping the airline business. Over the last three years, the domestic industry's loss of about $10 billion has drawn small new carriers which use low fares to lure passengers. [D1.]
Low interest rates are proving a problem for the nation's pension plans. As interest rates fall, corporations must set aside more money for pensions because the securities in their pension portfolios are expected to earn less. [D1.]
The outcome of the battle between QVC Network and Viacom for Paramount Communications is far from predictable, even though QVC won a clear victory in court last week. [D1.]
NEC is seeing profits from personal computers eroded by steep price cuts spurred by the invasion of Japan's market by aggressive American companies. [D1.]
A three-year study of pollution and how best to clean it up at an Amoco refinery is prompting the Clinton Administration to consider a new way to write the nation's environmental laws. [A1.]
 
The Media Business
K-III Holdings is returning to the spotlight with a lot of influence in the marketplace. But it needs to find editors for two of its biggest consumer magazines, New York and Seventeen. [D6.]
Five Jewish weekly newspapers are battling for New York readers and revenues, and the area's biggest Jewish philanthropy has been caught in the crossfire. [D6.]
International media companies have stepped up their activities in Latin America as economies there have opened. [D6.]
CBS Sports takes a just-folks approach to pitching its menu of professional football games. [D6.]
A game of 20 questions is inspired by some current and recent campaigns. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

A positive case for Dell Computer combines strong demand for personal computers with the assumption that the company has solved its manufacturing problems. Market Place. [D4.]
